editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A REGISTRE Of Hystories, conteining Martiall exploites of worthy warriours, Politique practises of Ciuil Magistrates, wise Sentences of famous Philosophers, And other matters manifolde and memorable. Written in Greeke, by Aelianus a Romane: and deliuered in Englishe (as well, according to the truth of the Greeke text, as of the Latine) by Abraham Fleming.
Seene and allowed.
¶ Imprinted at London, for Thomas Woodcocke: dwelling in Paules Churchyarde, at the signe of the blacke Beare. Anno a Messia nato. 1576.

div.head: Ornatissimo viro, necnon eruditione vitae{que} inteGRITATE CLARO, DOCTORI GOODMANNO, VVestmonasteriensis ecclesiae Cathedralis Collegijque celeberrimi dignissimo Decano, Abrahamus Flemingus faelicitatem precatur sempiternam.
div.p:
CVm animo meo diu multumque volutassem, quonam symbolo voluntatis meae propensitatem erga amplitudinem tuam (Ornatissime vir) propalarem, quae plus petit postu latque, quam vel ingenij mei exilitas, vel laboris tenuitas possint elargiri: irrepsit tandem mihi id cogitanti humanitatis tuae affabilitatisque recordatio, quae nonnihil officij crebro efflagitare, et quodammodo extorquere videbatur. Postquam autē hanc multiplicem compendiariamque Historiam ab Aeliano Romano, idioma te Attico, limatè politequè contextam et coagmentatam, mentis acie perlustrassem, in vulgarem Anglorum sermonem conuertissem, eiusdem denique aeditionem ad sudorem vsque promouissem atque exantlassem, adeo vt nihil desiderari videreretur q̄ vt eandē Typographicis psephismatibus absolutam, alicui Musarū patrono consecrarem, occurrit mi hi sic meditanti tua (Spectatissime vir) insignis benignitas cui hasce interpretationis primitias dicare consultissimum arbitrarer. Audax sanè et iuuenile factum si iniquus litigiosusque iudex suam sententiam interponeret, sed non
tam audax, Aedepol, quam sagax, si candidus arbiter integritatis{que} studiosus, idipsum ad calculos reuocaret.

Quid enim impudentiae, Proh superos, aut temeritatis in illo fossoris facto, quamuis rustico, tamen lepido delituit, qui perpusillo munere praestantissimum imperatorem ducem{que} animosissimum donauit? munusculum illud sumptu carebat et precio, sed honestate pollebat, ita quid inuerecundiae latet vbi probitas patet? quid reprehenditur vbi nihil fuci obtenditur? Pulchrum hoc pandocheum, cum politicarum, tum physicarum rerum cognitione cumulatum, apophthegmatw̄n et strategemmatw̄n varietate, vbertateque locupletatum, sententiarum sale conditum, verborum delectu exornatum, aromaticis eloquentiae odoribus perfusum, orationis nitore puritateque decoratum, viatorem non so lum inuitat, lenocinijsque suis illectat inescatque, verumeti am deliciarum affluentia ita permulcet, et effascinat, vt vel reluctantē renitentemque retardet, atque remoretur.

Experientia nixus hisce astipulari ausim, cum quae dixerim Sybillina folia sint, et cum oratio ex tripode loquatur. Nam simulatque in hunc Aelianum incidissem, in manus sumpsissem, aperuissem, inspexissem, vnam atque alteram historiolam percurrissem, integrum, denique, opusculum rationis statera, iudicijque aequilibrio examinassem, voluptatum phalanges, tanquam ex equo quodam Troiano, prosi lierunt, quae tantopere animum meum irretitum illaqueatumque tenebant, vt spaciosum libelli Oceanum, anserinis remis penetrare vtilissimum existimarem. Itaque, ne otiando mihimet ipsi obesse, cum nonnihil factitādo prodesse possem, vnamquamque paginam, lineam, verbum, literam, ex quibus, tanquam ex membris quibusdam et articulis, totum huius enchiridij corpusculū conflatur, a vertice ad vmbelicum, ab vmbelico ad calcem, velut miles leuis armaturae
permeaui, arreptisque, quibus vtendum fuit, instrumentis Anglicam interpretationem aggressus sum, cuius in vestibulo, repentina sese mihi prodidit delectatio, longe, vt aiunt a limine subito aspectu salutauit, obuijs tandem vlnis amplexata est, animoque meo, ne lassitudinis taedijque incommodo deprimeretur, mellistuos nectareosque humores instillauit: Cuius congressu hoc lucri ad laborem accessit, vt voluptas semper, sine vlla interpellatione, suggereretur, satietas vero et nausea nunquam excitaretur, per saxa enim et syrtes, per salebras et scopulos, tanquam vmbra corpus, solem serenitas, hyemen aestas, aestatē autumnus, flammam fumus, indiuiduo quodam nexu sese inuicem sequebantur. Nunc autem ad eam, meo Marte, maturitatem anhelauit libellus iste, vt firmissimo fundamento, artificiosae contignationes, contignationibus, quidem, fastigia satis solida imponantur, adeoque perfecta est haec conuersio (absit inuidia verbo) suisque numeris absoluta, vt cuilibet viatori sese vehiculi vice prebeat, ad pinguem aliorū Mineruam sese componet, ad elaboratum aliorum Mercurium sese accommodet, denique, nulli non generosi pectoris viro, semina, germina, flores fructus{que}, cum vtilitatis, tum voluptatis, copiosissime im partiatur atque communicet. Sed, ne haec luxurians oratio, tanquam planta hederacea, in immensum excrescat, caetera amoenissimi Authoris hortuli topiaria, taciturnitatis tegumentis implicabo: de meipso tamen paucula (pace tua, spectatissime vir) attexam. Si eam interpretandi facilitatem festiuitatemque, quam nonnulli nostri seculi Phaenices sunt consequuti adeptus essem, si auream illam scribendi formulam, praeclaram polygraphiam, egregias dilatandi dotes, et amplificandi facultates, inuentionis opulentiam et scaturiginem, conquisitam rerum inauditarum enumerationem,
chronologia, antiquitatis monumenta quarum flos nunquam flaccescit, quarum inquam gemma semper resplendescit, exemplorum agmina, verborum fulmina, aenigmatum inuolucra, adagiorū Laconismum, multiplices exterarum linguarum proprietates, et quicquid hominum animos in admirationem raperet intellectu obsepirem, Si denique dij de aeque, quot quot sūt, in me tanquam in aliquam Pandw̄ ram omnia omnium virtutum ornamenta congererent, et grandiora, et gratiora mihi negotium facesserent, manibus que tuis, vtpote religiosis, rariorà clarioraque consecrarem.

Sed cum nonnihil aetatulae temeritati sit concedendum, aliquid triennali ab Academia intermissioni tribuendum, plurimum denique sinistro omini (quod vtinam meo nunquam contigisset nomini) ascribendum, haec ieiuna interpretatio satis iucunda, exanguis satis succulenta, hirsuta satis compta, incondita satis tersa (ita enim sperare tua iubet humanitas) videbitur.

Nequeo (Ornatissime vir) expatianti calamo fraena inijcere, nequeo mansuetioribus Musis metas praescribere, nequeo orationem (quae torrentis instar) fluit, moderari, non quod verborum coaceruatione et tumultuaria variarum vocū multitudine (a qua nescio an alius quispiamquam ego magis abhorret) memet oblectem, non quod nihil aut saltem non satis me dixisse putem nisi mediocritatis terminos linguae volubilitate transilirem, sed quod amplissimū illud et peruulgatum meritorum tuorum pelagus mihi ante oculos obuersabatur, cuius reciprocas vices simulat{que}, per trā sennam intueor, plenisque tibijs conor praedicare, subita sinistrae opinionis suspicio viscera mentis meae diuexabat, cruciabat, torquebat, et (orationē futilibus mendaciunculis aspergere odiosum est) magnopere vt a proposito deflecte
rem, dehortabatur, deterrebat. Ea vero suspicio noctesque diesque animum occupauit, voluntatem, ne subuolaret et in cōtrariū niteretur, deprimit, deijcit, vinculis{que} quibsdam et pedicis castigat, adeo vt velle vecordiae videatur esse cum facultas perficiundi voluntatem contabescat.

Porrò, non illa tantum suspicio et metus mali animum meum assiduè agitauit, sed aliud quiddam portentosum mihi contemplanti oboriebatur, adulationis nimirum et Gnatonismi pestis periculosa, quamquidem etiamsi odio plusquam hostili prosequor, deprauata tamen nonnullorum ingenia his atque illis vocibus virulentis honestum institutum et ab omni assentationis tinctura alienissimum infuscabunt. Itaque non satis est imo vero nihil est, tanti ponderis prouinciam leuiter et summis, vt aiunt, digitis attigisse, nisi ad viuum resecare perrexero, non satis est delineasse, non satis est adumbrasse, aliquid est colorum gratia, varietate, et venustate ornasse, decorasse. Nisi ergo vel le et posse conspirent, nisi vno eodem{que} ligata loro vnum idem{que} iugum trahant, nihil omnino dixisse quam pauca oscitanter et haesitanter enunciasse laudabilius cōducibilius{que} existimo. In ista tamen contemplatione assiduus totusque sum, vt quicquid addidero, siue plus sit siue minus (cum neutrum possit esse quod nihil est) id totum in nominis tui celebritatem meritorumque magnitudinem cedat, in ea consenescat, acquiescat. Interim (Ornatissime vir) balbutienti Tyronis linguae (quae adhuc enucleatè loqui nesciat) faueto, claudicanti stylo (qui suis caret numeris, rythmis, succo, sanguine, membris et articulis) succurrito, orationem denique totam, quanta quanta sit, sic suscipito, vt quamuis humi serpat, pedibus tamen nequaquam conteratur, minutatim confringatur, elanguescat, animam exhalet.

Sed, ne verborum coaceruatione, dicendique prolixitate mediocritatis repagula perfringerem, cum totus hic sermo tuis praecipue (ornatissime vir) auribus obstrepat, finē faciam, et epistolae meae filum, ne extra ripas fluat, amputabo. Deus Op. Max. tui tuorumque patrocinium suscipiat, tibi tuisque ex animi sententia res omnes suppeditet, finitoque, huius vitae calamitatibus et aerumnis coopertae, curriculo, faelicitatē nunquam intermorituram largiatur.

div.head: Idem Epigramma, sic Latio donauit T.S. Cantabr.
div.l: Sumito me manibus, sis doctus, an inscius artis,
Causa vtris{que} ingens vtilitatis ero:
Amphora plena tibi sum, plenus fructibus hortus
Omnigenis: tuque híc Attica mella legas.
Obscurat genus & nomen gens Inclyta nostra,
Ʋrbs claros faciens patria Roma fuit.

div.head: In Abrahami Flemingi Aelianum Anglicum, Iohannes Bellus, Scholae Ratliffiensis Archididascalus.
div.l: Hâc facturus iter, decoratum floribus hortum
Inspice: tu{que} tuo pollice carpe Rosas.
Florum quicquid habet spaciosi terminus Orbis,
Illud in hoc horto cernere quis{que} potest.
Cuius suauifluum qui naribus hausit odorem,
Hoc magé gratus ei non odor vllus erit.
Tu modò FLEMINGVM memori sub mente reconde,
Qui sua, quò tua sint, non sinit esse sua.
Atque tuo studio quoníam sic profuit omni,
Fac possit per te, scandere laudis iter.

div.head: In laudem Aeliani Romani & Ab. Fl. Hexameter R. Pr. Cantabr.
div.l: Istius meritas operis sibi vendicet Author,
Ac habeat laudes: sua namqué industria summa,
Hystoriam variam Graecé qui scripserat istam.
Sed tamen haec Anglis latuit vix cognita terris,
Iám nobis splendet, necnón sua lumina praebet
Phoebo candidiùs, non abs{que} labore FLEMINGI:
Qui non summa ferat quamuis preconia facti,
(Cui laudes magnae debentur, gratia magna,)
Attamén ingratus né sis, ROMANE, tuarum
Participem facito laudum, sine fraude, FLEMINGVM.

div.head: In eiusdem Aeliani Hystoriam Graecè, Latiné, & Anglicé conscriptam: T. S. Cantabr.
div.l: Cùr animo in studijs contingit nauseà nulla?
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
Ergò tuos minimè miror, ROMANE, labores,
Dum Romam Graecè 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
Nec, GERMANE, tuos dum pandis Graeca Latinis,
Nec noua depingit penna, BRITANNE, tua.
Dicere sed cogor veré: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Hystoria, & mulcet Nectare quem{que} suo.

div.head: In eundem Aelianum renatum, Cuthberti Hopi carmen Epaineticum
div.l: Ficta quíd ingenium delectat fabula? Lector
Candide, quidué iuuat? commoda quaeuè feret?
Nonné foret melius, doctos tractare libellos,
Carmina quàm vatum quae nisi vana docent?
Ex doctis si docta libris didicisse requiras,
Hunc lege: Multa feret commoda, Magna feret.
Viue igitur (Fleminge) precor, (Fleminge) beatus
Viue: tuas laudes, terra fretum{que} sonet.

div.head: In eundem Aelianum, Epigramma T.D. Cantabr.
div.l: Pinguia Nectareo gaudent pomaria fructu,
Fragranti{que} nitet flore Sabaeus ager.
Doctum fidus habet medicamen Pharmacopôla,
Morbosis praesens quod ferat auxilium:
Vnicus iste liber tamen est praestantior illis,
Siue voluptates, commoda siue petas.

div.head: In eundem Aelianum Anglicum, Carmen Ri. B. Cantabr.
div.l: Scripta placent, tamen, interdúm non anté placebunt,
Nec póst, interdúm, quám tibi lecta sient:
Ast vbi sub docto, sub amico Iudice lis est,
Si minús antè placent, póst tamen illa placent.
Vtile delectat, Iucunda probantur, Honestum
Laudatur: tribus his non caret istud Opus.
Haec tria vestitus idiomatis anté Pelasgi
Induerant, & póst, inclyta Roma, tuos:
At núnc, facundo incedunt ornata cothurno
Anglorum, nitido versa reuersa sono.
Laus est danda tibi, FLEMINGE, & praemia danda,
Gratia par reliquis est referenda viris.

div.head: The poesie of Richard Tauerner Gent.
div.l: Yf stories should lye fainting vnder foote,
(Synce foes with force marche on to foile their fame,
VVhos buisy braines their flights of fury shoote,
To impaire their praise, and nippe their noble name)
If such I say should blotted be with blame,
No witte would worke a way by penne to showe
The state of such as liued longe agoe.
Yf Homers hed had slept in slouthfull ease,
VVhat wight had knowne Vlysses wandred wayes?
VVhat coasts he scapte, whar syrts, and surgeing seas,
Before he had in Ithac' happy dayes:
The Poets penne his passage open layes,
And many moe that diuersly indite,
Haue lefte at lenghte their labours large in lighte.
Such willinge wights in Englishe angle dwell,
VVhose paineful pēns haue purchasd peereles praise,
Obliuion blind their quiuering quills so quell,
As once her hed, that Hagg, she dare not raise:
Among the which in theis our drouping dayes,
No will doth want to wring from wit a verse,
Of Flemings praise the pension to rehearse.
Through stories straunge and many a tretise triewe.
Thy penne hath pearst, thy quill hath traced quite
And left them vs in English glasse to viewe,
As precious pearles and Diamonds of delighte.
Let Sycophants assault with darts of spighte
This planted plot: yet of this worke most wise,
The fame shall flye from yearth to azur skyes.

div.head: The poesie of Iohn Foster.
div.l: AS garden greene bedevved vvith shoures
doth vvalkers sprits delight,
And yealdeth store of fragrant flovvers,
(A comfortable sight.)
And as the byrds in golden springe
haue tunes of sundry sorte,
And diuersly dooe chirpe and singe,
one boughe, for their disporte:
Euen so this booke doth mention make,
of matters chaunge and choyce.
VVherin thou maist thy pleasure take,
and vvhen thou vvilt, reioyce.
And thoughe the booke a storehouse vvas,
of many things before,
Yet euery man could not in passe,
tyll Fl. vnlockte the dore.
VVhos hart is vvaxt so liberall,
He leaues it open still:
That thou maist take thy choyce of all,
and vse it at thy vvill.
For all his trauaile spent herein,
Fl. craues none other meede.
Then fauour and good vvill to vvynne,
VVherof he hopes to speede.

div.head: To the Courteous Reader.
div.p: This booke replenished with varietie & chaunge, (Courteous Reader) may be compared to a greate & stately building, which is not altogether outwardly voide of beuty, but inwardly also, gaily decked & finely furnished With all sightly and sumptuous implemēts. yt is lyke vnto an inestimable Iuell, or precious pearle, which although yt be inclosed in a homly woddē box, and shut vp in a simple casket, litle or nothing worthe in comparison, yet is it neuer a whit the lesse in vallue notwithstanding, but reserueth his price vndiminished. Wherfore (Courteous Reader) in consideration of thine owne profit, and vauntage, pleasure, and harts ease, enter into this princely pallace, view euery roome circumspectly, behold eache seuerall chamber and lodging aduisedly, and vse the benefite of euery thing liberally, to thine owne contentation. Open this base boxe, and lifte vp the lydd of this course casket, wherin so riche and costly a Iuell is inclosed, wey yt, and weare it, the commodity issuing from the same is singular, so is the delight redundant and plentifull. Take all, and possesse all, thy title is substantiall, and thine interest sufficient.

div.head: The corrections of faultes escaped.
div.p: The Englishe escapes, wee leaue to the correction of the Englishe Reader.

div.head: The first Booke of the variable History of Aelianus.
❧ Of the manifolde footed Fishes called POLYPODES.
div.p: THese Fishes are indued with great force & maine strength in and about the belly péece, they deuoure what soeuer is next them and make no bones of the matter, yea often times they spare not ne yet forbere their owne kinde, but when the lesser sorte are caught by the greater, falling into the stronger and faster snares (which are called the Fishes whips) by and by they be swallowed vp as meet meat and sauoury sustenaunce. Their vse of insnaring and catching Fish, I wil deliuer in breuitie of woords.

These Polypodes lye lurking closely by the sides and rootes of Rocks, chaunging them selues into the same coloure, in so much as they appéer in sight to be a parte of the Rock. When as therfore the foolish Fish swim towards the Rocks, they approch of necessity & draw néer to the Polypodes in whose nets (namely their whips) the poore ignorant fishes bothe vnwillingly and vnwittingly are intangled and taken.

div.head: ❧ Of the Spiders Phalanges.
div.p:
THese Spyders are not skilful in the trade of weauing, neither doo they knowe neither wil they know how to weaue or to be acquainted with the gifts of the goddesse Minerua. For indéed how should such a little beast were a wouen garmēt. These Spiders haue a snare and as it were a Bowe net (wherewith they vse to take
what so euer by Fortune falleth into them. They watch, they péepe, toote and spy, with great silence and quietnes to incompasse and winde in their pray, seeming to the eyes of the beholder vtterly void of stirring, moouing, féeling, and to be as stil as a stone and as dead as a doore naile, if they catche any thing they féed thervpon (whatsoeuer it be) as vpon méet morsels to maintain life: And so muche commonly they catche in their Net as it can holde or receiue and as is inough and sufficient to slake and asswage hunger.

div.head: Of the Aegiptian Frogges.
div.p: THey are directed with meruailous light of speciall policy, and excell all others in singuler wisdome and foresight, for if a Frog chaunce to espye a water Serpent (which the Riuer Nilus nourisheth) it snappeth a Cane or a Reede in sunder and taking a péece thereof beareth it ouerthwart waies and holdeth it fast and firme as we say, with tooth and nail. This defence in such sorte ordered, the Hyder is not able to deuoure the Frog. And why? because the Réed is a hinderaunce thervnto, for the mouth of the water Serpent is not of suche widenes as the Réede or Cane is of length. By this meanes the Frogs wel fraught with wisdome and polycy, auoide, escape, deceiue and ouermatch the sorce and strength of the water Serpents.

div.head: ❧ Of the Aegiptian Dogges.
div.p:
THis in like manner is to be thought a great gift of wisdome in the Aegiptian Dogs, for they lap not gréedely of the Flud nor faintingly, not largely nor sparingly: But casting their eyes vpon the course of the streme, they drink of the water, as they run by the Riuers
brink, so much as séemeth sufficient to quench their thirstynes. The reason whereof is, because they perceiue vnder the water, daungerous and deadly Beasts, whose rauenous Chops to escape, these Aegiptian Dogges as they passe beside the bank, lick the water with their tasting toungs, now a snatch and then a snatch, by fits as we say commonly in our familier spéeche, whereby they preserue their liues from perishing, and yet neuerthelesse qualifye and quenche the torments of thirstynesse.

div.head: ❧ Of the Sea Fox.
div.p: NOt the land Fox onely excéedeth in craftines, but the Sea fox also passeth in subtelties. For the Sea Fox hath no regarde to the baite for gréedynes nor yet to the hooke, but before the Fisherman draweth vp his Angling rod, and his Line, the Fox plungeth forewarde, and snaps the Line in sunder and so swimmeth away, oftentimes it deuoureth vp two or thrée Hookes, and yet the Angler neuer a whit the néerer his pray, no not to take it, muche lesse to tast it.

div.head: ❧ Of a Shel fish called a Sea Tortoise.
div.p: THey deliuer their Broode on the Land, wherof when they be disburthened, what doo they? Forsooth they hide their Egges in the ground and foorthwith returne to the Sea, where they swimme to and fro according to their accustomed manner.

Moreouer this reason remaineth in them that they can kéep the
which time and space their broode breake out of the shell, béeing of sufficient abilytie to mooue. Then come the Tortoises to the place where they couered their Egges & they raise vp the ground which before was cast vpon them to hide them and at laste leade their yung away quite, which haue strēgth inough to followe and might to continue.

div.head: ❧ Of vvilde Sovves.
div.p: THey are not altogither vnskilfull in Phisick, for when they haue of ignoraunce eaten Hyosciamum, by and by they draw in their hinder partes and séeme for a while to want hart and life, yet not withstanding, allbeit as it were shrunk vp togither, they créepe to the shore side and eate water Crabs, whiche offer vnto them (after they haue fed fréely) a present remedy of their disease, and a recouering of their former helthfulnes.

div.head: Of the spider called Phalangium.
div.p: THey doo as much mischéef to Harts as they doo vnto men, in so muche as the Harts oftentimes fall in daunger of suddain death, but if they might neuer so little nip Iuy, the poysoned sting of the Spider dooth no harme nor leaueth any spark of infecting gréef. But take this by the way, that the Iuy must be wilde.

div.head: VVhat Phisick a Lion vseth vvhen he is sick.
div.p: A Lyon falling into sicknesse can be cured and healed of his dissease by none other medicine then by deuouring an Ape, which is a soueraine salue against the Lyons sore.

div.head: ❧ Hovv the Gotes of Crete cure the shots of Arrovves.
div.p: THe people of Crete are cunning Archers and experte Shooters, it is their exercise to direct their shafts at rough Gotes which féed vpon the tops of mountains and on Hil heds whiche as soone as they féele them selues wounded with a pearcing Arrow, presently crop the hearbe Dictamus and swallow it down their throte. The qualitie of whose taste woorketh this effect, that the shiuering shafts which the Archers did shoot, fall out of the Gotes flesh wherin they were déepely fastened before.

div.head: That Mice haue knovvledge in things to come.
div.p: MIce excel all lyuing creatures in the knowledge of Prophecy & in the experience of things to come, for when any olde, house, habitacion, tenement or dwelling place waxeth olde, ruinous, and redy to fall to the ground, they perceaue it first, yea so plainly they perceaue it: that vpon that their foresight they make present auoydance from their holes and corners as fast as their legges will giue them leaue, and séeke an other abiding place wherin they may dwel without danger or fear of losse of life.

div.head: ❧ Of Antes.
div.p: ANtes in like manner (as I haue receiued by report) haue a certaine sight and quick vnderstanding in things to come, for if any fear of famin, any dread of dearth, any hasard of hunger be at hand, they are wunderful busy and painful, not onely to cary but also to lay vp prouision of Corne and other necessary frutes fit for food to succour and sustain them selues in the bitter time of nipping néed.

div.head: ❧ Of Gelon.
div.p:
GElon a man of Siracusae, did dreame in his sléepe that he was blasted with lightning, whervpon he was so vexed with an inward agony and trouble of minde, that he cryed or rather rored out, not with
a softly and stil voice, but (as the wunt is in dredful dreames) with a lowde and lofty voice, as if he had beene flighted with an outragious feare. But a Dog which lay by him, béeing a waked out of sleep wt the great noyes & rageing outcry which Gelon made, rose vp and went rounde about him, one while barking vehemently at his hed and feet: another while howling terribly, at his right side and his left, and neuer did stint or stay, til Gelon was wakened and deliuered from the terror of his dreame.

div.head: ❧ Of the Svvanne.
div.p: THe Swanne, after Aristotles opinion, bringeth foorth a goodly great broode, and is besides that, indued with that qualitie of minde, from whence wrath hath issue, whervpon it commeth to passe ye when they ar angrye they fight so fiercely togither that they doo not only fetch blood out of the flesh, but also murther one another before they giue ouer the quarrel. The self same Author affirmeth that Swans fight against Eagles, to reuenge wrongs & iniuries, rather then to obtaine rule: and vse power or principality ouer the vanquished. That they looue singing it is so common that it is growne in to a prouerb: But I neuer in all my life had the luck to heare a swanne sing, nor paraduenture any other, yet notwithstanding it is supposed that they sing, and then specially (say some) is their singing moste swéet and delightsome, when their exchaūge of life with death approcheth. They passe ouer the Sea, and through the waues flye they with their vnwearied wings, seruing them in sted of a paire of Ores.

div.head: ❧ Of Pigeons.
div.p:
IT is saide that Pigeones sit vpon their eggs by course & afterwards when they are chaūged from Egges to chickens, the Cocke dooth féed and foster them, banishīg all anger from them (as they say)
which if he should not doo, they would fight among them selues and fall at variāce. The Hen bringeth foorth two egg{is}, wherof the first alwaies is a Cock chick, the other a hen. They breed at all seasons of the yéer, whervpon it foloweth that they haue yung ten times a yéer. Somewhich write of AEgipt say that the pigeons in that countrey bréed twelue times a yéer: Aristotle affirmeth that Stockdooues differ from pigeons, because pigeons are somwhat bigger, Stockdooues lesser, and that pigeons be tame and gentle, but Stockdooues wilde and vnapt to be handled. The same Author saith moreouer, that the cock dooth not tread the hen, before he haue courteously kissed her, for the Hen wil not haue company with the Cock, if she want the due payment of a kisse. He saith furthermore that the hens when they lack a Cock tread one another, but nothing entreth in to their bodies whiche hath the quality of ingendring: Yet not withstanding they bring foorth egges, but these Egges ne-neuer prooue pigeons.

And if so be that Callimachus deserue credit, the Ringdone, the Pirall, the Pigeon, and the Turtle, are so far from béeing like one another that they are quite contrary. Some ther be which write of India, who reporte that there bée in that country Pigeons of a yellowe couler. And Charon Lampsacenus sayeth, that about Athon white Pigeons appéered and weare séene, at suche time as the Gallyes of the Persians which were driuen with thrée orders of Ores, were funk when they passed by Athon.

And in Eryce of Sicily, wherin is builded the blessed, the glorious, the holy and renowmed Chappell of Venus, some say that when the people of that place offer their ordinary and holy Oblations at a limited time, and when Lady Venus goeth in progresse frō Sicilia soile into Libia land, all the Pigeons vanish out of sight vppon a suddaine as though they were of Venus retinue and gaue attendaunce vppon her grace: Certain it is, that all other times of the yéere, there is great plentie of Pigeons sitting vppon the toppes of the Temple, and flying about the stately Pinacles of the same. To knit vp this in a round knot of shortnes and breuitie, the Graecians commend this to memory, that Iupiter him self took
vpon him the shape and porturature of a prety Pigeon, when he looued fine Pthia the famouse Virgin whose dwelling was in AEgio.

div.head: ❧ Of Socrates vvhen he drank poyson.
div.p: WHen the ship had made return from Delus, and Socrates was to suffer punishment namely losse of life, Apollodorus the familier fréend of Socrates comming to the Prison where he was laid vppe, brought vnto him a Cote of very fine and costly Wul, wel wouen and wrought, and there withall a Cloke of no courser stuffe, desiring him to put them on and to were them when he drunk the poyson which should procure his death, for he said that Socrates could not want a rich and honorable buriall if he béeing attired with those gorgious garments yéelded vp the swéet pledge of his life, nor that he should lye dead altogither vndecently, béeing decked with such bewtifull and comely furniture. These woords vttered Apollodorus to Socrates. But he not alowing therof, said to Crito, Simmias and Phaedon. O what a notable and excellent opinion dooth Apollodorus conceiue of vs, if he hope to sée Socrates in such brauery after he hath drunk vp the poysoned Potion ministred to him by the hands of the Athenians: But if he did consider and beleeue that shortly after I should droup downe, grouell on the ground, and at last lye like a lump of Lead vnder féet, he would not vouchsafe to knowe me.

div.head: ❧ Of a VVaggon vvith foure Horses and a Poesy, made in a very little compasse.
div.p:
THese be the woorkes of Myrmecidas Milesius and Callicrates Lacedemonius, not so wunderfull as worthy, bothe for the smalenes and the cunning thereof, they made a Waggon drawen with two couples of Horses, which might be hidden vnder a Flye: And wrote in a little small bery (no bigger then a Beane) a posy of two verses in letters of Golde: neither of whiche a wise and vertuous man would
worthely commend. For what other thing, importe these trifling toyes, but an idle spending of the time.

div.head: Of ryotous vvomen giuen vnto costly brauery.
div.p: MAy we not wel think that many womē, haue béen delighted in excessiue gorgiousnes, while some haue worne on their hed{is} high and huge Crownes, precious slippers on their féet, glorious Iuelles hanging at their eares, downe a great length, their garment{is} from the shoulders seames to the narrowing of the sléeues at the wristes, were not sowed vp with néedle or silke, but fastened with Laces of Golde and Siluer? This was the pomp and pride in ages of auncient memory. What costlynes the women of Athens vsed in trimming them self, I referre you to the testimony and recorde of Aristophanes.

div.head: ❧ Of the Sybarites, the Colophones, and the Corinthes superfluetie in fine apparel and costly cheere.
div.p: IT is a common saying, and swimmes in euery mans mouth, that the Sybarites & their Citie came to vtter ruine and destruction, by excesse, and superfluous spending. I wil by your leaue, declare in few woords such thīgs as are not trudge motly, (as we terme it) that is, manifest to the multitude, & apparant to the people, known to the common sorte, and familiar to all. But that wherof moste be ignorant, and very few vnderstand. Intollerable prodigalitie was the vtter vndooing and ouerthrow of the Colophones, for they limitted their proude and pompous apparel within no measure, besides that, their behauiour was beastly, in that they abused them selues distēperately at their tables. And ye office of authoritie which the Baccheiades had, when it was in the very top of power, and in the floure of felicitie, yet not withstāding, through wastefull and superfluous riotousnes it came to nought.

div.head: Of Dionisius stealing avvay holy things.
div.p: DIonisius albeit he was a king, yet he was not a heares bredth from a théefe, for he did steale much money out of Temples and Chappels, and holy places in Siracusae, he spoiled Iupiters Image of his garment and robbed him of all his fine furniture, whiche were valued at lxxxv. Talents of Golde. And albeit the woorkmen and Artificers thought it a matter of méere conscience to touch the Image, yet he was not only ashamed to hādle thē vnreuerently but ouer bolde to abuse thē felloniously. He robbed in like maner the Image of Apollo whiche glittered moste gloriously with golden heares, commaunding one of his retinue to shaue them of to the very stumps, and néerer, if néerer could be. And sayling from thence into Troezenia, he tooke away with him (whiche was an hainous offence) the money of Apollo and Leucothoe. He gaue commaundement also that a siluer table standing by the picture of Apollo should be remooued and conueyed from thence for his priuate vse and profit, which table, prosperous and lucky Fortune had bestowed vpon that God for maintainaunce of banketing and hospitalitie.

div.head: ❧ Ismenias vvorshipped the King of Persia and did him self no shame,
div.p:
I Cannot passe ouer with silence, the déede of Ismenias the Thebane, a déed seasoned with wisdome, and sauouring altogither of Graecian policie. This man bearing the office of an Embassadoure in his Countryes behalfe, came vnto the King, and would in his owne person haue communication with him concerning the busines whereabout he came: The chéef Officer therfore among the Souldiours, whose seruice and duetie was to cary Errands and tidings to the king, and to bring such before his presence as were desirous to attain to the spéech of him, said in this wise to Ismenias. Assuredly thou Theban straūger (these woordes he spake vpon pleasure and delight by the mouth of an interpreter, the Officers name was Tithrauftes) it is a naturall
law among the Persians and the custom of the Countrye, that he which commeth before the presence of the King to enter talke with his maiestie, should not obtain such licence and libertie excepte he humbly bowed his knées and did obeysaunce. Wherfore if thou art willing to go before the Kings highnes, it is necessary that thou satisfie the tenour of ye awncient Statute in this point prouided, if thou refuse so to doowe wil perforce constraine thée to exhibit such seruice as the law of this our land requireth. Ismenias made answere, go to then saith he, conduct me before your Prince. When he came within the compasse of the kings countenaunce, he drew of his finger a great Ring, which he did weare at the same time, this Ring he let fall frō him closely & priuely that his purpose was not perceiued, which béeing doone, by & by he did bend his body forward and ducked to the ground, vnder a pretence of worshipping the King, and in stouping down took vp his ring whiche he had let fall from him before, to woork the feat the more conueniently. Thus did Ismenias honour and obeysaunce to the king of Persia, and yet saued harmeles & blamelesse the renown of Grecia. What soeuer therfore he demaunded, that he obtained, neither did the Persian Prince giue him a denyall in any request.

div.head: ❧ The gifts and presents vvhich the Persian Kings vsed to bestowe vpon Embassadours.
div.p: THe gifts whiche the King gaue to Embassadours that came vnto him, whether they were of Graecia or any other Countrey, were these: To euery one a Babilonian Talent of ye best and the finest Siluer, which were two siluer standing Péeces. A Babilonian Talent is worth lxx. pounds of Athenian Coine, Bracelets, Iewels, a Persian sword, and a Chaine. All these were valued at a thousand Persian péeces of the golden stamp. Moreouer, besides all the rest he gaue them a Median royall robe, which was called Dorophorica.

div.head: ❧ Of Gorgias and Protagoras.
div.p: WHiles the aūcient Graecians flourished & were (as we say in their ruffe) Gorgias Leontinus the sonne of Philolaus, and Protagoras the sonne of Democritus, who but they in honor and renown, yet notwithstanding their great showe of worship, they were as wise as Wood cocks, for they were as far from knowledge, as boyes be from manhood. Reporte dooth not alwaies blase abrode the trueth, and therefore oftentimes it deceiueth vs, and flattereth erewhiles to win fauour, and filleth peoples eares with lewd lyes and tatling tales.

div.head: Of the contention of Hercules and Lepreas
div.p: GLauco the sonne of Neptune by Astydameia, the daughter of Phorban, begat a Sonne named Lepreas, who conspired with Augeas about the binding of Hercules, when he required of him the rewarde of his contention and labours. Wherfore (as it is not vnlike) they were bothe, not onely at variance one with an other, but also at vtter defiance. In the meane while, Iupiters sonne went to the Cautones, and Astydameia by her earnest request, quēched all hatreds, strifes and quarrels, betwéen Hercules and Lepreas. So it fortuned that an od youthful toy of trying masteryes, in casting a Leaden lump aloft into the Ayre, and in drawing water, grew betwéene them, and whiche of the twain could first deuoure a whole Oxe: In which practises Lepreas was quite quailed and ouercome.

After that, there arose betwixt them another contention, which could drink moste of them bothe: In which strife Lepreas went away, not the winner but the looser. At the last he béeing in a fumish chafe and angry heat, tooke vnto him harnesse and weapons, and challenged Hercules to fight with him hand to hand in Combat: wherefore he had his paiment
and deserued punishment, for those things wher about he and Augeas cast their heds togither, his luck was to be slaine in fighting through his malapertnes.

div.head: ❧ The large and Lordly liberalitie of Alexander towards Phocion, and againe of Phocion tovvards Alexander.
div.p: ALexander the sonne of Philip, or (if it like you) of Iupiter, it makes no matter of which, when he did write to Phocion the Captaine of the Atheniēs he vsed this woord, Salutem, that is, gréeting commendions of curtesie, or wishing of welfare, so did he to none other beside Phocion, for he had as it were, tied & linckt fast vnto him the Macedonian Kings hart, as may appéere by these presidents of his good wil. An hundred talents of Siluer for a gift, and the names of iiij. famouse Cities to choose and take which he would, that the tributes, subsidies, annuities, and yéerly reuennewes, which grew, of & by the same, might wholly, soly, and totally turn to his owne gain, profit and aduaūtage. The names of the Cities were these. The first Chius, the second Elea, the third Mylasa, the fourth Patara.

This liberalitie of Alexander was notable, honorable, and royall: But Phocion delt with Alexander, much more worthely, who would in no case receiue neither Siluer nor Citie: And yet notwithstanding, to the intent he might not séeme to set light or make no accoūt of Alexanders large gift{is}, he gaue a testimony of his thankful hart to the king, and vsed his frée nature to liberalitie on this wise: For he requested that those which were captiues in the Castle at Sardis might be let loose and set at libertie, their names follow in this order, Echecratides the sophister, Athenodorus, Himaereus, and De maratus, which twaine were brethern and bothe of Rhodes.

div.head: ❧ Of Aglais the great and greedy eater.
div.p: I Heare of a woman (Aglais was her name and Megacles was her mother) whose practise, trade, and occupation was to sound the Trumpet, her heare was counterfect and deceiptfull, and she did weare on her hed a Crest, as Posidippus witnesseth. This woman deuoured at euery meale xij. poūd of flesh, as muche Bread as two Bushels of Wheate could make, and she glutted down her wide Throte thrée quartes of Wine, or as some say (which is more like) thrée Gallons.

div.head: ❧ Of Gluttons and belly Gods.
div.p: IT is recorded in the Regester of memory, that the within named were mightie eaters, Pityreus the Phrigiā, Cambetes the Lydiā, Thyus ye Paphagoniā, Charidas, Cleonym{us}, Pisander, Charipus, Mithridates of Pontus, Calamodor{us} of Cyzicen, Timocreō of Rhodes who was both a wrestler & a poet, Cartibaris the Persian, Erysicthon the sonne of Myrmidō who for ye same cause was surnamed an Asse.

Moreouer it is reported yt in Sicily a temple is builded and dedicated to gluttony, and that there is also an Image erected and set vp in the honor of Lady Ceres the gracious goddesse of Corne. And Alcman the Poet, testifieth of him self, that hée was an insatiable deuourer. To be short Anaxillas the Enterlude maker saieth, that there was a certaine man called Ctesias giuē to vnmesurable consuming of Victuals, who neuer was satisfied, but the more he had the more he might.

div.head: ❧ VVhat meate the people of Rhodes moste esteemed.
div.p:
I Wil rehearse vnto you a Rhodian opinion. In Rhodes (as the talke goeth) he which looueth fish, setteh store by it, regardeth the swéetnes thereof, and preferreth it before all other vctualls: Him, I say, the common people account a right Courteour & a ioly fellow,
a frée harted man. But contrarywise, he which is more delighted in flesh then in Fish, refusing the latter and choosing the former, is il thought of in Rhodes, he is counted a Clownish loute and a bondslaue to his belly, to his greate shame and reproche. But whether the first or the last doo wel or il, it is not my meaning to giue iudgement.

div.head: That a Sheep brought foorth a Lyon.
div.p: THe people Coi reporte that in the pastures of Nicippus the Tirant a shéep was disburthened of her belly. And wil you knowe what she brought foorth? not a Lamb of the male or the female kinde, but a Lyon whiche Worlds wonder forewarned the Tiranny of Nicippus in time to come, who when this straunge and monsterous sight appéered was but a priuate man and no Prince.

div.head: ❧ That Ptolomey looued Galetes not so much for the comlynes of his fauoure, as for the singularitie of his knowledge in sundry things.
div.p: KIng Ptolomey swéetly loued Galetes a sprīgal both bewtiful in face & hansome in proportion and making. But the yung mans vertuous minde did far surmount his comely fauoure. Ptolomeus therefore oftentimes gaue witnesse to the same, saying. O pleasant hed, O smooth tunge dyouthe, thou haste neuer béen any mans hinderaunce, but many mens furtheraunce.

It fortuned vppon a time that this noble Impe, Galetes by name, rode abrode with the King and espying a far of certaine men led to execution, spake these woords to Ptolomey not coldely and cowardly, but boldely and valyantly: Because (O King) saith he, we are mounted on horseback to the good luck and fauourable fortune of yonder same condemned men, let
vs if it be your graces pleasure, set spurres to our horse ribbes, that making poste haste after them we may be as Castor & Pollux be to wandring Mariners, that is, helthfull helpers, & gratious aiders, to poore wretched castawayes (for that propertie is blased by tounge and by penne with a common prouerbe to consist in those Gods.) King Ptolomeus conceiuing surpassing pleasure and delight through the beautie and goodnes of Galetes, and greatly alowing his nature prone to pitie and compassion, did bothe pardon and saue the condemned Prisoners, & doubled or rather multiplyed his looue towardes the merciful youngman.

div.head: ❧ The lavve of the Persians concerning gifts and presents to be brought to the Kings Maiestie.
div.p: THe Persians haue a Lawe whiche among the rest, beeing in number many, is moste dillygently and dutifully obserued. When the King goeth in Progresse to Persia, the people generally one with an other, offer presentes and gifts to his maiestie, according to their abilitie, Husbandmen, labourers, farmers and Artificers, euery man proportionally.

The gifts which they offered vnto the king, as they weare not to base, homely and vile: so were they not to precious, costly and sumptuous. The ordinary gifts, were Oxen, shéep, Corne, wine and such like: These gifts are presented vnto him as he passeth in Progresse, and they be called Oblations, by which name he receiueth them at the giuers hand. The poorer people offer vnto him, Milke, Dates, Cheese, the firstlings of their frutes, and such like Iunkets.

div.head: ❧ Of VVater presented to the King of Persia for a gift
div.p: THis Historye sauoureth of Persia, it is saide that a certaine Persian named Sinetas, being far from his poore cottage, or dwelling house, and méeting Artaxerxes, who was surnamed Micamon, vpon a suddē, was not a litle vexed and troubled in mīde, with the feare of the Persian lawe, and greatly ashamed of him self, to beholde the King with empty handes. This Sinaetas beeing at that time ignorant what he might doo, and séeing other go beyond him in duty and seruice, was inwardly gréeued, yet did he what he might not to deserue in any case ye reprochfull reporte of such a one as had nothing to offer to his King. In this constraint, what dooth he? he runneth with posting spéed, as fast as a footman might, to the next flood or riuer, which was called Cyrus, and stouping down, he tooke vp water in the holowe palme of his hand, and spake after this manner to the kinges highnes. O King Artaxerxes (saith he) the Gods saue your grace and graunt thée a prosperous and a perpetuall reigne ouer vs, your maiesties subiects. I honour thée as the occasion of this time and place dooth permit, and as the measure of my welth and abilitie wil giue me leaue: To the intent, that thou shouldest not passe by, without some gift or other at my hands, lo as dutie required, & as mine estate affoordeth, I woorship thée with the water of Cyrus: but when your grace cometh to your lodging, I wil yéeld you such honor, as my simple house, my small substaunce and weake welth may with all humilitie, and I wil offer vnto your highnes the chéefest and the costliest things that I haue, & peraduenture I wil be equal with them whiche honor your maiestie with glorious gifts at this presēt.

Artaxerxes béeing delighted therwith, made this answere. Good fellow we receiue thy gift with great liking, and we account it in the number of the very best, & the worthyest, for so we take them in value and estimation. First because water of all things is most excellent: Secondly because it beareth the name of Cyrus. It is my plesaure therfore yt thou repair to our camp: These woords vttered, he gaue commaundement to his Chamberlains, to take the gift of the man, who ran spéedyly towards him, and receiued the water running out of his hollow hāds & dropping of his fingers ends, into a goblet of golde.

When the King came to his lodging, he sent to the plaine contry man for a rewarde, a Persian Robe, a golden Cuppe, and a thousand péeces of Persian coine, commaūding the bearer of those riche giftes, to say this message to the fellow, It is the Kinges will & plesure that thou delight thy hart with this glittering golde, because thou (when time serued) didst fill his minde with ioifulnes, not sufferīg his highnes to passe by thée vnpresented with a gift, but as necessitie gaue thée leaue and libertie, so didst worship & honor him, with all submission and lowlines. It is his pleasure also that thou take water out of the riuer Cirus, and drinck it out of this golden goblet.

div.head: ❧ Of a Pomegranate giuen to the same King.
div.p: TO Artaxerxes riding through Persis, a man named Mises offered a great pomegranat in a fan or a siue. The king wundring at the bignes and largenes therof, asked him saing, frēd out of what garden cometh this pomegranate which thou hast brought mée? The man aunswered, from mine owne howse (O King) and out of mine owne garden, Artaxerxes reioysing thereat, inriched him with princely presents & glorious gifts, vttering these woords, By the sun that shineth, this man in my iudgement, of a litle Citie can make a great, by his attendance and diligence.

This saing of the King signifieth vnto vs that all thīgs by carefulnes, continuall trauel and long lasting labour, may become better and wax much more excellent, notwithstanding the course of their nature be contrary.

div.head: Of a Father sitting in Iudgement vpon his ovvne Sonne, and suing him to death.
div.p:
A Certain man of Mardus stock named Rhaechones, had seuen Children, among whome the youngest who was called Cartanes, did much mischéef to Magicians, and was a sworne aduersary to wise men.
His father therfore first of all spared no paines to instruct and teach him, and sought with councel and admonitions to win him into the way. But he lightly regarding or rather contemning his Fathers warnings and corrections, continued in his knauery. It fortuned on a time, that the Iudges there about came thither, among whome this youngmans father had his appointed seat: Who took his sonne, bound his hands at his back, like a théef or a malefactor, brought him to the Session house, in the presence of Iudgement accused him of déeds offensiuely committed through boldenes and stubbornnes, and beséeched the Iudges, not only to condemne him as a trespasser, but to soūd out the sētence definitiue of death against him not vndeseruedly. But they béeing amased in minde, & much molested with stackering cogitations, would not vppon the fathers request, giue iudgemēt against the sonne, but brought them bothe before King Artaxerxes of Persia. Mardus or Rhaecones (which you wil) laboured against his Sonne with tooth and nail, as desirous of his death, whome the king tooke vp in this sorte. Canst thou, saith he, for pitties sake, stand staring vpon thy Sonne whiles he suffreth death before thy face? Who aunswered. Yea forsooth, O King, and why not? For when I pluck or cut of the bitter slip{is} of Lettuce whiche growe in my Garden, the mother Herb frō whence the rest did spring, is so far from sustaining hurt or harme (that to confesse the trueth in good faith) it flourisheth the more merrely, and increaseth, not only in greatnes but also in swéetnes. In like maner (O King) when I shall sée him, which endamageth my whole housholde, and bringeth the liues of his brethern in hassard, and their good estate in daunger: When (I say) I shall sée him loose his life, and by that meanes preuented of all wrongs which he purposed to woork against his brethern, my worship shall purchase the higher aduauncement, and I shall beholde the remnaunt of my race and alliaunce inioying prosperous Fortune and luckye happynes.

Which woords when Artaxerxes hard, he commended the wisdome of Rhaecones, and made him of the number of the Kings Iudges, vttering this spéech to the people that were present. He which is so hard harted and pittilesse in pronouncing
sentence with such seueritie, sharpnes, & Iustice against his owne Sonne, he wil vndoutedly, shew him self a Iudge vpright and vnspotted, in taking vengeaunce of other mennes offences.

At length the King pardoned the youngman, and cléerly discharged him of that presēt trespasse, threatning vnto him an horrible and hedyous death, if he (after these faults forgiuen) should be found an offender in the lyke.

div.trailer: The end of the first Booke.

div.head: The second Booke of AElianus his variable HISTORY.
❧ Hovv Socrates incouraged Alcibiades that he should not fear the people more then needed.
div.p: WE will now make rehearsall of Socrates woords to Alcibiades, who béeing but a youngman, cōceiued so great fear in his mīde, that he durst not go abrode into the assembly of the people. Socrates willing to arme him wt bolde courage and hardines, saith thus vnto him: Doost thou not set light by that slouēly sowter? (calling him by his name.) Wherunto Alcibiades graūted. Thē Socrates did procéed in talke, sayīg again: And doost thou not set nought by that cōmon cryer at open playes and games, and by that same greasy Currier? Alcibiades made no denyall. Then did Socrates infer the conclusion. And dooth, saith he, the peoples assemblyes consist of any other thē of such as I haue recoūted? Wherfore if thou despisest euery particuler person seuerally one by one, there is no cause why thou shouldest fear them whē they be gathered togither in a hed in one place.
These things did the sonne of Sophroniscus & Phenerata, teach the sonne of Clinias and Dinomache.

div.head: ❧ Of Pictures rashly and vnaduysedly commended.
div.p:
THen Megabyzus vpon a time highly praysed pictures whiche were botcherly and vncunningly painted, and contrary wise déeply discommended such as were worthely & woorkmāly wrought Zeuxis seruāts (as they were grinding yellow oker) mocked & scorned him.
And Zeuxis him self bearing stomack against him, said thus, when thou holdest thy peace, Megabyzus, I cannot sufficiently thinck in hart what great hope these fellowes haue of thée, for they looke no further then vppon thy outwarde gorgious garments and garish guise of gooing. But when thy toung bewrayeth thy crooked opinion, and thy want of wit in giuing iudgement vppon any Artificiall and cunning wrought picture: They make a scorne and a laughing stock of thée. Be circumspect therfore and sparing of spéech to praise: Or rather he altogither toung tied: Neither commend thou the woorkmanshippe of any man, wherwith to meddle thou hast little thanks, because it belonged not vnto thée so to doo.

div.head: ❧ Of Alexander hovv he did not praise a Picture as it deserued,
div.p: ALexander beholding his owne Picture at Ephesus which Apelles made, did not commend it according as the worthynesse of the woorkmanship required. But when a lyuing Horse was brought before hī, which we hed at a Horse painted in coulours, as though it had béen a lyuing Horse, of flesh, blood, and bone, and not represented.
O King, sayeth Apelles, this Horse béeing void of reason séemeth vnto me, to haue a better and a quicker Iudgement, then you in discerning pictures.

div.head: ❧ Of the loue and freendship of Chariton and Melanippus and of Phalaris the tirants compassion tovvards them conceiued.
div.p: I Wil rehearse vnto you the déed of Phalaris clene contrary to his conditions, and repugnaunt to his manners, for it smelleth of gentlenes, & it is leuened with lenitie and clemencye, and therefore it appéereth not agreeable to his nature.

There was a certain man called Chariton
of Agrigentine, a louer of beautie and comlines, & suche a one as was very busye (but to his il luck) about fair and wel fauoured springalls. This man made much of one Melanippus, who was an Agrigentine also, a hansome youth, of good and honest nature, and commendable comlynes therwithall.

To this Melanippus had Phalaris doon iniury in a certain case. For when he and one of Phalaris fréends were at controuersy in iudgement: The Tirant commaunded and charged him to giue ouer his sute, who not obeying the voice of Phalaris, was threatned to dye a shameful death, if he did not shew him self conformable to the King, his liege Lords commaundement. But he in iudgement ouerthrew the other, which would néeds haue tyed him to necessitie. The Princes of Phalaris béeing iolly Courtiers, procured that the sentence of Iudgement should ve void and of none effect. At the which Melanippus was not a little displeased & galled with inwarde grudge, in somuch yt he spake plainly (as he thought secretly) saying, that he had open wrōg wrought against him.

The youngman béeing thus griped with greef, and racked wt rage, bewrayed the motions of his minde to his fréend, rehearsing the sum of all the matter, and desiring him that he might haue his assistance to lye in wait for the Tirant, somewhat therby to woork his spéedy dispatch. Moreouer he was purposed, to get other youthful Impes to be his coadiutors, fellowhelpers, & parteners in that perillous cōspiracy & dangerous enterprise, and suche as he him self supposed to be fit instruments to serue his turn.

Chariton perceiuing Melanippus madnes, and outrage, and séeing him (as it were) frying & broyling in the Fornace of fury, and béeing also well assured that no Citizen, for feare and terror of the Tirant, durst giue his consent to further such a rebellious intent, said, that he likewise of late time did not only deuise in minde, but also bestowed his endeuour and diligence to the vttermoste of his abilitie, how he might banish bondage out of the borders and bonds of his Countrey, and bewtifie the same with flourishing fréedom and libertie. But as some déeds be not aduentured without daunger, so are they moste hainous to be commited. Wherfore he besought him to

〈1 page duplicate〉
giue him leaue and leasure to consider more narowly of this matter, and that he would watch a time conuenient to accomplish his purpose. The yungman did yéeld to his aduise, wherfore Chariton pondering and perusing in his minde, all the cōueyaunce of his indeuour would in no case take Melanippus (whōe he intirely loued) to be partaker of such a trespasse, to the intent that he only béeing apprehended in committing so villanous a fact, might declare by manifest euidences, that he was the offender, and that he alone was to sustain punishment, and not his déer fréend and louer, whome he would in no wise wish accessary to the déed.

Taking his arming swoord therfore in his hardy hands, he prepared himself forward on his way to the Tirant, but béeing vnable to dispatch his attempt closely (for there were sundry impossibilities in the matter) he was intercepted of the Garde, who in such perilous practises watch and warde most precisely and carefully. After which suddain apprehension, he was imprisoned, examined, tormented and sharply executed to appeach the residue that were confederate with him in this conspiracy, which cruel smarts and pinching punishmēt{is} he neuerthelesse moste valiantly suffred, and couragiously indured.

After long continuance of Charitons imprisonment and calamitie, Melanippus came to Phalaris, entring and presenting a priuate accusation against his owne persō, aduouching that he was not only an accessary to this councell, an assistant in this rebellion, and the ringleader in this insurrection, but also the capitall procurer and onely author of the same: And that Chariton was vngiltie, blamelesse and inculpable, and therfore harmelesse and vnpunished: This was the summe of his confession. The king demaunded of him what occasion mooued him to doo as he did. He rehearsed the totall discourse, in such forme and order as we haue made mention before, affirming, that bothe the abolishing of Iudgement and other semblable circumstances in law, séemed vnto him troublesome and intollerable.

The Tirant meruailing héerat, set bothe Chariton and Melanippus at libertie, pardoned their offences, and graūted
them a discharge, how beit vppon condition, That on the self same day of their releasement, they should departe, not onely out of the Citie Agrigentine, but also out of all the borders and limits of the land Sicilia, giuing and graunting neuerthelesse, vnto them & to either of them, of his speciall fauoure, that they should reape the due commodities, reuenues, and aduantages, which did yéerely arise by their possessions, hereditaments, lands, tenements, and what soeuer beside to them appertaining.
In processe of time it fortuned, that the fame of this fréendship béeing faithful and vnfained, was highly aduaunced of Apollo, in two sententious verses in this wise.

q.l: Of heuenly loue to mortal men approued captaines vveare
Bothe happy Chariton and Melanippus void of feare.

div.p: The Oracle calling the amitie and loue of these twaine, Heauenly, diuine, and celestiall.

div.head: Of bestovving time, and hovv vvalking vp and dovvne was not allowable among the Lacedemonians.
div.p: THe Lacedaemoniās were of this iudgement, that measurable spending of time, was greatly to be estéemed, and therefore did they conforme and apply them selues to any kinde of laboure moste earnestly and painfully, not with drawing their hands from woorks of much bodyly moouing, nor parmitting any perticuler person, béeing a Citizen, to spend the time in Idlenes, to waste it in vnthrifty gaming, to consume it in trifling, in vain toyes, and leud loytering, all whiche are at variance and enimity with vertue. Of this matter, among many testimonyes, take this for one.

When it was reported to the Magistrates of the Lacedaemonians called Ephori, in manner of complaint, that the inhabitants of Deceleia vsed after noone walkings, they sent vnto them Messengerrs with their commaundement saying.
Go not vp and downe like loyterers, nor walke not abrode at your pleasure, pampering the wantones of your natures, rather then acustoming your self to excercices of actiuity. For it becōmeth the Lacedemonians, to regarde their helth, and to maintaine their safety, not with walking to and fro, but with bodily labours,

div.head: ❧ A president teaching vs that vve must not please a multitude.
div.p: HIppomachus (as Fame flieth) a maister of wrestling, when one of his scholers did exhibit and showe a cast of his cunning in suche sorte that all the people gathered in a great assembly to sée him, gaue a showt in his commendatiō, Hippomachus his Master smot him with a wand, saying thus. Thou hast plaid thy parte rashely, vnaduisedly, & not as it became thée, in that point principally, whiche should haue been doon more curiously and more plausibly: For if thou hadst handled the matter, like an expert fellowe indéed, this multitude would not haue praised thée one whit: Meaning that such as obserue in all things, order, comlynes, and vniformitie, please not the vnskilfull people, but delight such only as haue knowledge & experience in the thing wherof they make a showe.

Socrates therfore dooth excellent wel in refusing ye blinde opinion of the people, making no account thereof in his communication had with Crito, at his comming to him when he was in prison, which Crito, ministred this councel to Socrates, namely to séeke meanes of escaping, and to corrupt the iudgement of the Atheniens bent against him.

div.head: ❧ That the people of Thebes put not avvay their infants to desperate aduentures.
div.p: THis law of the Thebans as it was tempered with wisdome, so was it poudred with compassion. For they made a Statute and a law, that no Inhahitant of Thebes should forsake the frute of his owne Loynes, namely their déer Children in their infancy, nor cary them into wildernes, there to leaue them at six and seuen, to sinck and swimme, to liue or dye, to lot and luck: The penaltie of which law was present death. Prouided alwaies by authoritie, that if the father were in néed, penury, want, and beggerlines, he was constrained by vertue of the statute in that case appointed, to bring their Infants, whether it were male or female, in their swathling cloutes, vnto the Magistrates. Who receiuing the Babe, deliuered the same to one or other to kéep at resonable charges (they to whome the Childe was committed) religiously swearing by their faith and honestie, that they wil nurish, féed, succoure & reléeue the childe, during the terme of his or her infancy. And when they aspire and come to ripenes ef yéeres, make them their houshold seruants, to recompence with dutiful dilligence, trusty seruice, and vprightnes, the expences of their nursing and bringing vppe, when they were vnder age of ablenes.

div.head: ❧ Of Xenocles and Euripides contending for preeminency in Olympia.
div.p:
IN the first and the sixt Olympiad, wherin Exanetus Agrigentinus got the gole, Xenocles and Euripides did striue for superioritie and excellency. In whiche contention Xenocles plaid his pagiant first (what soeuer he was) by his Oedipus, his Lycaon, his Bacchae, and his Athamas Satyricall. After him Euripides in the seconde place, by his Alexander, his Palamedes, his Troians, and his Sisyphus Satyricall. It is a toy therfore that the one was not ouercome, nor the other set vp with the maisteryes. Wherefore this must néeds follow that the cause héereof remained in
one of these two reasons, namely that the principall and chéefest in giuing of voyces, like blinde Beetels, either, perceiuing nothing therby, bewrayed their owne ignoraunce, reuolting from soundnes in iudgement, or els were corrupted with money which peruerteth Iustice and ouer throweth right. Bothe which blemishes and staining spots, aee reprochful and ignomious to the Atheniens.

div.head: ❧ The ordinaunces of the Atheniens for Rebelles and reuolters from true allegiaunce.
div.p: O Good and gratious gods, what statutes, what lawes, and ordinaūces, made the Atheniens, yea in the popular Regiment, that is, when the monster with many heds, namely the people, bare swinge and sway? They cut of the thumbes from the right hands of euery Aegenite, to the intent they should not be able to holde their Speares, swoords, and warlike wepons, but to handle their Oares in rowing at libertie without hinderaunce. They murthered the youth of the Mitylenenses, and that was determined by Cleon the Sonne of Claenaetus pronouncing it: As for the captiues of the Samies, they caused them to to be marked in the visages with a hot Iron, the forme wherof resembled the Image of an Owle, which decrée was made in like maner by the Atheniens. But Pallas, Minerua, Iupiter, Eleutherius, & all the glorious Gods of the Graecians, vtterly forbid, that it should be reported by me, that the Atheniens were the Authors of these Acts and Statutes: or that they gaue their assent and agréement vnto the same.

div.head: ❧ Hovv Timotheus, after he had heard the disputation of Plato, thought him self scarse happy and fortunate.
div.p:
TImothy, the Sonne of Conon, Captain of the the Atheniens, when he was in the blossom of his brauery, the flower of his felicitie, and the Pearle of his prosperitie, when he had subdued, conquered
and taken famous Cities with little laboure, in so much, that the people of Athēs, could not deuise what honour and renown to exhibite vnto him, for his puisaunce, worthynes, and valiancy.

This Timothy chaunced to méet Plato, walking without the walles in the Suburbs, accompanied with certaine of his Scholers, and diuerse of his acquaintaunce, whome Timothy beholding and séeing to be a man in body grose, heuy and corpulent, but in countenaunce milde, méek, gentle, and fauourable, reasoning of ponderous and waightie maters, not of disbursing money, not of Galleyes driuen with thrée orders of Ores, not of sayling, or affaires pertaining to the Sea, not of supplying wants where néed is, not of aide and succoure to be ministred, not of tribute to be demāded of league fellowes, not of Iseland borderers, and inhabithants, finally of no suche trifles or toyes: but of such celestiall sciences, as he him selfe professed, taught, practised, and published, wherin he accustomably spent all his study, insomuch that the sonne of Conon burst foorth into these woords. Oh blessed life, indéed, oh moste happy condition. Wherby it is manifestly gathered, that Timothy did not therfore iudge him self fortunate and lucky, because he was so honorable in the sight of the people.

div.head: VVhat Socrates spake of them vvhich vvere slain of the xxx. Tyrants.
div.p: SOcrates séeing many men, of no slender reputation or meane countenaunce, in the time of the thirty Tirants dominion, rule, and gouernment, to be murthered: and euery riche and welthy man, by crafty and fraudulent practises, to be punished, said thus (as the rumor runneth) to Antisthenes. Dooth it repent thée that we in all the course of our life, haue not obtained any great and notable thing? As we see Emperours ensigned with the Diadem royall, in Tragicall Treatises represented?

As those same Atreos, those Thiestes, those Agamēnons, and Aegisthos: of whiche some are recounted miserably to haue been murtherd, other some reported to haue banquited and fested with lothsome seruices, vnseemely messes of meat at their tables: But there was neuer any Poet so bolstred with boldnes and solde to shamelesnes, to bring vpon a stage in a play, a Pigge or Hogge killed.

div.head: ❧ Of Themistocles renouncing and forsaking Prodigalitie.
div.p: THis déed of Themistocles the Sonne of Neocles, whether it merit commendation or no, I wot not wel, after his father had forsaken him, he recouered the remembrance of him selfe, renowncing inordinate spendding, wilful wantonnes, and such like contagious and infectiue qualities, returning into the right way, forswearing by pathes of insolency, and abstayning from the filthy and polluted company of Harlots. And béeing inflamed with another kinde of affection contrary and opposite to the former, he did what he coulde, with the vttermoste of his indeuoure, to beare authoritie in the commō welth of Athens, to excel and surmount others, and to be principall and superminent in gouernaunce. Wherfore he said to his fréends and acquaintaunce, what wil you bestowe on me, whome no man, woman, nor Childe hath hated to this day? As for such whose delectation is grafted vpon the stock of enuy, runneth hedlong to that Tó periulaptesthai of Euripides, and yt is extreme foolishnes, Euripides him self approuing it.

div.head: ❧ Of Socrates beeing openly rebuked of Aristophanes in a Comedy.
div.p:
ANytus sought occasion and wayes of quarrelling with Sotrates for these reasons which we haue rehearsed, fearing, neuerthelesse, & suspecting the inclination
of the Atheniens wil, how they would take the accusation of the man. For the name of Socrates, as it was notable so was it famouse and the reporte of him was in a maner vniuersall. For many and sundry thing{is}, and especially, for that he cast out inuectiue spéeches, bitter taunts, and sharp woords against iangling Sophisters, in whome was no sound or substantiall ground of knowledge, but méer shadowes and apparaunces of lerning, teaching nothing that was profitable and commodious. He took his beginning therfore from them, and put in proof, how they would take the accusation of Socrates, for they supposed that it was no auailable way for them bluntly to burthen him with the blame of an offender, partely for the causes which we haue recited, and partely lest the fréends and companions of Socrates conceiuing an inward grudge against the accuser, should disswade and withdraw the mindes of the Iudges, to determine on their side, whervpon some mischéef should fall vpon him falsely and fraudulently accusing innocent Socrates, who procured no harme, hurt nor hassard to the common welth, but contrary wise was to the Athaniens, an ornament and Iuel of high honor. What dooth the aduersary in this case? he hireth Aristophanes the Comicall Poet, a trifling fellow, a merchant of vain meryments, & a common Iester (for so to be counted and named he did what hee could) and winning him to his will, that in a certain Comedy he would rebuke, check, taunt and nip Socrates, and charge him in an assembly, and conuent with all the euill that was blased abrode of him among the people, allbeit peraduenture despightfully and vndeseruedly. To reporte of him that he was a brabler, that he should say moreouer, that he was able by the eloquence of his language, and the finenes of his phrase to make causes clene contrary and repugnaunt to trueth and reason, to cary a copy or countenaunce of credit, ill matters good, wrong right, iniustce equitie, and so foorth, Furthermore that he introduced and brought in new and straunge God{is}, he himself, in the meane season béeing an Atheist, void of deuotion, Religion, and reuerence. And that he instilled this perillous opinion in to the mindes of such as imbraced his doctrine.

Aristophanes taking to himself a foundation substantiall,
an argument pithy, popular and plausible, tempred his toyes with the leuen of laughter, and perfumed his playes with the pleasant pomāder of his posies, choosing for his theme, the best mā and the most excellent, (without exception) among all the Grecians, for he did not backbite, sclaunder, and defame the Lacedemonians, Cleon was not represented in his pageant{is} and spectacles, he barked not at the Thebans, Pericles was not a bone to gnaw vppon with his téeth, But such a man he misused, such a man he reueiled and vnreuerently rated, as the gods them selues (and principally Apollo) moste déerly looued and preciously estéemed.

Wherfore at the strāgenes of the thing, at the vnaccustomed spectacle & gasing stock, abusiuely brought in vpon open stage, to the vtter discrediting, and defamation of Socrates, the Atheniens were astonished, and so much the rather were they rapt in admiration, as they perceiued that publiquely plaied which they leste suspected, looking, indéed, for no such thīg as was vndecētly doon. Afterwad{is} the people (because naturally they were prone to enuy, and swift to sclander the best men that Graecia bred among them, not only such as in the gouernment of the common welth and in place and office of authoritie many degrées excelled the rest, but such also as in learning, knowledge, sobernes, grauitie, and modestie of life and maners, glittered like Lampes through out the the whole land) were wunderfully delighted with that Comedy of Aristophanes, intituled Nebulae, that is to say, Clowdes.

Oh how pleasant a spectacle it séemed to the multitude, who so excessiuely reioyced at him which represented the person of Socrates, as they did neuer the like at any before, giuing and graunting vnto him, with one voice, the victory, and cōmaunding the Iudges, that the name of Aristophanes, and none beside, should be magnified with the highest and the statelyest inscription. The Enterlude was conueyed in this order. Socrates came seldome in sight vpon the stage, except when Euripides the Tragicall Poet contended with his new Tragedyes, then vsed he to enter into place vpon the scaffolde. And then, Lo, was he present also when Euripides was at contention with Pyreus, for he looued the man meruailously, aswell
for his learning and wisdome, as also for the pith and sappe of his vearse.

On a certain time Alcibiades the sonne of Clineas and Critias the sonne of Calleschrus, spieng him to resort vnto plaies, to view their behauiour, and to heare their discourses, kept a buskeling with him, as very lothe to haue him present, & thrust him of ye stage, whose resistance he did not greatly regarde, but like a modest mā, made light of the matter, & like a iust, a good, and a wise mā, passed all ouer with patience. Thus did he behaue him selfe towardes suche, as wrongfully & iniuriously, delt with him, snatching and catching at him like cur doggs, and vomiting out the venom of their stomackes against him, all which he suffered very continently, to the wunderful vexation of the contrary parte. This was, as it were, the seedes wherof his comedies sprung and grewe, and not those things only which Anytus and Melitus surmised. It is not vnlikely also, that Aristophanes him self, was by this meanes, greatly inriched, for when they instantly required, & with importunce and spéedy perswasions, assaulted him, to race the commēdable name of Socrates, out of the regesters of remembrance, with their sclaunderous and reprochful spéeches: Aristophanes being at that time beggarly, & skarse woorth thrée half pence (and besides his poouerty inclined to lewdnes of life & mischéef) was contēt to bée a hyreling, and to receaue wages to further a dishonest déed, and to maintaine a matter altogether built vppon the maine prise of malice, what absurditie therfore can insue if we giue this iudgement vpon him, according to his desarts? Of which two trespasses he is culpable, and cannot deny that he is guilty of them bothe. The enterlude purchased principall praise, and caried awaye the Crowne of commendation, for the sentence of Cratinus, was at that present moste trew, that the Theater did holde many a hateful and hellish hart.

And because great recourse was made, to the celebratiō of the feast daies of God Bacchus, a maine multitude of the Grecians swarmed thither by heapes, thick and thréefold, as desirous and gréedy to sée their vsuall sights, and accustomable solemnities. Whē therfore Socrates was borne about in ye play, and besides that was oftētimes named. (No meruail I trow)
