if he were séen represented in the person of a player: for certain it is and an vndoubted veritie, that Potters made his picture commonly vpon pitchers, Iugges, and such like tréene vessels: straungers there assembled, asked the question what he was that was borne aboute and gased at, like an ill faced Owle in the Comedy, and béeing togither ignorant in those knacks of knauery, made a pryuy whispering and murmuring noise, oftentimes demaunding what fellow that same Socrates was (which when he him self had precisely marked, for he was present at the playes, not of purpose but by fortune) and plainly perceiued that it was he and none els whome the Poet did so prick and pinche in his play (for he sat in a cōuenient place where he might bothe hear and sée the whole drift of the matter) To abolish and blot out all dubitations, and wauering opinions out of the mindes of the straungers, then and there assēbled, stood boult vpright, and so continued all the while that the Comedy indured, throughout euery Acte as the Players talked togither, so that there coulde be no choyse but the eyes of the people must of necessitie passe and perce vnto him, standing in the ful face of the multitude. So little did Socrates set by the canckred natures of the Atheniens, and the spightfull practises of Aristophanes.

div.head: ❧ Of a plane Tree vvhich king Xerxes loued.
div.p: I Cannot (beléeue me) but laugh at Xerxes, that he (all the woorks of Iupiter bothe on Sea and land set aside) appointed and aduentured straunge iourneyes to ride, and vnvsuall viages to sail, yt he became a seruiture to a plane trée and had the same in singuler admiration.

In Lydia (as the voice goes) when he saw a tall and a lofty faire plane trée, he made a whole dayes tarriance by it, no necessitie cōstraining him so to doo, he pitched his pauilions and tents in the void and empty places round about the same.

Moreouer he did hang precious Iewelles of great valure thervpon, he adorned and beautified the boughes and braunches
therof with chaines of Golde, with Bracelet{is}, with Tablet{is}, with Spangles and such like costly things, yeelding thervnto great worship and reuerence. Furthermore he appointed an ouerseer or keeper to preserue and defend the same from all miscasualties. But what aduauntage (I beséeche you) did the senceles trée reap by this curious dutifulnes. That bastardly beauty and counterfait comlynes bestowed vppon the body and the braunches beeing outwarde, and extraordinary Ornaments, and no naturall tokens, are to no purpose, nether yet auaileable to make the trée better, or more fruteful then otherwise it receaueth by kinde. But the naturall braunches of trées as they grow in Orchards and gardens, merit comendation in my iudgement, for the aboundance of their green leaues, for their firme & fast timber, for their deep & stedfast root{is}: for the spreading boughes gathering comfortable ayer, for their large compasses procuring holsome shadowes, and for the plētifulnes of their frute, when the furrowes of the soile is measurably moistned, with water belowe, or with raine and dewe from aboue: But the crimson skarfes of Xerxes, his rich robes of purple and perles, his fine golde fet from forraine countreis and the residue of those precious Iuels which he bestowed vpon the plane trée, procured no one iot of furtheraunce, neither to the bettering of the tree, nor to the dainty amending of any other trée.

div.head: ❧ Of the seates of the Lacedemonian magistrates, besmered with soute and dust.
div.p:
CErtain men of Clazomenia cōming to Sparta: with no lesse iniury then disdaine, filthely berayed the seates of the magistrats, Ephori with soyling soute and dust, where they vsually sat to giue iudgement in causes of controuersie, and to determine vpon maters concerning the wele publique. Of which déed the magistrates hauīg had knowledg, lightly passed it ouer, and sent for the cōmon cryer, to whome they gaue cōmaundement, that he shoulde openly proclame this Priuiledge graunted to the Clazomenians.
Liceat Clazomeniis indecore facere, let the Clazomeninans, haue licence to play the slouens,

div.head: ❧ Of Phocion
div.p: I Estéeme this déede of Phocion the Sonne of Phocus worthy comendation, who hauing to deale with the Atheniens in a Courte of assise, rebuking in them a certain vnthanckfulnes, said very learnedly, no doubte, and somwhat angerly therewithall, these woords insuing: I had rather, O yée Athenians, take wrong, then doo wrong, I had rather suffer harme, then inforce harme.

div.head: ❧ Of the vvisdome of the Persian magicians, and of Ochus.
div.p:
MEruailous is the wisdome of the Persian Magicians, who were furnished with the knowledge aswell of such things, as of dutie they ought, and throughly practised in the Science and experience of Prophecie: They did fortell the bloody crueltie and mercilesse murther of Ochus, threatned and executed vppon his Subiects, forséeing the same by sundry signes, euidences, and tokens. For when Ochus possessed the Scepter and Crown royal, after the funerall of his father finished, the Magicians gaue counsel to one of the kings Chamberlaines, diligently to obserue and marke when the table was spred and serued, vnto what thing Ochus first put foorth his hand{is}, among so many and diuerse as were set before him to choose & to vse. The Chamberlain hauing as quick an eye in this behalfe as any Eagle or Hauke, spied Ochus stretching out both his hāds, taking vp wt his right hand a knife which lay not far from his reach, & with his left a lofe of bread, which he did cut in slyces, & laid vpō them gobbets of flesh, which he deuoured with a sharp set stomack. When the Magiciās were certified heerof, they prophecied of ij. things to come. The first was the seasonable ripening of frutes, and the plentifulnes of victualles, whiles he occupyed the seat of the
kingdome, the other was the manyfolde murthers whiche should be committed within the compasse of his reign. Bothe which prophecyes were veryfied, and they found true in their premonstrations.

div.head: Of delicate Dinners, sumptuous Suppers, and prodigall banqueting.
div.p: TImothy the Sonne of Conon Captain of the Atheniens, leauing his sumptuous sare and royall banqueting, béeing desired and intertained of Plato to a feast Philosophicall, seasoned with contentation and Musick, at his returning home from that supper of Plato, he said vnto his familiar fréends. They whiche suppe with Plato this night are not sick or out of tēper the next day following, and presently vpon the enunciation of that spéech, Timothy took occasion to finde fault with great dinners, suppers, feasts, and banquets, furnished with excessiue fare, immoderate consuming of meats, delicates, dainties, toothsome iunkets & such like, which abridge the next dayes ioy, gladnes, delight, mirth, and pleasantnes. Yea that sentence is consonant and agréeable to the former, and importeth the same sence, notwithstanding in woords it hath a little difference: That the within named Timothy, méeting the next day after with Plato, said vn him. You Philosophers (fréend Plato) sup better the day following, then the night present.

div.head: Of Alexander vvho vvould needs be named a God.
div.p:
ALexander after he had vanquished Darius, and subdued the whole kingdome of Persia to his owne dominion, béeing wise aboue his capacitie, & puffed vp with the suddain blasts of his prosperous fortune and luckynes, which for the time present he inioyed, wrote vnto the Graecians to deify him and to make him a God. A foolish request, no dout, & méer ridiculous. For he wēt about to obtain ye of mortal mē by peticiō & intrelāce, which nature neuer graūted him, wherfore sōe supposing this, & other determinīg that.
The Lacedemonians among the rest made this decrée, saying thus. Because Alexander wil néed{is} bée a God, a God let him be. Breefly and according to the custome of their countrie quipping the want of wit whiche was in Alexander, his immoderate madnes, and impudent ambition.

div.head: ❧ Of the clemency of King Antigonus.
div.p: THey say, that Antigonus was appliant to gentlenes, and ful of affability, who soeuer therfore hath a desire to bee instructed throughly in the certain knowledge of this man, and inquisitiue after his deedes, must frequent the ful flowing foūtaīes of other volume writers, (for the narowe riuer of this historicall treatise is insufficient in that behalf), whiche if he doo he shall of necessitie, blase abroad the singuler bounty of Antigonus, his incōparable clemency, his lowlines & lenytie, wherof I wil now speake compendiously. This Antigonus perceauing his Sōne somwhat more fearce, hastie and violent with his subiectes thē him self, saide to his Sonne as foloweth. Knowest thou not yt our Kingdome is a noble seruitude, and an honorable bondage? which woordes of the father, vttered to the Sonne, gaue a glīmering of gentlenes, fauour & clemency, whereof whosoeuer alloweth not according to the worthynes of the same, séemeth vnto me to knowe nether Prīce nor people, nether King nor cōmoner, but rather to leade the life of a blood thirsty, and insatiable Tirant.

div.head: ❧ Of Pausanias, vvho looued the Poet Agatho.
div.p:
THe potter Pausanias, looued the poet Agatho, this no doubt, is manifest and euident, But I wil reporte vnto you, that which is not so common. Vppon a certaine time, they came bothe to Archelaus (a mā no lesse lōging after loue, thē groning after knowledge,) wherfore when he perceiued that there arose betwéen Pausanias and Agatho
many stormes of dissention, supposing that looue had not arriued in the hauen of their harts, he questioned with Agatho, and demaunded of him, how it fortuned that he was at square and daggers drawing so often with him, of whome he was so tenderly and vnfainedly belooued. To whome Agatho gaue this answere. Of this matter O King I wil render a reason, I am not his aduersary, I owe him no il will, I harboure no inwarde hatred nor grudging to his preiudice, neither doo I that which I doo, vpon any clownish and vncurteous péeuishnes. For assuredly, if I haue attained to the vnderstāding of any thing which depēdeth vpon good maners, then I finde both out of Historicall narrations, and also out of Poeticall discourses, that nothing is more pleasant or delightsom to such as be lightned with the Lamp of looue, then by strifes iarryings, brawlings, and variaūce, to alienate their mindes from mutuall amitie, and to growe in fauour again by louely reconciliation. And vndoutedly, to speake as I think, nothing is more ioyful and comfortable to such as be linked in loue, and as it were fettered in fréendshippe, then that which I haue alredy rehearsed. Of this consolation and pleasure I make him partaker oftentimes, by vsuall iangling and dayly wrangling with him: for he conceiueth great gladnes in his hart, if I dissolue the knots of loue by discention, and salue vp the sore again with the medicine of renewed amitie, if I quenche the flames of fréendly affection, and kindle the same again with the sparks of curtesie. But if I deale all alike with him, not interlacing loue with variablenes, continuing one custome, and following one fashion, he should not reape the haruest of perfect looue, nor taste the swéet sap of fréendships frutes, the benifit wherof, lo, now he dooth imbrace by trying the nature of contention. This reason of Agatho did Archelaus highly commend and extoll.

The same Agatho, did the Poet Euripides loue excéedingly, for whose sake (as Chronicles reporte) he compiled an Enterlude called Chrysippus. That it is a certain, vndouted, and an infallible trueth, I am not able to affirme precisely. But thus much I dare boldely aduouch, vpon perfect knowledge in this point, that this rumor hath béen scattered abrode by the
toungs of very many people.

div.head: ❧ Of the Mantinenses, that they vvere iust, and righteous.
div.p: THe Mantinenses are moste vpright, (for so they be reported) and no lesse iust then the Locrenses, then the Cretenses, then the Lacedemonians, and the Atheniens them selues.
For Solon was a passing wise, sober, iust, and righteous Citizen. Notwithstanding the Atheniens in tract of time, abrogated and tooke awaye the Lawes, Statutes & ordinances which were written by him.

div.head: Of Nicodorus the VVrestler, that vvas made a Law giuer.
div.p: NIcodorus an excelent wrestler, of great fame and name, In his latter yéeres by reason of his age and weakenes, béeing vnable to exercise his limmes and ioints in wrestling, as he had doon in his young and lusty dayes, chaunged his coppy, and became a Law maker among the Mantinenses, wherein he declared him self muche more profitable and honorable, then when he was proclaimed Conquerour in the common games and showes. Yet they say that Diagoras Melius, who loued Nicodorus, made lawes for him. Much more might I speake concerning Nicodorus, but lest I should séeme to aduaunce a miscreant with vndeserued commendation, I meane to limit my talke with measure.
For this Diagoras was a mortall enemye to the Gods, and I (to confesse the trueth) reape little pleasure in calling him to remembrance.

div.head: That Milo vvas strong and valiant in body, but vveake and cowardly in minde.
div.p: SOme haue extolled the strength of Milo Crotoniates to the very heauens, wherof many haue had much and often cōmunication, sounding as it were in a trumpet, this and that of him: But wil you hear an example of Milos péeuishnes? Not the mightiest aduersary of this manne, was able to wrest or wring an Aple out of his hands, which he griped fast in his fists: But yet for all that, his Lemmon and concubine, got the same from him, without any resistance, playeng with him wantonly, and vsing tricks of daliaunce. By which circumstāces it is manifest, that Milo in body was more then a mā, but in minde a very lout and a mome, and far worse then a woman.

div.head: ❧ That the sixt of February, vvas a lucky day to the Grecians
div.p:
THe sixte of the moneth February, did yéeld many good thīgs, not only to the Atheniens, but also to many other people. Vpon ye day came Socrates in to the world. Vpon that day the Persians were put to flight, and vtterly ouerthrowne. Vppon that day the Atheniens at Agrotera, offered thrée hundred young Kids, for a Sacrifice, performing that ceremonye according to the vow of Miltiades. Vppon the same day (béeing the eight of the Ides) there was a foughten féeld at Plateas, the Graecians béeing conquerours. For the first slaugter (which I remember) was committed in the Moneth of May, as the common voice goeth. And the victory which the Graecians got at Mycales, it is to be referred vnto none other day, then to the sixth of February, because the Triumph had at Plateas and at Mycales happened in one day. Moreouer vppon this day Alexander of Macedonia, King Philips Sonne and heyre, put many Millions of the barbarous people his enemyes to flight, vanquished them, ouer threwe them, made hauocke of them, to their great infamy and shame, but vnto his owne Honoure and renowne:
At which time Darius was taken, by the puisant power of the saide Alexander. Finally vpon this day (as the due obseruation of chronicles recorde) Alexander Magnus receaued the benefite of life and breath, and lost the aduantage of the same, in sembable manner.

div.head: ❧ Of Hiperboreus Apollo, and of certaine meruelous documents touching Pithagoras.
div.p: ARistotle affirmeth, that Apollo Pithius was surnamed Hiperboreus, of ye Crotoniates. And the same Aristotle, the Sonne of Nichomacus, addeth thus much more, that Pithagoras was séen in two sundry places in one day, and in one houre, namely in Metapontio and in Crotona, where he shewed his golden thigh. (A worlds wūder to way) The selfsame Author affirmeth, that as Pithagoras passed ouer the flood Cosa, he was called by his name, adioynīg to this reporte, that many heard the sounde of the voice.

div.head: ❧ Of Anniceris, that he vvas a good horsman: and that he which in small matters is ouer curious, dooth neglect causes of greater waight.
div.p:
ANniceris Cyrenesis, for his cunning in riding, and his skilfulnes in guiding a chariot, spred a brode his proude Pecocks taile, and was wunderful arrogant. This Anniceris being disposed vppon a time, to showe Plato a cast of his cunning, ioined his chariot and his horsses & furnished them with their cōuenient harnes, which when he had doone, he rode round aboute many courses and turnes (in the place called Academia, nigh to Athens where Plato published his profession, in philosophicall excercises) ruling the horsses so artificially, and kéeping the running of the chariot, vpon the whirling whéeles so vigilantly, that it swarued not a fingers breadth, out of the rundels, but alwaies remained in one, and the self same compasse of space & place and
neuer erred beside the Circle. All the company that were assembled, séeing this notable facte of Anniceris were rauished with a suddain admiration of the man: Onely Plato, among the rest, surpassing in prudence, and excelling in Iudgement, reproued the curiositie of his labour, saying, that it could none otherwise be, but that he, whiche in matters of no momēt, of no waight, or necessitie, bestowed such double diligēce, should be idle and vnoccupyed, or at least wise very remisse and dissolute in busy cases, and notable affaires. For where al a mans inuention, all a mans indeuour, and study is imployed in trifles and toyes, it foloweth orderly that he must néeds doo those things negligently, which in very deed are worthy to be wundered at, of the multitude.

div.head: ❧ From vvhence Cock fighting tooke originall beginning.
div.p: AFter the Persians were vanquished, the Atheniens made a Law that one ordinarye day euery yéere, there should be Cock fighting, in open place to be seen vpon the Theater or skaffolde. But from whence the occasion of this Statute or Iniunction procéeded, I wil now make plain and manifest.

At what time Themistocles was Capitain to an Army of Citizēs, and against the barbarous and forrain people, he saw two Cocks fighting fiercely togither, picking with their billes one at an others Comb, and smiteing with their spurres so stoutly that they drew blood. Of which game or sight he did not shew him self an idle gaser, but gathering his whole armye round about him, made this short Oration vnto them.

These two Cocks indaunger them selues, as we sée to the death, not for their countryes cause, not for the housholde god{is}, not for the Priuiledges of their honorable ancestors, not for renown, not for libertie, not for wife & children: But that th'one might not ouercrowe & beat th'other, or that th'one should giue ground and game to the other, as the wurse to the better, the weaker to the stronger. Which woords béeing beutified with
the flowers of polisie, ministred meruailous incouragment to the harts of the Atheniens, which stoutnes and audacitie, he wished and also willed so to be put in practise, that thereby they might purchase perpetuall remembrance.

div.head: ❧ Hovv Pittacus painted and figured Lady Fortune.
div.p: PIttacus made a Ladder in a Temple at Mitylene, seruing to none other vse in the world then to be a gift dedicatory to Lady Fortune, figuring also that suche clymed vp the steppes therof without impediment or hinderaunce, whome Fortune fauoured. And such came tottering down whome she resisted, in whiche representation there was signified a certain suddain motion.

div.head: ❧ Of the Philosopher Plato.
div.p: PLato the Sonne of Aristo, at the first, affected and marryed his minde to Poetrye, and was delighted in making verses Heroicall. But afterwards he made a voluntary seperation from that kinde of exercise, vtterly renouncing the study of versifying, when he had examined them with the stile of Homer, and perceiued his owne to be far wurse. Wherefore he turned his wit another way, and applied his labour to write Tragedyes, which he deliuered into the hands of Players to be published, and perswaded him self that his inuention and conueyance therin was excellent, wherupon he woulde néeds make a challenge to beare away the prick and price.

But after that he heard Socrates (not long time before the solemnizatiō of ye banquetīgs ordained in the honor of Bacchus) and beeing inchaunted with the swéet and mellodious vtteraunce of his deuises, he did not only cease and withdraw him self from that rash contentiō, but did vtterly giue ouer and forsake the composing of Tragedyes, and made Philosophy his
ordinary diet, which he preferred before all other studyes.

div.head: ❧ That none of the paynims and heathen people, were giuen to vngodlines.
div.p: WHat manne, would not highly commend the wisdome of the Barbarians? sithence none of them, at any time fel in to contempt of ye God{is} immortall, nether yet called this in question, whether there were Gods, yea or nay, that gouerned the worlde with their diuinitie, and celestiall authoritie, and to whome the condition of men, was a thing worthy of care and regard. No Indian, no Celtan, no Aegiptian, harbored so hellish an opiniō in their hart{is} As Euemerus Messenius intertained in to the mansion of his infected minde, as Dionisius Phrigius fostred in the closet of his brest, as Hippen, as Diagoras, as Sosias, and as Epicurus nursed in the cradles of theire misbeléeuing braines. But the heathenish & paynime people (whom I haue named) manifestly affirm, bothe, that there be gods which inhabit the glorious heauens, and also that they haue a respect vnto vs mortall men, communicating vnto vs, the knowledge of things to come, by Birdes, by bowels and entrails of beastes, by signes of assured certainty, by sundry obseruations, and manifolde circumstances. Of what things therfore, men, by the fauour and permission of the supernall powers, (namely the Gods) may haue a forevnderstanding, a great and principall parts of the same, by doutful dreames, misticall imaginations, and glittering starres in the skies. &c. are signified.

Which opinion they maintayning, with a constant and immoouable beléef, doo the Gods singuler seruice with simplicitie and sincerity, lead their life in purity and holines, imbrace the right vse of cerimonies, obserue the rites and institutions of Bacchus, & performe other duties so deuoutly, that these testimonies, giue a reporte of an vndoubted trueth, that they exhibit to the Gods great woorship and reuerence.

div.head: ❧ Of Hercules his surname, and of Apollos Oracle concerning him.
div.p: CErtain rumors are scattered abrode in Delphus, that Hercules was the Sonne of Iupiter and Alcmens, and that his name by dissēt of consanguinitie, was Heraclides. Vppon a time he came to demaund questions of the Oracle, and to require councell in a matter, which he obtained in such sort, that his comming was effectuall. Moreouer (among all other things) this is reported, yt Hercules standing alone by him self, heard these woords pronounced by the mouth of Apollo.

l.hi: Heraclem te alio Phoebus cognomine dicit,

lg.l: Phoebus calles the Heracles, thy name so termeth he:
By dooing good & gracious déeds, thy praise shal endles be.

div.head: ❧ Of the Images and figures of Fluds.
div.p: WE sée and beholde before our eyes the nature of fluds, their chanels, their reaches, their rowling, their ebbing and their flowing, we are not curious to assigne them any resemblance, yet notwithstanding, some there be, whiche hauing descrybed Fluds, haue pretermitted some without forme, and appointed other some a certain similitude. They haue compared some in fashion and figure to bullocks, of this number were the people Stimphalij, who likened the two fluds Erasmus and Metopa, to the forme aforesaid.

The people of Lacedemon, who compared the flud Eurotas to the same figure, the people Sicyonij, and the people Phliasij, who likened the flud Asopus to the same forme, the people Argiui who compared the flud Cephissus to the same figure. Other some likened fluds to the fashion of a man, of this number were the people Psophilij, who cōpared the flud Eryncanthius to the same forme. The people Heraenses, who likened
the flud Alpheus to the same figure. The people Cherronesij were of ye same imaginatiō, as touching the flud Alpheus aforsaid. The people of Athens worship the flud Cephissus, which they liken to a man wt a pair of hornes. Furthermore the people Siracusij in Scilia, compare the flud Anapus in porturature to a man, but the spring or brooke Cyana, they liken to a woman and haue it in honor. The people Aegestenses, reuerence and adore the fluds Porpax, Crimissus, and Telmissus, in the similitudes of men. The people of Agrigentine, offer sacrifices and oblations to a flud of semblable name to the Citie which they inhabited, imagining that it hath the likenes of a bewtiful Springall. And they also at Delphos, who consecrated the Iuory image, and intituled the fluds name, made the Image, the Image of a Lad.

div.head: ❧ Of olde, crooked, and decrepite age.
div.p: EPicharmus béeing very olde, and laden with the burthen of yéeres, sitting among his acquaintance, and interchaunging communication with them, after euery one seuerally had spoken as he thought good. One after this sort, fiue yéers space to liue for me is sufficient. Annother after this manner, foure yéeres are euen as much as I would wish and desire. The third in this wise, thrée yéeres is a number to my ful contentation: Epicharmus made the conclusion, saying. O good fréends, why contend you among your selues about a few dayes? for asmuch as we that are héere assembled and sit togither at this present, are by the ordinaunce and ratified decrée of desteny, néere neighbours to death and mortalitie, wherfore it is high time for vs all, to make spéedy passage from hence, before we taste the inconueniences of olde decrepite age, any further.

div.head: That sleepe is the brother of Death, and of Gorgias dravving to his end.
div.p: GOrgias Leontinus, looking towardes the end of his life, and béeing wasted with the weakenes and werysomnesse of drouping olde age, falling into sharp and sore sicknesse, vppon a time slumbred and slept vpon his soft pillowe a little season: Vnto whose Chamber, a familiar fréend of his resorting to visit him in his sicknes, demaunded how he felt him self affected in body. To whome Gorgias Leontinus made this pithy and plausible answere. Iam me somnus incipit suo fratri, Morti, tradere. Now sléep beginneth to deliuer me vp into the Iurisdiction of his brother Germane, death.

div.head: ❧ Of Socrates beeing bothe olde and sick.
div.p: SOcrates béeing worne with olde Age, and crooked through the féeblenes of his bodily members, certain asking him how he fared? Very wel, saith he, how so euer the world shall wag. For if I haue my life prolonged, I shall increase mine enemyes to bait me with rebukes: Again, if death shorten my dayes, I shall winne more fréends to Crown me with commendation.

div.head: ❧ Of the lavv inioyned to sick Patients, for the abstinence from drinking of VVine.
div.p: MAny lawes were made by Zaleucus Locrensis, of which some were politiquely ordained, othersome conueniently enacted, and among all other, this one moste prudently prouided, as a law of no lesse necessitie, then estimation.

If any of the Locrenses Epizepyrij béeing assaulted with sicknes, presumed to drink wine (the Phisitian prohibiting such kinde of receipts, or at the least not prescribing them) albeit he or she (after the Potion taken) recouered their accustomed helth, and escaped the danger of death, yet
notwithstanding, the appointed punishment for the offender in this case, was violent losse of life without parcialitie, because they durst drink wine béeing forbidden, or at least wise not warranted by the Phisitian.

div.head: ❧ The lavv of the Romains and other people not permitting the drincking of VVine to all maner of persons, nor to all ages.
div.p: THis likewise was a law made by the people Massaliotae. That women should abstain frō wine, of what age soeuer they were. What was their drink then I pray you? Forsooth fair water bubling out of the Spring. Theophrastus affirmeth that this law was effectuall among the people Milesij, and that the people Iadae kept them selues within the limits & reach of the same law: What impediment restraineth me frō rehersing the Romanish law in this hehalf prouided? And how can I auoid ye reprehension of foolishnes, if I hauing alredy made mentiō of ye Locrenses, the Massaliotae & the Milesij, should pretermit with silēce the actes and statutes of mine owne countrymen the Romaines? who obserued ye vertue of this law very precisely, that it was not tollerable, either for frée women or bond women to drink wine, nor sufferable by statute, that any noble personage either male or female, from th'age of xij. & xiiij. yeeres, to xxxv. yéeres, should violate the law aboue rehersed.

div.head: The lavv of the Locrēses prouiding vvhat their Children shold learne.
div.p:
THe Cretenses commaūded by publique authoritie, that the sonnes of freemen should learne the lawes and ordinaunces of the land, seasoned with the sweet sound and pleasant assent of Musick, to th'intent that they cōceiuing aabundant delight in that method of learning,
might plant the same with more facilitie in the furrowes of their remembrance, and also that they, if at any time they chaunced to transgresse the lawes, might not pleade ignorāce and by that cloke couer their skins from the rain. The second thing which they were bound to learne, were songs and Sonets made in the honor of the supernall Gods. The third and last thing was, the praises and triumphant commendations of noble and valiant men.

div.head: Of brute beasts vvhich abhorre VVine, and yet chaunce to be ouercome with drunckennes.
div.p: ALl brute beasts abhorre Wine naturally, and principally those beasts, which after they haue immoderately filled them selues with grapes, fall into extreme drunckennes. Furthermore Crowes, if they eat the crops of the herb Sinuta, are driuen perforce into contagious madnes.

The Dog also is subiect to the operation of the same, if he bite therof and taste it. But the Ape and the Elephant, the one surmounting in strength, the other excéeding in nimblenes, are bothe inféebled, if they drink Wine, For this is depriued of his craftynes, and that is robbed of his valliantnes, for the time, and bothe indéed so weakned, that they are easely to be caught without resistance,

div.head: Great Svvillers and drinkers.
div.p:
IN the catalogue of Chronicles, among great drinkers, and insatiable swillers, these, and many more were reconed. Dionisius of Sicilia, the Tirant, Niseus the Tirant, Apollocrates the sonne of Dionisius the Tirāt, Hipparion, Cossin to Dionisius, Timolaus Thebanus, Charidemus Orites, Arcado Erasixenus. Aloetas Macedo, and Diotimus Atheniensis, whiche Diotimus was surnamed Funnel or Tunnel, because he gulped down Wine through the Channel of his throte, whiche was poured into a
Funnel, the end wherof was put into his mouth, without interspiration or drawing winde betwéene gulpes. It is reported that Cleomenes Lacedaemonius, did not only drink very much, but was also inclined to that euil custome of the Scythians, namely, to vnmeasurable swilling. Furthermore Ion Chius a Poet (as men say) in drinking of wine kept no reason. Besides him Alexander of Macedonia, when he (in the honoure of Calanus Brachmanus the Indian sophister, who burned his owne body to poulder) appointed games of Musick, games of wrestling, and such like spectacles, béeing desirous and willing to shew the Indians a pleasure, adioyning to the former Pageants, a vsuall practise of his owne Countrie, instituted a common game of swilling Wine, and trouling the Cuppe and the Canne from hand to mouth, wherein he that did excell receiued for his rewarde, a whole Talent. The second to the best, receiued for his Guerdon thirtye poundes. And the third receiued the summe of tenne pounds for a recompence of his laboure. In this exercise one Promachus went away with the Spurres, for he was péerles, In Poto, potaui, & potatus sum, in troule the Boule to me.

In the feasts of God Bacchus, there was a pension appointed for him that could drinck more then the rest, and that was a Crown of Golde, whiche Xenocrates Chalcedemonius deserued, who after the receipt thereof at his return from banquetting, set the same vppon Mercuries hed, who stood at the entraunce or Gate according to the auncient custome.

For it was the vsuall fashion of this man to set light by garlands of flowers, of Myrre, of Iuy, and of Laurell. Moreouer (it is a common saying) that Anacharfis was an immoderate drinker and a Wine swiller, whiche prouision and maintenaunce he caried from house to house. For it is the custome of the Scythians to gul out of square. Lacidas also and Timon, were insatiable drinckers béeing bothe Philosophers.

Furthermore Mycernius the Aegiptian, when a Prophecie was brought vnto him out of Buta, giuing him premonishments and forewarnings of the shortnes of his life, he, béeing disposed captiously to cauill, and Sophistically to deale
with the same, by doubling his time and putting the nights to the dayes, wedded him selfe to continuall watching, bequeathed him self to bibbing, & became a notable swil Boule.

Among this rowe and rablement recken Anacharsis the Aegiptian, of whome Herodotus giueth sufficient testimony. And Nicocles the Corinthian, who could not be broken from this excessiue bibbing. Scopas in like manner the Sonne of Creon, and Antiochus the King, whiche were extreme gréedy of wine, and besides that, insatiable swillers, by the meanes of which enormitie he was so vnabled, as touching the gouernment of his Kingdome, that Aristeus and Themistion, Cyprians, were faine to be his Vicegerents in that behalfe, he him selfe bearing a bare and naked Cognisaunce of Principalitie.

Moreouer Epiphanes called Antiochus, who was giuen for a pledge to the Romaines, lusted after Wine and delighted therein without moderation. Another Antiochus also, of the same name, who at suche time as he made battail against Arsaces, with the Medes, bestowed his seruice in swilling and gulling. Antiochus the great may not be exempted out of the Catalogue of these, nor Agron the King of Illyrium, who fel into a sicknes of the sides, called the painful Pleurisy, and with vnmeasurable bibbing of wine hastened his owne death.

There was besides him whome we haue rehearsed, another King of Illyrium a notable eater and a famous drincker. What should we burthen you with the enumeration of Orhopheres the King of Capodacia? whose vse was to swil excessiuely. And if it be your pleasures, that I should wade further in this matter and touch the Female kinde (notwithstanding it is a Beastly and an vndecent thing, that a woman should be disposed to immoderate drinking, and haue the reports of such Bibbers whose bellyes are bottomlesse) to satisfie your desires in that case, I wil be applyant.

Cleio, was so experimented héerin, that she durst chalenge bothe women and men, what soeuer, to trye Maisteryes in drinking moste, in which practise she passed, and left them all many Miles behinde her. But this Victory and triumphe
which she obtained, was not so honest and commendable, as it was filthy, lothsome, and detestable.

div.head: ❧ Of PLATOES renovvne, and of his equabilitie.
div.p: THe renown of Plato, and the honourable reporte of his vertue pearced into forrain Regions, and came to the Arcadians and the Thaebans, who sending certain selected men in Embassage vnto him, earnestly requested yt he would take the paines to instruct the young men of their Countrey, in knoweledge, and reade Philosophy vnto them, besides that (which was a greater matter) to prescribe and appoint vnto them lawes and ordinaunces. Which request they were in likelihood and possibilitie to obtains (for Plato Aristonides conceiued plentiful delectation in the message. And when he had demaunded this question of the Embassadours, how they were inclined to equall diuision of riches and honour, and perceiued euidently that they were at defyaunce and hostilitie therewith, and would by no meanes be therunto perswaded, he condescended to trauail vnto them.

div.head: ❧ VVhat Graecians vvere moste excellent, and yet neuerthelesse very poore and needy.
div.p: THe verye best among the Graecians led their liues in pouertie and néede. Aristides the Sonne of Nicomachus Phocion the sonne of Phocus. Epaminondas the sonne of Polymatides. Pelopidas Thebanus, Lamachus Atheniensis. Socrates the Sonne of Sophroniscus, and Ephialtes the Sonne of Sophonidas.

div.head: ❧ The declaration of a Picture vvhiche Theon painted.
div.p: INfinit Testimonyes there be of Theons cunning, among which this Picture is principall. A man in armoure, running poste haste out of the gates of a Citie, the enemies assaulting the same and seeking the ruine and ouerthrowe of the land. The harnessed Souldiour ran with a courage to battail, yea, so liuely was the Image made, that the beholder (if he had séen it) would haue giuen iudgement, that the fellowe was mad, frantique, lunatique, and possessed with the furious force of murthering Mars. His visage was sauage, stearne, stubborne, and Lyonlike, he wringeth his weapons as one greedy of the conflict, he rusheth vppon his enemyes with violence, he holdeth out his victorious Target, shaketh his naked Swoord, whiche glittered like Glasse against the Sun beames, the terror of his coūtenaūce threatned a slaughter to his aduersaryes: Finally in all his gestures and behauiour, were resemblances of bloodshed without compassion.

Theon painted no warlike assistance aboute him, no showe of Martiall magnanimitie, no Standard bearer, no band of Souldiours, no Capitain ouer hundreds, no Dimolaunce, no Gunners, no Archers, to be short, no suche warlike furniture. But this one harnessed man painted he alone, whose Image was sufficiently set foorth, aswel to giue witnes of the liuelynes which was apparant therein, as also to leaue credit, that the cunning of Theon was miraculous.

The woorkman of this Picture, did not hang it out in sight of the assembly, before the Trumpeter (whome he hyred) standing hard by, sounded vp a thumping Alarum, as a signification of battail and spedy preparation to the feeld. So soone therefore as the Trumpet did sound, Theon bringeth foorth his Table containing the Picture aboue specified, which he placed in the open aspect of the multitude, whiche was viewed and looked vppon very circumspectly, all which space the Trumpeter continued sounding, whiche stirred vp more
effectuall cogitations in the mindes of the beholders, gasing more greedyly vppon the harnessed Souldiour, whiche Theon by Art and excellent cunning comprised in a Table.

div.trailer: ❧ The end of the second Booke.

div.head: The third Booke of the variable History of AELIANVS.
❧ By vvhat Characters, pictures and Images, the learned Aegiptians expressed the mysteries of their mindes.
div.p: WHen they would signifie wrathe & fury, they set down the image of a Lyon. Whē they wold signify talke, they set down the figure of a toung. When they wold signifye fleshly pleasure, they set down the number of XVI. Whē the would signify lerning, they set down the picture of Dew dropping from the Clowdes. By a Rat they meane destructiō By a flye, they meane shamelesnes. By the Ant running into the Corne, they meane prouision. By a man walking in water without a hed, they meane a thing vnpossible. By a swarme of Bées folowing the maister Bée, they signifie obedient Subiects. By a man hiding his priuy members with his hands, they meane Temperaunce. By the floures of Poppy, they signifie sicknes. By an armed man shooting in a Bowe of steele, they meane Rebellion. By an Eagle flying against the Sun, they meane windy weather. By an Owle standing vppon a Trée, they signifie death. By a Lace tyed in many knots, they meane mutuall Loue. By Bookes and Scrowles, they meane Auncientnes. By a Ladder set against a Castle wall, they meane a séedge about a Town or a Fortresse. By a Mule, they signifie a woman with a barrain wombe. By a Mole, they meane blindenesse. By a Lapwing sitting vppon a Cluster of Grapes, the meane a plentiful Vintage. By a Scepter and an eye on the top therof looking downwarde, they meane power and polisie. By a Spindle ful of thred broken of from the Distaf, they meane the shortnes of mans life. Apollo Niliacus describeth at large the Aegiptian Characters, & openeth the meaning of ye same.

div.head: ¶ The description of a pleasant plot of lande in Thessalia, which may worthily be called an earthly heauen.
div.p:
GO to then, and let vs launch further with good lucke, paynting out with penne, and relating with tong, the places of pleasure and inestimable delightes, which are blased abroad, to be in Thessalia. For manyfest it is, that wordes, if they beare the badge of eloquence, and be ensigned with the cognisance of substanciall and pithy reasons, canne no lesse expresse a thing, before the eies of the people: thē ye artificial fingers, and the sprinckling pencil of a cunning paynter, excelling in his profession, and singuler in his science. The places aboue specified, are, a percel of lande situate and lying betwéene two mightie mountaines, namely, Olympus, and Ossa, whiche huge hils are of an vnaccustomable heigth, and separated the one from the other, by the wonderfull working of the euerlasting God, whose habitation is in heauen. Betwéen which two mountaines, as it were in ye midst, a plot of ground is incompassed, the length whereof ariseth by estimation to fortie furlongs, euery furlong containing the measure of a hundred twentie and fiue paces, the breadth in some places (but not in all) containing two hundred fortie and two foote, and in other some places somewhat more. In this middle plot of grounde runneth a riuer, called Penaus, into whose receptacle, other channels haue recourse, making the same a great floude, by the abundant streams which issueth into the bosome of the same. The place before rehearsed, is adorned & decked with diuers goodly lodgings (as it were) & harbours of all sortes, wonderfull workes not wrought with the handes of men, but framed by the predestination and foreappointment of Lady Nature, which principall and preeminent priuiledges she bestowed therevpon, when the place was
(as it were) in his infancie, & had his original beginning. There groweth green Iuie most plentifully, there it flourisheth most beautifully, there it créepeth vpwarde to the tops of tal trées, winding it selfe round about the barkes, imbracing the branches, & springing about the body & the armes of them, in the similitude & likenes of most fruitful vines. There grow Yew trées abundantly, ouershadowing the gréen banks, wrapping themself round about the rocks, & couering the stone, in such sort, that ye rocke is altogither hidden, nothing perceiued but the fresh gréen colour, glorious to ye sight, & sumptuous spectacles to delight the eye. In the field it self, & the plain land, there be sundry gardens & arbours of great compasse, pleasant Sommer parlours, and comfortable clossets of rest & recreation for wayfaring mē, to be succoured in the hot season of yt yere, wherin they may conueniētly (as it were with restoritie) refresh their wery mēbers in their tedious & combersome iourny. Through this goodly groūd, many cleere brookes & holsome springs haue passage, whose water is cold, swéet, & sauory to drink for the quenching of thirst. Some say, that such as wash their lims, & bath their bodies in this water, reap an incomparable aduantage, for the maintenance of their healthfulnes, such singuler vertue is instilled from aboue, into the mylde & gentle streams of the saide springs. Furthermore, braue birdes of sundry sorts, syt scattering here & there, in diuers corners, singing most swéetly vpon the boughes, beautified wt blossoms & green leaues, & specially such birds, whose chirping tongs & whistling throats make such a musical sound, & such tuneable harmony, that ye delight proceding frō the same, & pearcing into the eares ingender such an indefatigable delight in the mind, that ye weary traueller forgetteth the tediousnes of his way, for so much as the lothsomnes of his labor is not only assuaged, but also abandoned. On both sides of the floud, are (as I haue already made rehearsal) places or rather pallaces of pleasure, garnished with notable delights, replenished
with renoumed recreation. Through the midst of this terrestrial Paradise, the floud Peneus doth runne, sliding forward with a smothe and a calme streame, as it were slipperie oyle, it is also ouershadowed with the boughes and branches of excellent trées, planted about the banks of the same, by the benefit wherof, the sun beames (which otherwise would cast a great heate) are kept from the superfice of the water the most part of the day, offering to such as saile that way, a temperate passage by reason of the ayre, which is moderately mixed with two contrary qualities. Besides the premisses, this in like manner is not to be omitted, that the people bordering and inhabiting thereabouts, make their accustomable conuents, their solemne sacrafices, their vsuall assemblies, and sumptuous bākets in those pleasant places. When therfore there be many to pay their oblations to the supernal gods, and to bestow their diligent labour, in the adoration and worshippe of them, & in the accomplishment of sacred exercises, it commeth to passe, that they preparing their passage, and continuing their progresse this way, eyther by lande or water, by horse or by shippe, by waggon or any kynde of vessel, seruing the necessitie of Nauigation, swéete smels, & odoriferous sauours are caried & conueyed by the spireable ayre to their nostrils, seasoning the instrument of the facultie of odoration, with the perfumes aboue specifyed.

Thus the perpetual seruice exhibited to the gods, maketh the place, shal I say prophane? No, but holy and heauenly. The people of Thessalia reporte, that in this Paradise of pleasantnes, Apollo Pytheus was purged at the cōmandement of Iupiter, when he slue the Serpent Python, with his bowe and arrowes, kéeping as yet Delphos, the countrey hauing the Oracle, Being afterwardes crowned with a garlande of Lawrell leaues, whiche sprang in those moste pleasant Medowes aboue mentioned, and holding in his ryght hande a Boy braunche, and so came to Delphos, Finally, that he whiche discended
of the loynes of Iupiter and Latona, occupied the Oracle. There is also in the foresayde place, an Altar, where he was crowned, and tooke away the branch. And therefore the people of Delphos, euery nynth yeare ordinarily, send the yong sonnes of their nobilitie, accompanied with the principal superintendant, in diuine rites and sacred ceremonies, to those famous places in Thessalia, (of which the whole summe of this present treatise dependeth) who at their comming thither, execute diuine seruice with no lesse pompe and magnificence, than with deuotion and reuerence, making garlandes of the Lawrell trée, which grew in that speciall place, whereof the louing God also (when time was) made him selfe a crowne, and so depart. In which returne of theirs, they followe the way, which is called Pythias, leading by Thessalia, into Pelagonia, into Oeta, into the region of the Aenians, the Melians, the Dorians, and the Locrans Hesperij. The conducters also of the boyes, exhibite great honour and reuerence to the Hyperboreans, which bring oblations and sacrifices to the same God. And herevpon springeth this custome, that Lawrell garlandes are giuen to such as winne the victorie in these games and exercises which were solemnized in the renoume of Apollo, called Pythiorum spectacula. But of the terrestriall Paradise in Thessalia, and of al the pleasures wherewith it is adorned, let this which I haue rehearsed, seeme sufficient.

div.head: ¶ Of Anaxagoras, valiantly suffering the death of his children.
div.p:
WHen a certain man brought these heauie tidings and sorowfull newes, to Anaxagoras Clazomenius at such time as he was busily occupyed, that two of his children were deade and departed: He, notwithstanding that losse, depriued him of the comfortable name of a father,
(for he had no more sonnes nor daughters in all the worlde besides them) was neuer a whit dismayde at the miserable message of the man, but made this answere, embaulmed with boldnesse, and spyced with wisedome, Sciui eos mortales esse natos, I knowe well inough, that by byrth, they were mortall.

div.head: ¶ Of Xenophon stoutly abyding the death of his sonne
div.p: AS Xenophon was intentiuely occupyed in diuine seruice, There came a messenger from Mantinea, and tolde him that his sonne Gryllus was dead: Xenophon put off his crowne or garlande, and perseuered in holy sacrifice notwithstanding. Moreouer, when the messenger added these words, saying, that the yong man dyed not villanously, but victoriously, he put on his garlande againe. These historycall abridgements flowe in the mouthes of all men, and are common among the multitude.

div.head: ¶ Of Dion, who was not disquieted for the death of his sonne.
div.p: DIon the sonne of Hipparianus, the scholer of Plato, being conuersant in publike affaires, at what time his sonne fell from the roofe of an high house to the grounde in a court, in so much that his body was not only brused pitifully, but his bones also broken lamentably, to the vtter shipwracke of his lyfe: Dion was not moued one whit in his mynd, neyther yet changed his countenance, but constantly continued to bring that to perfectiō which he had taken in hand, neglecting, in the meane season, the infortunate fal of hys sonne.

div.head: ¶ Antigonus seeing the dead carkasse of his sonnes body, was not molested in mynde at so sorowfull a spectacle.
div.p: ANtigonus the second, when certaine souldiers carried ye carkas of his deade sonne out of the armie, he behelde the body, but did not alter his visage, eyther with cloudie lowring, or with watry wéeping, in consideration of so crooked a chance, But praysed him that he dyed like a valyant ympe of mightie Mars, and commaunded that he shuld be decently buryed.

div.head: ¶ Of the magnificence and sumptuousnesse of Crates Thebanus.
div.p: THe disposition of Crates Thebanus, was noted in many pointes, to be sumptuous and singuler. For he despised all suche things as the popular sorte delighted in, and greatly estéemed. And specially he was a contemner of his countrey, and an aduersarie to riches, That he gaue all his wealth and substance from him selfe, to the possession and vse of the Thebans. What infant is ignorant? but his other déede is not so common, and therfore not so manifestly known. Will ye vnderstande what it is? Non opus est inquit, mihi ciuitate, quam Alexander, vel alius subuersurus sit. What néede haue I, sayth he, of a towne or a citie, for ambitious Alexander, of some other semblably inclyned to spoyle, to waste, and ouerthrowe?

div.head: ¶ Of the reprochfull accusations and slanders of the people.
div.p:
DEmochares the kinsman of Demosthenes, intending to signifie that he set nought by the backbyting tongs,
the slaunderous reports, and peruersse accusations of the people, when he espyed many of the sect of obtrectators, sitting together in a Barbers shop, & gréedie to tattle vnreuerently of him, what sayth he, do you babble & mutter among your selues, you Dismonidae. By this name discouering the corrupt conditions, and euidently detecting the naughtinesse of their nature.

div.head: ¶ Of Phrynicus, who was elected a captaine, for certaine poesies which he made.
div.p: THe Atheniens did elect, constitute, and make Phrynicus a captaine in warre. And why? not for his puisance, not for his manhoode, not for the noblenesse of his natiuitie and byrth, nor yet for any externall ornament, of wealth, of substance, and riches in lands, goodes and possessions, (Albeit the Atheniens, commonly turne their eyes and their myndes to those things, preferring such vsually, before other in election.) But when he in a certaine tragedie, made proper poesies, and verses altogether warlike, that they disagréed not from armed men, marching in battell aray, and dauncing their martial measures, in their clattering corselets and glittering furniture: He did so inchant the iudgements of the people, and strike suche an astonishment into the hearts of the Theatre or assembly, (without acception of any one) that they immediately did elect and chose him a captaine in martiall affaires, Supposing that he was not insufficient and vnable to gouerne an army of men, and to guide souldiers in battell politikely, that had inuention, skil, and conueyance enough, to make valiant verses in a Playe, and poesies polished with such thundering tearmes, clattering words, and triumphant sentences, that they differed very litle from the things represented, namely harnessed men skuffeling and skirmishing.

div.head: ¶ Of Loue.
div.p: WHat man that doth not loue, woulde proclaime battel, & enter a conflict with such a one as doth loue? sithence in so harde a case, armor & weapon shuld beare swinge and sway, without further arbitrement or deliberation. For he which wanteth loue, doth alwayes auoide and flée from his louer lyke a prophane fellowe, burthened with imperfections, and so farre he dareth presume, as the courage of his mynde, and the strength of his body doe warrant him to preuaile.

Moreouer he feareth the other, as one kindled with certaine sparkles of a heauenly and vehement concitation, and inflamed, not onely with the outrageous heate of Mars, whiche in déede is common, but also with the furious fire of Cupido. For such as be supported onely with the puisant power of one of these two gods onely, and not ayded by both, (of which twaine, the one raungeth with madnesse in mens mynds, as it were Mars him self,) whē their heartes be haunted with one of these spirites, they fight stoutly and lustily, so farre forth as that one spirite is able of it selfe to minister vnto them manhoode and courage. But when the seruitures of Cupido do fight, being pricked forward as well with the spur of martiall might, as féeling also the sting of effectuall loue, in that they sustaine the power of a double spirite, or rather are wrapt with two violent perturbations, purchase (as the Cretenses helde opinion) double honour by their puisance. No mā therefore will expostulate the matter about him, who killeth and slayeth, being furnished with the complet might of Mars and Cupido. If an armed man can not counteruaile his vertue, muche lesse suppresse the fulnesse of his force, fighting with the ayde and succoure of one God alone.

div.head: ¶ Of such as were amarous and Paramours among the Lacedemonians.
div.p: FOr so much as I haue many worthy sayinges, and notable déedes to rehearse, concerning the Lacedemonian magistrates, called Ephori, among a multitude I will picke out them onely, which I haue priuately purposed to repeate. When one with the baite if his beauty allured vnto him the loue of a rich and welthy commoner, he himself being poore, néedie, and distressed, the Lacedemonians seassed a fine vpon his head, punishinge (as it appeareth) his vnlawful lust and concupiscence, with a penaltie of money. They punished in like manner, another welfauoured and an honest man, because he loued none that were of a contrarie inclination to him selfe, in that he being good and vertuous, reputed none worthy of his loue, For by the communicating of his loue, he might peraduenture, make his paramour like vnto him selfe.

Sythence the familiaritie and conuersation of louers, preuayleth effectually in the hearts of their paramours, to the honourable intertainment of vertue, and the noble furtherance of honestie: If they them selues be vertuously disposed, and garnyshed with the garmentes of modestie. Furthermore, the Lacedemonians enacted and made this lawe, that if any yong man supplying the place of a paramour, offended in his behauiour and did amisse, somewhat they were content to ascribe to the simplicity of his manners, and to graunt a tolleration in respect of his tender yeares: But they made his louer to smart: willing that there should be ouerséers and arbiters in all things which they did.

div.head: ¶ Of the soule of man.
div.p: THe Philosophers called Peripatici, maintained this opinion, that the soule of man in the day time was wrapped in the body (as it were in a blanket) or clasped vp, as it were in a prison, doing dutifull seruice to the body, and euery perticuler member of the same, and that it was not of abilitie to aspire vnto the perfection of trueth: Moreouer, that in the night season the soule obtained fréedome, and was deliuered out of the bondage of the body, resting in a certaine place beside the stomacke, and to be made more méete for the prouision and capacitie of thinges to come, wherevpon dreames, phantasies, and visions take their generation.

div.head: ¶ Of the order of loue among the Lacedemonians.
div.p: AMong the Lacedemonians, such as were of a beautifull fauour and comely complexion, did not behaue themselues, wantonly, insolently, nor arrogantly towardes their louers: for these do cleane contrary to all other yong men, in that they beséeche and require their louers to loue them, and this is a prouerb among the Spartans, that loue ought of duty to be had, saying that loue and a Lacedemonian knowe nothing that is filthie, vnchast, beastly, lothsome, and vndeceent. For whether a yong man durst consent to suffer the blemish of bodily abuse, or the louer so hardy and presumptuous to offer or inforce it, certain it is that no aduantage might redound to a Spartane, sithen such a fault was punishable, either with the losse of liberty in his countrey, & vtter exile, or els (which was more grieuous) with depriuation of lyfe.

div.head: ¶ Of the superfluous wasting of wine which the people Tapyri vse.
div.p: THe people Tapiri are so wedded to wine, that they lead their liues altogether therein, and spend much of their time in that licentious vsage, Neither do they abuse the benefite of wine in drinking onely immoderately, but in anointing their bodyes therewith, as other people doe with oyle.

div.head: ¶ Of the wine bibbing of the people Bizantij.
div.p:
THe people Byzantij are so prone & addicted to drinking of wine, that they forsake their owne mansions and tenemēts, which they ought to inhabite, setting and letting them for rent to strangers, and they them selues in the meane season haunt vittailing houses and Tauerns: Neither do they set ouer their dwellings to sale, but also (which is a most execrable abuse) deliuer their wiues to aliens and forriners to hyre as hacknys. By the meanes of which dissolutenes, they intangle them selues in a reprochful laberinth of two detestable offences, namely, drunkennes, and baudrie. Furthermore because they haue planted the perfection of al their pleasure in tippling and quaffing of wine, they intermingle this delight with musical disportes, as with the sound ofth flute, the viole, the harpe, the lute and such like tuneable instrumentes. But the shrill sound of the trumpet they cannot abide to heare in any case, which is an euident argument & a plaine demonstration, that this péeuish people haue holow harts, and can away neither with warre nor warlike weapons. For this cause the captaine generall of their army, that is to say, lusty Leonidas in a very fearce and sharp assault
against the citie, when the enemies aduentured vpon the walles, and they neglecting watche and warde, consumed whole dayes, from the rising of the sonne, to the falling of the same, in their vsuall and accustomed hospitalles: Leonidas commaunded that the victualling houses which they frequented, should be remoued to the citie walles, by which subtile slight and politike deuise, he perswaded them not to forsake the army, each coulourable pretence, and reasonable occasion why they should so do, being vtterly dashed and remoued. These things concerning them doth Doemon manifestly affirme, to whom Menander alludeth, saying: Vinolentos negotiatores facit Byzantium, totam noctem perpotat. Bizantium maketh winebibbing and dronken merchantes, and consumeth whole nightes in swilling and gulling.

div.head: ¶ Of the winebibbing of the Argiues, the Corinthians, the Thracians, and the Illirians.
div.p: THe Argiues and the Corinthes haue binne openly rebuked in publike plaies and enterludes for their vnmeasurable swilling of wine. As for the Thratians the rumor which swimmeth abroade of them, is ratified with a warrant, and confirmed with this assurance, that they are notorious cannesuckers. Neither are the Illirians cleare of this beastly abuse, who haue annexed and added to that their detestable property, this shameles and reprochefull vsage, that it is tollerable (by their permission) that strangers in banqueting, and belly chéere, should quaffe about to women if they list, albeit they had nothing to do, or to deale with them.

div.head: ¶ A comparison of the two captaines Demetrius, and Timotheus.
div.p:
WHich of these two captains Demetrius or Timotheus was ye most puissant & excellēt, Demetrius, I say,
Poliorcetes, or Timotheus Atheniensis, it is a question to be demaunded. I wyll rehearse vnto you the déeds and actes of them both, which being accomplished, finall iudgment shalbe resigned vnto you, to determine of certenty, which of the twayne deserueth preferment. Demetrius by violent and couetous meanes molested manye, dealyng iniuriously with them and contrary to equitie, he conquered cities by force, beséeged them with warlike engines, vndermining the walles, battering them and vtterly racing them vp. But Timotheus on the otherside perswadyng with wordes, and teachyng with talke, that it was more profitable and commodious to be obedient to the voyce of the Atheniens, brought the selfe same thinges to passe by words, which the other dyd with weapons.

div.head: ¶ That Philosophy is necessary for the gouernment of a weale publique, and that certaine Philosophers haue had the administration of a common wealth.
div.p:
AMong Philosophers (of whō there was a swarme innumerable) some sate in place of aucthoritie, & had the gouernment of commō wealthes committed vnto thē. Othersome were satisfied wt this, namely, that their mindes were garnished and beautyfied with the precious pearles of vertue, and that al the course of their life was peaceable, quiet, and replenished with tranquillitie. For Zeleucus refourmed the common wealth of the Locrenses, Charondas of the Catanenses, & of the Reginenses in lyke maner, when he was cast into exile and banyshed out of Catana. Al these did amend the estate of such people as we haue already mencioned. Architas was a furtherance to the Tarentines, Solon semblably to the Atheniens,
Bias and Thales conueied great commodyties into Ionia, Chilon helped the Lacedemonians, so did Pittacus the Mitylens, so dyd Cleobulus the people of the Rhods, Anaximander brought people from Miletum to inhabit Apolonia, Xenophon flourished in warlyke renowne, and is iudged a puisaunt captaine amonge them which accompanied Cyrus, at such time as he himself and many more with hym were slayne: For when necessitie required that some one or other should be a preseruation to the Grecians, to cōduct them home in safety, this charge was committed vnto hym, Plato the sonne of Aristo brought Dion into Sicilia, and gaue him aduertismentes how he might ouerthrow the tyrannical dominion of Dionysius, and bring him to vtter and extreame ruin without any great toyle or molestation. But Socrates tooke vpon him no charge of the Athenien weale publique, because he perceiued the popular power to be more lyke tyrannicall regiment: therefore did not he geue his consenting voyce that the tenne Captaines should be adiudged to dye, neither had he any conferrence with ye thyrty tyrants in their heynous and horryble enterpryses. Neuerthelesse when necessitie constrained, that weapons should be taken in hand for the defence and protection of the land, he supplyed the place of a souldiour, and played his part without anie contradiction, hee wore armour against Delus, Amphipolis, and Potidea. Aristotle did lyft vp his countrye (not falling vpon her knées, as they say, but rather lying along with her face flat vpon the ground) wherein was a significatiō of valiātnes. Demetrius Phalarenis gouerned the common wealth of the Atheniens with great worship, vntyll such time as the accustomed duty and vsual spightfulnesse of the people dispossessed hym & thrust him into exile, yet notwithstanding the selfe same man was of a noble countenaunce and credite in Aegipt, occuping the chiefest and most principall place vnder King Ptolomeus in makyng
and enacting Lawes. Moreouer what man wyll stand in denyall that Pericles the sonne of Xantippus, was expert in the precepts of Phylosophy? And yt Epaminondas the sonne of Polimnius, Phocion the sonne of Phocus, Aristides the sonne of Lisimachus, and Ephealtes the sonne of Sophonidas, and after them in proces of time Carneades, & Eritolaus to haue ben excellent in the profession of sapience? because they were sent in embassage to Rome in the behalfe of the Atheniens, & obtayned peace, whose sage speach seasoned with sobernesse, and moistened with the orientall dew of wisedome, was so effectual, that it constrayned the assemblye of Senators, to vtter these words following: Miserunt Athenienses legatos, qui nos non persuaderent modo, sed etiam cogerent facere quod ipsis collibitum est. The Atheniens haue sent Embassadours vnto vs, which doe not onely winne vs with the grauitie of their talk, but also compell vs, after a sorte, to condiscende vnto whatsoeuer they them selfe lyst. I haue also to rehearse vnto you, that, of Perseus in the admynistration of a commō wealth, which was an instruction & a president to Antiochus. And I haue to repeat vnto you, yt, of Aristotle, who planted ye precepts of Phylosophy in Alexanders remembraunce, at such time as he was youthfull, and in subiection to perturbations, and commotions of the mind. Finally I haue to let you vnderstand further, that Lysias the Disciple of Pithagoras, was the teacher and the tutor of Epaminondas. Yf any man therefore obiect, that Phylosophers were idle drones and frutlesse fellowes, he doth not onely babble like a beastly foole, but also dealeth lyke a dissardly doult. For (to tell you the plaine truth) I my selfe wolde be content to imbrace their idlenesse of lyfe with all my harte, and repine neuer a whit at the pleasure of their solytarinesse.

div.head: ¶ Of the familiaritie of Midas the Phrigian, and Selenus, and of certaine circumstaunces which he incredibly reported.
div.p:
THeopompus declareth that Midas the Phrigian, and Silenus were knit in familiaritie and acquaintance. This Selenus was the sonne of a Nimphe inferiour to the Gods in condition and degrée, but superiour to men concerning mortalytie and death. These twaine mingled communication of sundrye thinges, at length in processe of talke, Selenus tolde Midas of certaine Ilandes, named Europa, Asia, and Libia, which the Ocean Sea circumscribeth and compasseth round about. And that without this worlde there is a continent or percell of dry lande, which in greatnesss (as hee reported) was infinite and vnmeasurable, that it nourished and maintained, by the benefite of the gréene medowes and pasture plots, sundrye bigge and mighty beastes, that the men which inhabite the same climats, excéede the stature of vs twise, and yet the length of there life is not equall to ours. That there be many and diuers great citties, manyfold orders, and trades of liuinge, that their Lawes, Statutes, and ordinaunces are different, or rather, cleane contrary to ours, such and lyke thinges dyd he rehearce. He added moreouer to this, that among all other Cities there were two Metrapolitan and capitall, discrepant in all respects one from the other, of which, one is called Machimus, that is to say Pugnax, the other is named Euseues, that is by interpretation, Pia, that the inhabitants of the hindermost Citie passe the pilgrimage of their life in peace, and plenty of all riches, that their soile yéeldeth aboundaunce of all kinde of graine and fruite,
without trauail in tillage, without paines at the ploughe, without the vse of oxen or yoke, and that they stand not in neede of harrowing, sowing, wéeding, reaping, threshing, or such semblable necessaries in husbandrie. Furthermore that they are (as he reported infected with no sickenesses, molested with no disseases, nor vexed with any sorow, but that theyr whole life is a perpetual pleasure, a continuall delight, interlaced with laughters and disportes. Besides this that they are fauourers and supporterers of iustice, followers of equitie, and mainteiners of vpright dealing, & that the immortall gods, oftentimes kéepe them compapanie, vouchsafeing to abase and conforme them selfe to their fellowship. Moreouer, he added this, that the inhabitāts of the citie Machimus, are altogether warlike, couered with complet harnesse, and busied in battell, subduing to their dominions such cuntries and people as bordered about them, and that this one citie alone, hath singuler iurisdiction ouer infinit nations, and regions innumerable. The Citizens of the same are not vnder two hundred thousand in nomber, some of them die with diseases, but that fortuneth very seldome, because they are beaten downe in warre, with stones, and with clubbes, for no sworde can wound the flesh, maime any member, or lame any limme of their bodies. Golde and siluer is to them plentifull in possession, in so much that these metalles are of no more estimation with them then yron is in reputation and value among vs. Furthermore, he said, that they attempted vpon a time to inuade our Islandes, that ten thousandes of them had passed ouer the Ocean sea, and came as farre as the people Hiperborti, and hearing the report of the inhabitants of our land, that they were most religious, holy and deuout, they had them in contempte, detesting & abhorring them as naughty people, of preposterous properties, & damnable behauiour, and for that cause interrupted their progresse, supposing it an enterprise of litle worthinesse or rather none at al, to trauaile into such
a countrey. Furthermore he tolde one thing among all others, meriting admiration, that certain men called Meropes dwelt in many cittyes ther about, and that in the borders adiacent to their countrey, was a perilous place named Anostus, that is to say, wythout returne, being a gaping gulfe, or bottomles pit, for the ground is as it were cleft and rent in sonder, in so much that it openeth like to the mouth of insatiable hell, ye it is neither perfectly lightsome, nor absolutely darksome, but that the ayer hangeth ouer it, being tempered with a certaine kinde of clowdy rednes, that a couple of floodes fet their recourse that way, the one of pleasure the other of sorow, and that about each of them growe plantes answeareble in quantity and bignes to a great plaine trée. The trees which spring by ye flood of sorow yeldeth fruite of one nature, qualitie, and operation. For if any man taste thereof, a streame of teares floweth from his eyes, as out of a conduite pipe, or sluse in a running riuer, yea, such effect followeth immediatly after the eating of the same, that the whole race of their life is turned into a tragical lamentation, in so much that wéeping and wayling knitteth their carkeses depriued of vitall mouing, in a winding shéete, and maketh them gobbettes for the gréedy graue to swallow and deuoure. The other trées which prosper vpon the bankes of the floode of pleasure, beare fruite cleane contrary to the former, for whosoeuer tasteth thereof, he is presently weined from the pappes of his auncient appetites and inueterate desires, & if he were linked in loue to any in time past, he is fettered in the forgetfulnes of them, so that al remembrance is quite abolished, by litle and litle he recouereth the yeres of his youth, reasuming vnto him by degrées, the times & seasons, long since, spent and gone. For, the frowardnes and crookednes of old age being first shaken of, the amiablenes and louelynesse of youth beginneth to budde, in so much as they put on ye estate of stripplings, then become boyes, then change to children, then reenter into infancie, & at length
death maketh a finall end of all. If any man doth suppose this report of Chius worthy credit, let him fix the anchor of his beléefe in the slippery sande of his imaginations talke: as for mine owne part, (to tell you the plaine truth) I take him to be a coyner of lyes, and a forger of fond fables.

div.head: ¶ Of the Emulation and variance which was betweene Plato and Aristotle two famous Philosophers.
div.p:
THe first contention betwéene Aristotle, & Plato, tooke original beginning herevpon. Plato disallowed Aristotles disordred life, the apparel which he did weare he could by no meanes approue, and his behauiour, as he thought, deserued much blame. For Aristotle (somewhat to touche his attire) trimmed himselfe with gorgeous garments, yea, the very shooes of his féete were costly and sumpteous, he vsed to shaue his head, contrary to the custome of Plato, and vpon his fingers he did weare gimmalles, and golden rings beautified with precious stones, for ostention sake, and vaine superfluous brauery. Furthermore, his countenance was altogether giuen to quarreling, to scoffing, and to caueling: beside this, his vntimely tattling, wherein he passed the Parrat, the popingey, or the pie, discouered his cankard conditions & corrupt inclination. That these things become not a Philosopher it is as euident as the bright beames of the sonne at midde day, as also howe offensiue they were to such as framed their liues after their professiō it is marueilous manifest. For prudent Plato perceiuing and pondring Aristotles demeanure, could not digest or brooke him in his brest, but set before him Xenocrates, Speusippus, Amiclas & others, whom he had onely in estimation and reuerence, but also admitted them to be partakers of his desputations. Vpon a time Xenocrates tooke a iournei into his own countrey, in whose absence, Aristotle with a company of his Disciples or schollers, (among whom was Mnason
Phocensis, and diuers other) impugned and withstood Plato of purpose. At the same instant was Speusippus sicke, & therfore could not conueniently be present with Plato, thē also was ye ancient Philosopher 80. yeres of age in so much that through méere extremitie of age the abilitie of memory decayed in him, which did the more animate Aristotle in his madnes, and ministred audacity vnto him to assault olde Plato with Sophisticall conclusions, quarreling questions, and subtile argumentes which he tempered with taunting tearmes, and carping language: by which circumstances he shewed plaine signes and tokens, not onely of iniury but also of ingratitude (& the self same, not indifferent, but excessiue) cōmitted against so profound a Philosopher. Plato therefore auoided, and instituted his way directly to his owne house, hauing the company of his familiar friendes. After thrée monethes were expired and ended Xenocrates returned and found Aristotle walking vp and downe, and teaching in the same place where he left Plato, at such time as he tooke his iourney, and perceiuing him with his complices and adherentes, so farre from folowing Plato, that they segregated themselues vtterly from his assembly, and to haue a conuenticle of their owne, he demaunded of one in the place of exercises called Peripatum what was happened to Plato, and what was become of him? Answer was made, that he was not sicke, howbeit the occasion of his absence from hence procéeded of Aristotle, who of late molested the man in such sort, & was such an intollerable trouble vnto him, that he was fain of force to forsake Peripatum the place of his profession, & at this present he is at his owne house, reading, teaching, and discoursing in Philosophie priuately in his garden. When Xenocrates had receiued this answer, wtout any further interposition of talke, vpon a very sudden, prepared spéedy passage to Plato, whom he found (as it was reported) reasoning with his auditory which were many in nomber, & the self same of no small countenance, & credit, and some of
them also yong men descended of good degree & in very worshipful place. When Plato had finished his disputatiōs, he saluted Xenocrates most louingly, according to his accustomed courtesie, and Xenocrates in lyke maner did the lyke to Plato. Anon, when the assemblye was broken vp & dismissed, Xenocrates moued no cōmunication to Plato cōcerning the former matter, neither dyd Plato once make mēcion thereof, nor called it in question. But gathering his companions togeather about him, first reprehended Speusippus sharply for geuing place to Aristotle in Peripato, and then consequently bent the mayne force of his mighte against him, contending with wordes, and withstanding his procéedings indéede insomuch yt the strife betwéene thē both waxed hot and fyery. In conclusion was kindled with such commotions of minde that he dispossessed Aristotle of the Peripatum, expelled and thrust him out by the shoulders as obtayning that place by vsurpation, and therefore most worthy of dislocation: So that in fine, the deuine Philosopher Plato, that good olde man recouered his accustomed roome, and was (by compulsory meanes) restored to his proper place.

div.head: ¶ Of Lysander, and of the presents which were offered vnto hym.
div.p:
TO Lysander the Lacedemonian going in progresse to Ionia, among many other giftes and oblations presented vnto him by ye borderers and inhabitantes, as simbols and pledges of his welcome to them, a fat bullock and another iuncket both daynty and toothsome was offered: Lysander beholding the iuncket demaunded what maner of meate it was, and of what simples it was made, to whome, the bringers therof made answer, that it was a confection made of Hony,
Creame, fine flower, and other things somwhat as it should séeme lyke a tarte, or a Marchpane. Then saide Lysander agayne, friends geue this to them that be accquainted with it and know what it is, for it is no meate for a gentleman, or great state. As for the bullock he procured that to be led to the slaughter, to be dismembered, sundred out in seuerall quarters and ioynts, and after the custome of the country, to be dressed diuersly, wherupon he fed and reaped great pleasure in that kinde of repast.

div.head: ¶ Of the courage and stout hart of Themistocles.
div.p: THemistocles when he was but a boy comming from schoole, was commaunded by his instructer & techer to geue place to Pisistratus the tyrant, if peraduenture hee met him: To whome the noble lad cast out this answer with boldnesse of minde, stoutnesse of stomack & lybertie of speach. Nunquid hec via ei non sufficit? is not this way sufficent for him to passe by? Whereupon from that time forwardes great hope of manhood and valyantnesse shined in Themistocles.

div.head: ¶ Of the godly disposition of Aeneas, and of the compassion of the Grecians towardes the Troians.
div.p:
WHen Troy was taken, the Grecians pittying the perplexities & miseries of the captiues, made this generall proclamation in the Grecian tongue, that it shoulde be lawfull for euery Citizen which was frée, to conuey and carry away with them some one thing or other,
what they themselfe would best lyke of, and most tenderly loued.
