Aeneas therefore, contempning al other things whatsoeuer of great value and estimation, carried out with him the Gods of hospytalitie, which when the Grecians behelde, and considered the vertuous and gracious inclynation of the gentleman, gaue hym leaue in lyke maner to take and chuse one thing, what he most made of, among all his goodes, riches, and possessions. Aeneas vsing the benefit of this their mercifull graunt, tooke his Father beyng olde and auncient, vppon his shoulders, and bore the burthen of his body out of the Citie, whereat the Grecians being wonderfully astonished, left vnto him the substance of al his wealth vndiminished, adding these words importing a testimony of their opinion. Pietatem in homines & deos exercentibus parentesque reuer enter colentibus, etiam natura inimicos, non posse non aequos & placatos se perbere. Such as behaue them selfe relygiously towardes the Gods, and vse themselfe also reuerently to their parentes, must of necessitie make blunt the sharpe edge of the yrefull enemye, and constraine such to be parciall as gaped gréedely after the spoyle.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexander.
div.p:
COmmendable and renowned be the actes of Alexander which hee dyd at Granicus and Issus. His foughten field at Arbeles, the taking of Darius, the subduing of the Persians to the Macedonians, the conquering of al Asia, the bringyng of the Indians vnder his owne dominion. &c. Lawdible be his feats of armes donne at Tyrus, and Oxydacris: But what meane we to comprehend in a skantlyng of lynes the puisaunce of so incomparable a Prince? let it be as some
enuyous varlets and backbiting tonges woulde haue it, that the prosperous successe of his aduentures is to be attributed to Fortune, what of that? yet is he notable and praise worthy, notwithstanding, insomuch as his fortune neuer fainted nor fayled, and in that hee was lulled in the lappe of so louing a Lady that she neuer withdrew her fauour from him. But these enumerations following deserue no shaddow nor cypher of commendation. First, vppon the fifte day of one month (as the reporte runneth) hee drunk somuch at Eumeus Manour, that he was quite ouercome, sléeping out his beastly surfeiting all the sixt day folowing, wherin he did nothing at al in a maner, but rise a litle from his drunken pillow and gaue commaundement of the morrowes voiage, saying, that it should be the next morning very early at the spring of the light from the East. The seauenth day folowing he feasted and banqueted at the Lorde of Perdina his Pallace, at what time he pampered his paunche like an epicure, with choise of chéere, and change of wines, ouer drinking himselfe, in such insatiable sorte, that all the eight day next insueing was consumed in sléepe. Furthermore vpon the fiftéenth day of the same month he fell to winebibbing againe, and spent the next day after in sléepe to digest his surfeting. The foure and twenty day folowing he supped at Bagoas table, whose Manour, was distant from Courte, about a tenne furlongs, the second seruice of whose vnmeasurable abuse (swallowing wine as swine do their swill) was drowsines and sléepe, which folowed his intemperaunce, successiuely. Wherfore to knyt vp all in one conclusion, of these two circumstaunces must of necessitie insue, eyther that lusty Alexander, by consumyng so many dayes in Epicurism and drunkenesse, did impare his owne profite, or els that they which were reporters of this vndecent and reprehensible vsage, were stark staring lyers. Whereby it may be gathered, that they also in other things wander wide from the truth, among whom that fellow Cardianus
hath not the hindermost place.

div.head: ¶ That Xenophon was precise in fynesse of furniture.
div.p: AS Xenophon had a singuler regarde, in sundry honest and good things, so had he a speciall care to haue his harnesse cleane, fayre, bright and shining. For sayde he, if happe did so hit, that he shoulde be conquerour and valiant in victorie, the best, the brauest, and the most beautifull robe among all his enemies, should be his to weare with worship. Agayne, if lucke did so light, that he shoulde be subdued in battell, and lose his life, that then his carkasse or corpes shouldly vpon the ground, not vile and debased, but garnished with glittering armour, which to a strong and courageous captaine is an ornament of honour, wherewith he ought decently to be decked. Xenophon therefore was curious in the prouision of martiall furniture, he had an Argolican target, an Athenien breast plate, a Boetian head peece, an Epidauriā ceval, &c. I do not make a recapitulatiō of these things to any other purpose, then to giue a specialtie by the way, of Xenophons desire in neatnesse and featnesse, and to iudge him worthy in déede, of that which is both rare, costly, fayre, fine, and curious.

div.head: ¶ Of Leonidas, and the thirtie men, who offered them selfe to dy of their own accord, for the safetie of Grecia.
div.p:
LEonidas the Lacedemonian, and thirtie men more of stout stomackes, yelded their bodies to the bitter passion of dreadful death at Pylas, which was pronoūced vpon them by a vaticination or prophesie. Who induring
battel boldly, and continuing conflict courageously, for the preseruation of all Grecia, obtained a most glorious and triumphant end, leauing behind them a name of nobilitie, and a perpetuall monument of excellent worthynesse.

div.head: ¶ Of the tyrant Pyndarus.
div.p:
PYndarus the sonne of Melanis, Alyattus nephewe to Hydran, by his daughter, not degenerating from the tyrannie of the Ephesians, shewed him selfe of nature faire inexorable, and paste intreataunce, in the execution of punishmentes, I meane: but in other things his behauiour was mylde, gentle, prudent, and curteous, applying his vttermost diligence, that his countrey should not be burthened with barbarous bondage, but frée from all forreine force. That these things are to be verefied, the sequele of this present historie maketh declaration. Whē his vncle Cressus by the mothers side had all Ionia in subiection, he sent embassadours to Pyndarus, requiring that the Ephesians might be deliuered into his dominion. But Pyndarus woulde not subscribe to the summe of the message, wherevpon Cressus made preparation against the citie, and layde siege therevnto. In this tumult, a certain tower or fortresse being so assaulted, that it was ouerthrowne and ruinously raced, whiche afterwardes was called Proditrix, that is, trayterous, and séeing the inconuenience of the mischiefe before his face, Pyndarus gaue aduise to the Ephesians, that from the gates and towers of the citie, to the pillers of Venus temple they should tye ropes, and let the citie be Anathema to that Goddesse. By this he persuaded the Ephesians to be secure, and to set all at sixe and at seuen, ministring moreouer vnto them this counsel as commodious: that they in their owne persons shuld repayre to Cressus and desire peace. The Ephesians did so, opening their suites and supplications to the same
intent. Whereat Cressus laughed, and séemed neuer awhit to be moued in mynde, at this their diligent endeuour, but graunted vnto them fréedome and libertie. Neuertheles vpon condition, namely that Pyndarus shoulde auoyde the citie, who indeede was so farre from impugning that appointment, that he gaue both heart and hand to the vtter satisfaction of the same, taking with him such of his friendes, as would willingly beare him company. As for his sonne and all his substance, he surrendred them to the citie. Thus the tuition and charge of his sonne, being committed to the conscience and credite of one of his best beloued and approued friendes named Pasiclus, and due order being taken for the disposition of his goods, he departed into Pelloponnesus, making an exchāge of pomp and royaltie, with voluntarie banishment, to the intent that the souldiers of the countrey, should not shrinke vnder the yoke of Hydrans subiection.

div.head: ¶ Of Platos pouertie, and howe he aspired to to the studie of Philosophy.
div.p: I Haue hearde this reported (whether it be true or not, I can not tel,) neuerthelesse, I wil take leaue to rehearse that which I haue heard. Plato the son of Ariston being plagued with impouerishment, & nipped with necessitie, determined with him self to be a souldier, and to go on warfare. But being taken in that mind by Socrates, and instructed in that, which was not onely more commendable, but also more auaileable, he solde his harnesse and weapons, changed his purpose, & framed him self to the study of philosophy, at Socrates persuasions.

div.head: ¶ Howe Socrates suppressed the pryde and hautinesse of Alcibiades.
div.p:
SOcrates séeing Alcibiades puft vp with pryde, and broyling in ambitious behauioure (because hee was
possesser of such great wealth, and Lorde of so large lands) brought him to a place where a table did hang, containing a discription of the worlde vniuersall: Then did Socrates wil Alcibiades to séeke out the situation of Athens, which whē he foūd, Socrates procéeded further, and willed him to point out that plot of ground, where his lands & lordships lay. Alcibiades hauing sought a long time, and yet neuer the neare, sayde to Socrates, that his liuings were not set foorth in that table, nor any discription of his possession, therin made euident. Whom Socrates rebuked with this secret quip. Horū possessione te effers, quae nulla pars sunt terrae? And art thou so arrogant, (sayth he) and so hautie in heart for that, which is no percell of the world.

div.head: ¶ Of Diogenes his beggerlynesse, and of his hautinesse.
div.p: DIogenes Sinopensis sayde vsually of him self, that he suffered many sharp shoures and sturdie stormes, that he had no abyding place, but was of the brotherhoode of vagabunds, that he was a verie begger, & yt his wearing garments were vile and ylfauoured, and yet he vaunted him selfe in this, that he liued notwithstanding, yea, so he liued, that he was no lesse satisfied with this scarsitie, then Alexander was delighted with his superfluitie, and no lesse contented with his want, then Alexander was proude of the whole world, when he hauing subdued the Indians, returned into Babylon.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine modest, chaste, and continent persons.
div.p:
A Certaine harper named Amoebeas, hath the report of maruellous chastitie, who albeit he had to his wife
and bedfellowe, a woman of rare beautie, yet dealt not with her in carnall knowledge. Such another continent fellowe was one Dionisius the tragicall player. To these must be annexed Clytomacus Pancratiastes, a man cunning and péerelesse in all exercises of actiuitie: who was of so chaste a countenance, that if peraduenture he saw at any time a dogge a lyning a bitch that went salute, he turned his honest eies aside, to the intent that he might not sée the coupling of them in their kynde. The verie same man was of such modest disposition, that if he heard any lecherous communication, and baudy taulke pertayning to Venerie, in bankets, and feasts, where he was present, As impatient of suche vnreuerent spéeche, he arose immediately from the table, left his trencher, and departed.

div.head: ¶ Of the earnest labour of Niccas, which he bestowed in his Arte.
div.p: NIccas the paynter was so earnest, so intentiue, and so busily occupyed in paynting, that he forgot to take foode and sustenance to succour nature.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexander and Hercules, learning to play vpon the violyn.
div.p:
ALexander the sonne of king Phillip, when he was in a manner but a boy, and scarsely growen to the age of a stripling, learned to play vpon the violyn, whose master bidding him play vpon a string agréeing in tune, called a concorde, as the science of Musike required, Alexander ouerthwarted him, saying, and what matter is it, if I strike vpon a contrary corde. The teacher answered againe in this sorte, Indéede, it is not materiall to thée as thou wilt be a king, but as thou wilt be a Musitian, it is worthy of marking. This man
suspected, that if he taught not Alexander fitly, ye like lot would light vpon him, which fel in Linus lap. For Linus taught Hercules when he was but a ladde, to play on the instrument, and to sing to the same in a tuneable voyce, whome Linus reprehending, because he handled his rebecke somewhat rudely, Hercules swelling with the poyson of anger, smote his master Linus with his bowe, and harmed him in such sort, that he dyed.

div.head: ¶ Of Satyrus the whistler or pyper.
div.p: SAtyrus the Piper was present at the Philopher Aristos disputatiōs, and being myraculously moued with the reasons which he had vttered, sayde, Cur ego non igni trado hoc mihi vtile tecum.

q.l: Why doe not I vile hare braine foole,
Consume with fire this fruitlesse toole.

div.p: Meaning indéede somewhat darkly, his pype, wherein he vsed to whistle, and after a secret sort, and close conceit of disdaine, abasing his homely profession, or rather vtterly contemning the same, in comparison of the studie and knowledge of Philosophy.

div.head: ¶ Of a lawe common to the Romaines and the Lacedemonians.
div.p: THe Lacedemonians and the Romanes had a lawe, that no man should suppe when he liste, nor with what he liste: meaning to withdrawe their citizens and people from intemperance, by many policies, and principally by due order & resonable vsage at the table, which was not accounted among the basest.

div.head: ¶ That it was not lawfull to laugh in the scholehouse called Academia.
div.p: THe rumour concerning Athens is so common, that it rouleth in euery mās mouth, Namely, that in auncient time it was not permitted, nor graūted, that any shuld laugh in the scholehouse called Academia: For they did what they could with the vttermost of their might, to preserue this place from lightnesse, from iniurie, and from ydlenesse.

div.head: ¶ For what consideration Aristotle did forsake Athens.
div.p: ARistotle being troubled with the fearefull cogitation and thought of iudgement, dyd forsake Athens: To a certaine man mouing this question vnto him, and demaunding what manner of citie it was, made this answere: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is to say, A goodly citie, and a very fayre, sauing that one Peare trée waxeth olde by another, and one figge trée wythereth by another, meaning Sycophants, false accusers, carrytales and yll disposed persons. And to one asking why he left Athens, he answered, Because he woulde not be a stumbling blocke to the Atheniens, to make them offende twise against Philosophy, shewing somwhat obscurely, and as it were vnder a cloud, the death of Socrates, and giuing an ynckling of the daunger which he him selfe was like to incurre, if he made any tarryance among such pernitious people.

div.head: ¶ The Statute of the people Cei, concerning auncient men.
div.p:
THe people Cei obserue this lawe accustomably, that such farre spent in yeres, & much wasted with old age,
waxing hoarie and auncient, should byd one another (as it were) to a computation and banket, or should assemble them selfe at some solemne sacrafice, and being crowned with garlandes in glorious maner, should drinke poyson, knowing this assuredly, that their strēgth was weaknes, and their wit dotage, and therefore vtterly vnable to further their countrey in any respect. It followeth then, that we are to be shaken off from the trée of the cōmon wealth like rotten fruite, reserued for no necessarie vse.

div.head: ¶ Of diuers things which were first inuented at Athens.
div.p: AT Athens (as some reporte) was the Oliue trée, and the fig trée (which that cuntrey soile did yéeld before any other ground,) first founde out. The seassing of fines, penalties, and forfetures, and the appointing of punishments, were in like manner deuised among them. They also were the first that inuented wrestling, and corporall exercises, striping themselues to their naked skins, and anointing their bodies. And, to be briefe, Ericthonius was the first that ioined horses together to serue in drawing.

div.head: ¶ What some people in times past vsed to eate.
div.p: THe Arcadians did eate acornes, the Argiues did eat wardens of the woode. The Athenians did eate figges, the Tyrinthes did eate wilde peares, the Indians did eate flagges, the Carucanes did eate dates, the Moeotes and the Sauroncates did eate millet, the Persians did eate of the turpentine trée. &c.

div.head: ¶ Of the Satires. Titires and Silens.
div.p: THe Satires were Bacchus companions alwaies: whō some terme by this word Tityres, which name they borowed 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to say, of wanton lewde and filthy songes, lecherous and baudy ballades, and daunces ful of detestable demeanure, wherein the Satires specially reioyced. They are called Satiri, ab oris rictu, of the gaping of the mouth. And the Silens haue their name, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , yt is of reuilyng, vpbrayding, and reprochfull raylinges, for they dyd shoote out of their brainesick bowes, scoffing boults, with a certaine kinde of yrcksome dallyaunce. The attyre which the Sylens vsed, were cotes all heary on both sides. This longe garment, doth represent the plantyng of Bacchus, the indented leaues of the vine trée, the thicknesse of the braunches as they spring, and the grapes growing in clusters.

div.head: ¶ The manyfolde sirnames of Bacchus
div.p: THe auncient men (time out of minde) tearmed the plentyfull increase of fruits by this worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifieth to abound, wheruppon sprang one of Bacchus sirnames that is to be called Philecon, he was called in like maner Protigas, he was called moreouer, Staphilitas, he was also called Omphacitas. Finally, he was called by manyfold and sundry appellations, which to recount in this place, were not a signe of so great wisdome, as a token of vaine curiositie.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine mad women.
div.p:
THe Quéene of Cyprus prouoked Elega, and Cel en a, the daughters of Proetus, to such extreame madnesse, and
outrage, that they were séene running vp and downe in sundry places of Peloponnesus starke naked, stamping and staring like hellish feendes. They rushed also, into s • ndry regions of Grecia, being perplexed with this lunatique passion. I haue receiued also, by report, that there were diuers women in Lacedemonia which were haunted with the mad spirit of Bacchus, of diuers women among the people Chij, and of diuers women, in lyke maner, among the Boeotians which were frantique, furious, and filled with a certaine celestiall commotion. Moreouer the tragicall pageants are replenished with outragious rorrings and terrible outcries. The women called Miniades, Leucippe, Aristippe, and Alcithoe by name, onely they refused (as the voice goes) the daunces of bawdy Bacchus, because they desiered husbandes, and for that cause refrained themselfe from such vsage as should serue the celebration of Bacchus, whereuppon his choler so increased, that he fell into an angry heate. Now when they were buisie about their huswifes cloth, and were occupyed in spinning thred, and in carding wooll, wandring Ivy with gréene leaues, crept vp incontinent, and ran rounde about their distaues. In their Osyer baskets did Serpents make their nestes, and ingendered, and from the endes of the flax or wooll, drops of hony and wine distilled. But when these wayes woulde not win them to the worship of the forsayde God, no lesse madnesse and outrage entered into their hartes without Citheron, then in Citheron. For Minyades being possessed with an implacable spirit of outrage, pulled and tare in mammocks the sonne of Leucippe being but yong and tender, supposing in these their frantique fits, that he was a fawne, and then dragged him to the aboue rehersed Minyades, who makyng speedy pursuit after them for the murther committed, were chaunged into contrary shapes, the first into the likenesse of a crow, the second into the figure of a bat, and the thirde into the fourme of an owle.

div.head: ¶ Of a Harper whom the Sybarits murthered.
div.p: AT what time a certaine Musitian, who commonly vsed ye Harp, did both sing and play at Sybaris in a solemne shew made & set forth in ye honour of heauenly Iuno, there arose about him, a great variance amonge the Sybarits. Now when this contention was so kindled, that the matter came to be tryed with harnesse and weapon, and euery one furnished to fight, the Harper, being attired in his long robe, fled with might and maine to the Aulter of Iuno. But the Sybarits, not sparing the holynesse of the place, layde violent handes vpon the Musitian, inso much that among them he was murthered. Anon the temple of Iuno appeared to flow with bloud, lyke streames of water from a xiuer, immediatly after that slaughter. The Sibarits sending to the Oracle for counsell in that case of crueltie, receiued this sharp and bitter answere.

q.l: Cede meis mensis, manibus nam sanguis adhaerens
Destillansque recens, prohibet tibi limina templi.
Non tibi fata canam: Magnae Iunonis ad aram,
Musarum innocuum strauisti caede ministrum.
Non immortales hoc dii patientur inulum.
Si quis enim prudens, scelerata è mente profectum.
Commitat facinus, grauis hunc propè paena sequetur.
Non exorabit, neque si genus ab Ioue summo
Duceret: ipse suo collo, collisque nepotum,
Hoc luet, & generis cumulatum damna ferentur.

div.p: Thus in English.

q.l: My table come not nere, for hands with bloud imbrude,
Which floweth fresh, frō holy temple gates doth thee exclude
Thy fate I wil not tel: By Iunos alter thou hast slain,
A guiltles soule, vnto the Muses nine who did retaine.
Th'immortal gods of this foule fact shal sharp reuēgment take:
For he which wilfully offends, & doth a mischife make
Of minde malicious, torments strong shall be his hoped hyre,
No suite may serue, but smart hee must, though Ioue be blasd his syre:
His head, & al his childrens heads, vpon the bloudy block
From shoulders shal be chopt, ill luck shall light vpon his stock.

div.p: Neither was the reuengment lingred, and delayed from morrow to morrow: But as they receiued of the Oracle so it came to passe. For when they entred battaile against the Crotomates, this prophesie had successe, so that they were subdued to the power of their enemies, and their citie (oh pytifull spectacle) brought to vtter ruine and desolation.

div.head: ¶ Of one that might haue succoured his fellow in daunger, but would not, and of another that dyd his good wyll to aide him, but had yll Fortune.
div.p:
THrée yong men, being all of one citie, and traueilyng together to Delphos to aske counsell and to be aduertised by the Oracle, fell into the spoyling hands of théeues, One of the thrée, tendring his owne lyfe, tooke his héeles and ran away, and so escaped perill. Another (after that all the villans were hackt, hewne, and kylled, except one, whom he inuaded also with might and mayue) bent the force of his blow to slay hym which was left aliue. But it fortuned (ah gréeuous chance) that as he foyned with his sworde at the théefe, thinking to haue thrust him through, he missed his marke, and smote his owne fellow with such a bloudy blow, that he gaue him his deathes wound. To him therefore which by taking flight,
auoyded daunger, this answer was made by the Oracle.

lg.l: Occidi socium presens & passus amicum,
Non tibi vaticinor, sacro te proripe templo.
Thou being present didst abide thy fellow to be slaine,
To thee I doo not prophesie: my holy place refraine.

div.p: And to the other asking aduise of the Oracle, this answer was rendred.

lg.l: Defendens socium, verso mucrone necasti:
Purior es manibus nunc, quam prius esse solebas.
Thou seeking to defend thy mate,
dydst kill hym with thy blade:
Thy handes, then they were wont to be,
are now much cleaner made.

div.head: ¶ The Oracle which pronounced to Phillip.
div.p:
PHillip in Boetia heard this pronounced by the Oracle in the temple of Trophonius, that he should be circumspect in auoyding a Waggon or Charriot, whervppon he fearing the premonition of the Oracle would turne to his detriment & harme, if he considered not superficially of ye same, would neuer mount vp after that into his chariot of estate. As concerning this history, there runneth a double rumour abroad. For some say that the sword of Pausanias, wherewt he slue Phillip, had in the hiltes or handle therof, a Chariot of Elephants bone or yuery ingrauen. Othersome say, that he was killed, at such time as hee rode in circuite about a fen or marrisse called Palus Thaebaica, which place
was called by the name of a Chariot. But the first report is the more vsual, the second not so common. By this is signified, that desteny cannot be auoyded.

div.head: ¶ The Statute of the Stagirites.
div.p: THis is a Statute of the Stagirites, and such a Statute it is that a man may manyfestly perceiue that it is a Grecian law the sume wherof is this. Quod non deposuisti, ne tollas. Take not vp that which thou hast not laide downe.

div.head: ¶ Of Timothy, and other valiaunt men, that were not aduantaged by their vertue.
div.p:
THe Athenians did singularly commend Timothy at the first, but afterwardes when he séemed to offend, his former vertue auailed him not a rushe, neither dyd his puisaunt déedes in times past, purchase him a pinnes worth of profit. As for Themistocles, though he did sow the séede of his valyantnesse aboundantlye, yet hee reaped aduauntage very sparinglye, for his commodyties were not great which he got by a battaile fought vpon the sea about Salamis, or by the embassage which he bare to Sparta: for his reward, in the end, was banishmēt out of the borders of the Citie, and also out of all the coastes of Grecia vniuersall. Moreouer, Pausanias had very slender furtheraunce, by his victory at Plateas, when he tooke new matters in hande at Byzantium and was troubled with a Persian sicknesse, notwithstanding,
all his practises of prowesse, and valliaunt vertue, he lost the grace and fauour, which he had obtayned by his former feates. And as for Phocion, hee was so farre from the rewarde of commendation for his iustice and bounty, that he was drowned in the depth of detestation: For he being thréescore and fifetéene yeares olde (a goodly and a gracious age) and hauing donne litle iniurie, or rather none at all to the Athenians, yet because it was Antipaters pleasure, who was willing to betray Pireum) he stoode to the sentence of condemnation pronounced by the Athenians.

div.trailer: ¶ The end of the thirde Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The fourth Booke of Aelianus variable Historie.
¶ The sundry manners of diuers people, and nations.
div.p: THe people of Leueani had a Lawe, the sum whereof was this. Yf a Straunger, or soiourner, was come amonge them, and entred into the soyle which they enhabited, a litle before the sunne setting, and was desirous to lodge in one mans house or other, if he were not receiued, intertained, and harboured, he or they, which neglected duty in this respect, payd an appointed penalty for their inhumanytie, and sustayned deserued punishment for their churlyshnesse. A Law (as it séemeth vnto mée) very profitable to the wayfaring man, and allowable to Iupiter the louer of hospytalytie.
The Dardane Illyrrians, vsed to washe and skoure their skinnes but thrée times in all their lyfe, namely, after their birth, at their marriage, and at their deathes.

The Indians put not their money to vsury, neither doe they receiue money to vsury. Because it is not lawfull that any Indian amonge them all should take wronge, or doe wrong. And therefore they make no bonds, no oblygations, nor hand writings to iustyfie any matter, neither doe they lay any thing to gage and to pledge.

There is a Law obserued among the people Sordoi, that the sonnes sowse and thumpe their fathers being aged and weaklings, with clubs to the death, and after they haue slaine them in such sort, to prouide for the due execution of
their funeralles, iudging it an absurd thing, and altogether repugnant to reason, that olde men should haue their liues prolonged, because that when their bodies be worne with multytude of yeares and imbecilytie, their wits are freshe and ripe to excogitate and deuise subtilties, crafts, deceipts, and mischiefes. The same people prouided by bréefe of statute, that slouthfulnesse, and ydlenesse, should be recompensed with due punishment, and that such as lyued without labour, and shifted the world without taking paines, should render an accounts (narrow examination being prosecuted) after what sort they liued, and whereuppon they were maintained.

The Assyrians, when their virgins, and yong damoselles are of sufficient yeares and mariageable, they bring them altogeather into one Citie, and set them out to sale lyke wares in a common market, and euery man is wedded and bedded with her, as with his spouse legitimate, whom hee purchaseth with his penny.

The people Biblij, if they sée any thing loste by the way, they take it not vp, because they layde it not downe. For if any infringed and brake the staffe of that Statute, they iudged the thing taken vp, not to be found, but rather to be stolne, and so hee or they that offended were attached of felony.
The people of Berbicae kill and slay all that be aboue the age of thréescore and ten yeares, hacking and hewing their men, stranglyng and choking their women.
The people of Colchi bury their dead in hydes and skinnes, sowing them vp close, and hanging them vpon trees.

The Lydyans vse and custome was, that women before they lay in bed with their husbandes, should lye open to be occupied, and hauing once had carnall knowledge and receaued the séede of generation, they should liue afterwardes chast and continent. And whatsoeuer she was that durste deale in fleshly delight with the body of any other, she should
be punished (as a terrible example) without all mercy and Pitie.

div.head: ¶ Of the strife betweene the two Minstrelles, Nicostratus and Laodocus.
div.p: AT what time Nicostratus was at strife with Laodocus about the art and science of minstrelsy, he vttered such and such words, saying, yt Laodocus in a great art had but litle skill, and in chiefe cunning small knowledge. But that he himselfe in a small art had great experience, and in a homely science singular vnderstanding. Therfore it is not onely commendable, to amplyfie and inlarge a mans family, or to augment and increase his substaunce, but also to prouide so by industrious labour, and carefull dilligence, that cunning likewise may springe, grow, flourish, and attayne to excellencie, if we will geue eare to the counsell and aduice of Nicostratus, and listen to his lore in this behalfe.

div.head: ¶ Of the two painters Dionisius and Polignotus
div.p: POlygnotus Thasius, and Dionysius Colophonius were painters both by their trade, science, occupatiō, and profession. Polygnotus vse and custome was to decipher and painte out thinges which were great and large, besides that in pictures perfectly, precisely, and artyficially handled, he made challenges and contended for superioritie. But Dyonisius pictures besides their magnitude & bignes comprehended also an exquisite, singuler, and curious imitation of Polignotus art, it contained also liuely resemblances of affections, of mouing the members, stirring the lims and ioynts, naturall composition and shape, wrinckles, seames, plights, foldinges, hems, and such lyke worthy and wonderfull workmanship.

div.head: ¶ The Law of the Thebans concerning Artificers and painters.
div.p: THe Thebans had an ordinance which charged handy crafts men, and commaunded al artificers, but principally Painters, & potters, and caruers, that they should describe, delineat, and set forth the fashion forme and lykenesse of such things as were incident to their art, after the finest, the featest, and the comlyest manner. The same statute did inhibit and forbid all Painters and Caruers to doe any thing grosly, slightly, and vncunningly, prouided alwaies by authorytie, that such as did contrary to the prescript of their law, should incur a penalty, and stande to the payment of a certaine some of mony for trāsgressing the tenor of the foresaide Statute.

div.head: ¶ What men haue bine mindefull of benefits and good turnes in time conuenient.
div.p:
AMonge many which haue maintained the remembraunce of benefits, and haue not only shewed them selfe thankfull therby geuing an euident argument of gratitude, but also making a recompence and requitall of the same among the number, I say, of such was Theseus to Hercules, for when Aedonius the king of Mollosus imprisoned and shackelled Theseus at such, time as he came with Pirithous to take away the kings concubine by violence, not to wed her, but to haue her for Pirithous behoofe. Hercules directing his iourney to Molossus deliuered Theseus out of his bolts and fetters, and let him lose at large in the pleasant pastures of golden lybertie. For the which occasion, Theseus erected and built an alter in his honor and renown. Moreouer these seauen persons of Thebes did not suffer ye singuler curtesie of Pronax to pas vnrecompenced, for whē Pronax had perished for their sakes, in ye worship & celebratiō of him they instituted & appointed publique plaies
which (as many hold opinion) were consecrated to captaine Archemorus. Furthermore Hercules rewarded Nestor for his good déedes, for when Neleus would not entertaine him, and al the residue of his sonnes had, as it were, sworne to the like, so that all curtesie was excluded, Nestor, notwithstanding, consented not vnto them, but was contrarywise inclined. Wherfore when the Citie was taken, Hercules made hauock of some, paying vnto them a new reuenge for an old grudge with a recumbentibus, for he made a slaughter of Neleus the father, and serued the remnaunt of his sonnes, (Neleus onely excepted) with the same sowre sawce, As for Nestor he found fauour at Hercules hands, in somuch yt he did not only escape wt the safety & preseruation of his precious life, but receiued also the gouernment of his predecessors kingdome, to rule and raigne with sworde and Scepter in maiestie and royall order. Whereupon the Athenians shewed themselfe thankfull to the posteritie of Hercules, and because the author of their stock deserued well at Theseus handes, therfore the Athenians did accompany them into Peloponnesus. Besides al this Hercules recompensed the same thrée hundred and thréescore Cleonians, which helped, succoured and defended him against the inuasion of théeues, and the sharp assaults of spoylers, who as they sought to make a slaughter, so were they themselfe vanquished, slaine and murthered, vpon whom he bestowed the worship which the Nemenses exhibited vnto hym, when he ouerthrew and ouercame by maine strength, the force of a cruell Lyon, which ramped and raunged ouer the borders of their landes, wasting their tillage, and bringing all their workes to nought. In like maner Menesthaeus the sonne of Peteo • s shewed himselfe not vnthankfull in behauiour towardes the Tyndarides, who after that Theseus was expelled and cast out into exile, and his mother Athera led away captiue, deliuered vp the scepter and crowne of the kingdome to Menesthaeus, for which cause
Menesthaeus exhibited great reuernce vnto them, honouring them with this tytle of great dignitie, namely, of Emperours, and Sauiours. Darius, also, when he was inferiour to a prince, and not superiour to a priuate man or commoner, receiuing a gorgious garment, or rich robe of Solon for a gift, after yt the felycity of Fortune had established and confirmed hym in the throne royall, hee recompensed the curtesie of Solon, committing vnto him power, authorytie, gouernment, and iurisdiction in the Countrie Samis, and so made an exchange (if wee ponder precisely the vallue of the giftes on both partes) of glittering Golde with rustie yron.

div.head: ¶ The Oracle pronounced for the Athenians.
div.p: WHen the Lacedemonians were fully determined vtterly to ouerthrow and race vp the Citie of the Athenians, asking counsell of the Oracle, answere was made in this fourme and maner, Communem aram Greciae ne moueatis. Remoue not the common alter of Grecia, styrre it not but let it stande.

div.head: ¶ That wicked and malicious men are so far from tranquilytie, that they are neuer in rest and quietnesse, no not in death, and of Pausanias.
div.p:
WIcked & heinous offenders reape no aduantage at al by death. And why so? Because they are then voide of rest, and depriued of quietnesse. Moreouer because they do rather want the rites of their funerall, or els at the least, notwithstanding they be buried for a season, yet their
corps is dispossessed at length of ye honorable hauen which is common to all dead bodyes. This to be true, take this testimoniall of the Lacedemonians and of Pausanias, which Pausanias takeing part with the Medes, was not onely famished and hunger starued to death, but also his carcasse was so farre from being intoumbēd, that it was cast out of the borders of the land. This was the vsage of the Lacedemonians towardes Pausanias, as Epitimedes reporteth.

div.head: Of the variablenes of Fortune.
div.p:
WHat man is so blind, blunt, & blockish, that can be ignorant of ye sudden and vnstable changing of Fortune? So the Lacedemonians when they were Lords ouer the Thebans, they were so subdued vnto thē, and of captaines made captiues, that the Thebans did not onely rushe into Pelloponnesus, but also passed ouer into Eurotas, wasting the land of the Lacedemonians, and ruinously ransacking the same, in somuch that they had almost taken the citie and brought it into subiection, but that Epaminondas feared least the Pelloponnesians, making a conspiracy and an vniuersall insurrection, should take the Lacedemonians parte, and venture lymme and lyfe in their defence and preseruation. Dionisius the Tyranne being intercepted of the Carthagineans, and taken in the midde way of his enterprise, when hee perceaued that there was no hope of safty remaining, he was altogether abashed in hart, and his courage not onely cooled, but quite quenched, insomuch that he thought to saue his life by flight. But when one of his acquaintance whose name was Hellopidas, said vnto him, O Dionisi, quam speciosum sepulchrum est ipsa tyrannis? O Dionisius, how glorious a
graue is Tyranny? he blushing at these wordes and looking with a countenance stayned (as it were) with crimson colour, tooke hart of grace, and gathered his skattered strength together, in somuch that with a very fewe souldiours, he ouer ranne many thousands, inlarging his kingdome, and amplifiing his dominion.

Amintas the Macedonian when he was vanquished by the borderers and inhabitantes of out cuntreys, and had lost his kingdome, he purposed in minde vtterly to forsake his natiue soile so that he might escape with the safgard of his life. Whiles he was beating and canuassing his braines with this cogitation, one came to him and vttered the spéeche of the aboue named Hellopidas, which was this Amyntae, quam speciosum sepulchrum est ipsa Tyrannis? O Amintas how beutyfull a tumbe is tyranny? At which wordes he was so affectioned, that he possessed his former place of principalitie, gathered souldiours againe about him sufficiently furnished, and recouered his kingdome which he had lost before.

The Aegiptians called Ochus an Asse in their mother toung, comparing his cowardnesse and blockishnesse to the weaknesse and vnskilfulnesse of that vnreasonable beast, in his discommandation and reproch: wherefore he violently snatching away their great God, which was an oxe, offered the same to an Asse.

Dion the sonne of Hipparinus being thrust into exile, and driuen into banishment by the force of Dyonisius, set vpon Dionisius againe, with two thousande souldiours, vanquished him, and brake the staffe of his power in shiuers, yea, he brought thus much to passe by his valiauntnes, that the authour and procurer of his former miserie, was likewise tormented with semblable calamitie.

The Syracusi setting vppon an hundred and twenty gallies of the Carthaginians, with the aide and succour of
nine gallies of their owne, notwithstanding the inequallytie of the number of Gallies, and warrelyke furniture, were more valliaunt and conquerous then the other by many degrées.

div.head: ¶ Of the lowlynes and humilytie of Plato, and of the ingratitude and vnthankfulnesse of Aristotle.
div.p:
PLato the sonne of Ariston in the Olimpiad, was in company with certaine persons to him vnknowne, hee himselfe also being a straunger to them and vnacquainted, whose mindes neuertheles he did so bow and bende, so winde and winne vnto his desire, meritoriously no doubt, in societie and fellowship, banqueting, and making merrie with them, and spending a whole daies space in their company, insomuch that the straungers, then and there assembled, reioyced greatly that it was their good luck to light vpon so notable a companion. But hee, albeit that merry méeting, ministred no communication concerning the Academy, neither yet entred into any talke touching Socrates. Thus much onely did hee disclose and lay open to their knowledge and vnderstandinges, that his name was Plato. When the within written persons came to the famous citie of Athens, Plato intertained them with singular courtesie, and with manifest significations of friendship: anon the Guestes entreated him saying, go, we beséech thée, and shew vs the phisiognomy, face, and personage of Plato the Philosopher, who is of thine owne name, and somtimes the Disciple or scholler of Socrates, and conduct vs, wee pray thée, into his Academy, bring vs before the man that we may satisfie our eies with the sight of him, and reape some pleasure by his procurement. At which
request of theirs, Plato smiled in his sléene (as his maner was) and saide vnto them, Aedepol, quem quaeritis ego sum, I am the man whom you séeke, I am euen hee, which wordes when they heard, they were merueilouslye amased, and why? because Plato was in their company, and they neuerthelesse ignoraunt of the same, for they had vsed the famylyaritie of that famous Philosopher, and he lykewise did vnite himselfe to their society, yet were they ignoraunt all this while that learned Plato was among them, for he detected not, ne yet discouered the secret misteries of his knowledge, with ostentation and vainglory, neither shewed any token of his excellent learning, yet notwithstanding (this accustomed speaches, poudered with philosophycall salt excepted) was able enough to purchase the fauour, the friendship, and the goodwyll of whom he himselfe list. This princely Philosopher vsed to call Aristotle Mule, what this tearme did importe, may easely be suspected, because a Mule when he hath suckt his fill, and hath enough of his dams milke, casteth vp his héeles and kicks vnkindly, Plato therfore signified by this comparatiue speach, the ingratitude and vnthankfull nature of Aristotle, for he hauing receiued plentyfull séedes, and aboundant increase in the garden of phylosophye, through Platos meanes and admission, in somuch that he was perfectly furnished, and fraught, not onely with the principles and elements of that singular science, but with the profounde practise, and absolute knowledge of the same, in tract of time this Aristotle, disdained and contempned his master Plato, he renounced and forsooke him, he planted a schole, and gathered an assembly in his despight. In conclusion, he and his auditory resisted Plato in Peripato shewing himselfe an vtter aduersary, rather then a dutyfull disciple.

div.head: ¶ Of what minde and affections Pericles was towardes the people of Athens.
div.p: DId not Pericles the sonne of Xantippus greatly regarde the people of Athens, had he them not in high estimation, assuredly I suppose yea, For so often as he came in open place to confer with the Athenians, he wished that no word should issue out of his mouth, whereby the people might be displeased at him & sharpen the weapon of their wrath and anger against hym, in any respect, or that might sound to their discontentation, or séeme in any one point or other, repugnant to their wils.

div.head: ¶ Of the nycenesse, the featnesse, and the finenesse of Socrates.
div.p: DIogenes dyd say that Socrates himselfe vsed to be curious, nice, neat, fine, and feate, for he built himselfe a Manour, which serued to no vse in the world sithence he was not vrged thereunto by any necessary occasion. Moreouer hee made a horse licter to ride in, which was but superfluous. Finally he made him a paire of buskins, or as some say, a payre of buckled shooes, which he vsed to weare somtimes at his pleasure.

div.head: ¶ Of the picture of Helena which Zeuxis paincted.
div.p:
ZEuxis Heracleotes, after he had painted the picture of amiable Helena, he gained greatly thereby, and his aduantage did amount to no small valure, so excellent was his workmanship, for he did not let who list to looke
vpon it for nought, but such as were desierous to sée the same should pay downe a certaine sum at his demaund, which being done, they were permitted to view, and beholde the picture of that beautyfull Quéene, without disturbance. And because Zeuxis Heracleotes gathered in a plentyful haruest into his barne by this péerelesse picture, that is, because his gaine was excessiue, therfore the Grecians which were liuing at the same time, called Helena a common strumpet, sithence it is the property of a strumpet to pledge her honestie, and so profite may be reaped, to let shamefastnesse suffer shipwrack.

div.head: ¶ The opinion of Epicurus, his felicitie and happines.
div.p: EPicurus Gargettius was of this opinion, that hee which was not contented with a litle, was insatiable and neuer had enough. The selfe same Epicurus sayd, he was redy buckled and harnessed to contend with Iupiter himself, in beatitude and blessednesse of lyfe, if hée might not want meate and drink. Seing that Epicurus was of this iudgment, with what dispsition of minde, hee commended & praised pleasure, we shal learne otherwise.

div.head: ¶ Of sparing, spending, and keeping money.
div.p:
THe mony, which is scraped and raked vp together like dunghils, and pinched in sparingly skarsely ounce by ounce (according to ye saying of Archilochus) is powred by heaps and handfuls into a harlotes bagge, and put plentyfully into a strumpets pursse. For there is more facilytye and easines in purueying & getting riches, then in kéeping and
preseruing the same, which to doe is a very hard matter, and passeth the capacitie of many men, wherefore it is notably and truly saide of Anaxagoras, and very agréeable to our purpose in these wordes, saith he in his Booke intituled De regno, sententiously thus Magno cum negotio pecuuiae comportantur, sed multo maiori opera conseruantur & custodiuntur, Riches and wealth are gotten together with great trauaile and toyle, but much more labour & paines is required in the keping and preseruing of the same.

div.head: ¶ Of some which in their sicknesse learned musick, and other thinges besides, and recouered their former health.
div.p:
HIero the Sicilian tyrant was at the first but a priuate man, and such a one indéede, as of all other men cared least for Musick, bending his study another way, but abhorring harmonious and tuneable instruments, the same Hiero, in rusticalytie and clownishnesse differed not from his brother Gelon, neuerthelesse he falling sick, at a certaine season, became very cunning and skilfull, when as he bestowed much leasure (which the imbecilytie and weaknesse of his body lent him) in hearing the talke and communication which flowed from learned mens lippes, when, therefore he recouered his former health, and escaped the hassard of sicknesse, he became a frequent hearer Simonides Cous, of Pindarus Thebanus, and Bacchylides Iulieta: But Gelon his brother continued vnlearned, and remained rusticall. It is recorded also, that Ptolomeus secundus aspired to great learning and knowledge in the time of his sicknesse. Plato in lyke maner, affirmeth that Theages vnderstoode the precepts
of Phylosophy by none other occasion and meanes, then by the leasure which hee obtayned in his sicknesse, for whiles that restrained him from politique matters, hee was as it were spurred forward to the loue of wisdome, and the study of Philosophy. What wise man woulde not haue wished such a sicknesse as this, to Alcibiades to Critras, to Pausanias the Lacedemonian, and the residue? who reuolting from Socrates and his discipline, dealt iniuriously with him, and one whiles tooke part with Beotrans, another while with the Spartanes, and somtimes to the Thessalians, the Medians, and the Persians, cleauing to Barnabazus as confederat. The other, namely, Critras became a bloudy butcher, and stayning his handes with manyfolde murthers, and slaughters infinit, procured no small miseries to his country, insomuch that all men had his lyfe in hatred, enuy, and detestation. These twaine, notwithstanding their wisedome and eloquence, were saide to be, Suis quidem ciuitatibus non bonos, that is, they were not good to their Cities, so that then, the contrary may be concluded, Suis quidem ciuitatibus fuisse malos, that they were yll disposed towardes their Cities.

Furthermore, Straton the sonne of Corrhagus fel sick, but his sicknesse was so far from working his hindrance that it procured him great aduantage and furtheraunce, (as appeareth). This man dissending of a noble lynage, and an honorable house, besides that flowing in streames of riches, and wallowing in waues of wealth, applied him selfe to no laborious and painfull practise, before that he was troubled with the disease of the Spléen. Then lo, hée framd himself to séeke some remedy against that sicknes, namely, by wrestling, and semblable exercises of the bodely members, which he vsed at the first, as meanes and instruments to recouer his accustomed health. In processe of time, hauing by practise, obtained the habit of that art, and such perfection as deserued not repentance. For
as he vttered a triall what he could doe, he did so far passe others, that in the games at Olympus in one day, he woon the best at wrestling, and at all other games of actiuitie, so did he in the Olimpiad following, so did he in Nemea, so did he in Pitho, so did he in Isthmo. To conclude, Democrates the wrestler, notwithstanding he was gréeued with the goute, yet came he to the common games, and standing in the place vsually appointed for the playes he made a round circle about himselfe, and challenged the aduersaryes (if they coulde) to driue him without the compas of the lyne. But so far vnable were they to doe the déede, that they themselfe were ouercome by the resistance of a man whose limmes were not sounde but diseased (the greater commendation his) so that Democrates standing stoutly in his place, and not shrinking frō the same, carried away the crowne of victore, and bare away the golden bell.

div.head: ¶ The properties and conditions of diuers men in auncient time.
div.p: YF any man follow the rule of Callias, he shal soone proue a drunkard. If any man treade in the stepes of Ismenias, he shall soone proue a Musitian. If any man kéepe company with Alcibiades he shal soone proue a proude & a vaingloryous fellow. If any man lyke well of Crobylus, hee shal soone proue a cooke. If any mā builde vpon ye platform of Demosthenes, he shal soone proue an excellent Orator. If any man be delighted with Epaminondas, he shal soone proue a skilfull souldiour. If any man loue to learne of Agesilaus, he shall soone proue honorable.

If any man frame himselfe after Phocions rule, he shall soone proue honest. If any man regard the discipline of Aristides he shall soone proue vpright and iust, if any man draw in one and the selfesame yoke with Socrates, he shal soone proue wise, fober and discrete.

div.head: ¶ Of diuers wonders and opinions concerning Pythagoras.
div.p: PIthagoras taught men that his generation was not temporall, but that he was bred and borne of the confusion and mixture of the most notable and best séedes, and therfore that he was euerlasting, and not subiect to the dominon of death. This Pythagoras (as the rumor goeth) was séene in two seuerall places, namly in Metapontio and Crotona, in one present day, and in one instant houre. Besides that, he discouered his golden thigh in the Olimpiad. Moreouer he informed Milo Crotoniata, that hee was Midas the Phrygian, the sonne of Gordius. Furthermore hee plucked of the feathers of a white eagle which carried him, and as he passed ouer the floud Cosa, the streame spake vnto him with an intelligible voice, calling him by his right name in this manner, Salue Pythagora, welcome Pythagoras.

The within named Pithagoras defended many Paradoxicall opinions, and persisted in sundry erronious assertions, he saide that the leafe of Mallowes, was a thing most holy and sacred, hee sayde that the number binary, that is the number of two, which is compounded of two vnities, was the number wherin most wisedome and vnderstanding was contayned, because it gaue names to things. He held this absurde opinion, that terrestrial commotions, & earthquakes, procéeded from none other cause, then frō ye méeting together & assembling of dead bodies.
Other opinions he maintained, concerning the rainbow, and the riuer Nilus in Aegipt which is the onely hope of that countrye and the certaine signification of plenty or scarsnes.
Of soundes also perciptible by the organ or instrument of hearing namely, the eare, he had his seuerall assertions.

It was not lawfull, nor tollerable, to call any thing in controuersie or doubt, which he pronounced, neither was it permitted to aske him one question twise. But such as were present at his lectures, disputations, and reasonings gaue great credit vnto him, and beléeued his words which they estéemed equiualent, and counteruaileable in truth, with Apollos Oracles. When he came to any citie, the report spred abroade of him, that his cunning was not to instruct lyke a teacher, but to heale and cure lyke a Phisitian. The same Pithogaras in lyke maner gaue precepts of abstinence, namely to forbeare the eating of the hart of any beast, not to touch or medle with a white hen, and generally, to abstaine from all cattell, finally not to deale with Akehorne, nor to trade in common waies, and beaten pathes, because it was doubtfull, whether these things were consecrated and holy, yea or no.

div.head: ¶ Of the reuerence and honour which Dyonisius did exhibit and shew to Plato.
div.p:
AT what time many messengers came to Plato from Dionisius to visit Sicily soyle. Dionisius being then but a striplyng, let Plato ride in a Chariot, hee himselfe in the meane season, vsurping the office of the driuer. At the same time (say some) this man of Siracuse, was inclyned to singular courtesie, hee was gracious in
the eies of the people, and furnished with the fauour and goodwill of all men, at which instant he remembred the Heroical verses of Homer, and was delighted aboue measure to sée so glorious a pageant and to beholde so beautyfull a sight. Then Dionisius, rayneing in the horses, and making the Chariot to stay, or at least, to goe by leaue and leasure, rehearsed these verses out of the Iliades.

q.l: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.p: ¶ Which words sound thus in English.

q.l: The Axell tree of Beech most strong,
a creaking noyse did make,
With bearing of that worthy wight,
whose toung deuinely spake.
And whose renowne through cloudy skies,
to Ioues abiding brake.

div.p: This Dionisius, albeit he mistrusted other and shreudly had them in suspitiō, yet his behauiour towards Plato was not only not culpable but also commendable and orderly, for somuch as he denied him not passage, recourse, and accesse to and fro, fréely (all cumbersome cogitations and misdéeming conceipts abandoned) yet was not Dionisius ignoraunt, that betwixt Plato and Dion friendship was confirmed, and established vpon a faste foundation.

div.head: ¶ Of Phillip, how he loued learning, and of Aristotle.
div.p:
PHilip of Macedonia was not onely famous in warlyke affaires and virtues of magnimitie and valiantnes, but he was likewise excellent & notable in the art and
faculty of an exquisit orator Furthermore he was a great fauourer, and an earnest wel willer to learning, and had knowledge in high honour and singular estimation. Hée bestowed gifts vpon Aristotle very largely, liberally, and bountifully, and as for money he wanted none, the kings benesicence was such. This laudable vsage was an occasion therefore, that hee increased in vnderstandinge, and that his learning attayned great maturitie and ripnesse, as well that which he had in ciuill matters touching the politique estate, as that also which hee had in naturall things, namely, in beasts and semblable creatures indued with the benefit of life, wherin his contemplation was frequent, and vsuall. The history of which lyuing bodies, Nicomachus sonne gained for the aboundance of Phillips riches. Finally he gaue gifts to Plato plentifully, and his largesse to Theophrastus was not lame, or colde, but fresh and flourishing.

div.head: ¶ Of Democritus and of his glory, and of the glory of Theophrastus, Hipocrates, and others.
div.p:
DEmocritus Abderita (if reports be true) was inriched wt the indowmēts of wisdome in many and sundry thinges, and specyally in this, that he was desirous to be vnknowne, which indéede he compassed, brought to passe, & dispatched. For he trauailed into many lands and countries, he ventured into Caldea, & entred into Babilon, at last he came among the Magicians and Sophisters of India. When distribution should be made of his fathers Damasippus possessions, hereditamentes, and al things deuided by him in thrée portions to thrée Brethern, he tooke neither scot nor lot of any kinde of implementes (so litle regard had he to enrich himselfe) except money,
to beare his expenses and to discharge his costs in the continuance of his voiage. The remnaunt of goodes which were left after his fathers deceasse hee was content to resigne vp his interest therin, and conueied all by gifte and graunt fréely, to the vse and possession of his Brethren. For which cause he was commended by Theophrastus, insomuch as he passing from Countrey to Countrey (as it were in peregrination) gathered into his barnes a greter haruest then either Menelaus, or Vlisses, sithence they traueiled from region to region, after the custome of the Marchantes of Phenicia, for they did hourde and heape vp money lyke mountaines, the desire wherof spurred them forward, and imboldened them to attempt dangerous iourneys by lande, and perilous voyages by sea. The Abdirites in lyke maner, called Democritus Philosophy: But they named Protagoras, Phantasie. The saide Democritus vsed to laugh at euery man, affirming that they were mad, whereupon he was called Gelasinus, that is, a man soulde to laughter, or such a one as could not refraine from that condition, wherefore he was worthely counted by the mouthes of all the citizens, one with another to be in name, as hée was indéede. Furthermore (the rumor goes) that Hippocrates at his first méeting with Democritus, thought none otherwise of hym than of a foole, and of such a one who was vtterly voide of wisdome. But as processe of time, and continuance of conference increased their acquaintance, he woondered aboue measure at the profound knowledge of the man.
To conclude, Hippocrates (if reportes deserue credite) was of Dorica (a part of Greece about Thassaly) and hee wrote his booke in the speach and language of Ionia, for Democritus his sake.

div.head: ¶ Ths Paramours of Socrates and of Plato.
div.p: ALcibiades was the Paramour of Socrates, Dion was the Paramour of Plato, who reaped profit and aduantage by Plato his louer.

div.head: ¶ Of the delicatenesse, and superfluous nicenes of the Atheniens.
div.p: THe auntient Atheniens vsed to weare purple garments, and to attire themselfe with chaungeable apparell, they bound vp their heire with silken laces, and mingled their hearie lockes with aglets and round knobs of golde lyke to litle beries, mufflyng their mouthes wt ornaments & Iuels of the same mettall, which were formed and wrought after the similitude of Greshoppers, with these and such lyke thinges of no smal estimation and cost they decked and garnished themselues, and so went abroade in the common & open stréets to be séene of all men. Furthermore whether soeuer they went they had their waighters attending vpon them and following them with folding chaires, to auoide the necessity of sitting downe sodenly and rashly in any place. It is manyfest also, that they at meate and meale, finally in all their fare and trade of life, were too nice. And albeit they were so delicate and effeminate in maners and behauiour: yet in a battaile called Praelium Marothenense, they got the victory and were conquerours.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine wast goodes and spend thriftes.
div.p:
PRodigall lauishing of substaunce, vnthrifty & wastfull spending, voluptuousnes of life, & palpable sensualitie
brought Pericles, Callias the sonne of Hipponicus, and Nicias, not onely to necessitie, but to pouertie and beggerie. Who, after their money waxed scant, and turned to a very lowe ebbe, they thrée drinking a poysoned potion one to another (which was the last cuppe that they kissed with their lippes) passed out of this life) as it were from a banket) to the powers infernall.

div.head: ¶ By what meanes friendship is kept and mainteined.
div.p: VNto Leoprepes Ceus, the father of Simonides, as he sat on a time, in the appointed place of wrestling and games of actiuitie, two yong men came, which were of his acquaintance, and asked him howe it might be prouided, that their loue and friendship might be knit and lincked to continuance, and remayne inuiolable many yeres and dayes. Vnto whose demaunde Simonides shaped this answere. Mutuus amore assiduitat sociatur, si amicitia coniuncti ne{que} mutua ira concitati, ne{que} dissidentes animis, alter alterum irritarit. Loue may long continue without breach, if one friend prouoke not the other to anger and indignation, with contentious myndes, but agrée together, like concordes in musicall instrumentes.

div.head: ¶ Of the sodeyn outrage and madnesse of Thrasyllus.
div.p:
THrasyllus Aexoneus, was haunted with a straunge, rare, and a miraculous kynde of madnesse, for hee went into Piraeum, forsaking his owne countrey, And whyles he tooke vp his dwelling thereaboutes, all the shippes which lay at anker in that hauen,
he imagined to be his owne, yea the force of his frantique phantasie wrought so effectually in his braine, that he thought vndoubtedlye, they were all his by good title and interest, in so much that hee registred the number of them in a paire of tables. Moreouer if any ship arriued safe, sounde, and vnshaken, he reioyced aboue measure. In this mad sicknes he continued a long season, vntil his brother comming out of Sicily had committed hym to a cunning phisician to be healed, who taking him as his pacient, & ministring such confections as he thought necessary, deliuered him at length from that disease. This Thrasillus, when hee fell in communication of the life which he led during the tearme and space of his madnesse (whereof he made mencion oftentimes) he affirmed that his hart was neuer more glad and light, then when he saw ships saued from wrack, spoyle, and daunger, notwithstanding none of them were his, neither in whole nor in part.

div.head: ¶ Of Electra.
div.p:
XAnthus the versifyer, who was the Legat of Stesichorus Himeraeus, saith, that Electra the daughter of Agamemnon was not called by that name at the firste, but that her originall name was Laodice. How then happened this, that shee was called Electra? this was an accidentall name, for when Agamemnon was dead, and Aegistus maryed to Clytemnestra, and gouerned the kingdome, she continued a maide and was vnwedded, insomuch that she waxed olde and full of yeares, so long lasted the time of her virginity. For which occasion the Grecians called her Electra, because she liued a single woman, viduated of the company of a man, or rather not regardinge the societie of a husband (for she was yoked in no such felowship before) yea,
so far was she from the degrée of wedlocke, that shee wist not what marriage ment.

div.head: ¶ Of Pampheus and Diotimus their giftes.
div.p: PAmpheus Pyrenensis gaue to Cresus the Lidian his father being yet aliue, thirty poundes fréely, who when he came to the possession of the seate royal, sent vnto him againe for a reward, a carte lode of siluer. Diogenes also hauing receiued a small portion of money, at the handes of Diotimus Carisius, vttered these words. Dij tibi tantum largiantur, quantum animo tuo cogitas, & cupis: virum nempe & donum. The Gods be bountifull vnto thée, and bestowe as much vpon thée as thou doest wish in hart, & desire in thought: namely, a man able to make retribution and recompence, and a gifte of congratulation, that lyke may be rewarded with like. This Diotimus séemed to be somwhat nice and stately of stomack.

div.head: ¶ Of Pherecides whose flesh was eaten with lyce very lothsomly for his wickednesse against the Gods immortall.
div.p: PHerecides Sirius ended his lyfe most miserably, most straungly, and most horribly, for his whole body was eaten vp and consumed with lyce: most straungely, because no man suffered the lyke punishment, and most horibly, because lyce lodged in his fleshe, and scrawled in all partes of his body, as Caterpillers vpon trées in the spring of the yeare, when fruites bee younge.

This Pherecides when his face appeared most yrcksome
and ougly to looke vpon, he absented him selfe out of the company and countenance of his acquaintance, and forbeared the fellowship of his friendes. If any man came vnto him, and demaunded howe he did, he putting one of his fingers which was withered, and wasted away in a most miserable manner, out of the keyhole of a dore, made this answere. Totum corpus perinde se habet at{que} digitus iste. My whole body, from the crowne of the heade, to the soule of the foote, is in the same case that this finger is in which you sée. The people Delienses say, that the great God in Delus being moued mightely wyth wrath and indignation at this man, punished him with this most grieuous plague and lothsome perplexitie. For Pherecydes vpon a time sytting with his schollers, bragged and boasted very much of his owne wisedome, and among all other wordes which he vttered, spake these following, with great pryde, ambition, and insolencie. Etiam si nulli Deo rem facram facio, nihilo iniucundius, ne{que} tristius vitam ago, quā qui Hecatombas sacrificant. Although I do sacrifice to no God, yet my lyfe is as pleasant and as voyde of sorowe in euery respect, as the life of such as offer an hundred beasts for an oblation. This arrogant and mallapart spéech, leauened with contempte of the Gods, and sauouring altogether of disdaine of the religious ceremonies, purchased to Pherecydes that sharpe and bytter punishment, which he not vndeseruedly suffered.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexander, who was of this beliefe, that there were worldes without number.
div.p:
I Can not measure my selfe with modestie, but must of necessiti, laugh at Alexander the sonne of Philip. For when he heard that Democritus in diuers of his bookes helde opinion, that there were worldes infinite and innumerable,
hée was smytten and stung to the harte with great anguish, because he was not Lorde, King, and Emperour of one world among so many. What néedeth it to declare how Democritus laughed at him, sythence it was his propertie, and accustomed fashion to doe no lesse.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the fourth Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The fifth Booke of the variable history of Aelianus.
¶ Of Tachus who finished his lyfe, by geuing himselfe to excessiue fare.
div.p: TAchus the Egiptian, so long as he contented himselfe wt moderate diet, vsed his owne country fare, and leda thrifty & commendable lyfe. No man in the worlde was more healthfull in body then he, but after yt he came among the Persians and framed himselfe for a time to their excessiue fare and belly cheare, being vnable to continue long in their straunge dishes which hee was not acquainted withal, he fell into a disease called Dyssenteria a fretting of the guts, and in the ende lost his lyfe, by reason of his superfluous & vnaccustomed diet, which ingendred the dyssentery, and the dyssentery wearied him to death.

div.head: ¶ Of the order and maner of Pherecides his death.
div.p:
PHerecides the master of Pithagoras, being assaulted and oppressed with sicknesse, fel firste into a hot sweatyng agonye, which was slymy and ilfauored lyke vnto filthy mooldinesse in sighte, and as thicke as byrdlyme to a mans féelyng. Anon hee became as it
were, putryfied and rotten carrion, after that his fleshe turned into spraulyng lyce: and then lo, the substaunce of his body mouldered and became méere muck, so that at the last, one alteration successiuely following another, hée dyed a most miserable death.

div.head: ¶ Of the pillers of Hercules.
div.p: ARistotle affirmeth yt those pillers which are now called the pillers of Hercules, before the assumption & taking of this name, were called the columnes or pillers of Briareus. But after that Hercules had scoured the seas & the Land, and had, no doubt, very well deserued of all men, they blotted the remembraunce of Briareus with obliuion, and named them the pillers of Hercules, to his high honour, dignltie, worthines, and renoune.

div.head: Of certaine plants and trees which flourish in Delus.
div.p: The reporte runneth thus, that in Delus the Oliue trée, and the Date trée flourisheth most fruitfully, which when Latona had touched, shee was sodeinly disburthened of childebyrth, whereas before shee could not be delyuered.

div.head: ¶ Of the pouertie of Epaminondas, and of his Lordly disposition.
div.p:
EPaminondas had but one garmēt to couer his nakednes & no more, which was not very good nor skant worth wearing, if al things be true which ar reported, for it was
slouenly and yll fauoured, which is an argument that it was very simple, if at any time he sent the same to the fullars, his choice and chaunge was so great, that hee was constrained euen for extreame néede, and beggerlynesse, to tary at home and kéepe him within the dores, for hee had none other, but that alone, to put vpon his back. You heare how rich he was, what his wealth was you vnderstande, and you are not ignoraunt of his substance, yet when the king of the Persians sent vnto him a great treasure of golde for a gifte he receiued it not. Now wyll you heare my iudgement concerning them both. He, as I suppose, was more magnificent and lordly disposed that tooke not the golde, then he which gaue the golde.

div.head: ¶ Of the voluntary and willing death of Calanus.
div.p:
THe ende of Calanus deserueth no lesse cōmendation, then it procureth admiration, it is no les praise worthy, thē it is worthy wōder. The maner therfore was thus. The within named Calanus being a sophister of India, when he had taken his long leaue & last farwell of Alexander king of Macedonia, and of his life in lyke maner, being willing, desirous, and earnest to set himselfe at lybertie from the cloggs, chaines, barres, boults and fetters of the prison of the body, pyled vp a bounefire in the suburbs of Babilon of dry woodde, and chosen sticks prouided of purpose to geue a swéete sauour & an odoriferous smell in burning. The kindes of wood which hee vsed to serue his turne in this case were these. Cedre, Rosemary, Cipres, Mirtle, and Laurell. These things duely ordered, he buckled himselfe to his accustomed exercise, namely, running and leaping into the middest of the wodstack he stoode boult vpright, hauing aboute his head a garlande
made of the gréene leaues of réedes, the sunne shining full in his face, as he stoode in the pile of stycks, whose glorious maiesty, glittering with bright beames of amiable beuty, he adored and worshipped. Furthermore he gaue a token and signe to ye Macedonians to kindle the fire, which when they had done accordingly, hee being compassed round about with flickering flames, stoode stoutly and valiauntly in one and the selfe same place, and dyd not shrincke one foote, vntil he gaue vp the ghost, whereat Alexander meruailyng, as at a rare strange sight, and worldes wonder, saide (as the voice goes) these wordes, Calanus potentiores hostes debellauit quam ego, Calanus hath subdued, ouercome and vanquished stronger enemies then I. For Alexander made warre against Porus, Taxilas, and Darius. But Calanus did denounce and bid battell to labour, & fought fearcely and manfully with death.

div.head: ¶ Of Anacharsis.
div.p: THe Scythians trauell onely in the coastes of their owne country: but Anacharsis being a Philosopher furnished and fenced with the excellent instruments of wisdom and knowledge, aduentured further a great way. For he came into the region of Graecia, and was much made of, and greatly set by, and estéemed of Solon.

div.head: ¶ How some men haue forborne, and paciently put vp frumpes flouts and scoffes.
div.p:
SCoffes, floutes, frumps, reuilinges, and semblable language, flowing from a foule and a filthy mouth, haue no force (in mine opinion) of themselfe, for if they bee
throwne out and cast at a man of a sound iudgment, a stedfast minde, and a constant nature, they vanishe lyke smoke in the ayre. But if they be attempted and vsed against an yll disposed person, and such a one whose conditions are corrupt, whose maners are peruers, and whose behauiour is preposterous and mischieuous, they preuaile mightely, and work many efects, for oftentimes (as wee sée) they do not onely inffecte the hartes of men with momentany sorow, and transitory anguish, which passeth away in tract of time, but driue them to desperation, death, and destruction. Will you that I borrow an example of both? Socrates, when he was villanously reuiled, scoffed, skorned, and taken vp lyke a dishclout in an open Interlude, was so far from conceiuing gréefe and vexation of minde, that hee fell in a laughter considering their folly. But Polyagrus cōtrariwise was so impaciēt in this point and therewithall so desperate, that hee made no more a doe, but strangled himselfe.

div.head: ¶ Of Aristntle,
div.p: ARistotle hauinge consumed, spente, and wasted all his stock of money which was left him by inheritaunce, after the death of his father, vsurped the office of a souldiour and went on warfare. Alterwardes, his lucke being crooked and froward, and his fortune ilfauored and stark naught, he tooke vpon him to be an Apothecary, and frequenting the Philosophycall Schoole called Peripatum, where Plato taught, & hearing the readinges and reasonings there vsuall (for somuch as he of nature was much more excellent then many of them) he acquainted himselfe with the right trade of their exercises, which in processe of tyme, he professed and put in practise.

div.head: ¶ The number of Ships, and armed men which the Atheniens lost.
div.p: THe Atheniens alwaies prouided them selues a nauy of ships with great dilygence, and carefulnesse, and being subiect to the chaungable countenaunce, and variablenes of lady fortune, were somtimes conquerours, and somtimes conquered. They loste two hundred galleis in Aegipt with al the furniture vnto them belonging. Furthermore this was a warranted statute and ordinaunce among them, saide they, Bouem aratorem, qui iugum trahit, vel in aratro, vel in plaustro ne mactes, Slay not an oxe which beareth the yocke, either goyng to plough, or going to carte. They render a reason of their law, Quoniam ille etiam agricola est, & humano generi laborū socius, because the selfe same, in lyke maner, is a husbandman, & a felow labourer with men in their tillage, and necessarye practises.

div.head: ¶ Proper places in Athens appointed for the Assise and Sessions to the maintenaunce of iudgment in sundry matters.
div.p:
THere were certaine speciall places appointed in Athens for the court of Assise and Sessions to be kept in. If any man offended the lawes by committing wylful murther, iudgement was prosecuted in a place called Martius Pagus. Yf a man transgressed the ordinaunces of the land by committing murther against his wyll, not thinking to haue done so foule a fact, the Sessions were kept at a place called Palladium. Moreouer, if a murtherer were apprehended, and acknowledged hymselfe
guilty, but the controuersie requyring canuassing, whether the fact were wilfull, or chaunce medley, whether there was any right or iniury in the same, then iudgment did procéede in Delphico.

div.head: ¶ An eluish boy condemned to dye for stealing church goodes, and holy reliques.
div.p: A Litle eluishe boy taking vp a golden plate which fell from Diana her Diadem or crowne, and carryng the same away with him, was apprehended, arrayned and pronounced guilty. The Iudges therfore being somwhat parciall, and loth to geue sentence definitiue to his condemnation and death, supposing that the boy did the offence of simplycity, rather then of any voluntary disposition, commaunded the officers to lay before the boy a plate of golde, and a timbrell or pipe, or a top and scourge, or some such lyke childish toy, to try whether of the twain the boy would elect and choose, or leaue and refuse: The officers dooing as they were commaunded, and experience taken in the sight of the whole Assise, the boy was brought fourth, and bydden take his choyse of the things which lay before him, he put fourth his handes to the plate of golde, tooke it vp, and offered to put it in his pocket agayne as he did before, which thing the iudges perceiuing and considering the corrupt inclynation of the lewde lad, stayed iudgement no longer, but as he had committed shamefull sacrilege, so was he punished in the order of a théefe. No compassion or pittie proffered in respecte of his tender yeares, but sharpe reuengement pronounced for his felonious fact.

div.head: ¶ Of the superstition or superfluous deuotion of the Atheniens.
div.p: THe Atheniens nurssed supersticion in the cradles of their harts, and fostered vaine reuerence with too precise vsage: For it was agréed vpon among them, that who soeuer durste scrape and shaue any thing of from the monument of any noble and renowmed personage, should not escape with impunity, but for his trespasse committed, lose his lyfe. Moreouer they punished Artabes bitterly and sharply, because hee had chased and wearied the sparrow of Asclepius to death. Wherefore as his misdéede was death, so his rewarde was death, his iudgment was death, his desart was death, his punishment was death. Thus did the Atheniens, hauing consideration, neither of his ignorance, nor yet of his madnesse, but preferring sacred and holy things before other outward circumstances, lesse auaileable. This Artabes was thought and supposed to haue done the déede aforesayde contrary to his knowledge and vnderstanding. Othersome say that hee was no in hys right minde, but out of his wits when he fell in the within named offence.

div.head: ¶ Of a woman condemned to die which was great with Childe.
div.p:
THe Iudges of Areopagum whē they had brought before them a woman which was a sorceresse and witch, her accusers standing at the bar and geuing euidence against her, insomuch yt she was founde guilty, and sentence of death vttered against
her. Howbeit, because shee was at that present season great with Childe (and it séemed singuler iniustice that the infant should dye being innocent) shee was not forthwith executed, but deliuered back againe to the Iayler, vntill such time as she was lightened, which time being past and expire, she was punished for her méere trespasse of sorcery (the blamelesse babe being saued harmelesse) and as the measure of her merits required death, so death she suffered.
