div.head: ¶ How Aeschilus escaped without daunger, albeit he was accused and condemned of impietie.
div.p:
AEschylus the Tragedie writer, for a certaine representation & show whiche he made in an open play, was condemned of impyetie and vnreuerence towardes the supernal gods. Now when the Atheniens had prouided the instrumentes of his torments, and were prepared to stone him to death: Amintas the younger Brother, putting of his garment in the common assembly of the people and great multitude, shewed his naked arme which wanted a hande, differing very litle in lyknesse from a stumpe, vnto all that were present (This Amintas was one of the princypall and chéefest at Salamis where he lost his hand in fighting, and got the noblest name among all the Atheniens.) The Iudges beholding the hurt happened to the man, and considering the lack of so necessary and requisite a lymme, pondering al so how, when, and wherefore he lost the same, callyng also to remembraunce what feates of actiuytie and marciall prowesse he had done in
times past, were tickled with compassion, pardoned Aeschylus for Amintas sake, and set him at lyberty againe, notwithstanding he was condemned.

div.head: ¶ Of the fasting of the Tarentines and the Rhegineans.
div.p: WHen the Tarentines were assaulted and beséeged by the Romanes, they were intangled and trayned in such nettes of desperate distresse, that a man woulde haue sworne that the force of famishement, and the gréedye grating of horrible hunger would haue constrayned them to yéelde.

The Rhegineans fasting euery tenth day, victualled the Tarentines. Wherefore when the force of the Romanes fayled, and the Tarentines recouered lybertye, they ordained a feastiual day in the remēbraunce of their former misery and distresse, which they called by this name Ieiunium.

div.head: ¶ That Medea murthered not her owne Children.
div.p:
SOme say that it is a false tale which is blowne abroade of Medea, for shee did not kyll her Children, but the Corinthians did such a déede. The reporte which touched Medea so narrowly arose vppon this occasion. Euripides at the requestes and intreataunce of the Corinthians, imagined and fayned such a thing to be, insomuch that the sun of truth was blinded and darckned
with the clowdes of lyes, by reason of the Poetes wittie inuention, and skilfulnesse in his arte and profession. And now the voice goes abroad very common, that the people of Corinth, in consideration of their foule offence wrought vpon their owne sonnes, offer sacrifices pacificatorye vnto them, and pay vnto them, as it were a certaine tribute of duty.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the fifth Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The sixte Booke of the variable history of Aelianus.
¶ Of certaine mens anger, vngentlenesse, wrong, violence, and reprochfull vsage.
div.p: AFter the Chalcedonians were vanquished and ouercome, the Atheniens diuided their lande which was called Hippabota into forty porcions. But the temples of Minerua they left in the place named Lelantum. All the residue of their land they did let out for rent, not so much as the pillers which ioyned to the porch royall but contained monuments to be hyred and let out. As for their prisoners and captiues they layd them fast in fetters, neither thought they this sufficient, but let the furiousnes of their anger flame further, which was kindled against the Chalcedonenses.

The Lacedemonians, after ye Messans were vanquished did take and possesse the halfe part of euery thing in Messania, what so euer. They vrged frée women by compulsory meanes, to goe furth to funerals, to bewayle and lament straungers which were dead, who pertained vnto them in no kinde of respect or circumstaunce.

They left some men to plough and till the land, othersome they solde, and many they murthered and put to death. The Atheniens vsed the lyke crueltie, for when fortune fauored & smiled vpon thē, notwithstanding they had prosperous successe, yet their vsage was not tollerable, nor their behauiour moderate, sober and commendable. For they constrayned the daughters and yong damsels of
such newcome dwellers as were amonge them, to beare boothes before their daughters and damsels, so dealt they in lyke maner with their women and maryed wiues: as for the men, they compelled them to carry mattockes, shouels, spades, and other thinges, at their appointment, vpon their heads and shoulders.

The people Sicyonii, when they had taken Pellena, they abused the wiues and daughters of the Pellenenses most villanously, as it were in a commō, filthy, and stincking stues. (O euerlasting God) a déede moste damnable, and vnséemely for a beastly Barbarian and trecherous Turke (in my iudgement and opinion) to commit.

When Philip was conquerour in the Cheronean battell, as well hee himselfe, as the Macedonians were meruailously puffed vp with pride for the puissaunt déeds and feates of chiualry which they had done. The Grecians, standing in feare of him, yéelded vp themselfe into his hands, according to their seuerall cities. The Thebans did nolesse. The Megarians, the Corinthes, the Achaians, the Elians, and the Euboians, all which bordered by the sea coastes did the lyke. Philip, notwithstanding their submission and humilitie, stoode not to the couenaunts which he had contracted and made with them, but (contrary to iustice, right, and equitie) brought them all into bondage, captiuity, and seruitude.

div.head: ¶ Of the strength and manhoode of Harmacodius his sonne.
div.p:
THe sonne of Harmacodius Thespiensis accompanied with other Citizens to succour and ayde the Atheniens, at the firste assault and encounter, fought stoutlye, couragiously, and manfully. In fine when all his weapons were worne, wasted, broken, and quite spoyled, he continued the conflict still,
buffityng his enemies with his hands and fists, and so did finish and ende his lyfe with nolesse renoume, praise, puisaunce and glory, then admyration. Wherefore I haue called ye yongman after ye name of his father & his cuntry, and haue extolled hym with Homericall commendacions. His proper name whosoeuer be desirous to vnderstand, let hym séeke els where, and be resolued.

div.head: ¶ Of the young springall Isadas.
div.p: THe Lacedomonians crowned Isadas being but a springall, and such a one in déede as the law allowed not, ne yet admitted to battell: which rewarde Isadas receiued, because he behaued himselfe valiantly in the wrestlyng place. Howbeit, the selfe same Isadas, because he (his age not requiring it) rushed vppon his enemies with vnusuall weapons, and fence not accustomed, was punished accordingly, at the determination of the foresayde Lacedemonians.

div.head: ¶ Of a youngman, to whom Lisanders daughter was betrouthed.
div.p:
AFter Lysander was deade, a certaine yongmā which had geuen faith and truth towards wedlocke vnto Lisanders daughter, (a proper yong damosell and a wise wenche) did not perfourme that indéede which he pretended in word, for the mayden being left fatherles, and Lysanders case, after his decease, founde nothing so good as was thought, & beléeued, ye youngman reuolted from his vow, and shrunke from his promise made in the way of marriage, affirming precisely that he wolde neither medle nor make further with her in that matter.
The magestrats Ephori vnderstanding of this dealing, by a common voice, consent, and agréement, punished the yongman as an offender. For it was not (as they supposed) ye point of Lacedemonian honesty and conscience, nor agréeable to the nature of Grecia, that any man shoulde crack his credit after the death of his friends to whom he made solemne promise, and by that meanes prefer riches and wealth before his oth and couenaunt.

div.head: ¶ Of the Embassadours of the Atheniens.
div.p: THe Atheniens put their Embassadors to death, their Embassadors, I say, whome they sent into Arcadia. And why? Because they went not the way which was commaunded them, but tooke a contraryway. This rewarde had they notwithstanding ye discharge of their message, and the accomplishment of the preceptes whereto they were deputed and put in office.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine Lacedemonian lawes.
div.p:
DO not these ordinaunces smell of Lacedemonian discipline? it is a lawe among the Lacedemonians or Spartanes, yt hee which had deliuered thrée sonnes to the common wealth should be priuiledged from watching both by day and by night, he which delyuered fiue sonnes shoulde not be burthened with any publique office and buisie charge, so highly estéemed they procreation of Children, and increasing the multytude with bodely
issue, it was a law amonge them also that no marriages should be made for dowries. Moreouer that such as went to warfare should be apparelled in purple, to thintent that the coulour might represent greater force, and that drops of bloud spirting out of the wounded flesh, & sprinkled vpon their attire, might strike the more feare and terrour into the hartes of the aduersaries, the sight of the same pearcing their senses more vehemently.

Furthermore it was not lawful for a Lacedemonian, to take from their enemies, no not the booty or spoyle: But such Spartanes as shewed themselfe stout and valliaunt, and lost their liues in battaile couragiously, were crowned wt garlands of olyue & other braunches, to their great praise, cōmendacion, & aduancement. Such also as prooued themself conquerrours, indéede, & fought it out wt strength and manhood in streames of bloud, they were not only clad, in purple robes gorgeously, but they were also, buried most gloriously.

div.head: ¶ Of an Earthquake which was in Sparta.
div.p:
AT what time the Spartanes, or Lacedemonians, violently, proditoriously, and traiterously rebelled against their seruitours the Teraneans, making a butchery and slaughter of their bodies (these seruitours were of the race and dissent of the Eilotanes) Neptune was in a great rage, in a heauy displeasure, and a hoat anger, in somuch that there arose a terrible Earthquake, which put the Spartanes fearing no such violent storme, to great vexatiō and trouble, and shooke the whole Citie so mightely, that throughout the compasse and circute of the same, were left but a
very few tenements standing.

div.head: ¶ Of the slaughter and murthering of Artaxerxes.
div.p: ARtaxerxes, who was lykewise, syrnamed Ochus, when as Bagoas the Aegiptian Eunuche had wrought his destruction by snares and priuy practises of deceipte, in somuch that the one, to his vtter desolation loste his lyfe, and the other to his contentation had that which he sought: his fleshe was cut in morsels and mammocks most miserably, and cast to cats to gnaw vpon and to deuoure. In whose place another was buryed, and layde vp in the sepulchre royall. This Ochus had bin a long practised pilferer and stealer of holy things from sundry and diuers temples, and specially from Aegipt. The aboue named Bagoas was not satisfied with the murthering of Ochus, but hee sought further meanes to staunche his cruell desire, for hee caused the thigh bones of Artaxerxes to be sawne in sunder, to be fyled, to be scraped, to be shauen, to be carued, and made handles for swordes and daggers. Hoc fecit vt ammum suum ad caedes prop ensum repraesentaret. This dyd hee to geue a manifest token and signification of his tyranical stomack gréedely set vpon manslaughter and bloudshed. He hated him somuch the more because hee had slaine the white oxe in Aegipt whom they worshipped for their gracious God, as Cambises had likewise done before.

div.head: ¶ Of the treasure which the people Delphi sought for in the temple of Apollo.
div.p:
BEcause there ran a rumor to Delphos, by the meanes of Homer his verses, that Apollos Temple, in auncient
time, was most riche, and wealthy, which verses are these.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.p: Sounding thus in English.

q.l: Nor yet such riches plentyfull, of siluer sine, & golde.
As doth Apollos temple pau'de with stone, containe & hold.

div.p: This reporte dyd so kindle the mindes of the people at Delphos with such a desire of couetousenesse, that they beganne with mattocks and spades to digge about the altar and the thréefooted table called the Tripod, thus they continued digging and vndermining, vnto such time as most horrible Earthquakes suddenly arose, then loe they considered of their doynges, and accounting that which happened as a premonition and forewarnyng of further mischéefe to follow, left of from their enterprise.

div.head: ¶ A lawe made by Pericles to priuiledge Citizens.
div.p:
PEricles the Captayne of the Atheniens enacted and made a law, that it should not be tollerable nor permitted, that any should be aduaunced to the gouernment of the common wealth but such as were borne and bred of Parentes beynge both Cityzens. The force of which lawe stretched out vnto himselfe: For his two sonnes Patroclus and Xantippus, being both sicke of an extreame pestelence and plaguy feauer, neuer recouered their health, but dyed. To sée and consider the sequeale if is somwhat straunge, for Pericles departyng out of the worlde left behinde him certaine sonnes misbegotten,
commonly called bastardes, from whom the authorytie and priuiledge prouided for the administration and gouernement of the common wealth, was withdrawne and vtterly taken away, by the meanes of his owne decrée and ordinaunce.

div.head: ¶ Of Gelon being willing to restore regiment and rule to the Subiectes.
div.p: GElon, after hee had vanquished the Carthagineans in a foughten field at Himera, brought all Sicily into his rule and dominion. Afterwardes he goyng forth into the place of resorte called the market place, naked, vnarmed, and voide of furniture, made an Oration to the assembly, saying that hee was willyng to resigne and geue ouer to the citizens, their rule and authorytie, who refused his offer after the tryall of his courtesie, because he was more homely in conuersation and more base in behauiour, then was decent or séemely for a King. And therfore standeth his simulachre or image in the temple of Iuno, starke naked without any garment or cloth to couer the skin. The bare body of which dumb and spéechlesse picture, setteth before the eyes of the beholders the déede of Gelon, and reuiueth the remembraunce of hym.

div.head: ¶ Of Dionysius his beatitude and happinesse, and what ende was alotted to the same.
div.p:
DIonysius the seconde of that name, was well appointed, established, and confirmed in his kingdome: hee
had in his possession no lesse then foure hundred Ships, he had in his possession a great number of Gallies, some of fiue orders of oares, and some of sixe, he was furnished with footemen, amounting to the number of a hundred thousand, and his horsemen were at least nine thousand by computation.

Moreouer, the Citie Siracusae was defended, and substancially maintained with very great hauens, and compassed about with high, mayne, and mighty wals. Finallye he had all warlyke prouision and necessaries at hande in a redinesse in fiue hundred Ships. Besides all this hee had plenty of Corne in store, about a hundred thousande quarters in measure. And as for hys Armorye that was filled with shealds, swordes, speares, morris pykes, harnesse for the legges, brest plates, gauntlettes, helmettes, calléeuers, partizens, bowes, and quyuers (these same bowes were of Dionisius his own inuention and deuice) furthermore he had confederates and league fellowes innumerable, redy at a becke to ayde hym by theyr power, and what was it that Dionysius wanted. The aboundaunce of his wealth, and this his plentyfull prouision did so infect his hart with the poyson of pryde, that he bearing himself bould, & to to lusty hereupō, thought his kingdome, and Empire fast founded, and grounded vpon hard stones of Marble or Adamant. But marke the sudden alteration & chaunge of his felicitie, & ponder how Fortune tourned al things topsie turuey, for first of all he procured his brethren to be murthered, then he saw his sonnes cruely slayne before his face, besydes that he behelde his daughters shamefully and villanously abused, and at the last murthered as naked as they were borne of their mother. To be bréefe, none of his posterytie and ofspring enioyed that kinde of buriall which they looked and hoped for, and why? Some of them were burnt aliue and consumed to ashes, othersome were mangled, slashte, and
gasht and throwne into the salt sea, this sowre and vnsavery sawce was serued him when he occupied the kingdome of Dion Hipparinus, and as for himselfe, such was his luck, such was his fortune, that when he was an olde man, and had séene many dayes and yéeres, hee finished and ended his lyfe, not in courtly iollity, not in ruflyng brauery, not in aboundaunce of riches, but in néede and penury, in patcht beggery, and in extreame wretchednes. Theopompus sayth that hee lost both his eyes with vnmeasurable glutting and swillyng of wine, insomuch that he became as blinde as a block, or a béetell. Furthermore, that his custome and fashion was to sit in barbars shops, tellyng tales to such as came to be notted, shauen, and washed, and moued them to mirth and laughter by his behauiour in speach. Finally that he led his lyfe in the middest of all Grecia beastly, vndecently, and lothsomly. This mutation, chaunge, supplantation, and ouerthrow of Dionysius from such wealth, such worship, such renowne, and such maiestie, into such pouertie, such shame, such necessitie and nakednesse of all things, was, and may be an effectuall and forceable example, a spectacle, and warning, to admonish men of their estate, and to printe in the tables of their minds that they ought to intertaine temperaunce, to harbour honesty, to imbrace modesty, & highly to estéeme commendable maners.

div.head: ¶ Of tyraunies which continued in Grecia, but to the ages following.
div.p:
IT is worthely (no doubt) prouided by the gods immortall, that no tyranny is lynked to long continuance, but abridged before it come to the third generatiō. They crack the yoke therof, they bruse, and breake it lyke a réede, yea they spoyle and depriue tyrannes children of all force and violence. Among the Grecians
these tyrannies are onely recounted, (time out of minde) to haue lasted to the next line of affinitie, namely, the tyranny of Gelon in Sicily, the tyranny of the Lucanes in Bosphorus, and the tyranny of Cypsellus ofspryng in Corinth.

div.head: ¶ Of Darius being layd in waight for to be taken.
div.p:
THis déede doth import and signifie vnto vs a certayne singuler gentlenesse and courtesie in Darius the sonne of Hydaspis. Aribazus Hyrcanus layde snares to intangle and take hym, and so did more besides him, which were men of no small countenaunce and worship in Persia. These snares were cast in the game of venery or hunting, and as they were a bréeding, Darius perceiued them, and was not for all that, discouraged with any fearefull conceipt, but with boldnesse of spirite bad them take their weapons and their horses. In the vtteraunce of which wordes hee cast a sowre, a stearne, a grimme & a Saracen visage vpon them, and manifestly vnderstanding wherabout they went he saide, vnto them yet againe. Quid igitur non exequimini id, cuius gratia venistis? Why doo you not, sayth he, dispatch your purpose, in respect of the accomplishment whereof you be resorted hether? When they behelde the countenaunce of Darius to be so farre from feare, that it represented a lyonlike boldnesse, they did not only withdraw their force and violence, but were also so amased, so terrified, and agast, that they threw downe their speares, lighted of their saddels, and did humble obeisaunce vnto Darius, submitting them selfe & proffering their voluntary seruice, to doo whatsoeuer he gaue thē in cōmandemēt: Darius seperated thē one from another, and sent one into the borders of India, and
another into the coastes of Scithia, and they both, from that time forward, being mindful of his gracious benefit, were faithfull vnto hym, were obedient, and full of dutye and allegiaunce. Thus did he preuent the present perill of those which layd in waight for his lyfe, wherein was no lesse wisedome then polycie declared.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the sixte Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The seauenth Booke of the variable history of Aelianus.
¶ Of Semiramis, and how she conueied the kingdome of Assiria into her owne possession.
div.p:
OF Semiramis some say this, and some set downe that, and amonge all other thinges this (as deseruing a monument of sempeternall memorye) is recorded that shee was the moste bewtifull, the most amiable Lady and Quéene throughout the vniuersall worlde, albeit shee dyd litle regarde her fine proporcion, her excellent comlynesse, her angelicall grace: and had no respect to ye trymming & decking of her body wt gorgeous garments, & robes of royalty. It fortuned yt this Semiramis, by reason of the rumor and fame of her surpassing beauty, was sent for into Assiria, that the king of that region might satisfie himselfe with the sight of her péerelesse maiestie, before whose presence she came according to the tennor of the message. The King of Assiria, had no sooner cast his wanton eye vpō her, but was forthwith inflamed with the fire of affection towardes her. After certaine circumstaunces ouer passed, she required of the King a rich rewarde, namely, a robe of estate, the gouernement of Asia for fiue dayes continuaunce, and the absolute authorytie in all thinges that were done in the kingdome. Which peticion of the Quéene was granted vnto by the king, no deniall made to the contrary. In conclusion when she was set and established in the throne of maiesty, and had gotten all things (without exception) in the gripes of her aspiryng minde, she commaunded the
king to be slayne, whereby he was dispossessed of his dominion, and she presently therevpon enioyed the scepter and crowne imperiall ouer Assyria vniuersall.

div.head: ¶ Of the delicates, the disportes, and wanton toyes of Straton and Nicocles.
div.p:
IT is reported that Straton Sidonius, applyed his wit and will to excéede and go beyond al men in superfluitie, ryot, and magnificence, Wherevpon Theopompus Chius compareth his life, to the gormondising and belly cheare of the Phaeacenses, whiche the Poet Homer according to his custome and knowledge, hath described in his Odisses. This lustie youth was not contented to haue one alone present at his feasting and sumptuous table, to moue his mynde to myrth, with the swéetnesse of songs and sonets, and such like instruments of pleasure, but scarsely satisfied with a multitude of wāton women, some cunning in musick, some expert in playing vpon the pype, and suche like practises of lasciuiousnesse. Moreouer, he had the company of arrant whores and strong strumpets, but yet braue and beautiful at his banket. And besides all this, selected dauncers, to kindle his greater delight amidst his excessiue cheare. He coulde in no case abyde to heare of one which was equall to him in the aboue named spectacles of leudnesse and prodigalitie, whervpon sprang a certaine strife and contention betwéene Nicocles Ciprius & him, whiles the one did what he could to excel the other. O vaine and ridiculous emulation, not arising in the behalfe of vertue, but of bellycheare, not of commendable demenour, but of beastly behauiour. For when the one had vnderstanding by commers and goers, of the others conditions and fashions in
feasting, such spitefulnes, such repining, such ambition, & grudging was ingendred in the hearts of them both, that the one, with might and maine, with tooth and naile, with shippe and saile, laboured with all possibilitie to passe beyonde the other: But to say the very trueth, neither of the twaine did enioy these their delicates, and disportes continually, and why? because violent and sudden death assaulted them whereby they were cut short, contrary to their expectation.

div.head: A speach of Aristippus very conuenient to asswage sorowe.
div.p: ARistippus, when certaine of his friends, vexed and tormented them selues wyth vehement and bitter lamentations, vttering many thinges to mitigate their griefe and heauines of heart, spake these wordes vnto them, as an entrance to further communication. Non venio vt ad vestros dolores meum adiungam, sed vt vobis omnem moerorem ex animis eximam. I come not hether (my friendes) to annex my heauines to your pensiuenes, but to expell and banish out of your mindes all anguish and vexation.

div.head: The commendation of a mill.
div.p: PIttacus precisely praised a grinding mill, and ascribed great commendations to the same, because that, it being contained in a little compasse, setteth many to worke labour and exercise. There was a ballade made thervpon called Epimylion, the song of the mill.

div.head: ¶ Of the handy worke of Achilles and Vlysses in many and sundry thinges.
div.p: LAertes the Father of Vlysses was founde at his handy worke and bodely labour, namely, grafting and planting, at such time as hee stouped forwarde by reason of his feablenesse and aged yeares. Furthermore Vlysses sayeth of himselfe that hee was well séene in the knowledge of many things, and perfectly experimēted and practised to worke them with his hands, the verses wherein the vaunting speach of his cunning is comprised, are these.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,
Viribus haud potuit quisquam contendere mecum,
Ad bene condendos ignes et ligna secanda.

div.p: Thus in English.

lg.l: No man was able, t'ncounter with mee,
In cunningly cutting downe wood from the tree,
And makyng of fires which vsed must bee.

div.p: He made Ships and vessels to serue vpon the Seas, by the dillygence of his owne labour and cunning workmanship. And Achilles in like maner, obtayning the third place next Iupiter, playde the butcher, in cutting out of fleash, the cooke in dressing it, and making the same ready to be serued in at a supper, which he prepared for the intertainement of certaine Embassadours that came from the country of Grecia.

div.head: ¶ The aunswer of a Scythian to a demaunde concerning colde.
div.p: WHen aboundaunce of snow fell vpon the face of the earth, from the grosse and congeled cloudes, the king of Scythia questioned with a certayne odde fellow, whose custome was continually to goe starke naked, and demanded of him if he felt not the horror of colde ransacking his fleash & sinewes. The which question propounded, this Scythian did absolue with an other demaunde, namely, whether his forhead might féele the coldnesse of the wether? whereunto the king made aunswer and sayd no. Why then sayeth the Scythian should not I suffer and indure the sharpnesse of frost and snow, séeing I am nothing els but altogeather a méere forehead?

div.head: ¶ Of the watching and nightely studies of the Orator Demosthenes.
div.p: PYtheas scoffed at the Rhetorician Demosthenes, saying that his oratory exercises sauored of the candle, because he consumed the whole night season in watching without winking, and studying without sléeping, meditating and committing to the tables of remembraunce such matters as hée was to publysh in the common conuent and assembly of the Atheniens.

div.head: ¶ The lamentation and heauynesse of Alexander for the death of Hephaestion.
div.p:
AT what time Hephaestion was dead, Alexanders minde was much moued with sorrow, insomuch that he cast his armour, his riches of gold and siluer, a Persian garment of great valuation and price, into the bonefyre with the carcasse. Moreouer he caused all his warlyke and marciall souldiours to become shauelyngs, not exempting himselfe from the communion of their vncomfortable chaunces, but including his owne person within the fellowship of their fortune, wherin he séemeth to tread ye trace, & to follow ye footsteps of Achilles of whō ye poet Homer maketh mention. But yet neuertheles hée vsed more violence then the other, insomuch as he ouerthrew ye fortres of ye Ecbatanes. So far forth therfore as he shaued of his haire, he dyd lyke a Grecian (in my imagination) but in that he fell to batteryng and racyng downe wals, fences, & such like munitions, his lamentation is leauened with ye behauiour of a Barbarian. He chaunged likewise his robe of royaltie, offeryng, and opening a gap and frée passage, to sorrowfulnesse, to teares, to complaintes, and heauynesse. Hephaestion let his lyfe at Ecbatana, the reporte was that the circumstaunce before rehearsed, were prouided for the dead body of the sayde Hephaestiō, but destiny (whose dominion is vniuersall) so wrought in this matter, that all the abouenamed preparation was bestowed vpon his owne carkasse. For the anguish and sorrow which Alexander conceiued through the decease of Hephaestion, tooke such déepe roote in his bowels, that being vnable to refraine heauinesse, he was
in lyke maner swallowed and deuoured vp by death.

div.head: ¶ Of a continent, chast, and vertuous matrone.
div.p: WAs not this continence incomparable, this sobriety singular, and this vertue péerelesse? deseruing (in my iudgement) a common admiration? For the wife of Phocion, wore Phocions garment, she had no néede of a traine gowne purfled and embroydered, plighted and garded, shee had no néede of a rounde silcken kertle to beautyfie her body, she had no néede of a costly call hung with glittering spangles of golde and siluer, she had no néede of lawne sléeues and neckerchers of fine lynnen wrought with curious flowers and intricate knots, she had no néede of gorgeous attire stayned with the princely colours of purple and Crimson. But firste and principally shee apparelled her selfe with temperance, and so consequently sought for other thinges necessary.

div.head: ¶ Of Xantippe the wife of Socrates.
div.p: TT what time Socrates his wife Xantippe by name, refused to put on his garment, and in that sorte to goe abroad and beholde sumptuous sightes and pleasant pageants, he sayde vnto her. Vt quam non spectandi causa, sed potius vt specteris, abeas, video. I perceaue thy goyng abroade is not to sée, but rather to be séene.

div.head: How the women of Rome vsed to be shod.
div.p: MAny of the Romanish women accustomed to weare such shooes as the men did weare.

div.head: ¶ The Apophthegme or short sentence of Lysander concerning periury.
div.p: CHildren muste be circumuented and compassed in subtely with playing at cardes, dice, and tables, but men must be inclosed and deceitfully dealt with all by periury and foreswearing. Som ascribe this saying to Lysander, othersome attribute the same to Philip of Macedonia. But whether of the twayne was the author of this sentence, he wandereth wide (in my iudgement) from the pathway of iustice and equitie. Neither may it séeme a thing absurd and repugnaunt to reason in that I dissagrée from Lysander, for he vsed tyranny. Of what minde therfore I am in this case it is manyfest and euident, in that I much mislyke of the foresayde sentence.

div.head: ¶ Of the pacience, and sufferaunce of Agesilaus.
div.p:
AGesilaus of Lacedemonia being an old man and hauing séene in the course of his yeares many choices and chaunges, went abroad oftentimes, barefote, barelegd, and a ragged cote vpon his back in the colde morning of sharp and frosty winter. When one rebuked and blamed him for
behauyng himselfe more childishly and boylyke then became his old age, if (sayeth he) I should weare a youthfull garment ouer this, the Citizens of the younger sorte would stande staryng vpon me lyke a company of Asses and Mules.

div.head: ¶ Of Philosophers that were both warriers and magestrates.
div.p: WHy should not learned Philosophers be accoumpted skilfull in battell? in mine opinion there is no impediment to the contrary, for Architas was elected six times by the Tarentines to supply the place of their Captaine. Melissus had the gouernement and charge of a battell fought by sea. Socrates marched in battell ray, and went on warfare. Plato in lyke maner was at the assaultyng of Tanagra, and the beséeging of Corinth. As for Xenephons voyages, his exploytures, his feates of armes, and practises of puisaunce and magnanimitie, many haue moste largely written of them, and he himselfe in his bookes of Cyrus maketh mencyon sufficiently. Dion suppressed the tyrany of Hipparinus Dionisius. Epaminondus Boetarchns being sent to Leuctra vnquished the Lacedemonians, and was principall among the Romanes and the Grecians. Zenon wroughte many things wisely and worthely for the Atheniens against Antigonus. For, whether succour be ministred by counsell, aduisement, and polisie, or by manhood, courage, an actiuitie, it is not to be called in question.

div.head: ¶ How the league felowes of the Mitylenenses were punished for sweruing from allegiance.
div.p:
WHen the rule, power, dominion, and authorytie of the Mitylenenses stretched ouer the seas, they executed
this punishment vpon their league fellowes, which had drawne their necks and shoulders out of the yoke of their communion, and shrunke from the participation of their seruice, that it should not be lawfull for them to traine vp their children in learning nor in ye knowledge and experience of liberall sciences, supposing this of all punishments the sharpest, namely a lyfe in vnskilfunes, and ignoraunce of al arts lyberall.

div.head: ¶ Of Rome, of Remus, Romulus, and Seruia.
div.p: THe Citie of Rome was founded and builte by Remus and Romulus, the sonnes of Mars, and Seruia, who were of the dissent, lynage, and ofspring of Aeneas.

div.head: ¶ Of Eudoxus comming into Sicilia.
div.p: WHen Eudoxus was come into Sicilia, Dionisius intertained him courteously with aboundaunce of wordes, geuing him thankes in lyke maner for his comming. But Eudoxus not flattering him with semblable affabilitie, without soothing or smoothing the matter, sayde thus to Dionisius, Veni quasi ad bonum hospitem, apud quem Plato diuerteret. I am come hether (as to a common Inne) and a frée harbouring Oaste, with whom Plato shoulde be lodged and bourded, meaning indeede that he came not so much for his owne sake, as for Dionisius behoofe.

div.head: ¶ That the Aegyptians are patient in tormentes, and of the women of India.
div.p: THey say that the Aegyptians patiently suffer torments, and constantly indure the stinging smartes of the same, and that they will sooner dye the death, being pittifully pinched and payned with the horrour of punishment, rather then they will acknowledge and confesse the truth. Among the Indians also, the women of that countrey are so courageous, bolde, and manly, that they dare plunge into the fire, with the deade bodyes of their husbandes. They boyle in like maner with the fire of emulation, many women louing one man, till lottes be cast to end the controuersie, and she vpon whom the lot lighteth, obtaineth her louer, & is content to be burned with him.

div.head: ¶ Of Solons Strategemme against the Megarenses, and how he conuinced them with words.
div.p:
SOlon in a battell fought for an Island by Athens named Salamis, played the valiant captayne, and tooke a couple of great temples or churches (as we call them) wherein he put the chiefest of the Atheniens, and gaue to his souldiers the haruesse of the enemies to weare, and so circumuented the Megarenses which were vnarmed, that there was a great and a bloudy slaughter made of them: he conuinced them also, not with finesse & curiousnes of vtterāce, but with substancial arguments built vpon a firme fundation. For he opening the old & aunciēt reuositories, shewed al ye Atheniens lying towards ye west
after the custome of the country. But the Megariens disorderly and confusedly buried. Of which thing the Lacedemonians declared the occasion.

div.head: ¶ Of an olde man of Ceus that dyed his haires.
div.p: AN olde man of Ceus comming to Lacedemonia, being puffed vp with pryde and swellyng with insolency, was, for his fatherly olde age, had in reuerence, and honour, insomuch that hee couloured his hoary head ouergrowne with gray haires. This olde man comming into an assembly of Lacedemonians, discouered his head for them to behold, and made a declaration of such matters about which he cam. Archidamus the king of the Lacedemonians rysing vp, sayde in this wise, what sounde and true tale canne the toung of this felow reporte, whose hart is stayned with spots of hipocrisie and double dealyng, and whose head is coloured with counterfect comelynesse. Thus would hee in no case alow the wordes of the olde man, but vtterly reiected them, taunting the euill inclynation of the olde mans nature, by those circumstaunces which were obiect to the fight, and apparaunt to the eye.

div.head: ¶ Of the diligence of Caesar and Pompey, in learning such things as pertayned to the administration and right gouernaunce of a common wealth.
div.p:
Caesar disdained not to frequent the thresholde of Ariston, nether did Pompey think skorne to go oftentimes to the house of Cratippus. For their principallytie and
honourable estate were not alluremntes to drawe them from vertuous studies, nor spurres to pricke them forward to the contempte of such thinges, as were thought both commodious and commēdable for them to imbrace: yea they were glad and faine to request and beséech them (notwithstanding their titles of renowne) to impart some principles of Philosophy vnto them, Non enim imperare, vt apparet, sed rectè imperare cupiebant. For they desired not to gouerne only (as it appeareth) but gouerne prudently, vertuously, and politiquely.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the seuenth Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The eight Booke of the variable history of Aelianus.
¶ Of the spirite of the Philosopher Socrates.
div.p: SOcrates had this communication, concerning his spirite which alwayes did accompany and folow him, with Theagenes Demodocus, and diuers other, that oftentimes he harde a heauenly voice ful of maiestie (which sayeth he) at such time as it soundeth in mine eares, it signifieth a dehortation and a spéedy intermission from the thing which he purposed to accomplish, but the selfe same voyce doth neuer perswade mee to attempt any thing. Moreouer, if any of my frindes make me of their counsell touching any waighty businesse, and this voyce chaunce to sounde, it is a forewarning that he must not continue or perseuer in his intent, & this voyce maketh me pertaker of his secret aduise. Then I, imbracyng the heauenly premonitions of this sacred sounde, resorte to my familiar friend, who craued my iudgement, and withdraw him quite from the thing which he determined to doo. In this behalfe he recited Charmis the son of Glauco for a witnes, who vpon a time woulde néedes buckle himself with al preparation to go vnto the games and showes of Nemea, this voyce was hard immediatly, speaking vnto Socrates, wherupon he dissuaded Charmis from his purpose, but hee not admitting Socrates faire warnyng, receaued such a recompence as his labour deserued.

div.head: ¶ Of the the wisdome of Hipparchus, and of his loue towardes his instructours, and of Homers verses.
div.p:
HIpparchus, the sonne of Pisistratus, as hee was the eldest of all his brethren, so was he the wisest Gentleman amonge all the Atheniens, he was the firste that brought the verses of Homer into Athens, and compelled musicians (appoynted for the lyke purpose) to sing and sounde them in an open assembly, and common audience of Grecians. He sent also a nauye of fifty sayle, for Anacreon Teius to come vnto him, he made very much of Simonides Ceus, to whom he cleaued as cloasely as the skin to the flesh, or as the flesh to the bone, or as one ioynt to another, bestowing vpon him many great gifts, precious Iuelles, and royal rewards who indéede, was soone perswaded, where any hope of gayne remayne, or any commodytie was graunted, for if I should report vnto you the insatiable couetousenes, and gréedy yawning of Simonides, hunting after money and mundained muck (which moldereth away lyke mosse,) I thinke there is none to stande in contradiction with mée, that will say I burthen him with an vntruth. This Hipparchus spent all his time, his studie, dilligence, and labour, in the company and societie of such as excelled in wisdome, knowledg and vnderstanding, wherein he was to the Atheniens, a bright burning bearō, directing them by his lyght to the loue of the lyke labour, wherein he applyed himselfe to surpasse them all, and did his vttermost endeuour yt his gouernment might be linked to learning, and the Atheniens the better disposed. Hee supposed moreouer, that no man should be enuyed for his wisdome, because he himselfe was both bountifull and vprighte,
These thinges are reported of Hipparchus by the pen of Philosophycall Plato, whose scholer and disciple he was.

div.head: Of the slaughter of a bullock amonge the Atheniens, and of their festiuall dayes called Dijpolia and Buphonia.
div.p: IT is a custome and a vse continued among the Atheniens, that when they haue stayne a bullock, they pronounce al things frée and vnguilty (after particular iudgement geuen orderly in euery case) by proclamation. The sword only, as the comitter of the murther, they accuse, and also condemne. Finally the dayes festiuall, wherin these things are performed, they call by these names Dijpolia, and Buphonia.

div.head: ¶ Of the wastfull and foolish prodigally tie of Poliarchus.
div.p: POliarchus was so grafted & grown in foolysh prodigallytie, and excessiue nicenesse, that he would bring forth the dead carkasses of dogs and cocks (if hee loued them when they were liuing) & gather al his frendes and acquaintance to the buriall of them, wherein he spared no costes, charges nor expences: for he raised vp out of their graues great pillers, and caused Epitaphes to be carued in the same.

div.head: Of Neleus, Medon and the twelue cities of Ionia.
div.p: NEleus the sonne of Codrus being driuen out of his kingdome left Athens, because the oracle of Apollo had appointed the Empire for Medon who departed out of the citie into a place sometime solitarie, and not inhabibited, and he arriued at Naxus (as he sayled on the seas) not according to his will and wishe, but by the violence and outragiousnes of the tempestes. Then would he full faine haue lanched from that Land, but contrary windes arising stopped his passage with their blustring blastes, being therefore lefte, as it were in a laberinth of doubtes, the Magicians tolde him that his army should be clensed and purified, because many of them which were vnder saile with him, had polluted their hands with bloudshed, wherfore he fained that he had murthered a childe, & that he vpon that occasion, stoode in néede of a purgation, as well as the residue: by which example of his owne person he perswaded all that knewe them selues offenders to pleade for an expiation. Which being brought to passe, & they manifestly knowne that were trespassers, he forsooke their felowshippe and left them behinde to inhabite Naxus. But Neleus him selfe came into Ionia, and ariued first at Miletum, driuing out the Cares, the Mydones, the Leleges, and other barbarous people of whome the twelue cities in Ionia were named, whose appellations be these, Miletus, Ephesus, Erythrae, Clazomenae, Priena, Lesbus, Teus, Colophon, Myus, Phocaea, Samus, and Chius. And he procured many mo cities sittuate vpon the continent or firme land to be inhabited.

div.head: ¶ Of the ignoraunce, and want of knowledge which was in the Barbarians.
div.p: OF the auncient Thracians there was not one indued with the precious iuell of learning. The Barbarians also which inhabited Europa, thought it a thing most filthy, discommendable, and reprochfull, to haue knowledge and vnderstanding. The people of Asia (as olde recordes testify) attayned cléerer light of learning and discipline, wherupon they were so bolde as to auouche that Orpheus, the experte musician, wanted wisdome, and what was the reason which they rendred? forsooth, because he was a Thracian bred and borne, they affirmed likewise, that his sonets, verses, and dities were fearsed with foolish fables, stuffed with triflyng toyes, and seasoned with the leuen of lyes. Thus much hath Androtion committed to the monuments of memorye, if any man account his authorytie worthy credite, in the within named circumstances concerning the grose ignoraunce and vnskilfulnes of the Thracians.

div.head: ¶ Of a wedding solemnised by Alexander after Darius was vanquished.
div.p:
ALexander, after he had vanquished Darius, made a wedding banket for himself and for his frends, ye nūber of ye womē whō they should marry were by cōputation, foureskore & ten, and as many bedchambers. The pallace which was assigned for the seruice of the feast and the intertainment of the guests, was of great capacytie and receipt, contayning in it, no lesse then an hundred tables, al which stoode vpon frames of siluer, & the table royall vpon a frame of golde. They were couered with carpetes of purple, and with sundry sumptuous clothes of outlandish worke being of great price and estimation.
He entertained straungers to bee his guestes, whom he commaunded to sit downe directly against his owne person. There sat in the common hall or pallace at the celebration of these weddings, both land and sea souldiours, horssemen, embassadours, purseuants, and strangers of Grecia. Before the messes of meate were serued in, the trumpet did sound an alarum to assemble them together when time required that the tables should be furnished, there was in lyke maner, another alarum sounded, when they should arise being sufficiently refreshed. The solemnization of these marriages were of fiue whole daies continuance. There resorted to these feasles, cunning musicians, practised players, as well tragicall as commicall, representers of pleasaunt interludes, as of stately and pitifull discourses, not a few. There came also thither crafty and subtile iugglers, which shewed many straunge and wonderfull castes of legerdemaine which they brought wt them out of India, who in their arte and exercise far excelled the iugglers of al other countreis.

div.head: ¶ Of the art or science of porturating or painctyng.
div.p: COnon Cleonensis perfourmed & made perfect the arte of painting, when it did as it were, but bud and blossome, being vsed in his time without knowledge and cunning, and when it lay as it were in ye cradle wrapped in swathling clowts, hauing attained no maturytie and ripenes of liuelynes, for the which his trauaile he receiued a reward of greater value then al the paineters and limmers that were before him many yeares.

div.head: ¶ Of a tyrant, that was murthered by the hands of his paramour.
div.p:
ARchelaus a tyraunt of Macedonia (for so Plato tearmeth him & not a king) was murthered by the handes
of his paramour whose name was Cratenas, that lusted no lesse after the kingdome, then the tyrane longed after the loue of him. Cratenas therefore slew Archelaus vpon hope of possessing the seate imperiall and princely prosperytie. But Cratenas the paramour, hauing binne king, scarcely thrée or foure dayes space, was layde in waight for, and murthered in semblable maner by the meanes of other men. To this Macedonian déede, this verse agréeeth as it were in a musicall consent.

lg.l: Who seeketh other men t'insnare
Nets for himselfe he doth prepare.

div.p: For it is registred that Agesilaus promised and betrothed one of his daughters vnto him, whom hee afterwardes contrary to his couenaunt bestowed vpon an other, which déede kindled such indignation and fury in the bowels of Cratenas, that he became the manqueller of Archelaus.

div.head: ¶ Of Solon and his statutes, and of the lawes of Draco.
div.p:
THe Atheniens did choose wise Solon to gouerne and rule the bodye of their common wealth, not by hap hassard (as they saye) but by voyce and consent, who anon after he was admitted and established in the administration therof, he adorned and beautified the Cittie with many goodly things. He did write actes and Statuts for their better estate which they obserue at this present
day ratyfied & confirmed. They kepe them religiously and inuiolably without any breach. Then did the Atheniens adnihilate and make of no force the bloudy ordinaunces of Draco, called Thesmi, which were writen in wodden tables or plates of brasse. But the lawes and statutes made concerning manslaughter was not abolished.

div.head: ¶ Of the consuming and wastyng away of thinges which seemed euerlasting, and of the wyde worlde.
div.p: WHy shoulde we muse, and maruaile that man is mortal, and in subiectiō to death? knowing that his nature is vncertayne and transitory: and therefore his lyfe, is of no long continuance, muchlesse of perpetuity. We see before our eyes that thinges of great induraunce, namely, floudes and seas haue dryed vp and became drie lande, and that mighty mountaines haue consumed, and at length became hollow bottomes and low valleies. Thus say some which passe perilous biages vpon the seas, aledging in this behalfe the highe hill Aetna, which appeareth lesse in sight by a great parte then it was woont to be. The same obseruacions are to be noted in the two tottering mountaines of Parnassus, and Olympus Piericus. Moreouer they which professe themselfe to be most skilful in the coagmentation and nature of the worlde vniuersall, affirme that it shal vanish, consume, waste, perish, and come to nought.

div.head: ¶ Of Demosthenes, Aeschines, Theophrastus and Demochares.
div.p: PEraduenture it may séeme a lowd lye, but yet it is a substancial truth, yt whē Demosthenes wit faynted, & his vtteraunce fayled him in Macedonia, Aeschines Cathocides the sonne of Atromita was of flourishing fame and renowne among the Macedonians, and excelled al other Rhetoricians in iudgement, vtterance, and counsell.

The occasion why Aeschines had such fortunate successe in his exercises, was the beneuolence of king Philip, his liberalytie, his attentiue hearing, his fauourable countenaunce, and rich rewardes, besides that, many euident demonstrations of his bountifull affection conceiued towards Aeschines, all which circumstaunces were incouragements, and prouocatiōs to the Orator, to boldnes of minde, libertie of inuention, copy of wordes and flinging out of eloquence. The aboue named infirmyties were not incident, onely to Demosthenes, that excellent Rhetorician in Macedonia, but to Theophrastus Eresius also, for he at such time as he should haue made an oration in Areopago, was vnable at that instant by reason of some soddaine preturbation, albeit (no doubt) sufficient in knowledge and vnderstanding, which defection of his at that present he couered with this excuse, namly, that he was abashed at the authorytie of the Senate. To which speach of Theophrastus, Demochares very spightfully, but yet not vnaptly, made this aunswere. They which sate in iudgement (Theophrastus) were magistrates of Athens, and not the twelue Gods full of maiestie
and power: meaning yt it was enough to tremble at the presence of the supernal gods & not at ye sight of mortall men, albeit, most honourable.

div.head: ¶ Of such as neuer laughed.
div.p: ANaxagoras Clazomenius (as it is recorded) was neuer séene laughing, or perceiued to smile from the day of his natiuity and birth. Aristoxenus in lyke maner, did wonderfully bridle himselfe from laughter. And to conclude, Heraclitus was at such detestation and defiaunce with laughing, that wéeping was the gayest and the brauest flower in his garland, for he wept at euerything that he saw, whatsoeuer.

div.head: ¶ Of the death of Diogenes.
div.p: DIogenes Sinopensis, being so sorely assaulted with the force of sicknes, and drawyng towardes his death, threw himself toppling downe from a bridge abutting next to ye common place of exercises, and commaunded the kéeper, or ouerséer, that when lyfe fayled, and breath was quite departed, he would cast his carkasse into the riuer Ilissus. Adeò pro nihilo duxit mortem & sepulturam Diogenes. So litle regarded Diogenes the inuasion of death, or the tranquilytie and quietnesse of the body in the graue.

div.head: ¶ Of the continency of Philip, and of what thing his pleasure was to be put in remembraunce.
div.p: PHilip hauing conquered the Atheniens in Chaeronea, notwithstanding fortune had set him a floate in felycity, yet he brideled his affections with reason, & dyd so moderate the motions of his minde, that he inferred wronge to no man. Wherefore he thought it necessary and auaileable for the auoyding of insolency and alienation of behauiour, that one of his pages or chamberlaines, euery day, early in the morning should knocke at his lodging and put him in remembraunce that he was subiect to mortalytie. This was the office and charge assigned to his page, neither would the King set his foote ouer the threshoulde, neither was licence graunted to any man, to haue accesse to the kings maiestie (no not in ponderous causes) before his page had pronounced this sentence, thrée seueral times a day, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . O Philip thou art a man.

div.head: ¶ Of Solon and Pisistratus
div.p:
SOlon the sonne of Excecestida at such time as hee was aged and had séene many yeares, began to misdéeme and to haue in suspicion Pisistratus of hunting after the power imperiall ambitiously, and of a desire to exercise tyrany. When he went among a great assembly of Atheniens, requiring the ayde, succour and
assistaunce of the people, Solon perceiuing the Atheniens negligently lystening to the wordes which procéeded from him, but geuing ayme as it were to Pisistratus, and leuellyng their cogitations to his person, sayde that hée was craftyer then some, and stronger then other some, for who aspyred not to the vnderstanding of this, namely that he would become a flat tyrant, if he might get garde for the preseruation of his person, hee was craftyer then they: and who perceiued and knew it well inough, & yet drowned their vnderstanding, in that poynte obtayned, with silence and pausing from speach, hee was stronger then they. Neuertheles when Pisistratus had obtayned power sufficient, hee chaunged his coppy, and became a tyrant. Solon sitting at the gates of his manour, stretched out both his handes holding in the one a speare, and in the other a shielde, and with his gesture vttered these words seasoned with magnanimitie & courage, that he was harnessed and weaponed, to defende his country, and to preserue the same according to the measure of his mighte, and the proportion of his strength, notwithstanding the ripenesse of his yeares in that poynt prohibiting, and his inhabilytie of bodely fortitude, which séemed to reuoke him from the seruice of a captayne or souldiour, yet his hart, his lyfe, his bloud, and his breath, was (as he sayde) payable for his country which hee fauoured as himselfe. So Pisistratus (whether he was woon with the wisdome and worthynesse of so reuerend a gentleman, or reclaymed with the remembraunce of his youthfull yeares (for he was reported to haue binne Solons paramour) as hap was did him no harme. In processe of time Solon waxyng very olde, and droupinge downwarde through the extremitye of age, and weaknesse, ended at lengthe, his lingring lyfe, and left behind him singuler spectacles, principall praises, and honourable commendations of his polycie, his manhood, his puisaunce, and valiantnesse
as sempiternall monumentes of his remembraunce neuer vading, but euer flourishing. In whose worthynesse and dignitie (after his death and funerall) according to the measure of his merits, a standing image was erected and set vp in publique place of common concourse and popular resorte, and a sepulchre was néere to the wall gates at the right hand of the entraunce, and there was built vpon his graue a tumbe passing fayre and beautyfull.

div.head: ¶ Of Oenycinus, the king of the Zanclaeans.
div.p: OEnycinus a Scithian, the king of the Zanclaeans, when he came vp to Darius into Asia, Darius supposed him in iustice and equitie to surmount and excell all other which came out of Grecia: because he went to the king into Cicily, to require peace, and tooke his iourney backward againe to the king, from Cicily. But Demonides the Crotonate did not so, and therefore Darius gaue him these trecherous termes, naming him a subtile, a craftie, a deceitfull, a fraudulent, and a naughty fellow. So the Scithian led his lyfe in Persia enioying prosperytie and happynes, and his felycity remayned in her gloryous and chaungeable colour vntyll the day of his death.

div.head: ¶ Of Eutymus, and of a noble man in Temesa, and of a prouerbe.
div.p:
Eutimus Locrensis the chéefest and the best wrestler in all Italy, was supposed to be wonderfull stronge and stoute of body, and of might incredible and beyond all beléefe, for the Locrenses shewed a certayne stone of a merueylous
monstrous magnitude and bignesse which hee did lifte vp lustely and layde in the open streate, Moreouer there was a noble man in Temesa, who was collector of tributs and subsidies of the inhabitants and borderers theraboutes, whom Eutymus depriued of his authority and put beside the vse and commodity of his office, for comming to his temple, whereunto the vulgar sorte might not haue accesse, Eutymus chalenged him to wrestlyng, and held him tacke so stoutly & strongly, yt he cōstrained ye other, to restore much more then he receued, much more then he purloyned. Wherupon sprange a prouerbe, aptely agréeing, to such as gather gaine gréedely, but yet reape not ye profit of their hoorded haruest. That the noble man of Temesa wil come to them in visitation. Furthermore, it is reported, that Eutymus, when he went downe to the floud Caetis, whose streame ronneth by the citie of the Locrenses, vanished out of sight and appeared no more vpon the earth, whereby it may be supposed that he was taken vp into the heauens and crowned with immortalytie, or els that some other sudden and straunge metamorphosis or alteration happened to the man in a moment of time, and the twincklyng of an eye which séemed miraculous to the mindes of people.

div.head: ¶ The Epitaph which was ingrauen vppon Anaxagoras Tumbe, and of his Altar.

lg.l: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

l.hi: Hic situs ille est cui rerum patuere recessus

lg.l: The bones of him in this sepulchre lye
Whose passing skill did many secrets trie
And caused truth descend from heauen hie.

div.p: There was, likewise, erected vnto him an Altar, wherupon was written an epainetical posy, or Epigramme, in the honour of vnderstanding, as the other was dedicated in the renowne of truth. Of his lyfe Diogenes Laertius writeth abundantly in his booke intituled De vitis Philosophorum. Where his opinion, in like maner, which hee held in sundry circumstaunces is largely declared.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the eight Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The ninth Booke of the variable history of Aelianus.
¶ Of Hiero an earnest louer of learning, of his free hart and liberality to all men, and of the faithfull frendship and vnitie which he did professe, and practise towardes his Brethren.
div.p:
HIero of Siracusae, bare special goodwill and affection to Gréeke learninge, and had knowledge in high reputation. In distribition and larges he was notable, ye more redy was he to geue then the asker was to receaue, hee was in lyke maner of a commendable courage, and his stoutnesse of mind was worthy principall praise. Moreouer it is recorded in the registers of remembraunce, that this Siracusan Hiero vsed company and fellowship of his thrée brethren, with no-lesse affection and friendlynesse then became fraternitye and brotherhood (all iarring, all strife, all debate, variaunce, and dissention vtterly suppressed) woonderfully louing them, & being recompenced againe wt semblable measure of amitye and kindnes. He led his lyfe, all after one sorte, with Simonides and Pindarus, neither did the olde crooked age of Simonides hinder him, from hauing accesse and recourse vnto Hiero: for he was inclyned to
couetousnes, and gréedely geuen to the desire of money, and how much, the liberall dealyng of Hiero was inlarged and encreased so much the more was the couetous minde of Simonides kindled and inflamed.

div.head: ¶ Of the victory of Taurosthenes.
div.p: THe victory of triumphing Taurosthenes was made manyfest to his father (as some affirme) by a certaine fantasie, imagination, and vision, and declared vnto him by reuelation, from Olimpia to Aegina, in one daies space which is a very small and a short time in consideration of so great distaunce of place. Otherso in say that this Taurosthenes tooke a pigeon out of her nest from her broode which were skarsly fledged, being but latly hatcht, and crept out of the shell, which hen pigeon hee tooke out of Aegina and carried the same with him into Pisa. So that at such time as he woon the victory, he tyed a ribbend of purple silke about the pigeons legge, and immediately threw her vp into the open ayre, which libertie of wings being obtayned, she prepared her flight with great swiftnesse from Pisa to Aegina in one dayes space, to her young ones which were left in the nest, whereby intelligence and vnderstanding was geuen of Taurosthenes his victory.

div.head: ¶ Of diuers mens superfluous finenesse, and of Alexanders sumptuous curiositye.
div.p:
ALexander was so infected with superfluous finnesse yt he corrupted many of his friendes and companyons
with the same spice of his prodigalitye. Agnon was so neate and nice in his attyre, that he ware golden buckles, and siluer nayles in his shoes. Cletus, also, whensoeuer he was to pleade any cause in the courte, his apparell was altogether of purple, in which kinde of gorgeous garment he vsed to shew himselfe in the presence of his Clients, and in the sight of the iudges that sate vpon the deciding and due determination of the matter which was in controuersie. Furthermore Perdiccas and Craterus being altogether geuen, and déepely delighted in the practise of wrestlyng, and in semblable games of actiuity, and had a great many gotes hides, (or as some suppose bucks skynnes) which were sowed one to another, carryed after them, which were in measure and length six hundred, twenty and fiue féete, wherewith they compassed and inclosed a large plot of grounde beside their campe, yt they might therin exercise themself conuenientlye, no impediment or hindraunce to the contrary withstanding. There did follow them also, a great deale of drye sand and dust, which was carryed after them in waynes and cartes drawne with oxen, all which were appertenaunces and vtensiles to the necessitie of their game. Leonnatus and Menelaus, both skilfull, conning, and paynefull hunters, had a hundred, twenty and fiue elles of Tapestry worke carryed after them. Alexander in lyke maner had a pompous and princely pauilyon, garnished and decked with a hundered Tables, euery table hauing fifty grauen pillers to stay and vnderprop it, and also to bewtyffe and adorne it. Which tables beside their multytude of pillers, where polished and trimmed with gold guilt, variable workmanship, artificially, cunningly, and curiously compact. There stoode rounde about him a goodly company of Persian Pensioners named Melophori, which were attyred in robes some of crimson, some of purple, some of murry, some of yellow, & some of orange colour veluet. Next vnto thē a thousande
archers in garments of bright red silk and skarlet, before them a hundred Macedonians armed with siluer shields, and in the middest of the campe was a golden throne erected, whereupon Alexander vsually sate to heare and vnderstand the causes of such as had any suite or supplication to his maiestie: the guarde of his body compassing and hemming him on euery side, Moreouer there was a trench round about the camp, which a thousand Macedonians, and ten thousand Persians did defend and kepe, so that no man durst be so hardy, presumptuous and bolde as once to come néere the kings person: For there was a great and a terrible feare crept into mens hartes, because of Alexanders ambitious, hautye, and arrogant minde, and his frée fortune furnished with all felycity, which was altered and tourned to tyrannicall regiment.

div.head: ¶ Of the diligence of Policrates in hearing Anacreon. And of gelousie.
div.p:
POlicrates Samius did imparte and bestowe much dilligent labour in learning, and made very much of Anacreon Teius, to whom hee dyd cleaue in vnfayned kindnesse, beyng greatly delyghted not onely in the company of his person, but also in the sugersome swéetnesse of his posies, howebeit, notwithstanding the premisses, I cannot account his excessiue behauiour in carnal knowledge worthy commendation. Anacreon aduaunced Smerdias the Paramour of Polycrates with a peculier praise, wherin the young striplyng reioysing, had Anacreon in worship, and reuerence, who loued the proper youth for
his wit and gentle nature, and not for any externall qualytie of body: For no man (by the Gods immortall I dare sweare) can speake any thing in reproch of this poet Teius, or once accuse him of vnchaste and incontinent behauiour: But Polycrates being kindled with the sparckles of gelousy, suspecting that the Poet loued the striplyng Smerdias excéedingly, shaued of the golden lockes of his head, thereby (as hee supposed) to make the louely youth misshapen and ilfauoured, and Anacreon, in lyke maner, heuy and sorrowfull, whose gelous déede in this respect the poet being disposed to rebuke, yet in such sorte as his purpose might not be playnly perceiued, vsed subtilty and dissimulation in this behalfe, transferring the fault from Polycrates the Agent, to Smerdias the pacient, whom he charged with great folly on the one side, & with rash bouldnesse on the other side, in that he spared not to clip and shaue of his owne hearie bush and fayre tuskes, with an edge toole. But let Anacreon, in his owne person, reporte the vnlucky losse of these louely lockes, for he can declare it more orderly, by many degrées, then my Penne can expresse it.

div.head: ¶ Of Hiero and Themistocles.
div.p:
THemistocles séeing Hiero comming to the games and pageantes at Olimpus, and with him a fayre troope of horsemen, withstoode and resisted him, saying these wordes followyng for a confirmation of his déede. Qui maximi periculi se socium non praebuerit, non aequum est, vt communis conuentus particeps fieret. He which in mayne hassard withdrew his helping hand, and assisting ayde, it was no right nor reason, that such a one should be admitted and receiued into open assemblies and common méetinges of people, to view and behold the stately showes and games
of the country. For which cause Themistocles purchased a precise commendation.

div.head: ¶ Of Pericles and his sonnes which dyed of the plague or pestelence.
div.p: PEricles was depriued of his children in a hot and infectiue sicknesse of the pestilence, yet was he so far from conceiuing sorrow, that hee suffered the losse of such deare & precious pledges with no lesse wisedom then stoutnes, and by his example procured the Atheniens, paciently to take the deathes of their néere kinsfolks, and best beloued friends, were they neuer so déeply planted in the tables of their harts.

div.head: ¶ Of the constant, and vnmoueable minde of sage Socrates, in all thinges.
div.p: XAntippe sayde, that though a thousande thousande troubles incombred and ouerwhelmed the commonwealth, yet Socrates was of an vnchaungeable countenāce, of an vnuariable vissage, and of an vnmouable minde, whether he went from home, or whether he retourned home, or whersoeuer hee came in company: for he was of a nature to pacience inclineable, to gentlenesse conformable, to pleasantnesse applyaunt, to sorrowe repugnant, to feare an enemy, with stoutnesse in amitye, To be shorte in all cases constant.

div.head: ¶ The lothsome lust of Dionysius towardes young women.
div.p:
DIonysius Iunior comming into the citie of ye Locrenses (for his mother Doris was a Locrean borne) tooke vp, possessed, occupied, vsed, or rather abused, the greatest, the largest, and the fayrest houses that were in all the citie, strewing them with Damaske roses, Lauender, Sauoury, and such lyke odorifferous Floures, and swéete smellyng hearbes. He sent for the daughters and younge Damsels of the Locreans to come vnto him, wt whom he had fleshly pleasure & delight past all shame, honesty, or regarde of chastity. The filthynesse of which lewde and lothsome offence abounding in him, escaped not vnpunished: for when his kingdom was rent and torne from him by Dion, the Locreans (rewarding lyke with lyke) dealte carnallye with the wife and daughters of Dionysius, inforceyng vpon them most abhomynable fornication, without intermission or ceasing. And such, specially, as were of the lynnage, consanguinitye, and kinred of those virgins and younge maydens whom Dionysius defloured, were most egar and fearce to be so reuenged. After they had satisfied and staunched the lust of their fleash with the bodies of Dionysius his wife and daughters, they tooke néedels and thrust them into their fingers and toes vnder the nayles, misserably murthered them, & stamped their bones in morters, from the which they had launced & cut collops of flesh, offering the gobbitts to be eaten, wherof, whoso refused to taste, such they abused moste villanously, and handled worse then hell houndes. The remnaunte of the slaughtered
and dismembered carkasses was cast into the Sea, there to be consumed with the wharlyng waues, or to be deuoured by monstrous fishes. As for Dionysius himselfe, after he had indured manyfold mischaunces, and sustayned sundry distresses of lyfe and estate, at Corinth, being pinched with extreame neede, he became a starke begger, and went from place to place, playing vpon a Timbrell and a Flute, and singing ballades, in the company of such as hyred him, and gaue him for his labour. This was the ende of Dionysius, and after this sorte he fynished the course of his lyfe in no lesse beggery then infamy.

div.head: ¶ That Demetrius was incontinent.
div.p:
DEmetrius Poliorcetes when hee had taken cities in seage, sellyng himselfe ouer (as it were in seruitude) to prodigalytie, and lechery, commaunded and compelled the people whom hee had vanquished and subdued, to pay him euery yeare a thousand and two hundred talents. Of which great summe hee spent a very small porcion vpon his army and souldiours, all the reste he wasted in fleshly filthynes, and consumed in lecherous lewdnes, he was washt with perfumed waters, and rubbed with compounde oyntments, and so were the pauements and flooers of his lodgings. Moreouer, besides the former expences which were idle and superfluous, fresh Floures and gréene herbes were gathered at all times of the yeare to skatter vpon the ground for hym to treade vnder his féete, so nice, and so effeminate a minyon was he. Furthermore he was greatly geuen to womens company, and addicted to bodyly delight aboue all measure, he hunted after the loue of fayre and wel fauoured youthes, and was so curious and dainty in trimming
himselfe, in preseruing his bewty, in increasing his comlynesse, and mayntayning his hansomnesse, that no woman was euer hard of, more fine in fashions then hee: for his vse and custome was to pieck and kembe his head in such smooth sort, that one heire should not lye awry. Furthermore he had a certayne kinde of liquor or strong water, wherwith he stayned the naturall coulour of his heire and made it looke betwixt red and yellow, he washed his face often with sundry sorts of oyntments, to séeme amiable and louely. Finally what labour refrayned he, what expences spared hee, to paynte out his owne prorer, and pecocklyke person.

div.head: ¶ Of Plato his contempte of lyfe.
div.p: AT what time the Academy was reported to be infected with the pestilence, the Phisicians gaue Plato counsell to remoue his schoole from the Academy into Lyceus: But he neuer a-whit agréeing to the counsell ministred vnto him by the mouthes of the Phisician, sayd. Sed ego producendae vitae causa, ne in Atho quidem summitatem transmigrare velim: I would not remoue to the high tops of the maine mountaine Athos, for the prolonging of my daies, and the preseruinge of my mortall lyfe. So litle regarded that good Philosopher the contagion of the pestilence.

div.head: ¶ Of Parrhasius the painter.
div.p:
PArrhasius the painter vsed to weare purple apparrell, and to weare vpon his head a crowne of golde. This to be no vntruth, there be many testimonials, and amonge other euidences, certayne Epigrames, inscriptions,
and posies of pictures, which he made, beare manyfest recorde. He contended for preeminence vpon a time at Samus, and chaunced vpon such an aduersary, as was able to counteruaile wt him, both in courage and in strength, insomuch that he was ouercome in the contention. The argument or theame whereupon their artificiall handy worke was expressed, was this. Aiax dimicans cum Vlysse, pro Achillis armis. Aiax standing in controuersie with Vlysses for Achilles armour. In the descriptiō of which history, Parrhasius being conquered and greatly ouermatched, made this sober, wise, prudent, and modest aunswere to a fréende of his, who was not a litle gréeued at Parrhasius his yll and crooked luck, his answere was this. Equidem paruipendo victoriam: condoleo potius filio Telamonis, qui in eadem re bis iam aduersario fuerit inferior. I passe not much for the victory my selfe, but I am sory at my hart for Telamons sonn, whose chance it is to betwise vanquished in one thing by his aduersary. He went with a walking staffe, which had wrought rounde aboute it braunches of golde. The vpper lether of his shooes were tyed with golden latchets. To conclude, it is noysed of him, that in his worke he was so far from a molested and troubled minde, that whatsoeuer he tooke in hande, he did it with a courage, with a stomacke, with a delight and a pleasure: for his vse and custome was to temper and season the painefulnesse of his labours, with swéete tuned songes, and ditties made in measure, and equall number of sillables. This is reported concerning him, by the pen of Theophrastus.

div.head: ¶ Of the Epicures, whom the Romanes and the Messanians expelled.
div.p:
THe Romanes expelled and droue out of their citie, the Epicures, namely Alcaeus and Philistus because they
were the sowers of many detestable desires, and procures of many pestilent concupiscences, and the maintainers of many misschefous lustes in the mindes of young men, wherewith they were corrupted. And as the Romanes dealt with them, so did the Messanians in lyke maner, who serued the Epicures with the same syrrup of expulsion.

div.head: ¶ Of the deuoureing greedynesse of Dionysius, and of the glore fatnesse of his flesh.
div.p:
THe common voyce is, yt Dionysius Heracleotes the sonne of Clearchus, through his immoderate glutony, superfluous fare and insatiable féeding, by the meanes wherof he waxed grosse by litle & litle, & at length became so big, that his flesh was a burthen to his bones, and his fatnes not much differing from bacon, his lymmes therefore and bodely members (in consideration of the former circumstaunces) must néedes surmount all measure, and séeme in a maner, monstrous. The fulnes of his fleash, and the increase of his fatnes, did not only hinder his speach, but also stop his windpipe, in such sort, yt he had no abilitie to vtter any voice. The physicians counsell being inquired for the remedy of yt disease, he prescribed these meanes following, that he should take long and slender wyers, sharp at the points like néedles, prouided of purpose for the same intent, and thruste them into his sides and his belly: which he not dareyng doe to himselfe, the matter was committed ouer into ye hands of another to performe & fulfil. So long therfore as ye sharp & pearceing wiers went through ye thick, grosse, superfluous, and waste flesh, he lay still like a stone, without soule, sence, or féeling: But when they touched the quick, namely the naturall fleash, which was of the liuely substaunce of the bodye, when, I say, that fleashe, beynge not ouergrowne
with glore larde and fatnesse was pricked with ye néedles, then lo began he to féele some smart, and sprang suddenly and startingly out of his sléepe. The aforesayde felow, Dionysius I meane, if at any time he had to deale in matters of controuersy betwixt man & man, and wold therein geue iudgement and pronownce sentence according to law, he vsed to haue set before his body, a great presse or a cheast, (some say it was not a presse but a litle castle or towre) to thintent that all the partes and menbers of his monstrous body might be couered and hidden from the eyes of the people, and nothing séene but his platter face only, which was a sufficent spectacle for the assembly to gase and stare vpon. After this fashion and order spake he to such as were present in the court, putting on that yll fauoured garment which was vnméete for a man to occupy, and more lyke a grate full of crosse barres to kepe in wilde and vntamed beastes, rather then for any man to vse for the couerte of his body.

div.head: ¶ Of the leanenesse and lightnesse of Philetas his body.
div.p:
BEcause Philetas the Philosopher was very small and litle of lymme, slender of ioynt, and leane of body, it is therefore reported that euery litle and tryflyng occasion was lyke to ouerthrow him, against which inconueniences he did weare shooes with yron soles, to thintent that the blustring blastes of the windes should not whurle him from place to place, and tosse him from post to piller, if at any time the weather was somewhat rough, stormy, and tempestuous. Wherefore sithence his
weaknesse was such, and his body so voyde of strength and ability, that he could by no meanes withstand ye puffing of the winde, how then I pray you would he carry any great burthen vpon his héeles? Vndoubtedly it séemeth vnto me a thing excéeding all lyklyhood and credite, neuerthelesse blame me not for that which I haue registred, for that which I haue both red and knowne I may be bolde to report.

div.head: ¶ Of the Poet Homer.
div.p: THe Argiues gaue principall praise in Poetry to Homer, all other Poets and versifyers they accoumpted his vnderlyngs. Moreouer if they were at any time to exhibit reuerence, due adoration, and worship, and to offer sacrifice, they vsed inuocation and callyng vpon Apollo and Homer in their hospitals. Finally the selfe same Poet doubting how he might bestow his daughter, and with whom to marry her, to thintent that this report should not passe amonge the people, that she had no porcion to-be geuen with her, which might hinder the mayden from a husband, assigned vnto her for her dowry certaine Cyprian poesies. As Pindarus manyfestly witnesseth.

div.head: ¶ Of Italy, and of Mares who was named Hipppmeges.
div.p:
THe people Ausones inhibited Italy first being both bred and borne in that country. It is reported also, that there is in the same Citie a very auncient and aged man, who is called Mares, whose vissage and face had the similitude of a
a man very formall, but he was lyke vnto a horse behinde in proportion and fashion, which among the Grecians is declared by this worde Hippomyges. Howbeit I am of this opinion that ther was no such misshaped monster in that country, but yt this rumor & brute bred of an accidentall cause otherwise then is supposed: namly that he was the first that did ryde horsse with bytt and brydle, brought them into subiection and obedience, tamed them & made them seruiceable for the sundry vses and purposes of men, for which occasion he might be thought and imagined, to haue bin deformed with the double nature of a man and a horsse. Furthermore it is saide that hee liued a hundred, twenty, and thrée yeares, that he died thrée times, reuiued & receiued life after death thrée tymes againe, which fable seemeth vnto me ridiculous and repugnant vnto truth thrée tymes.
