Moreouer it is said that in Italy many and sundry people inhabyt, and so many indéede, as are not dwelling in the whole wide worlde almost besides: which plentyfullnes of people is procured by this cause principally, that is to say, because euery quarter of the yeare wc them is temperate and seasonable, because their soile surpasseth in abūdance, bicause it is replenished with springs of excéeding pleasauntnes, because it is full of all manner fruits, medowes, arable lād, pastures, &c, because it containeth many faire flouds & cléere ronning riuers, because it hath the swifte sea adioyneing vnto it, because it hath many hauens belonging vnto it, to lodge ther shipps & other sayleing vessells in places conuenient, and to lawnch into the déepe when occasion so requireth. Besides all the premisses, & circumstaunces aboue rehearsed, such is the gentlnes of the Italian inhabitants, and so singuler is their courtesy, that they allure many to forsake their natiue country, their to builde, and among them to abide. Finally, they say, that Italy (time out of mind) was gayly garnished, and brauely beautyfied with a thousand, a hundred,
foure skore, and seauen famous cities.

div.head: ¶ Of the ambitious disposition, and vaine minde of Demosthenes.
div.p: THis short history registred in the monuments of antiquitie, importeth an accusation against Demosthenes, for-his lightnesse and vanitye, for it is a common voyce blowne abroade, that Porters and Waterbearers instilled the liquor of arrogancy into his harte, at such time as they whispered together one in an others eare, as he passed by them through the stréetes, for hee was tickled with their admurmurations, priuy speaches, and secret conferences, and was not a litle infected with the ytch of ambitiō. The self same Demosthenes if at any time the auditory, or assembly of people, gaue a plausible showte in his prayse and commendation, he tooke it for a custome to erect and lifte vp his body, and to stand vp on typtowe, that he might be séene ye better of the multitude.

div.head: ¶ Of Themistocles.
div.p:
THemistocles the sonne of Neocles, compared himselfe vnto Oake trées, whose strong and stretched out armes, men cannot choose but stande in néede of, to protect and defende them against rainey showers, blustring winde blastes, crackling hailestones, and such lyke tempestuous and stormy weather. The broade boughes and braunches also of the same, are no lesse necessary for refection sake, to gather the coole and fresh ayre, when the sonne shineth
bright, and the skies séeme calme and cléere. In such cases men doe not onely shroude themselfe vnder the shadow of the oakes, but for the refreshing of themselfe robbe the trées not onely of their leaues but also of their rynds. The same Themistocles was not ashamed to haue this damnable speach in his mouth. Si quis mihi duas vias monstraret, alteram ad infernum ducentem, alteram ad tribunal, multò libentius ingrederer eam quae recta ad infernum tenderet. If any man show me two seueral wayes, the one leading to heauen, the other guiding to hell, I wolde choose that way which leadeth directly vnto hell, rather of the twaine. Othersome interpret these wordes after another maner thus, if any man should set before me two sundry pathes, the one leading to the throne of estate, the other to the tumbe of vilenesse, of the twaine I had rather take ye last, and leaue the first.

div.head: ¶ Of Demosthenes whom Diogines called to come into a victualling house, and he refused and wold not.
div.p:
DIogines, vpon a certayne time entring into a victuallyng house, and spying Demosthenes passe by the dore called vnto him, and desired him to take parte of his homly fare, who refused Diogenes courtesy in that case, wherupon hee vttered these wordes following by way of reprehension: Putas, O Demosthenes, hoc esse tibi dedecori, si in cauponam ingrediaris, cum nulla dies praetereat quin Dominus tuus intrò veniat? Thinkest thou, O Demosthenes, that it is a reprochfull and shamefull thing vnto thée to be séene in a victuallyng house, siththen there is neuer a day throughout the whole yeare but thy good Lorde and master haunteth the same? Meanening the people, and euery one of the cōmonalty, because
Counsellers atturneyes, Barristers, Petyfoggers, & such lyke officers be, after a sort, seruantes, and hyrelinges to the multytude.

div.head: ¶ Of Aristippus.
div.p: ARistippus saylyng in a shippe which was shaken almoste in shiuers with the sourges of the seas, and tossed to and fro with the wallowing of the waues was afrayde out of measure, to whom a certaine man beyng of the number of the passengers which were in the vessell or barke, saide: what, art yu also flighted with feare as the common sorte be? To whom Aristippus coyned this aunswere, yea mary, and not without substancyall cause, for the care which you conceaue, and the present danger which you doubt, is only for your vnlucky lyfe, and infortunate condition: But the thought that I take is for th'imbaceing of my prosperity, the abateing of my beatitude, and the hassarde of my happines.

div.head: ¶ Of Theramenes.
div.p:
THeramenes being vnder the roofe of an house, and going out of the same (as lucke serued him) the foundation shrunck, the walles rushed togeather, the slaight came ratlyng downe, the beames fell flat to the ground, and all vpon a sudden, in a moment. To whom when the Atheniens came by swarmes, some from one place, some from another, by heaps as thick as hops, reioysing that he had auoyded the violent and mortal ruine of the house, and saued his lyfe, which a man woulde haue sworne was in desperate perrill paste all hope of
escaping: He contrary to the opinions of them all, spake these words 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , O God Iupiter vnto what time doest thou reserue me, for what day doost thou spare me? Not longe after, this Theramenes was tormented by the thirty tyrants, and being constrained to drink poyson, yéelded vp his lyfe.

div.head: ¶ What men bestowed their time in the study, and profession of physicke.
div.p: IO begin wc a singuler sect, it is saide yt ye Pithagoreans spente great payne & employed much labour in the professiō and practise of Physick. So did Plato with no lesse sedulity, & ernestnes. Sēblably did Aristole, and other Philophers infinite and innumerable.

div.head: ¶ Of Aristotle when he was sicke and diseased.
div.p: ARistotle being surprised with sicknes, a physician came to visit him, and to minister holsome counsell vnto hym for the mitigation of his malady, and the recouering of his former health, To whom Aristotle gaue this blunt language: Ne me cures vel vt Bubulcum, vel vt Fossorem, sed prius causam edissere: sic etiam facili persuasione me morigerū reddideris. Deale not, nor heale not me, like a heardmā, a deluer, a ditcher, a reaper, and a labourer: But first of all canuasse and sifte out the cause of my disease, so shalt thou win me to thy wyll, and binde me in obedience to thy precepts. By which wordes he signified that nothing is, either to be taught, wrought, or thought vnaduisedly, rashly, & wtout a resonable occasion.

div.head: ¶ Of the wantonnesse and deintines of Smyndaridas.
div.p: SMyndaridas a Sybarite borne, wallowed in such waues of wantonnesse, and was so drowned in delicatnes of lyfe that (not withstanding his country men tooke pleasure in pampering their bodies, and were wonderfull loose, dissolute, and remisse, in maners) he went beyond them in this poinct many furlongs. For Smyndaridas lying alonge, tumbling himselfe in rose leaues, and solacinge his deinty nature with sléep, anon awaked, complayneing that he had certaine bumps and swellings rysen in his flesh, by reason of the hardnes of his bed wherein he tooke his rest. How coulde this fellowe abide to lye vpon harde Boordes, vpon the bare ground, vpon a mattrisse, vpon a bedstrawe, or vpon the thinne grasse of some stiepe hill? Or how coulde he frame himselfe to sléepe in an oxe hide, as Diomedes did, which kinde of cabbynes and lodges, become a couragious captayne and a valiaunt souldiour. How, I say, coulde hee content himselfe to haue a buls hide, or the skinne of some other wilde beaste spred vnder his bones and his fleash, and satisfy his nature therewith, as with pillowes and boulstres of the softest doune.

div.head: ¶ How Pisistratus behaued himselfe towards his Cityzens.
div.p:
PIsistratus being established in his kingdome, commanded al such to be cōuented & brought before him, as spēt their time in going vp & downe loyteringly, like masterles
men of no trade, science, or occupation, and questioned with them, what occasions moued them to passe to and fro in the common stréets consuming the day in idlenesse. Thus much more also added he, saying to such as were assembled before his presence, if thy ploughing oxen be dead, take vnto thée some of mine to serue thy turne, and buckle thy selfe about some businesse, if thou lack séede to sow, go to my garners, & take of my store for thy priuate vse & behoofe. This did Pisistratus, fearing least the permission and sufferaunce of them to liue securely and idely, should one time bréede some scab of daunger against his maiesty.

div.head: ¶ Of Zeno and Antigonus.
div.p: KIng Antigonus had Zeno Citiensis in great reuerence, worship, & estimation. It fortuned therefore vpon a time that hee being ouercome with wine and drunckenesse out of measure, mette Zeno full in the face, kissing and clasping him, not lyke a sober soule, but lyke a drunken sot, and desiring Zeno to commaund him any seruice and hee would do it, binding his wordes, moreouer, vndiscretly and vnaduisedly with an oth, that hee woulde perfourme no lesse then he promised. To whom Zeon aunswered, Abi et euome. Auoyde and vomit, pack hence and spew, rebukeing in these few wordes, both wisely and soberly the drunkennesse of Antigonus, and geuing him a watch-worde therewithall, that immoderate gluttony, and vnseasonable swilling would doe him much harme and mischéefe,

div.head: ¶ Of naturall disposition.
div.p: A Certaine man rebuked a country fellow (who indéede was a Lacedemonian borne) because he wept with tears, and sorrow brusting from the very bottom of his bowells: But this Clowne and country lobbe made this witty aunswer without hypocritical doublenes and dissimulation, saying: Quid facerem? non enim ego sed natura mea mihi luctum excutit. what should I dooe? for it is not I that lament and wéepe, but my nature and inclination, which inforceth me thervnto.

div.head: ¶ Of Diogenes
div.p: A Certaine man of Sparta, aduaunced this vearse of the Poet Hesiodus to the Azur skyes.

lg.l: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

l.hi: Non vel bos pereat, nisi vicinus malus adsit.

lg.l: It cannot be an oxe should dy,
Except yll neighbours dwell hard by.

div.p: Diogenes héering that, sayd to the Spartane in this maner. But the people Messenii dyed, and lyke lucke was alotted to their oxen: and you are their nexte neighbours.

div.head: ¶ How Socrates as he forced not for feare, so he regarded not gifts.
div.p:
SOcrates vppon a time comming somewhat late in the night from supper, it chaunced that certaine young men better fed then taughte (as they say) haueing an inckling
before hand which way he would passe, disguised themselfe with deuilles vizardes, and had in their handes lighted lincks, wherwith they lay in waight closly, thinking to haue slighted Socrates (for it was the custome and practise of these mumming merchauntes to delude men by these meanes, and to spende the time which they got at their leasure, in such triflyng toyes and paultery pageants) When Socrates saw their iugling and perceaued their legerdemaine, hee stoode still, and was neuer a whit abashed at the matter, and as his fashion was asked questions of them, according to his custome and order in Lyceo and Academia two common schooles.

Alcibiades was a great distributer and bestower of giftes, of a proude, arrogant, and ambicious minde. He sent gifts to Socrates, which as they were very great, so were they very many, wherat Xantippe wondring, for the dignity and worthines of them, was semblably desierous and gréedy to receaue them. That is not enough said Socrates to Xantippe, but let vs rather contend with Alcibiades in largesse and liberality, not taking such thinges as he sendeth: In which refusall, a singuler kinde of beneuolence, and frée exhibition consisteth. Moreouer, to a certayne man saying that it was a matter of great difficulty and hardnes, to haue and hold that, which hee doth wish and would: Socrates made this short aunswer. That it was a farre greater matter not to couet and desire at all.

div.head: ¶ Of the prophecy of Anaxarchus.
div.p:
ANaxarchus, in sharp and bitter wether, foreknowing that Alexander would pitch his pauilion, and incampe in a place where was no wood nor fuell, layd vp all his vtensiles, implementes, and necessaries
in store for a déere yeare, as they say, and a season of skarsity, he caused skulleines, drudges, and slaues to carrye wood also by the loade for his owne prouision, & maintenaunce. When Alexander came to the appoynted plot of lande, they found that there was great want of woodde, which droue them to such inconuenience, that they were faine to burne their tables to warme them in thextremity of the colde. In this lack (being in a maner vniuersall) it fortuned that one odde fellowe amonge the rest, tolde Alexander that Anaxarchus had fyering sufficient, whereupon the king made resorte vnto him, and refresshed his frosen limmes in Anaxarchus tent, praiseing the man that he was not vnpurueyed at such a pinche, and redoubling all that he had receiued, as well vessels, as vestures, because he had the vse, benefyt, and profyt of his fyers.

div.head: ¶ Of a Wrestler who woonne the best game, and dyed before he did weare the garland of victory.
div.p: A Wrestler of Crotona, winning the victory at Olympus, where common games were playde, and goyng from thence to Hellanodicas to receiue and weare the garland of glory sor his rewarde, had a sudden fall, and a sore, whereof he waxed so sicke, and diseased, that he fainted very pittifully, and at last dyed: by which meanes he was vtterly depriued and dispossessed of the recompence, whereof peraduenture he made full accoumpte.

div.head: ¶ Of the picture of Phryna the stewd whore, and of the images of Cymons Mares.
div.p: PHryna the stronge strumpet which solde her honesty for mony, had her picture erected & set vpon an high piller by the Grecians, not by ye Greciās generally, I will not say so, least I should séeme to make thē culpable & giltie of this offence, whom I fauour most déerely, and loue most déepely: but of such naughty, peruerse, and ill disposed persons of Grecia as deserue blame and reprehension. The picture of that arrant whore was al of gold. Furthermore Cymons Mares of brasse, which be at Athens were of no small quantity and substaunce, when as they counteruailed Mares in déede, in bignes, in greatnesse, in measure, and proportion.

div.head: ¶ The aunswere of a young striplyng to his father, demaunding of him what he had learned.
div.p: A Certayne young striplyng of Eretria, had frequented the schoole of Zeno a longe time, at whose comming home to visit his friends, his father being very desireous and earnest to vnderstande how hee had profited and increased in knowledge al that space, demaunded how much wisdome he had attayned, & to what learning he had aspired: who aunswered his father, Syr I wil shew you anon. At which words of the sonne the impacient father being displeased, and much moued in minde smote his sonne, who bearing the blowes without resistaunce or grudging, yea without any resemblance of repineing, sayde, Hoc ipsum didici, Pater, vt iram tuam verberaque moderatè ferrem. Thus much haue I learned, Father, to take well in worth the heate of thine anger, and paciently to suffer the bitternesse of thy blowes.

div.head: ¶ Of such as were gorgeously apparelled.
div.p: DIogenes when as he was come to Olimpia, and saw certayne youngmen of Rhodes gorgeously decked, & sumptuously apparelled, laughed at them and sayde. Hoc nihil est praeter fastum. This is nothing elles but méere pride and hautynesse. The same Diogenes chaunceing to sée certaine Lacedemonians in ragged, iagged, rent, riuen, slouenly and lothsome garments, said: Haec longè alia est superbia, This also is a kind of pride, but farre differing from the former.

div.head: ¶ Of the pride of Antisthenes, which he tooke in his tatterd and torne cloake.
div.p: SOcrates, when he marked this in Antisthenes, that he dyd all wayes weare the ragged péece of his threde bare cloake outwarde in sighte, sayde vnto him. Quin desinis, arrogantiam tuam nobis prodere? Wilte thou neuer leaue bewraying vnto vs thine arrogancy and pryde?

div.head: ¶ Of Antigonus, and a certaine Musician.
div.p:
A Musician comming into the presence of Antigonus, shewed his cunning in the Art of Musick, whom Antigonus oftentimes interrupting with these words, Fellow set vp thy treble string higher, and yet once agayne
thy meane: The Musician takeing pepper in the nose said thus vnto Antigonus. The deuill is in it, by the Gods I sweare, if thou (O Kinge) art more skilfull and expert then I in this science and profession.

div.head: ¶ How Anaxarchus laughed Alexander to skorne, who would needes be numbred among the Gods.
div.p: ANaxarchus, syrnamed Eudaemonicus, laughed and scoffed at the extreame folly of Alexander, because he made himselfe, not a Gods fellow, but a very God. This Alexander falling into sodayne sicknes, the Physician was sent for, who ministred purgations vnto him, & prescribed certaine receptes and potions for the recouery of his health. Whereat Anaxarchus laughed, and floutingly sayde thus: At Deo nostro spes omnis in sorbillatione patellae posita est. All the hope of our goodly God is in sypping a platter, for in such vessels were the confections and syrops geuen by the Physician.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexander, and of the Cyterne of Paris.
div.p:
WHen Alexander came to Troy, and viewed euery thinge with earneste eyes, a certayne Troian approching towards him, shewed him ye Cyterne of Paris. To whom the king sayde, I woulde haue this harpe of Paris in more value and estimation, if thou couldest helpe me to a sighte of the Cyterne of Achilles,
for he desired to sée somthing which belōged to so stowte, so valiaunt and so conquerous a Martialist, and specially his Cyterne wherwith he vsed to play the passing prayses of notable personages. As for the Cyterne of Paris whereunto serued it ells, then to sounde baudy ballads, filthy songs, wanton tunes, & lewde daunces, being baytes to allure younge women to lightnes, vanity, & naughtynes.

div.head: Of ridiculous Loues, and louers exceeding the limits of reason.
div.p:
WHo is so blockishe, so sensles, & so destitute of iudgemēt, yt wil not think these loues, & louers, worthy to be laughed to skorne, as showes of singular fooleishnes, and deseruing dispraise, rebuke & discōmendation for their vnresonablenes? First the fonde & phantasticall loue of Xerxes, whose hart was wōderfully bewitched to loue a Planetrée. The light hed of a certain youngman of Athens, discending from a noble house, who loued the picture of Bona Fortuna which stode hard by the portall of the Parleament house, yelding him selfe most amorously into the bosom of the image, and kissing the same as if it had bene indued with breath and lyfe: Vpon the continuance of which officious and dutyfull behauior, he waxed frantique, and séemed in the sight of men extreamely haunted wt madnes, in so muche that his conceit of minde gathered such efficacy and force, and his desire in this case, tooke such déepe roote, that he could no longer conceale and couer ye flaming affections of his perplexed spirit, but entred into ye conuocation house boldly and lustely, beséeching such as sate there in place of authority, most earnestly & vehemētly that they wold geue him leaue to buy the picture of
Bona Fortuna. But he not preuaileing in his suite and supplication, vttered neuertheles, manyfest significations of his kindled concupiscence, for he beutyfied the image with costly garlands, & princely crownes, he offered sacrifices & oblatiōs vnto it, he garnished and adorned the same with precious apparrell, all which circumstaunces being accōplished he wepte most pityfully (O immoderate and excessiue folly (stremes of teares gushing out of his eies, which stayned his tender chéeks, and made his fauour frustrate, in the end he murthered himself so far gone was he from the rule of reason, and robbed of his righte wytts. Som say that Glauca, a woman which played vpon the harpe, loued a Duck, othersome say she loued a Goose. Moreouer it is reported yt Xenophons sonne loued a dogge in Sole a city of Cilicia. And to knytt vpp the knott, the voice goeth that a certaine misshapen and yll fauoured fellow of Sparta, fell in loue with a Iack dawe, sett greate store by the same and planted therin al his pleasure and delectation.

div.head: ¶ Of the Gouernours of the Carthaginean shipps.
div.p: THe Carthagineans appointed two gouernours in euery shippe, saying: that it was not séemly, nor conuenient that a vessell haueing twoo ruthers, (a thing most profitable for sailers, and to passingers not incommodious, besides that dooyng best seruice for direction in voyages) should be destitute of one to supply so necessary a roome, and to furnishe so fit an office.

div.head: ¶ Of Pausanias, and of Simonides
div.p: SImonides being present at a certaine banquet, it fortuned that Pausanias the Lacedemonian, was bydden thither as guest at the same instaunt, at which méeting Pausanias tooke occasion to desire Simonides, that he would vtter a sewe preceptes and rules of wisdome: at whose wordes the good old man laughed and said, Tune memento te hominem esse. Then beare in remembrance that thou art but a man. Which watchword preuayled not with Puasanias, sithence hee set nought thereby, but being pufte vp with pride, because he had entred confederacy and partnership with the Medes, had obtained great familiarity, and intertainement singuler, with the kinge, and besides that, peraduenture, not all with the wisest (for somuch as he had ouerdrunke himself with wine) looked aloft insolently, lightly regarding the shorte precepte of wisdome geuen by Simonides. Howbeit this Pausanias, at what time he was in a prison of brasse, wrestling with hunger, and fightinge for lyfe and death with famishmente, furthermore séeing before his face a most miserable, a most lamentable, and wofull ende, hee remembred, vpon a sudden, the saying of Simonides, cryyng out with a loude, and a pityfull voyce, thrée seuerall times in this sort: O Cee hospes, magnum quiddā in tuo sermone inerat, ego vero inani persuasione sum adductus vt eum nullius momenti putarem. O friende Simonides, in thy watchword was a great and a waighty matter included, as for me I was caried away with vaine perswasions, and made smal acoumpt (Alas) of thy wise warning.

div.head: ¶ Of Artaxerxes, and of Darius.
div.p: AFter that Artaxerxes had caused his eldest sonne Darius to be slayne, for certen trecherous tricks and disobedient behauiour: the second brother next vnto him, hearing of his fathers commaundement drew out his Persian skuchillatro, which was fashioned lyke a woodknife, and therewithall murthered himselfe violently, before the kings pallace.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the ninth Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The tenth Booke of the variable hystori of Aelianus.
¶ Of Pherenice, who was admitted and allowed to looke vppon the games at Olympus.
div.p: PHerenice brought her sonne to the games at Olympus, to show his ability & actiuenesse in those solemne exercises. But the ouerséers or officers called Hellanodica withstoode her, and would not let her sée them in any case, whom she for their quarrellyng called to a reckoninge before the Iudge, referring all to the determynation of the law, & aledging the reasons folowing in her owne behalf. My Father sayde she was a conquerour in the games at Olympus, my thrée Bretheren were Captaines in lyke maner: and héere I haue brought my sonne, the fruite of my body, who is a wrestler by nature & by art. By which reasons vttered with opportunity, she ouerthrewe her aduersaries the officers, and obtained her purpose: making that lawe, statute, and ordinaunce, of no force or effect, which was prouided against the admissiō of women to common games. Thus did Pherenice sée and beholde all the exercises exhibited and shewed at Olympus.

div.head: ¶ Of the continency, and chastity of Eubatas.
div.p:
LAis, when she saw Eubatas Cyrenensis, shee had such good liking of him, that she burned in loue extreamely for his sake, insomuch that she fel in cōmunication wt him
about contracting, and marrying: whose subtile snares, and daungerous deceiptes the youngman mistrusting, promised to do no lesse then she desired, yet dealt he not with her in bodily delight or carnall pleasure, but, whereas he might haue had his will, to the full staunchinge of his fleshly lust, yet did hee not vse any such meanes, but shewed himself of honest vsage, and vnspotted behauiour in that poinct. The couenaunt and promise was concluded and agreed vpon with these conditions, that after the common showes and pageants then published, were ended: it should be ratifyed and confirmed by actuall marriage, which was graunted before at the knittinge of the contract. No wsyr when the games were finished, and all things pertaining thereunto dispatched, this youngman Eubatas being winner in the foresaide exercises, & perceauing himselfe intangled, and hooked in, with the snares of an harlot, to th'intent that he might not be thought to reuoult from his former bargin, and agréement made with the wanton woman, he caused the picture of Lais to be painted in a scutchiō, saying: Ecce Laidē duco & pactum non praetereo: Beholde Lais, I stande to my worde, and perfourme the summe, of my promise. For which occasion of constancy, and perfect president of vnfayned loue, the young mayden which was betrouthed vnto him, and afterwarde luckely wedded, procured a great and a fayre standinge image to be erected and set vp at Cyrena, recompencinge his temperaunce and chastity with this worshipfull rewarde. The pretty conueyaunce of Eubatas commendable shift, consisteth in this word Ducere, which importeth a double meanyng, for it doth not onely signifie to marry, but also to beare. The first interpretation seruing the worde wedlock, the seconde proper to a burden. So that, notwithstanding, Eubatas did not obserue Ducere, one way, yet he obserued the same another, but sophistically & not simply, as ye womā was perswaded.

div.head: ¶ Of the properties of certaine brute beastes, and birds.
div.p: YOunge Partridge pullettes are very swift and nimble in running, so soone as their legs be out of the shell: young ducklinges swimme imediatly, in a manner, after they be hatched: and Lyons whelps scratch and claw their dams bellyes, being gréedy to get out of so close a prison.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexanders speedinesse in dispatching his attempts.
div.p: ALexander the sonne of Philip vsed no stop, nor stay for the space of thirtye furlonges, whiles hee encountered with his enemyes and ouercame them, during which time, neither hee nor his souldiours tooke any rest.

div.head: ¶ Of Tyrauntes, an opinion out of Aesops writinges.
div.p:
I His history sauoureth of a Phrigians opinion, & this Phrigian is Aesop. If any man holde a hog fast by the eares, it roreth, and maketh a shrewd noise. And wott you why? Because they beare no wooll, nor yéelde any thinge from their backes of any such kinde, but carry fat fleash, seruing for the sustenaunce of man. And Tyrauntes are very lyke them (in mine opinion)
who liue alwaies in feare and suspition, knowing that their liues are compared to the liues of hogs, which albeit they liue, are reserued and kept for the slaughter: sythence all men gape after the deaths of tyrauntes, and wish their destruction, and ouerthrow by some violent meanes or other.

div.head: ¶ Of leane, slender, and light men of body.
div.p:
THe excéedinge smalnesse, and slendernesse of these men vndernamed, hath passed by reporte, to the eares of many people. First and formost the leanesse and lightnesse of Samyzio, the Comicall Poet. The slendernesse of Melitus the tragical writer: the smalnesse of Cinesias the Vauter or Tumbler, who was so litle, and therewithall so nimble, that hee coulde daunce through a ringe. The pretynesse of Philetas the heroicall versefier. The lightnesse of Archestratus the Poet, who being apprehended and taken by the handes of the enemies, and put into a payre of ballaunce, was founde (as it is reported) to haue wayed no more but sixtéene barely cornes. Furthermore Panaretus was very smal and slender of body, yet notwithstanding he was frée from all infection of sicknes, and far from any consumptiō: albeit he was as leane as a rake. Moreouer, the voyce goeth that the Poet Hipponactes, was not onely of small stature and making, but also yll fauoured and ougly therewithal: besids al these, Philippides, of whom Hipperides maketh mencion, was a very spare man of limme and ioynte, meruailous leane, litle, & slender, insomuch yt he became a common prouerbe amonge people, for when they were disposed to talke and common of any maner of person
that was singuler in leanes and lightnes, they saide that such a one did 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 that hee resembled Philippides. Heareof is Alexis able to geue testimony, and witnesse sufficient.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine Astrologians and of the great yeare called Annus Magnus.
div.p: OEnopides Chius, a man singularlye séene in the science of Astrology, dedicated and set vp a table of lawes in Olympijs wherein hee described the reuolution of the starres for the tearm of fifty yeares and nine, affirming that this was Annus Magnus ye great yéere. Meton the Lacedemonian, a man no lesse skilfull and cunning in the art Astrologicall, erected and set vp, columes or pillers, wherein he did ingraue the circle and course of the sun, & found out (as he said) Anum Magnum, the great yeare, which he included within the compasse, and space of nintéene yeares.

div.head: ¶ Of Benefites, and Goodturnes.
div.p:
ARistotle Cyrenensis had this sentence in his mouth: Non oportet beneficium oblatum a quoquam recipere: aut enim vt rependere possit, molestias habiturus: aut si non referat, in ingratitudinis reprehensionem incursurus. We ought not to receaue a benefyt, although it be offered and put into our handes: And why? Because it is a gréefe vnto vs, yf wee bee not able to make sufficiente requitall for that which wee haue taken, or elles yf wee doe not recompence like, with like, in due and
equall proportion, we ar obiect to reprehension, and guilty of ingratitude.

div.head: ¶ That Philoxenus was a Glutton
div.p: PHiloxenus was a notorious glutton & a very bondslaue to his belly. It was his chaunce to be in a victualing house wher the pot was boyling full of broth béelyke, and good fleashe, with the smell & sauour wherof he was so delighted, that he shewed himselfe no ydle guest in that case. After yt the odour and fume of the liquor and the meate, had sharpned his appetite, and prouoked his stomacke to barcke, he being vnable to bridle his inordinate desire, commaunded his sonne (O gods imortall) to buy potte and all out righte: whoo sayd to his Father againe, yt the cooke wold hold it at to highe a pryce: whose obiection Philoxenus answered in this sorte. Hoc suauior erit & iucundior, quo maiori pretio ollam emero. Hold thee content, the more it doth cost the swéeter it wil be. These things are to be committed to remembraunce, not that we should imitate and followe the like foolishnes, but rather learne to auoide and flye such vanity.

div.head: ¶ Of Painters in the old auncient tyme.
div.p:
WHen as the art of painting and limming was newly brued, & skarcely sett a broche, when, I say, it lay, as it were in the cradle and swathling clowts: painters described the formes and shapes of beasts, byrdes, & other things so homely, so simply so rudely, & so nakedly, that for the better vnderstanding of their botchery (for it
was farre dissonant from cunning worckmanship, they were fayne to write these posies ouer such things as thei painted. Hoc est Bos. Hoc est Equus. Hoc est Miluus. Hoc est Arbor. This is an Oxe, This is a horse, This is a Puttock, and this is a Trée.

div.head: ¶ Of Diogenes hauing a sore shoulder.
div.p: DIogenes being gréeued very much in one of his shoulders, by some wounde (as I suppose) or such like mischance séemed to suffer great pain & anguish by ye extremity of the sore: to whō one of his aduersaries cōming, reioycing and triumphing to sée him in such an yll taking, said: Quin igitur mortem obis, & teipsum his dam nis liberas? why doost thou not kill thy self, if thou art willing to be deliuered out of this torment? whose counsell, not so enuious, as vnaduised, Diogenes ouerthrew with this prudent and wise sentence. Qui sciunt quae in vita fieri dicique conuenit, in vita manere aequum est. It is conueniēt and requisite that such should liue, as knowe both what is to be donne & what is to be saide, in the course of their life (in the number of whom he reckened himself) But as for thée, saith Diogenes, which art ignorant what should be wrought, and what should be thought, it is more thē highe time to be dead. Me vero, qui sciam illa, par est in viuis agere. As for me, who vnderstand the vttermost in ye matters aboue mencioned, it is good reason to liue & not to dye.

div.head: ¶ The Apophthegme of Archytas concerning men.
div.p: THis was the sentence of Archytas. As it is not possible for a man to finde a fyshe without prickelinges, although he take neuer so greate paines & labour neuer so busily: so it is not possible to finde a man, that hath not som craft, subtiltie, and captious inuention harbouring in his hed,

div.head: ¶ The Testimonie of Archilocus in his owne rebuke
div.p:
CRitias reproued Archilocus, because he spake not well of himself. For if, saide Critias, he had not spred such an infamous report and opinion touching his owne person in the country of Grecia: we should neuer haue known that Enippo the bondwoman was his mother: nor that he leauing Parus, was driuen by extreame néede and beggery to Thasus, and that he fell at variance wt the inhabitants when he cam thither, nor yt he was of such a crooked, cankard, and corrupt inclination, and naughty nature, that he spake yll of all men indifferently, as well of fréends as foes with out exceptiō. Moreouer if his own tongue had not betrayed his sensuality and peruerse disposition (sayth Critias) we had not knowne that he was a whoremounger, a lecherous varlot, an iniurious merchant, a wrangling and vniust person. Neither had we attained the vnderstanding of his behauiour in battell, how he cast away his weapon and threw his target out of his hand lyke a cowardly cullion, which was far woorse then all the rest. These circumstaunces
shoulde not haue béene discouered to the capacities of our wits and memories, if his owne tongue had not béen the trumpet to sounde his owne preposterous properties in the eares of people. Now certainly, & as God helpe me, Archilocus fauoured not himselfe, to blase abrode such beastly talke touching his owne estate, neither was his testimony commodious or profitable, sythence therby he was so far from reaping aduauntage that he purchased a reprochefull, an ignominious, and a shameful name. But as for me I iudge Archilocus inculpable and voyde from any blot of blame in this behalfe: it is Critias, peraduenture, that forgeth such & such false fables, and coineth this accusation against Archilocus, to his contumelie and sclaunder.

div.head: ¶ Of Slouthfullnes or ydelnes.
div.p: SOcrates was the Author of this swéete sentence. Soror libertatis est pigritia, slouthfulnes is the sister of liberty: to the confirmation wherof, he alledged notable testimonies and singular examples, deriued and borowed of stowte and strong men & people liuing in greate licentiousnes: As the Indians & the Persians, both which people are very slowe & sluggish to take pain, & loth to labor. But the Phrygians, and the Lydians, being of conditions cleane contrary, ar quicke and spéedy at their worke, and loue to labour, so yt it may be gathered, that what is wanting throughe default of liberty in the first, is supplied by subiection and bondage in the last.

div.head: ¶ Of those which made a contract with the daughters of Aristides, and gaue their fayth & truth solemnly to marry them: & of Lysander.
div.p:
THe best & the chéefest among the Grecians gaue their fayth and troth precisely, to marry the daughters of Aristides, this promise & contracte was made whiles ye good father was aliue. But they had not an eye of iustice to Aristides trade of life, neither did they regarde his vpright and irreprehensible dealing: for if they had béen of that profession, if, I say, they had béen his Disciples and Scholers, they would neuer haue stretched and strangled their credit, by the violation and breach of their couenaunt. Now therfore, when Aristides was dead, they were so farre from marying the maidens, that they vtterly refused to make and meddle with them any more, yea thei sequestred themselues out of the wenches company, cast of all acquaintaunce, and béecame very strange as if there had no such promisse procéeded from them. For so soone as the aboue named sonne of Lysimachus died (as we were giuing you to vnderstand before) an inuentory taken of his goods, & a suruiew had of his wealth and substance, he was found to be but a poore mā, and far vnable to contribute so largely as was thought to his daughters marriages: which thing procured this mischéefe, that the younge women lost their husbands, and those vnhappy men were dismist of their wiues, with whom otherwise they would haue béen wedded. The selfe same lucke was alotted to Lysander, for so soone as the youthes which were suiters to his daughters, had vnderstanding that he was not welthy, they wrung their neckes out of the yoke, and withdrewe
both witt and will from wedlocke.

div.head: ¶ Of Antisthenes and Diogenes.
div.p: AFter that Antisthenes had byddē many guests to the banquet of wisdom, & none wold come at ye sound of his voice, béeing very angry at the length, and much moued in his minde he wold admit neither one nor other to tast of the learned chéere, which he was purposed to set before them: wherupon he excluded Diogenes in like maner out of his society & fellowship. But when he perceaued the man more desirous of his company, & the more he was prohibited & forbiddden to repaire vnto him, ye more to frequent and cōtinue his comming: Antisthenes did not only check him but threatned him also, & not therwith contented procéeded further, and smote him vpō the pate with a cudgel which he had in his hand: Diogenes notwtstanding these thunderclaps & tempests, was neuer awhit terrested he shrunk not an inch frō his purpose, but was so much the more constant and vnmoueable in mind to heare Antisthenes wisdom, vttering these words vnto him. Tu percute tantum, ego tibi caput prae bebo: neque vero tam durum fustem inueneris, quo me a disputationibus tuis abigas. Lay on and spare not, héere is my hed and shoulders, for thou canst not finde a slaffe hard enough, although it were crab trée, to driue me from hearing thy disputatiōs. Which words Antisthenes hearing, & therwithall pondering how inclinable Diogenes was to learning, he cast a fauourable countenaunce vppon him, cut of all contention and varriance, became his feruent and faythfull fréend, and made great account of him for his prudent perseuerance.

div.head: ¶ Of such as increased their riches, and amplifyed their possessions, by bearing the offices of magestrates in the common wealth.
div.p: CRitias sayth, that Themistocles before he was elected to beare authoritie in ye common welth, was worth no more thē three talents which were left vnto him by Legacy: In processe of time when he had occupied that place of superioritie and préeminence, an apprisment or valuation of his goods being taken, after his exile & banishment: he was found to haue bynne worth a hundred talents, which he had hoorded vp & kept in store. Cleon in lyke maner, before he was aduanced to place of authoritie in the commonwealth, had not the substaunce that a frée man ought to haue, yet neuertheles he gathered as much wealth as was worth fifty talents, & a better pounde.

div.head: ¶ Of Daphnis the Syracusane, and of Poesies called Poemata Pastoritia.
div.p:
SOm say (vppon their immagination) that Mercury loued Daphnis ye herdman tenderly and déerly. othersom suppose that Daphnis was his sonne, and that he had his name Ex euentis of the issue of his luck & fortune. For he is reported to haue had a Nymphe to his mother, and anon, after his natiuitie and birth to haue bynelayed vnder a Bay trée. As for the bullocks which he did grase, they were (as som surmise) the sisters of Sol, of whome mencion is made by Homer in his Odysses. So it is ye when Daphnis did grase in Sicilia, one
of the Nymphes was intangled with the loue of him, being an amiable youngeman, louely of looke, and comely of complexion, yea, so farr did the fyer of affection kindle & burne: that she had to deale with him in the very floure & pearle of his lusty youth, at which time bewty is in her blossom. At ye same instant, that the things within written were a doing, the Nymph vrged him to make this precise couenant: That he should not vse the company of any other woman, to ioyne in bodily pleasure we her, but to abstain from al other, her self excepted: which promise if he did not perfourme, his destenie should be to loose his eye sight, and to become starke blinde, if he brake the bargain: to this they both cōdescended and were fully agréed. In tract of time it chaunced that the Kings daughter fell in loue of Daphnis, with whome, he (the wine being in his braine and the witte quite out) had carnall knowledge: vpon the committing of which déede he was detected & found vnfaithfull in the couenant which he concluded. Hereuppon sprunge the shepherds poesies called Poemata Pastoritia, which were solemnly sunge: the occasion wherof the losse of Daphnis eysight ministred. Stesichorus Himeroeus is reported to haue béen ye first inditer of these sonnets, and ditties.

div.head: ¶ Of him which swallowed down his owne teethe.
div.p: EVrydamas of Cyrena, was Victor in a game of whurlebatting, or (as some say) in an excercise of buffetting, whose téeth, when his aduersary had dashed out, he made no sower coūtenaunce at ye matter, but swallowed downe his téeth, bloud and al: To thintent that he which gaue him the blowe might not perceaue the misschief.

div.head: ¶ Of Agesilaus
div.p: THe king of the Persians sent embassadors to Agesilaus to cōclude a league of peace betwéene them: who made them, which represented the kings person, this aunswere. Fieri non potest vt mea priuatim amicitia fruatur, sin Lacedemonijs communiter omnibus amicus fieret, ego quoque in amicitiae ius venturus sum. It is not possible for him to knit concord & agréement with my priuate person only, but if he enter friend ship with the Lacedemonians generally: I shalbe willing also to subscribe to the same condition. For the king hath an interest and title in all his people and subiects.

div.head: ¶ Of Plato.
div.p: PErictione caried Plato in her armes when he was an infant: And when Ariston was sacrificing to the Muses and the Nymphes in Himetto hil, she in like manner being disposed to semblable deuotion, layd Plato downe vpon the soft gréene grasse, vnder the thickest Myrtyle trées whiche grewe in that place: to the end she might with lesse interruption & hinderance occupy herself in deuiue seruice. Whiles they both were religiously busyed, a greate swarme of Bees did light vppon the babes lipps, buzzing, humming, and makeing swéete sugred honny vppon his minikyn mouth, prophecying by this their déede, what eloquent and Rhetoricall vtterance, what heauenly learneing, and famous philosophy should flow from him when he came to yeares of rypenes.

div.head: ¶ Of Dioxippus.
div.p: DIoxippus, in the presence of Alexander, and a multitude of Macedonians caught a club fast in his fistes, and challenged Corrhagus all armed, to enter cumbat with him: when Dioxippus had smitten Corrhagus speare out of his handes, hee closed with him, laid gryping hold vpon him, his harnesse, and his weapons: threw him downe, set his foote vpon the neck of Corrhagus, lying prostrate on the grounde, drewe out his Sworde, and gored him through with the same. For which act and déede Alexander conceiued hate against him, wherupon Dioxippus tooke inward thought and gaue such scope to the force of phantasy, that hee pyned and consumed away with extreame agony of minde, and at length ended his lyfe, no lesse lamentably, then miserably.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the tenth Booke of AElianus.

div.head: ¶ The eleuenth Booke of the variable hystorie of Aelianus.
¶ Of Oricadmus, and of the Art of Wrestling.
div.p: ORicadmus instituted the law of wrestling, and whurlbatting: and by his industrye and dilligence, the game of wrestling, after the Sicilyan fasshion, (as they tearme it) was deuised. A proper pastime, and an actiue exercise.

div.head: ¶ Of the verses of Oraebantius, of Dares, and Melisander.
div.p: THe Verses of Oraebantius are more auncient then the Verses of olde Homer, so say the Troesenians, a people lincked in most sincere, and inuiolable society with the Atheniens. Dares also the Phrygian liued before Homer, and wrote a Booke called the Illiades, or the Troian skirmish, in the Phrygian speach: which are kept and preserued in a certaine Register or Library, I wot not where. Melisander Milesius likewise, made certaine Poems, wherein he described the warres betwéene the Lapithes (inhabitants sometime of Thessalia) and the Centaures, whiche were also named Hippocentauri, whose dwellinges were besides the hill Peleus, in the same countrey.

div.head: ¶ Of Ichus, and of Wrestling.
div.p: TArentinus practised Wrestling, during the time of which his accustomed exercise, he liued most continently, eating his meat with moderation, and measure: and forbearing fleshly pleasure, with great abstinence and chastitye, all the tearme of his lyfe,

div.head: Of the bouldnesse of Agathocles.
div.p: AGathocles the Sicilian Tyraunt, had an ylfauoured head to looke vpon, and good for nothing but to moue laughter and skorning. For when the very skinne of his skull might easly be séene, by reason of his haire, which grew so thin, that the least winde in the worlde dispearsed and blew it abroad: he being ashamed of himselfe for that foule deformity, vsed to weare a garland of Myrtel leaues, which was a couering, as it were, to his bauld pate. But the Syracusans were not ignoraunt of that which Agathocles would haue concealed: yet feare and terror constrained them to be silent, because the Tyraunt was of an ill disposed nature, and of a minde much set vpon mischiefe.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine men which were vniustly condemned of Sacrilege.
div.p: AS certaine men were occupied, in offering sacrifice to Apollo: They of Delphos inuironed them rounde about subtelly, and threw in amonge them, closly and couertly, plate, which was consecrated and made holy, and therwithall franckinsence, and toothsome iunckets to blind their eies, as it were, with a mist: vpon whom they layde handes, in the ende, as fellons, théeues, and stealers of holy metall, leading them to an high and huge rock (being the appointed place of executiō for such offenders) from the top whereof, they were cast downe hedlong, and yet were innocent.

div.head: ¶ Of an Adulterer, or Fornicator.
div.p: IT fortuned, that an Adulterer was takē in the towne of Thespie, whom, (as he was leade about the common stréets and market place fast bounde) certaine of his fréends and fauourers came with maine force, and violently tooke him away, whereupon sprange an vprore, and tumulte, an vniuersall insurrection, a great slaughter of people, and miserable murthers, infinit and innumerable.

div.head: ¶ Of Lysander and Alcibiades.
div.p:
EThocles, the Lacedemonian did say that Sparta might not suffer two Lysanders. And Archistratus the
Athenian did say, that the city of Athens might not abide two Alcibiades. Assuredly, (notwithstanding they were in maners diuers and contrary) yet they were both intollerable.

div.head: ¶ Of the death of Hipparchus.
div.p: HIpparchus was murthered by the meanes of Harmodius, and Aristogeiton, because (peraduenture) hee would not let Harmodius sister beare a basket, as the custome of the country required, when the feastes of Minerua, called Panathenaica, were solemnized: which continued fiue dayes long. (A smal occasion to worke such a mische) he put the damosel beside, as vnworthy place, whereupon followed the depriuation of his owne lyfe.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine men in manners very commendable, and therewithall very poore, who, notwithstanding, receaued no gifts when they were largely offered.
div.p:
THe worthyest, the wisest, and the notablest men amonge the Grecians, liued a lyfe loden with extreame skarsity, and perplexed with perpetual pouerty. Who therfore would attempte to praise and extoll riches? séeing before their eyes such speciall paternes, types, and presidents of the contrary. Their names folow
orderly in a short catalogue. Aristides the sonne of Lysimachus, whose behauiour was commendable in the time of peace and tranquillity, and also auailable in the state of warlyke affaires: hee obtayned many tributes, payments, and pensions for the aduantage of the Grecians, yet notwithstanding his politique prouision, hee had not in all the world, so much as would discharge his funeral, as the ouerséers found at the day of his death. Phocion, in lyke case, was merueilous indigent and poore, yet when Alexander, of his gracious liberality, sent him an hundred talentes: Hee moued this demaunde to him that brought the gifte. Quam ob causam haec mihi donat? why doth his maiesty bestow vpon me so large a present? who made this aunswer to Phocion. Quoniam te solum ex omnibus Atheniensibus bonum honestumque virum iudicat, Because his iudgement inclineth so much to thée, that among all the Atheniens, thou art in his memory, for thy vertue and honestye: Sinat, inquit, me talem esse, Let his grace geue me leaue to continue in that course still, sayeth prudent Phocion. What shall we say touching Epaminondas the sonne of Polymnis, was he riche? was hee wealthy? nay, hee was poore and néedy, yet when Iason sent vnto him fifty talentes of fine golde, hee woulde not receaue them, but sayde, Iniuriam mihi facis. Thou dealest not vprightly with me. The same Epaminondas borrowed fifty groates of a certaine Citizen a friend of his to pay his expences, and costage by the way, in in his iourney towardes Peloponnesus, & complaint being made vnto him, yt one of his reteiners or seruitors, tooke mony of such as were captiue, vttered these wordes vnto him: Mihi da scutum: Tu vero tibi caupouam ome, in qua viuas, non enim vlterius pericula subire potes, cum factus sis diues. Geue me my target, and buy thy selfe a tauerne or ale house, to maintayne belly chéere, for thou canst not henceforwarde, indaunger thy lyfe willingly, sithence thou art waxed wealthy.
Pelopidas, when his fréendes fell out with him, and reproued him for his carelesnesse, in that he regarded not mony (without the which mans lyfe is vnpurueied of all necessaries) sayd thus vnto thē. Now out of doubte mony is a profitable thing, and very requisite: But for whome? for Nicomedes forsooth: pointing with his finger at one which was hault and lame.

Scipio, for the space of fifty and foure yeares, neither bought nor sould any kinde of thinge, he was so well satisfied and contented with a litle. A certaine man shewing him a sheald finely made, and well trymmed, he sayde (as it is reported) behoofull it is, that a citizen of Rome hold hope in his right hand, and not in the left.

Ophialtes the sonne of Sophonidas was very bare, and néedy, yet when his fréends offered him fréely (without expectation of retribution) tenne talents, he receiued them not, saying. These giftes would inforce mee (albeit I am bound by specialty of duty to haue you in reuerēce) somewhat to presume which is repugnant and rebelling against the rule of right and reason. For in takinge and not requiting, is cold courtesy, ingratitude, and vnthankfulnesse.

div.head: ¶ Of zoilus.
div.p:
NOilus Amphipolitanus, who wrote against Homer, Plato, and other learned men, was the Disciple and Scholar of Polycrates, this was the selfsame Polycrates that indited an accusation against Socrates. And the abouenamed Zoilus was called the doggish Rhetorician, or the Rhetoricall and eloquent Dogge, whether you will, since neither of both are dissagreable. But shall I describe the Man?
He kept his bearde somwhat long, but the heire of his hed he caused to be shauen of to the hard stumps, his mantell houng aboue his knées, his delight was in deuising slaunderous and malicious reportes, he spared no labour nor leasure, to scatter and sow the séedes of damnable dissentions: To be shorte he had a rakehels tounge of his own, from whence contumelious, and reuiling language flowed as fast, as water out of a sluce. A learned Doctor demaunding of him, why he spake wel by none, he gaue him this short aunswer: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Because I cannot doe yll when I would.

div.head: ¶ Of Dionysius the tyraunt of Sicily.
div.p: DIonysius ye tyrant of Sicilia, employed much industry, labour, and dilligence in the art of Phisicke and Surgery, he was cunning in curing, in cutting, in launcing, in boxing, in burning, in searinge, and in euery thinge besides, to those professions and Sciences appertayning.

div.head: ¶ Of the banketing dishe, or deinty Iunket which Alcibiades, sent to Socrates.
div.p:
ALcibiades, vpon a time sent to Socrates a delicate iuncket, swéete, toothsome, and made with great cost (which kinde of gifts louers send one to another, to excite, styr vp, increase, and confirme their harts with mutual affection) at which instant, Xantippe
the wife of Socrates was in her mad moode of vnbrideled braulyng, (as her accustomed maner & vsual trade was) and taking the basket and all as it was brought, shee threw the banqueting dish vnder foote, and trod it to durt: at which folly Socrates laughing, said: thou mightst haue had thy parte in it, as well as I, but now wee are both lyke to goe without. If any man think this which I haue tolde méere childish, and skarce worth rehersall, I dare be so bolde to say, that his tounge goes before his wit: For who is ignoraunt, that by such circumstaunces, due and true tryall of a stout harted man is taken: In so much as they set light by such costly and curious cates as the common people haue in great estimation: supposing, and affirming that they are the beauty of their boorde, the trimnesse of their table, the floure of their foode, and dellicatnes of their dyet.

div.head: ¶ Of a certaine Sicilian whose ey sight was woonderfull sharpe, and quicke.
div.p: THere was in Sicilia a certaine man indued with such sharpnesse, quicknesse, and cléerenesse of sight (if report may challenge credite) that hee coulde sée from Lilybaeus to Carthage, with such perfection and constancy, that his eies coulde not be deceiued: and that he tooke true and iust account of all Ships and Vessels which went vnder sayle from Carthage, ouerskipping not so much as one in the vniuersall number.

Something straunge it is, that is recorded of Argus, a man that had no lesse then an hundred eyes, vnto whose
custody Iuno commited Io, the daughter of Inachus, being transformed into a young heyfer: which Argus (his luck being such) was slaine sléeping, but the Goddesse Iuno so prouided, that all his eyes (whatsoeuer became of his carkasse) should be placed in the Pecoks taile: whervpon (sithence it came to passe) the Pecock is called Auis Iunonia, Lady Iunos Birde. This historie is notable, but yet the former (in mine opiniō) is more memorable.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the eleuenth Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The twelfth Booke of the variable hystorie of Aelianus.
¶ Of beutifull Aspasia.
div.p:
ASpasia the Daughter of Hermotimus Phocensis, after yt her mother dyed in childbed, was trained & brought vp, not as the children of rich, welthy and worshipfull parents, (for such ability of substance was wāting) but like a friendlesse infant, in pouerty and great lacke, and yet notwithstanding in honesty, hansomnesse, and decent order. There appered often times to her in her sléepe a vision, or dreame, prophecying what fortune she was borne vnto, namely that she should be married to a wel fauoured gentlman, of courteous demeanour & laudable behauiour. This Aspasia when she was but a younge wenche and nothing néere womans estate, had rysen vnder her chinne a sore swelling, much lyke vnto a wenne, which was a meruelous deformity, and a disfiguring to her faire and amiable countenaunce, an occasion of great gréefe to her father, and a prouocation of no lesse sorow to the tender maiden. Wherfore ye careful & louing man being desireous to haue his Daughter deliuered from such a blemishe, brought her vnto a certain Surgeon to be cured, who after he had séene the damosell, to salue and handled the tumor with his fingers, promised vp the sore, and to heale it so perfectly, that all future inconueniences shoulde be preuented and no doubt of daunger remaine. Howbeit he made this couenaunt vppon condition, that vnto hym shoulde
be payd the sum of thrée Staters, which kinde of poyse is by valluation the summe of six nobles of englishe coyne. The poore man making aunswere that hee had not somuch as he demaunded, no more sayde the Surgion haue I further to deale with you younge daughters disease. Whereupon Aspasia conceiued such sorrow and anguish of hart, as the penne of this historiographer cannot sufficiently describe, nor the mindes of such as reade this present declaration perfectly enough consider: in so much that she departing from thence home to her fathers house where her continuall abydinge was, wept, wayled, lamented and mourned, that great streames and riuers of teares gushed from her eyes, in which sorrowfull estate she tooke her looking glasse sundry and oftentimes, & laying the same in her lap, behelde the wenne which grewe by her throate, and pondring what a great stayne it was to her face, pitifully complained, as the swéet singing and siluer feathered Swanne, at the appropinquation and drawing néere of death: when as therefore she was plunged in this perplexity, and drowned in the whirlpoole of hideous and gastly heauinesse, when I say the increase of her comfortlesse cogitations, and troublesome thoughts, did so sting her that she forsooke her ordinary sustenance, she fell into a déepe and dead sléepe (very luckely no doubt) and therewithall appeared vnto her a vision in the forme and figure of a Pigeon, which immediatly chaunged his shape, and was transformed into the similitude of a woman, vttering these wordes to Aspasia, with a cléere and a swéete sounding voice. Bonum animum geras Aspasia, vale antque medici cum suis pharmacis: tu vero rosea serta veneris, que iam aruerint, cape, eaque contrita tuberi impone. Be of good chéere Aspasia, and let the Surgeons goe with their salues, their emplasters, their instruments seruing for incision, and adustion: onely take thou the roses which are in the garlands dedicated to Goddesse Venus,
so they be dry and withered, bruse them and stampe them to pouder, and lay them to thy swelling. After Aspasia had heard these words of consolation, and had put that in experience which was reported vnto her by reuelation, the wenue consumed, and vanished away, and was no more perceiued then a trembling starre when the bright and glittering sunne shineth in scortching Cancro, then a pale primerose or purple violet among high Elmes and Okes, then a litle wren among great birds with spreding winges, then a young lambe among a thick flock of shéep, or a huge heard of tall stéeres, then a light wherry among a multitude of mighty Ships. Then was Aspasia reckoned in the number of beutifull and amiable maydens, and her comly countenance was couloured with crimson hew, which came to passe by and through the cōpassion & clemēcie of Lady Venus, in somuch that (to acknowledge the manyfest truth) she looked so louingly, and glistered as it were, so gloriously that she had not her match aliue, but was singuler and incomparable: her haire was as yellow as Saffron, Cytron, or beaten Gold: her locks were curled, crisped, friseled, and tusked: her eyes were great, gray, round, and rowling: her nose was white, smoth, shining, slipperye, and crooked, her skinne soft as silke, and tender as carded wull: her eares short, thinne, prety, feat, fine, and proper: Finally her whole countenaunce, forhed, eilids, nose, chéeks, eares, lips, & whatsoeuer els, was lyke the damaske rose sprinkled with morning dew. For which circumstaunces thin habitants of Phocis called her when shee was but an infant, and sucking babe, by the name of Milto: her lippes were bright sanguine red, her téeth as white as the elephants tooth, or as the fethers of a swan, as the tops of hills couered with daseling snow, as lawne, callecooe, or the finest Holland, washt and swadled in cléere running water. Besides all this shee was swift footed, as the women were in the age of Homer that auncient and gray bearded Poet, whom he tearmed
by this Epithet 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a worde well agréeing to Aspasia for that property, she had a fine and a swéete toung, in so much that when she spake a man would haue auouched that he heard a Syren sing, for the vtterance of her voyce excelled the reuiuing sound of the wyre strynged Citerne: and yet, notwithstanding the premisses, she abhorred brauery, she passed not for pompe, pride she vtterly defied, gaynesse she set light by, curious apparel she contemned, to trim and painct out her selfe shee had no desire (for such costly prouision requireth large expences, and the maintenaunce therof a mountaine of money) as for her, she was but a poore mayden, her cofers were not ouercharged with coyne, sithence she was borne, bred, and brought vp vnder the winges of her poore parentes: and therfore had not to disburse and lay out largely in gorgeous ornamentes, to cast a misty cloude ouer mens eyes to iudge amisse of such suborned beuty.

It fortuned vpon a time, that Aspasia was brought before the presence of Cyrus the sonne of Darius, and Parasatis, the brother of Artexerxes, but sore against her will, and no lesse, likewise against her fathers minde, who was very loth to geue his consent thereunto: but being vrged to goe by compulsorie meanes, after which manner commonly, they came by the constraint of the Kinge, his Péeres, and Nobles, when their cities were taken, ouerrunne, and subdued. One therfore of Cyrus his Lordes amonge the rest, tooke vpon him to bring her before the Kings Maiestie, in the companye, and trayne of other young floureing damosels: vpon which generall presentation (wherin there was such varietie of visages, such confusion of faire faces, such a selected troupe of Venus beutifull blossoms) Fortune did so fauour her, and her inestimable indowments so further her, that she was preferred before all the trim troupe of damosels, and caryed awaye the golden spurres of prayse from all that
faire flocke. Which name of noblenesse she at that instant obtained for thrée seuerall qualities. Primo, propter integritatem animi. Secundo, propter morum verecundiam. Tertio, propter carentem omni fuco pulchritudinem. First for the vprightnes of her minde, secondly, for her honest behauior, & thirdly for her fairenes which was meere natural, and in no respect adulterine or counterfait. Moreouer, this was a singular helpe, that she grew and increased in the fauor and loue of the King, because wisedome had, as it were, taken vp an harbour or lodging in her humble hart, in so much that her deuises were precise, her studies singular and her policies péereles: for which causes Cyrus required her counsel in many matters, and disdained not to vse her aduise in ponderous and waighty affaires belonging to the common wealth. At the first time that Aspasia was presented before the kings person, he had but newly ended supper, and néedes would carrowse the cup after the custome of the Persians, (whose order was after meate, to haue a druncken compotation) and notwithstanding they had packed, farsed, and stuffed their paunches with choyse of dishes before, yet must they fall to their bibbing and bouling immoderatly, wrestling with wine as it were with their enemie, of full intent and purpose, not to spare it till it were consumed, wasted, and spent. In the middest of this their superfluous quaffing, continued of custome and not required of necessitie, two couples of amiable maidens Graecians borne, were brought before the kinge, namely Cyrus, vnprofitably occupied at that instant and vndecently: of which foure Aspasia Phocensis was one, and they were brauely apparelled, gorgeously decked, and set out after the finest and the trymmest fashion. For the other thrée damosells had their heary locks peckt, kempt, and spred in order, by the helping hands of certaine women being their friends, which also came vp with them: their faces were washed with oyle, fragrant oyntments, and swéete
swéete smelling waters, that the orient sauor springing from their skinnes (as it were from a muske rose trée) might make them appeare more amiable. They were also instructed and taught of their ouerséers, what behauiour they shoulde vse before the presence of the Prince, and what maners might best beséeme them towardes his grace when occasion required: that they should not spare painted speach, that they should not shrink for deinty dalyaunce, that they should stande still in one place if he approched néere them, that they should not take it in dougeon if he did touch and finger their faire skins and fine flesh: Finally that they should be liberall in kissing, and pay one for another.

Thus were they furnished with the compleat harnesse of loue, which women commonly vse, as well to allure the hartes of men with their faire faces, as also to purchase good will with their wanton qualities, in so much that one of these young damosels did contend & striue wt another, to surpasse and excell in beautye, brauery, and behauiour. As for Aspasia she was so far sequestred from this corrupt vsage, that she did vtterly abhorre and detest the same, séeing in a mirrour as it were, the mischefes dependinge thereupon and pondring all thinges in the ballaunce of wisdom, perceaued what was conuenient, and what was séemely and decent. She would weare no gorgeous garment, no sumptuous apparell would shee put on, she wold not be sprinckled with cōpound waters, she would not be poudered with perfumes, but contemning all such vanity, wept, wailed, and made inuocation to the Grecian Gods, and the Gods Eleutherian.

She cryed vpon the name of her father Hermotimus, and cast out wofull inuectiues against him and her selfe, as accursed wretches, borne vnder an vnfortunate planet, for she thought the straunge and vnaccustomed train gowne which she was compelled to weare, to be a manifest argument of seruitude, and the superfluous apparel
which she was forced to putt one, to be an euident token of bytter bondage. She resisted to weare such attire, till she was beaten, buffeted, and vncurteously intreated for her so dooing, and albeit she subscribed to the will of the noble man, whose office and peculier charge it was, to sée such things orderly done, and did yeald to his commaundement with a grudgeing and a repining stomack (as they might apparauntly perceaue) yet was she constrained to put that in practise, which became not a chast and vnspotted Virgine, but an impudent & shameles strumpet. The other thrée young maidens (if they were such) entred into the priuy chamber of King Cyrus, beheld him boldly without blushing, smiled vppon him smoothely, and cast a venerious countenaunce vppō him, not respecting the celsitude & highenes of his grace, nor regarding the homelynes and base estate of themselues. But Aspasia (who was also with them at the same time) looked downward to the ground, hanging her chin in her bosome (for her face was stayned with the crimson coulour of shamfastnesse) & from her eyes gushed fluds of salt teares: such were ye perturbatious of ye modest maidens minde. To be short, in al her behauiour and external gesture (which was aunswerable to the commotions of her hart) she shewed a certaine kinde of seemly bashfulnes, O how properly it béecame her person. Now when the king had viewed and reuiewed them with glauncing eyes, & commaunded them all to syt downe about him, the other thrée damosels, without strayning courtesy, did as the kings maiesty bad them, & tooke their seates with a great redynes. Onely Aspasia, gaue no eare to ye words of Cyrus, or at least wise though she heard his voice, was very lothe in that pointe (considering her lowe degrée) to be obedient. But the noble man which presented her to the king wold not haue her so excused, but pulled her perforce and placed her in a conuenient roome. When Cyrus had béen a while in this amorous company of damosels, whē
he fealt & fingred their softe fleshe, when he beheald their rowleing eyes, when he pleased him selfe with the sighte of their cherry cheekes, when he handled their longe and slender fingers, when he did what sensualities stinge prouoked him to practise, they let hym alone and gaue him leaue to dooe with their bodyes what he lyst. But Aspasia being impacient of such petulant and wanton demeanour, shriked and squeaked out when Cyrus offered to touche her after such an vnhoneste fashion, and sayd that if his Grace would not leaue such wanton dalliance, shee would make him beshrewe his owne fingers. As for Cyrus he was inclined to the greater disport, and procéeded further then he did before in so much that he was buisy to handle her silck softe, and milck white papps, wheruppon she being moued, arose suddenly out of her seate, and ranne awaye from him contrary to the custom of the Persians. Then Cyrus broyleing in loue, beganne to burne, or rather to flame in the fyer of affection, for the bewty of Aspasia had not so much inchaunted his hart, as her behauiour had bewitched the same. Anon Cyrus lookeing vppon the Noble man whiche bought and brought Aspasia to the Courte, sayde, Hanc solum ingenuam & incorruptam adduxisti, Reliquae vero tam facie quam moribus sunt impostrices. This damosell whome thou hast presented vnto me is honest, blameles, vnspotted, & without blemishe: as for the other thrée, both their painted and starched faces, and their vnmodest manners betrayes them to be no better then harlots. And therfor did Cyrus plant his loue vppon her, more then he did vpon any other, with whom he had aquaintaunce and kept company. After yt tyme, loue begaine to gather strenghte and tooke déepe roote in the harts of them both, insomuch that the swéet sapp of mutuall amity, dispersed and spred it selfe so abundantly, that the braunches of true loue beganne to budde and beare blossoms, yea at last yealded
such fragrant frute, and therwithall so comfortable, that Cyrus and Aspasia waxed in a maner all one, and séemed, in all points and circumstaunces, to agrée and consent in the sober society of mariage, after the custom and trade of Grecia. This goodwill of king Cyrus to Aspasia was so manyfestly testifyed both by worde and by déede, that the fame therof dyd flye, not throughe Ionia alone, but also throughe out the whole region of Grecia: and Peloponnesus in semblable manner was replenished and filled with the same reporte. Furthermore Kinge Cyrus was enriched with this renowne besides, and this glory was added to his noblenesse, for it was thought and beléeued that he vsed the company of no woman, nether one nor other, but forsooke all his lemmans, concubines, & paramours, after he had gotten the loue of Aspasia, and obtained the body of so bewtifull and vertuous a damosell. Among al these alterations, chaunges & chāces, Aspasia remembred her dreame of the Pigeon, and recorded ye wordes which were vttered vnto her by reuelation in her sléepe, and whatsoeuer ells was prophecyed by the lady of loue she called to memory: wherfor, she being touched with deuotion, to thintent she might séeme wel to deserue of so gracious a Godesse, procured a great image to be made, which she called by the name of Amiable Venus, and caused the type and forme of a white Pigeon to be set next by it, which she decked with pearls and inriched with precious stones, offring sacrifices vnto Venus daily, beséeching her with prayers and supplications, that she wold of her clemency cast the glymmering beames of beuty vppon her continually, and that she wold indure to be her fauorable mistres and louing lady that as she had wonne a certaine préeminent opinion of worship and estimation, so shee might by due desartes, kepe the same vndeminished, such was her noblenes of minde, and her vertuous inclination so incomparable.

Moreouer Aspasia was kindled with due consideration of her fathers Hermotimus pouerty, to whom she sent innumerable gifts, and presents of no small pryce and estimation, wherby of a pore man he was made rich, & of one worth naught, he waxed opulent & welthy. She was also very chast, sober, modest and continent, al the length of her lyfe, wherof the women, as well of Grecia, as also of Persia can giue sufficient testimony & witnesse. There was sent to Cyrus from Scopas Iunior out of Thessalia, a Iewel of great value & price, which was first sēt to Scopas out of Sicilia. This Iewel was wrought with wōderful cunning, & therin was variety of workmanship, in so much that euery one to whom Cyrus gaue a sight therof marueled not a litle at ye worthines of the same. Cyrus reioycing in this Iewel out of measure, & accompting therof as of an inestimable treasure, went to Aspasia vpon a sodain, when the sunne was entred into ye South, whom he founde fast a sléepe in her bed chamber: then crept he closely vnder the couerlyd or carpett, and layed himself, downe by her with such silence & quietnes, that in this his endeuour he procured vnto Aspasia no maner disturbaunce in the world, but lay as stil as a lambe vntill she had ended her golden sléepe. when Aspasia awaked, and sawe Cyrus her swéete hart so nighe vnto her, she cast her armes abroade, and after her accustomed fashion of courtesy, embraced him louingly. Then Cyrus takeing out of a caskett or boxe, the Iewell aboue mencyoned, shewed the same to Aspasia, saying, Hoc vel filia vel matre regia dignum donum est, This Iewell is worthy to be giuen to the daughter or mother of a Kinge: wherat Aspasia beckned with her hed, as not dissalowing ye words of Cyrus: En, inquit, id tibi possidendum dono, tu vero cura vt e collo suspensum gestes. Behold, sayth ye kinge, I giue it vnto thée Aspasia to possesse, and to vse, kéepe it & were it about thy lilly white necke. Nuertheles she did not receaue the
Tablet at Cyrus handes, but aunswered his Maiesty in this sorte very prudently, discréetly and wisely, sayeing.

Et quomodo ausim, cum hoc donum matrem tuam Parasatidem, potius deceat? illi igitur mittito: Ego vero vel sine ornamento hoc, tibi collum satis venustum praestitero. Should I be so bold to weare such a princely Iewell, which is more méete for thy mother Parasatis? send it, I beséech thée, vnto her: As for me (O Cyrus) I hope to shewe vnto thée, a necke amiable and beutyfull enoughe, notwithstanding this tablet be wanting. Thus (as is largely declared) Aspasia practised and accomplished with her policy, prudent wisdom, and counsell, things contrary, Et ex diametro pugnantia, and flat ouerthwart to the déeds of the rest of the kings wiues and concubines: and passed them as far in excellencie, as the Sunne dooth the Moone, as Arabian gold doth rusty yron, as Indian pearles dooe grauell stones, as Spanish siluer dooth English leade, as the yellowe marygold doth the wilde wéede, finally as the better thing dooth the worse: albeit they were supersyne and too too curious in trymming themselues, and more nyse then wise in all things to their attyre appertaining. But Cyrus being singularly delighted with the sober answers of Aspasia, and her commendable demeanour, loued her still more outragiously, so that her wise words, and her faire déedes were vnto his hart, as oyle to a burneing lampe, and as séere wood to a scortching ouen. In this effectuall operation and working of loue, he wrote all the sayinges and dooinges of Aspasia methodically and orderly in a letter, which when he had ended, and sealed with his owne Signet, hee sent it vnto his Mother Parasatis, and therwithall in a caskett or boxe, the Iewell or tablet, wherof mencyon so often was made before. After that the letter and the gifte were deliuered, the one perused, and the other vallued, Parasatis conceaued greate ioye and gladnes in them both. But she was
not so much delighted in the gifte sent vnto her by the meanes of Aspasia, as she was enamoured with the reporte of the younge damosels courtesy: For which considerations Parasatis the mother of Cyrus, recompenced Aspasia with royall rewards and princely presents. The young woman (no doubt) was prudent and circumspect, For albeit she was so far admitted into the fauor of the kinge that all other were excluded, that others were forgotten and contempned, yet thus she thought with her selfe secretly. In the sight of Cyrus the sonne, I am precious, and he exhibiteth that excellence of loue vnto me, wherunto none hath ability sufficient (as it séemeth) to aspire: neuertheles, I am not so hauty of hart, to think my self equall to Parasatis the mother, but acknoweledg my self (in comparison of her Gracious ladyship) a very vnderling. The presents and gifts which Parasatis sent vnto Aspasia, were glorious and vnualuable, yet did not she desire to possesse them, but praising the same, and ascribing greate aduauncment vnto them for their inestimable worthines, saide yt she had no néede of such Iewels sythence she had of her owne store, both money and other precious treasures, which were giuen her franckly and fréely. Being thus contented with her owne, and not desireous to increase that which she possessed, she gaue the presents of Parasatis vnto Cyrus, sayeing. Tibi haec vsui esse possunt, qui magnam hominum multitudinem alis: mihi vero sufficit, si te simul amem, & ornamento vtar. Thes thīgs will doo thée seruice, O Cyrus, which maintainest many pensioners, many of ye garde, many officers and seruitures in thy court and ells wher: as for me I thinke this sufficient, namely to loue the, and to liue with the as the pearle of my pleasure, the Diamond of my delighte and the Iewel of my ioy. With this and semblable vsage, she kindled the kinde hart of Cyrus towards her more and more, for (without question) this rare woman, as she
was most amorous in face, so was she most vertuous in minde, and there was not halfe so much force in her heauenly hew, as there was grace in her noble nature.
