This woman (as you sée) with vertue adorned, to honour aduaunced, in fauour confirmed, shee was to the people an admiratiō, to the courteor a spectacle, to the Prince a singular delight, to none inferiour as touching good qualities, beyond all otherin gracious indouments, incomparable and péerelesse in all respects, for her modesty, for her beuty, for her prudence, for her excellencie in all notable properties.

In tract of time, it fortuned yt Cyrus in a foughten feeld against his brother was slaine, and his army discomfited by the force of the aduersary. Aspasia, in lyke maner, fell into the cruell clawes of the gréedy enemye, but Artaxerxes made diligent inquisition for her, vnderstāding her dexteritie in behauiour & noblenes. Now when the mercylesse souldiours brought her bound with halters lyke a prisoner and miserable abiect, Artaxerxes was angry out of measure thereat, and charged that the masters of the mischéefe should be imprisoned for their paines. Hee commaunded moreouer (after he had satisfyed his eyes with the sight of Aspasias beuty) that gorgeous garmēts should be geuen her to weare & put on, which words whē she had no sooner hard, she refused all wt sighings, sobings lamētatiōs, & siluered teares trickling downe her chéeks, wherwith all her bosome was wet & moystened, yet notwithstanding these euident signes of a grudgeing stomack, she was constrained to be clad wt ye rich robe which the king assigned & gaue her, al this while she mourned & sorrowed most bitterly for ye death of her déerely beloued Cyrus. When Aspasia had put on the apointed princely apparell, there was not a woman more beutyfull to beholde throughout all the Borders of that Region: Then, loe, the forge of Artaxerxes affections flamed,
then, Lo, it sparckled, then, Lo, it was in an inextinguible heate which might hardly be quenched, in so much that his hart fryeing in this fornace, languished and fainted with extreame loue: wherefore he estéemed more of her, then he did of all his wyues and concubines, and as she was chéefest and principall, so had she moste bestowed vppon her, to her worship, honour, and renowne, by the benefite of her externall fauour which was angelicall, and her internall vertue, whiche was supernaturall. Thus dealt Artaxerxes with Aspasia, hopeing indéede, and confidently persuading himself, yt this was the only way to roote and race Cyrus out of the register of her remembraunce, and to conuert and turne her hart wholy, and soly vnto himselfe.

But he sat beside the saddle (as the prouerbe sayth) and leaned besyde the cushing, immagining such a matter: for her hart was so closely lincked and chayned to the hart of Cyrus whiles he liued, that nothing might suppresse & ouerwhelme the same when he was dead: sythēce the loue of him was ingrauen in the depth of her bowels, & wrought in her, like a magical incantantion and witch craft, effects that were incureable. Not many dayes after this, Teridates the Eunuche, (who was the fairest youngman in all Asia, and the very floure of beutye in comparison of the rest, when he was past the state of a stripling, & was newly planted in the pearle of his age, the softe heares springing about his chéekes, his chynne, and his lipps like soft wooll or fine downe, and his youthful bloud dispersed through his tender flesh, stayning his allabaster skynne with a crimsone colour) ended his life.

This proper youth was the kyngs principall delight, and therfore did hée moste gréeuously, and pitifullye lament the losse of his lusty loue, and the gemme of his Ioy: besides that, there was a vniuersall sorrowe
and a generall mourning throughout all Asia, euery one supposing that they exhibited good seruice and duty to the kings person, in pertaking his pensiuenesse, anguish, vexation and perplexity. No man durst be so bold as to come within the Princes presence, either to comforte his hart oppressed with heauinesse, or to mitigate and aswage the motions of his minde, considering that it did exceede all possibility to reclaime him from these perturbations, or to succour him in this grating agonie.

After thrée dayes were expired and ouer passed, beutifull Aspasia hauing on her mourning gowne, stoode in the way as the king should goe to the bath, wéeping waylyng, wringing her yuory handes, and looking downeward to the grownd as one dashed with tenne thousand doubtfull doumps: whom when the king behelde in that plainting plight, hee was abashed, his harte was griped with gréefe, and he demaunded the true occasion of her so sudaine comming vnto that place. To whom she shaped this aunswer and sayde, Te, Rex, lugentem moerentemque consolatum veni, si tibi sic visum esset: sin minus retrogrediar. I come, O King, to minister consolation and comfort vnto thée, which lamentest so bitterly the death of thy late delight, if it may please thée to admit my goodwyll, and to accept my seruice: if not, as I am come hether, so am I content to returne. The king reioysing at the sober speach of Aspasia, bad her goe back agayne, and abide in her bedchamber till his comming, whose commaundement she fulfilled with great diligence, and no lesse duty and obedience. When Artaxerxes returned from the bath, and founde Aspasia in the appointed place, he tooke the garment of Teridates the Eunuch, and put it on Aspasias mourning gowne, and the young mans robe did in a manner fit her body, as if measure had bin taken to kéepe iust syze, in so much that the brightnesse of her fauour, and the glittering glasse of her coulour, appeared more gloryous in the presence of the kings maiesty then
it was wont: for Aspasia by the wearing of that apparrell, represented the persō of the Eunuche whom Artaxerxes loued excéedingly, and within the same costly wéede was her owne body harboured, so that the gemination and coupling of these two seueral and singular benefits, ingendered delight in the hart of the King. Then Artaxerxes declaring himself well pleased with that kinds of attire, which Aspasia at that instant had put on, intreated her swéetly and louingly, that she would vse his company oftentimes, in that sorte apparrelled, vntill the stormes and tempests of sorrowes, which were but latly and newly rysen, were alayd and ouer paste. To whose desire she shewed her selfe applyaunt to the vttermost of her ability, as one most willing to do his maiestie good. And she alone (all other exempted) comforted his Grace, asswaged, or rather soundly salued vp the sore of his harts heauinesse: for the which her kindnesse he behaued himselfe courteously vnto her, and framed himselfe to some lightnesse of spirit, and at length forgat all vexation and anguish. Thus did Aspasia performe and accomplishe that, which al the faire women in Asia besides, not al his sonns, nor any of his affinity and kinred could compasse by any maner of polisy and practise.

div.head: ¶ Of the Muses.
div.p: NO Painter nor Grauer, hath at any time described and sette out before the eyes of the people the Images of Iupiters Daughters harnessed like warlike women. Whereby is signified, that the lyfe which is led in learning, and spent in knowledge, ought not to be tumultuous, and troublesome, but calme and peaceable.

div.head: ¶ Of Epaminondas, Daiphantus, and Iolaida.
div.p: EPaminondas hauing receiued his deathes wounde in a foughten féelde at Mantina, & being carryed all in gorebloude to his owne tentes while hee was yet aliue, commaunded that one should go for Daiphantus, yt he might resigne his whole authority vnto him and proclaime him Captaine general in his place. When they which were present at the geuing out of this mandate, or message, saide that Daiphantus was slayne, hee commaunded yet once agayne that Iolaida shoulde bee gone for, that hee might occupy the roome by succession: when aunswere was made, that Iolaida was dead also, Epaminondas persuaded his people to conclude peace, and agréement with the enemies, because there was not remaining in all Thebes, after his decease, a man fyt ennough for the office of a Captayne.

div.head: ¶ Of Sesostrides.
div.p: THe Aegiptians saye, that Sesostrides learned cunning, skilfulnesse, counsel, and knowledge of eloquent Mercurie, the Embassadour to the Gods immortal.

div.head: ¶ Of Lais.
div.p: LAis the Harlot, as Aristophanes, Byzantius rehearseth, was called by the name of Axine, which worde reproued her sensualitie, her wyldnesse, her forwardnes, and her cruelty.

div.head: ¶ Of the the parents of Marius, and Cato.
div.p: THey which brag, and boast of the nobilitie of their byrth, & vaunt of the antiquity of their progenie, ar not so much to be commended as to be dispraised and skorned: For it cannot be knowne who was father to Marius, among the Romanes, and yet his worthy prowesse, and valiaunt feates of Armes, haue made him a worlds wonder. Furthermore, whosoeuer is desirous to learne and vnderstande, who was father to Cato Senior, it is requisite, and necessary, that he impart much paines, and bestow great labour, in searching out the same in olde records, and yet peraduenture be neuer a whit néere his purpose.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexander, and Hephaestion.
div.p: ALexander crowned the tumbe of Achilles, and Hephoestion crowned the tumbe of Patroclus: signifying that he loued Alexander as sincerly, as Patroclus loued Achilles.

div.head: ¶ Of the craft and deceipt, of Cleomenes, against Archonides.
div.p:
CLeomenes Lacon, taking vnto him one of his acquaintaunce called Archonides, made him coadiutor, partner, and fellowhelper with him of his purpose: To whom Cleomenes sware, that if he might be master
of his attempt, he would neuer take any enterprise in hand but Archonides hed should be at one end therof, to speake more plainly, that the head of Archonides should be present with him in euery practise, and polisy. Now when his luck was such that he obtayned his desire, and had his will and wish to his owne contentation, he found the meanes to murther his companion, cut his head from his shoulders, and layde it in a basen of hony: so when Cleomenes was determined to put any deuise in aduenture, he cast his eyes aside and looked vpon the basen, or charger wherein the head of Archonides lay, which hee vsed in al his consultations saying these wordes. Pactum meum non violo, neque iusiurandum fallo, Etenim consilium cum Archonidis capite capio. I breake not my promyse, but I stand to mine oth, for I take counsell with the head of Archonides according to my couenaunt,

div.head: ¶ How Timesias departed out of his countrey, vpon a conceipt of his owne. minde.
div.p:
TImesias gouerned the Clazomenians, in iustice and equitie, for hee was a man well furnished with all kinde of vertues. Enuy therfore, which commōly controuleth such men as he was, did spyt and spewe out the canckeringe sting of her poyson at him. At the first the hate and yll will of the people hunted him, but hee was not much moued therewithall. The cause why hee forsooke his country (as some say) was this. Vpon a time as he passed by a schoole, he met certaine boyes comming homward, and as two of them were disputing and reasoning De Linea, of a Line, the one of them sware with
an oth, saying, Sic ego Timesiae cerebrum discusserim. Thus would I knock Timesias about the costarde, and beate out his braynes: which wordes Timesias heareing, conceiued in his mind, and imagined with himselfe secreatly, that he was hated of all men, and that nether citie nor countrey could abide him: besides that, he gathered thus by his priuate consideration, that he whom pilde boyes had in such contempte, must néedes be lesse regarded among men indued with discretion, whereupon he packte with spéede out of his countrey.

div.head: ¶ That the Aeginets first coyned money.
div.p: THe Aeginets, when time was, coulde doe very much, and in a maner what they wold, among the Grecians, vsing the aduauntage and profit of all seasons as well as they: For they had their nauies furnished for fighting, and they were of great force, and power. Besides that, they preuailed against the Persians, and therefore they had the first victorye, and triumph. They were the firste that coyned or stamped money, wherupon it was called by this aunswerable name, that is to say, Aeginean Coyne.

div.head: ¶ Of the hill Pallantium, and of the Temple, and Altar of Febris.
div.p: THe Romans erected and built a temple & an altar to Febris, at the foote or bottome of the mountayne Pallantium.

div.head: ¶ Of an Adulterer, which was apprehended and taken in Crete.
div.p: AN Adulterer taken at Cortyna, a citie in Crete, after his apprehension, was brought before the iudge was accused, cōdemned, and wore about his head a wreath or rowle of wull: signifying thereby, his sensualite, lightnesse, effeminacy, and womanlynesse. Moreouer he had a penalty set vpon his pate publiquely, namely the sum of fifty Staters. Thus sustained he singular shame for his misdéede, and was vtterly vnabled, and debarred from all possibility of preferment, and worshipfull offices in the common wealth.

div.head: ¶ How Gnathena gaue a pratlyng fellow a priuy quippe.
div.p: A Certen louer came from Hellespōtus to Gnathena, an harlot of Athens, by and through a certaine brute, which was published and blowne abroade of her: when as therefore this fellow babled many words without rime or reson (as they say) among the cuppes and cannes, and could not sée when to make an ende of tatling: Gnathena spake vnto him in this sort, didst thou say thou camst from Hellespontus? who aunswered yea, why then (sayth she) art thou ignorant of the Archipolis, or principall citie in that region? what citie I beséech thée saith he is that, I wot not wel: It is faith she, Sigeum. By which word or name (very witely and pretily) shee quipt the pratling panion, for his liberty of speach which was limited with no measure. For this word in Gréeke signifieth Silence, wherof cam Sigeum, ye name of ye said citie.

div.head: ¶ Of diuers which excelled in beuty and comlynesse.
div.p: AMong the Grecians, Alcibiades is reported to haue carried away ye spurres for amiablenesse of countenaunce, and comlinesse of proportion. Amonge the Romanes, Scipio, and Demetrius Poliorcetes were counted péerelesse. And Alexander the Sonne of Phillip was very faire, and louely, yet did he bestowe no labour, nor cost in decking, pecking, and painting himselfe: for his haires hung about his eares and shoulders this way, and that way, being as yellow as the Marygold, & in coulour lyke Safron. Some also say that Alexanders looke was somwhat terrible, his visage fearefull and tyrannicall. The auncient Poet Homer, in describing such as were fayre of fauour, and amiable in making, compareth them to tall trées.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine notable men, that made themselues playfellowes with children.
div.p:
HErcules (as some say) asswaged the tediousnesse of his labours, which he sustayned in open and common games, with playing. This Hercules, I say, being an incomparable warriour, and the sonne of Iupiter and Latona, made himselfe a playfellowe with boyes. Euripides the Poet introduceth, and bringeth in, the selfe same God speaking in his owne person, and saying, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . I playe, because choyce
and chaunge of labors is delectable and swéete vnto me, which wordes he vttered holdinge a boy by the hande. Socrates also was espied of Alcibiades vpon a time, playing with Lamprocles, who was, in manner but a childe. Agesilaus riding vpon a réede, on cockhorse as they terme it, played with his sonne being but a boy: and when a certayne man passing by, sawe him so doe, and laughed therewithall, Agesilaus sayde thus. Nunc tace, cum verò & ipse pater euaseris, tunc etiam patres imitaberis. Now hold thy peace and say nothing: but when thou art a father, I doubt not, thou wilt doe as fathers should doe with their children. Architas Tarentinus, being both in authoritie in the common wealth, that is to say a magestrat, and also a Philosopher, not of the obscurest sorte, but a precise louer of wisdom: at what time he was a housbād, a houskeeper, and mainteined many seruaunts, he was greatly delighted with their younglinges, vsed to play oftentimes with his seruauntes children, and was wonte, when he was at dinner and supper, to reioyce in the sight and presence of them: yet was Tarentinus (as all men knowe) a man of famous memorie and noble name.

div.head: ¶ At whose vertue Alexander was displeased.
div.p:
ALexander could not abide Perdiccas, because he was warlyke, he hated Lysimachus, becouse he was cunning in ordering a battel and pitching a féeld: he enuied Seleucus, because he was full of prowesse, courage, and valiantnesse, he abhorred Antigonus, because he was ambitious, and high minded, he grudged at Attalus, because his power was princelyke, and his estate imperiall. Finally he repined at Ptolomeus, because of
his beatitude, his prosperitie, and happinesse.

div.head: ¶ Of Demetrius haunting the house of an harlot.
div.p: DEmetrius, ye Lord of so many nations, and Prince of so many people, haunted the house of an harlot called Lamia, hauing on his armour, the badge of a warrior, and his Diadem or croune, the cognisaunce of a King. It woulde haue binne a great shame and reproche vnto his person, if he had sent for her to come to his Pallace: what was it then, in that he frequented her baudy abideing, and vsed her company so lasciuiously and wantonly. Assuredly I commende the Musician Diodorus beyonde Demetrius, for he although he was sent for, and desired to goe, refused the harlot Lamias courtesie.

div.head: ¶ That Phaon was of a fayre complexion.
div.p:
PHaon, a proper youth, excelling al other in fauour and comlynesse, was hidden of Venus among long lettisse which sprung vp and grew very rāckly. Some holde opinion that this Phaon was a ferry man, and that he vsed that trade of lyfe and exercise. So it fortuned that Venus had occasion to passe ouer the water, whom he not so redely as willingly, tooke by the hand, and receiued into his whery, and carryed her ouer with as great dilligence as he could for his lyfe, not knoyng all this while what she was: For which dutifull seruice at that instaunt exhibited, Venus bestowed vppon
him an Allablaster box full of oyntment for her ferrage, wherwith Phaon washing and skouring his skin, had not his fellow in fairenesse of fauour, and beutyful complexion aliue: insomuch that the women of Mitylen were inflamed with the loue of Phaon, his comlynesse did so kindle their affections. To be short, he was taken playing ye leude knaue with a commō whore, and abusing his body in beastly pleasure of the fleash, which swéete meat had sower sawce, for he was slayne and murthered.

div.head: ¶ Of Sapho.
div.p: PLato the sonne of Aristo, numbreth Sapho the Versifyer, and daughter of Scamandronymus amonge such as were wise, lerned and skilful. I heare also, that there was another Sapho in Lesbus: which was a stronge whore, and an arrant strumpet.

div.head: ¶ Of the Nightingale, and the Swallow.
div.p:
HEsiodus reporteth that no byrde, but the Nightingale alone, auoydeth slepe and is greatly addicted to watching, for she sitteth all night singing vpon a bough, the sharpe end of a thorne standinge against her breast to kepe her broad waking: he saith also, that the Swallow doth not watch alwaies and at all houres, but sléepeth now and then, by halfes as they say and fyttes, which is no sound kinde of rest. This punishment suffer they both for the heynous offence committed at Thracia, in a banquet most abhominable & an vnlawfull feast
wherin the mother made the father eate the fleash of his owne sonne: afterwardes there was a transmutation of shapes, for Tereus was turned into a Lapwing, Itys into a Phesant, Progne into a Swallow, and Philomela into a Nightingale.

div.head: Of the women of Lacedemonia
div.p: THe Mothers of the Lacedemonians, as many as heard saye that their sonnes were slaine in battel, vsed to goe and searche their dead bodies, how, and in what order they were cut, slasht, & mangled: And yf the woundes, and the gashes were in their forepartes, then they carried their sonnes to the monumentes of their progenitours, and tumbes of their auncestours, with manyfest resemblaunces of ioy: but yet casting grim and sower vissages now and then, for the losse of such courageous ympes. Againe, if they were wounded behinde, or one either side, they blushed thereat, as vtterly ashamed: and pyning away with bitter teares, and wofull lamentations, conueied themselues closely out of sight, leauing the carkasses of such cowardly children behinde them, that they might be buiryed among the common graues, sithence they deserued no peculier place, by their puisaunce and manhoode: Or els they gotte the dead bodies away by stealth, and laide them in Sepulchers priuatly, at their owne mansions.

div.head: ¶ Of the strength of Titormus, and Milo, and of a certaine Prouerbe.
div.p: MIlo spreading abroade his proude pecoks tayle, because he was so stronge in body and large of lymmes, chaunced to méete Titormus the heardman, and perceiuing hym of stature substantiall, huge, big and mighty, wolde néedes take a triall of his strongth: but Titormus sayde that he was nothing so strong as he séemed, or as he was supposed. Now when he was prepared to wrestling, and cast his garmentes aside, he drewe towardes him a stone of maine bignesse and waight, hee did lift it vp and downe twise or thrise: Anone hee tooke it vp againe and did lift it to his knées, then to his shoulders and cast it quite from him. As for Milo he could not once styr the stone for his hart.

The second exercise that Milo and Titormus had, was this. Titormus went to his herd of bullocks, & standing in the midst of thē, caught a fearce Bul faste by the foote, and griped him with such sure and harde holde, that the Bull could not sting or flurt out of his fingers, though he would neuer so tayne, he tooke holde in like maner of another Bull which came towards him, and did as he had done before. When Milo had séene and marked these practises of Titormus, as a man all amased in minde at these miracles, he cast vp his hands to heauen, and made this exclamation, or outcry. O Iupiter, num hunc alterum Herculem nobis dedisti? O Iupiter, haste thou geuen vs this fellow as another Hercules? Hereupon sprung and spred this common prouerbe, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
This is a second Hercules.

div.head: ¶ Of the audacitie and bouldnes of the people Celtae.
div.p: THe people Celtae are most ready, and able, to take any kinde of daungerous aduenture, and are not afrayde of any blustringe storme. Therefore in the honour of such as fought manfully in féelde and lost their liues lustely in battel, were hymmes & songs deuised and made: and the vse of them was, when they went to skuffling and skirmishing to weare garlands or crownes vpon their heades, as infallible and confident persuasions to themselues of hoped victory. Furthermore they appointed themselues monuments of triumphes, vaunting of their valiauntnesse, and left euidences of their vertues for their posteritie and successors, as the maner of the Grecians was. They count runninge away so reprochfull, that oftentimes they will skarce moue when a house is ruinous, and ready to fall vpon their heades, or when it burneth eagerly in euery corner, and is in a bright flame rounde about them: Moreouer some of them are so boulde or rather desperate, that they throw themselues into ye fomey floudes with their swordes drawne in their handes, and shaking their Iauelines, as though they were of force and violence to withstand the rough waues, to resist the strength of the streame, and to make the floudes affraide least they should be wounded with their weapons.

div.head: ¶ Of Smyndiridas curiousnesse, and costlynes in meates, and of his gluttony.
div.p:
Smyndiridas the Sybarite, was so geuen to gluttony, and belly cheare, that when a younge man, who had
long wooed and at last wedded Agarista the daughter of Clisthenes, he tooke a iorney to Sicyon, and brought with him from thence, a thousande Cookes, a thousande Butchers, a thousand Foulers, and a thousand Fishers.

div.head: What helpers & frendes many worthy and noble men haue vsed.
div.p: VLysses had Alcinus to be his helper, Achilles had Chiron, Patroclus had Achilles, Agamemnon had Nestor, Telemachus had Menelaus, and Hector had Polidamas. The Troians had Antenor so farre fourth as they were his followers, the Pithagoreans had Pythagoras, the Democristes had Democritus, and certenly, if the Atheniens had geuen eare to Socrates, and had ben desirous to acquaint themselues with his wisdome, happy, yea twise happy had they bene, & might meritoriously haue bene named Socratists. Hiero the son of Dionomenes, vsed the familiarity of Simonides Ceus, Polycrates vsed Anacreon, Proxinus vsed Xenophon, Antigonus vsed Zeno. It is my duty also (as I think) to make cōmemoration & rehersall of Rome mine auncient Countrey, as wel as of Greece a forreigne region, sithens I am a Roman bred and borne. Lucullus vsed the familiaritie of Antiochus Ascalonita, Mecoenas vsed Arius, Cicero vsed Apollonius, Augustus vsed Athenodorus. And Plato the Prince of Philosophers, who excelled me in wisdome and learninge many degrées, sayth that Iupiter himselfe hath one or other to be his counseler: But who he is or what he is, or how he healpeth, or wherin, we wold gladly and willingly, that Plato gaue vs to vnderstand.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine Tosspots, and Drunckardes.
div.p: These vnder named, ar reported to haue bin the greatest swillers and most notable drunkards among all men. Xenagoras Rhodius, who was called Amphora, a Flaggon. Heraclites the wrestler. Puteas the sonne of Lanica, whose education, and bringing vp was with Alexander the king. And Alexāder himself was counted a singuler winebibber, and such a one indéed, as no man was able to ouermatch.

div.head: ¶ That Hercules shewed himselfe pityfull and gentle to his enemyes.
div.p: HErcules vsage towardes his enemies (as some say) was very pitifull and gentle. For he (time out of minde) deliuered, according to his couenaunt, the carkasses and dead bodies of men to their fréendes and acquaintance, honestly and decently to be buried: when it was not the custome in those daies, to be touched with any care of the dead, for they left them vnburied, to be eaten and deuoured of Dogges, whereof Homer maketh mencion.

div.head: ¶ Of Leocorium a Temple in Athens
div.p:
LEocorium at Athens, was called the Temple of the daughters of the people, namly Paraxithea, Theopa, and Eubula. The voice goeth, that the people deliuered
them to the Oracle at Delphos, and that they were slain for the health and sauegard of Mineruas citie. For the Oracle sayde, that except they lost their liues, there was no hope of preseruation. So the Temple was called Leocorium, by the meanes of them and the people, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifyeth Populus, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifieth Puella, or, Filia.

div.head: ¶ What Plato saide of the Agrigentines for their prodigall and excessiue spending.
div.p: PLato the sonne of Aristo, when he saw the Agrigentines bestow vnmeasurable costes and charges in building, and banqueting, vttered these words. Agrigentini aedificant, quasi semper victuri: & comedunt, quasi semper morituri, The Agrigentines builde as though they should alwaies liue, and they féede as though they should alwayes dye. And Timaeus saith, that they vsed oyle potts and instruments of Siluer in forme lyke horscombs, and that their tables were made, wholy of Elephantes tooth, or Iuory.

div.head: ¶ Of the drunkennesse of the Tarentines, and of the intemperaunce of the Cyreneans.
div.p:
IT was the maner of the Tarentines to swill lyke Swine, so soone as they started out of their nestes, and to make themselues drunke in open place of resort, in the midst of the multitude. The Cyreneans also, did so contaminate and stayne their liues with the filthy
spots of surfeiting and intemperaunce, that when they sent for Plato to institute and appoinct them lawes, he refused to come among them, because their loosenes & lasciuiousnes, was knytt to continuance by the lincks of custom, and their slouthfulnes and ydlnes déeply rooted in them from the begining. And Eupolis wittnesseth in Marica, that the meanest men, and they which be of the rascall rablement, had armeing sworde girdles of tenne pounde, and that they graued rings very cunningly, curiously, and incomparably, insomuch that their woorckmanship was woonderfull.

div.head: ¶ The soundry sorts of wines which the Grecians had.
div.p:
NOw will I commemorate and rehearse vnto you the diuers kinds of wines amoung the Grecians, which wines were most cōmended in auncient tyme, and principally praysed in the dayes of our predecessours. Ther was one kinde which they called Vinum Paramneum because it was consecrated & made holy to Ceres ye Goddesse of Graine. And another called vinum Chium after the name of a certaine Island in the middland Sea. And another called vinum Thasium after the name of Thasus an Island in the Agean sea, very famous for the cobnuts which grow there, and for the goodnes of the wine which is made in that soile. And another called vinum Lesbium, after the name of a certaine Island called Lesbos, abbutting nighe Troas a Countrey in Asia bordering vppon Hellespontus. Moreouer, they had besides the aboue specified, a certain wine called vinum Dulce (which we call Yppocrasse, or Bracket) because it was swéete, deinty, toothsom and pleasaunt. And another called vinum Creticum, after
the name of an Iseland called Creta lyeing betwéene Graecia and Cyrenea, and in Syracuse the same wine is called vinum Polium, which tooke that name of a certaine king of that region. And another wine called vinum Coum: after ye name of a certaine Island called Coos or Cos in the Aegean Sea. And what shall I say to this variety of wines? ar they not testimonies of the Grecians intemperance, & manifest argumēts of their excessiue swilling? To conclude, they vsed to drinck Wine mingled wt ointments, which kinde of medley they inglutted aboue measure, and thrust in more then nature (whiche is satisfied with a small quantity) required. The name of the said compound wine was vinum Myrrhinitum. Philip the Comicall Poet maketh mention therof in his poesies.

div.head: ¶ Of the Garments and the shooes of Pythagoras, Empedocles Hippias, and Gorgias.
div.p: PYthagoras Samius was clothed in white apparel, and did weare vppon his head a crowne of Golde, so did Anaxyrides. Empedocles Agrigentinus did weare murrey or violet blewe garmēts, and his shoes were of brasse. As for Hippias & Gorgias they vsed to iet vp and downe the streats, in clothing of purple colour.

div.head: ¶ Of the Romanes, that allowed not of the subtilty, and false dealing of the Phisician of king Pyrhus, against his soueraigne Lorde and King, intended.
div.p:
Cyneas the Physician of King Pyrhus, wrote letters priuely to the Courte and counsell of Rome, wherein hee craued a péece of money and promised that he
would so worke with potions and Apothecary compositions, that king Pyrhus should come to ruine, and destructiō. As for the Gentlemen, to whō these trayterous schedules were sent, and directed, they vtterly mislyked of so mischeuous a fact, and refused his proditorious promise in that pestilent point, and damnable attempt: for Romanes haue learned to be valiaunt in vertue, and seeke not to subdue their enemies by such couert and close practises, and deceiptfull dealynges. Shortly after they informed king Pyrhus of Cyneas his knauery, and bewrayed the trayterous purpose which he was fully intēded (for lucres sake) to accomplish against the King, his league Lorde and Soueraigne.

div.head: ¶ Of the loues of Pausanias, and Appelles.
div.p: AMong all the Loues in auncient age, longe since paste and gone, which are left in the Annales of antiquitie, and recorded in the Chronicles of our great grandfathers, these following (in comparison of the reste) are memorable, and excellent. Pausanias loued his wife, so feruētly, and so vnfainedly, that it is not possible to describe it. Appeles in like maner, loued Alexanders Leman, named Pancasta, a Larissean borne with no lesse constancy: with whom (as it is supposed) Alexander had fleshly pleasure.

div.head: ¶ Of the Perianders, the Miltiades, the Sibylls, and the Bacides.
div.p: THere were two Perianders, the firste a Philosopher, and the second a tyran. There were thrée Miltiades, the first was the founder and bulder of Cheronesus, the seconde was the sonne of Cypsellus: and the third was the sonne of Cymon. Ther were foure Sibylls, the firste an Erithraen, the seconde a Samian, the third an Aegiptian: and the fourth a Sardianan. Some there be which ioyne six more, to the other foure, and so make tenne in number, among which they recon these twaine: Sibylla the Cymean, and Sibylla the Iudean. There were thrée Bacides the first a Grecian, the second an Athenien: and the third an Arcadian.

div.head: ¶ The numder of Niobes sonnes.
div.p:
THe olde auncient writers dissagrée among themselues, in the number of Niobes Sonnes. Homer recounteth syxe Sonnes, and syx Daughters. Lasus recordeth twise seauen, that is fouretéene. Hesiodus rehearseth two eightes and a third, that makes ninetéene. But (peraduenture) they ar not Hesiodus verses, wherin that number is expressed, for hee was thought to be the author of many poesies, which indéede he neuer deuised, nor yet penned. Alcman saith that there were but tenne. Mimermus affirmeth that there were twise tenne, that is twenty. And Pindarus
is of the same opinion, who also writeth that there were no more, nor no lesse then twenty.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexander being in skarsitie of victuals: and how certaine villages, or country townes were taken by the sight of smok.
div.p: ALexander, in pursueinge Bessus, was driuen to great skarsitie of victuals, both he and his souldiours (except they had rather starue and dye with famishment) began to eate the fleash of Camels, oxen, and other cattell. In which want of necessary foode, they were constrayned (for the great lack of wood and fuell) to eate the fleash rawe, that the bloud ranne about their téeth and gummes, as they did crashe it with their grinders.

Othersome they did eate, boyled and rosted, accordinge as their burnable stuffe (which was a certen hearb wherof commeth, as some say Gumme Benioyne, or as other some say, Gumme Laser) serued them, wherof their was aboundaunce, and plenty in that place growing.

Moreouer the souldiours tooke certayne villages and townes of the Bactrians, by reason of the smoke whiche they perceiued a loofe, after they had remoued the abundaunce of snow which lay before their dores.

div.head: ¶ Of the horses of the people Sacae, and of their maners, custom, and behauiour.
div.p:
THe Horses of the Saces, (a people inhabiting beyonde Scythia, and thought of some to be Persians) if at any time they hoysted, cast of, and vnsadled their riders, vsed
to stand still like Lambes, that they might mount vp againe on their backs, at their pleasure without perill, to delight them without daunger. Moreouer, if any man was desirous to marry a maide, and to wedde her to his wife, the fashion and custome was, that hee should fight with her, in which encounter, if he were ouermatched, it was lawfull for her to leade him away as prisoner, and to haue rule ouer him and full authoritie: But if shee were the weaker (as women commenly be) and therfore vnable to moue masteries with him, then had hee iurisdiction and power ouer her. Furthermore, they striue and contend, but why? and for what? not about life and death, but about victory, liberty, and triumphe. Finally, the custome and trade of the people Sacae is, to hide themselues in certain blinde, & vnfrequented places, as darke as pitch, like dens, and dongeons, at such time as they mourne, and lament.

div.head: ¶ Of the bouldnes of Perdiccas, and of a Lyonesse.
div.p:
PErdiccas the Macedonian, who followed Alexander Magnus in battel, was so stout and bolde, that he feared not, to enter into the daungerous denne, of a Lyonesse, solitary, alone, and no body, accompanyed with him. But (in this aduenture) he tooke not the Dam, but her welpes, which he caryed out of the Denne with him, not fearing ye clawes of so violēt a beast: which déed of Perdiccas deserued the admiration and astonishement of all men, and challenged a commendation of desperate courage, not onely among the Grecians, but also among the Barbarians. And therefore (say some) yt Semiramis of Assyria, wolde not, that a Lyon, a Pardall, or any such sauage and stately beast should bee slaine: and that
she her owne selfe (if it were her chaunce at any time to haue a Lyonesse) was so far from killing her, that she did most carefully kéepe her, delight in her, and plant the principall portion of her pleasure in her, accordingly.

div.head: ¶ Of the prouision, and purueyaunce which followed Xerxes in his expedition.
div.p:
AS great prouision and store of all necessaryes, followed the Campe of Xerxes, so was ther water also of the riuer Choaspis carried, to serue and succour the souldiours. It fortuned that in their expedition, they came to a sandy soyle, and dry plot of lande, in maner of a desert or wildernes, insomuch that they were assaulted, and oppressed with an extreame thyrst, to quench the heat wherof, no remedy could be found. Then was the king himself a cōmunicant of ye same vniuersal incōuenience, ye peril wherof to preuent (in respect of his owne person) he caused proclamatiō to be made, through out the whole army, that if any maner of man (what degrée so euer he bare) had any water of the riuer Choaspis he should bringe it to the kings maiestie, to asswage his thyrst. The Proclamation being made, and the charge geuen generally, an od fellow was founde who had a litle of the same water in store, but it was so farre from swéetnesse, that it stunk lyke puddle pysse: Howbeit the kings maiestie did not onely reioyce at that same present preseruatiue, but also vsed the benefit of the same incontinent, and drunke vp the filthy & vnsauory water, with a good stomak, whereby he slaked the fire of his former thirst. As for the homely fellow, who presented and offered this tymely medecine, and holsome antidote, to
Xerxes, was recompenced for his labour, and the kings Grace numbred the meane man, amoung his benefactors and wellwillers, because he had bene in hassard and losse of lyfe, if that water had not bin brought with such-oportunitie, wherby he was preserued from imminent mischéefe, as by a principall potion ministred by the Physician in due season.

div.head: ¶ Of Protegenes the Paynter.
div.p: PRotogenes, after he had consumed and spent seuen yeres space, in limming, and paincting, the picture of Ialisus, at last (as hap was) he finished and ended the same. when cunning Apelles saw it, he stoode still at the first, a pretty while, and held his tounge, as alltogether abashed at the brauenes of the same: At the lenghte he looked behinde him and said, Labor magnus est, & artifex item excellens, verū operi gratia non inest: quam si homo consecutusesset, Labor eius caelum attingeret. The worckmanship (vndoubtedly) is notable, & the worckman excellent, but it wanteth Grace, which, if Protogenes his picture might haue obtained, the praise therof would haue pearced the Azur skyes.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine men which were nourished, and fostered by wilde beasts.
div.p:
CYrus ye sonne of Mandala was nourished by a Bitch, Telephus the sonne of Agaue and Hercules by a Hynde, Pelias the sonne of Neptune & Tyro by a Mare, Alexander the sonn of Alope & Pryamus by a Bytchfox,
Aegisthus the sonne of Thyestes, and Pelopia, by a Goate.

div.head: ¶ What men, comming of a homely and obscure offspring, became noble, and honorable.
div.p: DArius the sonne of Histaspa was Cyrus his quiuerbearer. The last Darius, whō Alexander vanquished, was borne of the body of a bondwoman. Archelaus, the Macedonian Kinge, cam of ye loynes of Smicha, a poore maid seruant. Menelaus, the Graundfather of Philip, was numbred among bastards: and Amyntas, his sonne, was a seruingman, & gaue attendaunce vppon Aeropa. Perseus, whome Paulus the Romane ouercame, was but an Argiue, & sprung of a homely house. Eumenes (as it is thought) had but a poore fellow to his father.

Antigonus, the sonne of Philip (who had but one eye, & theruppon was called a Cyclop) serued for sallery, and waighted for wages, vnder Polysperches, and differed litle from a théef, for he practised purloyneing prancks, and filching fetches. Themistocles, who foiled his foes, in a skirmishe made on the Sea, who had, also, the gracious gift of interpreting Oracles, was the sonne of a simple Tressan woman, named Abrotonus. Phocion, syrnamed Iustus, was at the first but a Spoonemaker or a Ladell maker. Demetrius Phalareus, was but a seruaunt in the maison and house of Timothy and Conon. Hyperbolus, Cleophon, and Demadas, notwithstanding they were in place of principality, in the Athenien commonwelth, yet it is a difficil and hard matter to prick out their parentage. Callicratidas, Philip & Lysander were
called Mothaces in Lacedemonia, which signifieth such as were domestical seruants, trayned and brought vp among the children of the house. Cōcerning thē Lycurgus made a lawe, wherin was graunted, that such as continued their children in exercises, (which was no lesse necessary to the common estate, then profitable to their priuate person) should haue frée passage (without interturbāce) to offices of dignity in the Lacedemonian weale publique. Epaminondas also, had but a simple man to his father. And to be short, Cleon the tyrant, Monarch. or kinge of the Sicyonian people, was but a Pyrat, or roner vppon the Sea.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine persons, which continued a long tyme in quarreyes of stone in Sicilia
div.p:
IN the bounds of Sicilia were certain quarreyes of stone the lenghte of one furlong, and the bredthe of two Acres. In ye place were diuerse persons kept so longe, that they marryed, mingled, and raised vpp issue of eather sex: And if any of their children cam to Siracuse, and sawe horsses draweing waynes and waggons, they were so flighted and frayed, at the sighte thereof (which to them was straunge, and vnaccustomed) that they roared and ranne away, with hydious and yrcksome squeaking. The fairest, and largest place of these quarreys of Stone, borrowed the name of the Poet Philoxenus, wherin, at such tyme as he was conuersant, he made his Cyclopean Pamphlet, which contained the best, the fineste, and the excellentest Poems that euer his brayne deuysed: little regarding the punishmente
which Dionysius had appointed him, and not careing, a corne graine, for his condemnation. But this man was so far from feare and trembling, that in his tormentes and miseries, he would exercise sweete and delightsome musicke.

div.head: ¶ Of Midas, Plato, and Pindarus, in the time of their in fancie.
div.p: THis is a Phrygian reporte, whereof I am now to make relation: when Midas was but a sucking babe, and lay faste a sléepe, Ants or Pismers crept vpon his face, and carryed into his mouth (as into a barne or garner) wheate, rye, and other portable graine, with great sedulitie and painefulnesse. Of Plato, it is saide all ready, that the Bées made hony in his mouth, as in a hiue. Pindarus, also after he was committed to the desperat aduenture of doutfull luck, Bées ministred sustenance to the infant, féeding him with toothsome, and comfortable hony, in steade of milk, and sugred pap.

div.head: ¶ Of a straunge Miracle, and wonder, prognosticating the gouernment of Dionysius.
div.p:
DIonysius, the sonne of Hermocrates, swamme ouer a riuer vppon his Ceuals back, now, Syr, when his Paulfrey approched nie the shoare, the durt & mud was so fat and so fast, that the horse faultred, and was not able to wade through without much moyleinge: Howbeit Dionysius made shifte to fauour himselfe, and by meanes made as hee might, caught holde
of the bank side, and left his horse behinde him, as though it were his, no longer to possesse and vse: when Dionysius was gone, and the horse left in that hassarde, by much strugling he recouered ye land, which aduantage being obtained, he made swift gallop after his Lorde and master, wehing very often, and flurting vp his héeles all the way as he went, insomuch that Dionysius hearing the noyse which his horse made after him, returned and méeting his Paulfrey, tooke him by the mayne, offering to mount vpon his back, & as he was thus dooing a swarme of Bées, came buzzing about his hand, which when Dionysius marked, and mused at, he demaunded what this Miracle and straunge thing might preporte and signifie: To whom the Galeotae made aunswere, that it did prognosticate and foreshew the Monarchie, and Regiment of Dionysius.

div.head: ¶ Of Aristomache, the wife of Dion.
div.p:
DIonysius hauing expelled, & driuen Dion out of ye limits & bounds of Sicilia, kept his wife Aristomache, & his sonn in lyke maner, still with him, & dealte not with them, as he did with the housband, and the father Dion aboue named: In tract of time, it came to pas, that he bestowed the Gentlewoman in wedlocke (but sore against her wil) vpon a Pensioner of his, called Polycrates, a studious seruitour, diligent in his office, & dutiful in all respects, by birth & ofspring a Syracusā. But, fortune fayling Dionysius, and furthering Dion, it hapned that Dion tooke Syracusae, and droue Dionysius to Locris, a country of Phocis. The matter being brought to
this issue, Arete his Sister (after much communication continued) intreated Dion (for at that instant, she vouchsafed to be mediator, and intercessor, in Aristomache her behalfe, for her restitution, and reconciliation to her husband, and yokfellow) to take vnto him Aristomache his wife, whom sinister luck had before abandoned: As for the Gentlewoman (notwithstandinge the case touched her owne person to the quick, and did as it were searche the marrow and sinewes) yet by reason of her shamfastnesse, and bashfulnesse, whereunto she was forced by her late froward Fortune, she was so far from pleading her owne suite, that she hid her selfe out of sight, and durste not be so bould as once to come within the compasse of her housbands countenaunce, much lesse to speake with him personally: and this did shee, because she was constrayned, by compullsory dealyng, in despight of her hart, and vtterly against her will, to breake the bondes of dutie, sealed with the signet of faith and truth in marriage, and to crack in sunder the couenaunt whereunto shee subscribed solemnly. But after Arete had maintained her cause, and made the best of the matter, like a wise and prudent woman, affirming alwaies this in circular talke, that what soeuer she had doone, procéeded of prouocation, and constraincte, by the meanes of Dionysius: Dion was intreated, contented, and pacifyed, and commaunding that his wife Aristomache, and his sonne shoulde be brought before him, sent them both home to his owne manor.

div.head: ¶ Gf the poesies of Homer.
div.p:
THe Indians vsed to sing the poesies of Homer, as they were translated and turned into their mother tounge. So did the kinges of the Persians, if we count them worthy
credite, who haue so reported.

div.head: ¶ Of Phocion, who pardoned and forgaue his enimies, and such as did him harme.
div.p: PHocion the sonne of Phocus (who oftentimes, spent his labour and diligence, in the affaires of his natiue country) was adiudged to die: Now when hee was deliuered to the Gaile, and kept in close prison, diuers of his fréendes had recourse vnto him: & when the poyson was ministred in a Cup or a Chalice, by the hands of the executioner or officer, his acquaintaunce standinge by, demaunded of him, what he woulde leaue to his sonne in charge, after his death to be accomplished? To whom Phocion made this aunswere. Hoc ei mando, ne cum iniuriae memoria rependat Atheniensibus hanc propinationem, quam ego nunc bibo. It is my will and pleasure that, for this cup of poyson, which I take, taste, and drinke vp, as my present dispatch, hee recompence not the Atheniens with remembraunce of iniurie. He which denieth this man worthy of aduauncement and praise, wanteth wisdome and iudgement in my simple opinion.

div.head: ¶ Of the Lacedemonians, imparting no paines, nor bestowing any labour, in the learning of liberal sciences.
div.p:
THe Lacedemonians were vtterly vnlearned, for they regarded nothing but the excercises of the body, and to be warlyke was their whole study and desire, if any of them stoode in néede of the helpe of knowledge, the ayde of learneing, and the succoure of counsell, eyther by occasion of sicknesse, or in an opinion preposterus, and
perilous, or els a common calamity of the people: they betooke them to the aduise of straungers, as ignoraunt of themselues, what should be done in such cases: After this sorte they vsed the furtheraunce of Physicians, and the Oracles of Apollo Pythius. They sent for Terpander, for Thales, for Tyrteus, for Cedoniat Nimpheus, and Alcman a Musician, to be conuersaunt amonge them. And Thucidides (speaking of Brasidas) reporteth, yt they were destitute of learning, and vnderstanding, for (saith hée) this Brasidas, being a Lacedemonian, was very vnskilfull, and indéede, differed but litle from an idiot.

div.head: ¶ Of the ostentation, and bragging of Menecrates, and how Phillip gaue him a dry frumpe, and a priuy mock.
div.p:
MEnecraces, did so swell in pride (being a Physician) that he called himselfe Iupiter, or Iuuans Pater. This arrogant asse, sent vpon a time, to Kinge Phillip of Macedonia a letter, wherein was written this sawcy salutation Menecrates Iupiter, Philippo salutem &c. Menecrates Iupiter, to Phillip gréeting &c. whose vaunting vaine the king perceiuing, wrote back againe in this sort and maner. Philippus Menecrati sanitatem. &c Philip Macedo, to Menecrates wisheth welfare, &c. Consulo vt ad Anticyram te conferas, I counsell thée to take thy iorney to Anticyra: meaning by this drye frumpe, that the man was moonesick, and beside his right wits. The foresaid Philip, made vpon a time, a sumptuous and costly banquet, whereunto he inuited and bad Menecrates, commaunding his seruitours that ther should be a table prouided, and set by it selfe in a place seuerall, that the
cuppboorde shold be furnished with due preparation, and swéete perfumes tempered, burned, & scattered, against the comming of the sayd Menecrates, all which costes was expended and laid out, to pleasure the fyne nosde gentleman, whooe sat solitary, and alone at a syde boorde by himselfe. Whiles all the company (which were byddē guests) tasted of the toothsome chéere, and the sumptuous feaste, which wanted no variety of delicates, but nothīg serued in to the table where he sat by himselfe: he held him contented, for a season, and delighted, in the greate worship and honor which was exhibited vnto him (being in a manner regall, saueing that he was kept fasting, which was after a sorte, seruile) But after that hunger griped his gutts, and appetite whetted his stomack, in so much that his téeth watered at the Cates which he sawe he was then taught by experience that he was not Menecrates Iupiter, but Menecrates Mortalis, & forthwith he arose from the table, went his way, & thervppon complained of the iniury which he suffered, béeing a bydden guest to that banquet, wherof he not once tasted. Thus did Philip cut Menecrates combe, and detected the mad mans vanity.

div.head: ¶ Of Isocrates, vnto what he compared Athens.
div.p:
ISocrates the Rhetorician, was woont to say, that the city of Athens was comparable to a Strumpet, or a common whore for (sayth he) such as be allured and entysed with ye beuty of harlots, would willingly deale with them in bodily delight: but yet no man (except he cared not for his honesty and life) so wel thinketh of a strumpet, that he estéemeth her worth the marrying. And, assuredly, the citie of Athens is at the same stay, for
it is pleasant & delectable to soiourne in (& in that point excelleth all other Cityes through out the countrey of Grecia) but it is scant holsom to inhabit. By these words he gaue a glaunce to Pickthanks, Clawbackes, and Flatterers, of whom Athens nourished a great number, for the Citie was naturally addicted to harbour and lodge such Helhounds.

div.head: ¶ Of the beginnings of bloudy Battailes, and of causes of contentious.
div.p: I Am not ignoraunt, what wofull warres, and bloudy battailes haue sprounge of small beginnings (as sore consumeing fyers, commonly are séene, to be kindled of litle glittering sparckles) and tryfling matters, in a maner. For the Persian skirmish grewe by the occasion of a grudge betwene Maeander Samius, and the Atheniens. The Peloponnesian warre arose about the table of the Megarenses. The conflict, called Praelium Sacrum, began about the exaction of the iudgments of the Amphyctions. The Cheronean warre, bred of a light occasion betwéene Philip and the Atheniens.

div.head: ¶ How Aristotle attempted, to turne the anger of Alexander, to gentlenes.
div.p:
ARistotle being desireous to assuage ye wrath of Alexander, and to mitigate ye motions of his angry mind or rather to quench the flame of his fury: wrote these words vnto him. Excande scentia & ira, non in pares, sed in meliores existere solet, tibi vero nemo par est, Indignation, and anger, ought not to be conceiued against a mans Equall, but against his Better: As for thée, (O Alexander)
I know none that is thy péere, much lesse thy superiour. The same Aristotle ministring counsell to Alexander, in his affaires, and informing him, what to doo was conueniēt: procured sundry soueraigne cōmodities in many matters, and specially in reedifiyng, & building his countrey, which Philip had, almost, vtterly subuerted, spoyled and ouerthrowne.

div.head: ¶ Of such, among the Libyans, as were slaine of Elephants, or els lost their liues in hunting, or fighting.
div.p: THe Libyans buiry such, as were slaine of Elephantes, or dyed in battell, or hunting, moste honourably, and soung funerall ditties in their high commendation. The argument of those sonets is this: that such men as valiauntly, and victoriously behaued themselues, in resistinge, and as it were in wrestling with wilde, sauage, and indomitable beasts, not feareing their force, were worthy the name of noble Martialists. Furthermore, this is their sayeing, that to make an exchaunge of lyfe for death, gloriously, is a triumphant tumbe, to him which is interred, and layde in the bosome of the graue.

div.head: ¶ What Diogenes spake of the Megareans.
div.p:
DIogenes did after a sort, vehemently inueigh against the doultishnes, and blockishnes, of the Megareans, speaking of them in this order. Mallem alicuius Megarensis arietem esse, quam filium, that is to say: I had
rather be the Ram, then the sonne, of a Megarean: importing by this his speache that those people are more carefull ouer their cattell, then ouer their children.

div.head: ¶ Of the Miracles, which appeared to the Thebans, when Alexander assaulted the Citie.
div.p:
WHen Alexander was conductinge his hoste to the Theban Citie, the supernall powers, namely the Gods, sent straunge signes, and tokens amonge them, prognosticatinge, and foreshowing such a slaughter, as the semblable was neuer before. But they heareing that Alexander was dead at Illyrium, discharged opprobrious pillats, of slaunderous language against him. The Miracles which appeared vnto thē were these: A certaine Lake in Onchestus, made such a horrible & continual roaring, that both wals, fortresses, gates, foundations, and buildinges substantial, trembled and shaked therewithall. Moreouer a certaine Springe, or brooke, called Dirce, which was not far of from Ismenus, and somwhat nye the walles of the Cittie, where as at all other times before, it ran with a cléere, pure, fayre, swéete, and wholsom streame, sudainly and contrary to all expectation, was turned into bloude: By which prodigeous and wonderfull sight, the Thebans suspected, that the Gods immortall threatened destruction to the Macedonians. Moreouer within the citie walles, namely in the Temple of Ceres, a venemous spider, hard by the vissage and face of the delubre, or Image, practised her science and art of spinning, and drew her cobweb strings in great length, very nimbly. The Image also of the goddesse Minerua called Alalcomēis (signifiyng by interpretation,
mighty to defend, and puissaunt to preserue) set it selfe on a fyre, and flashed out flickering flames, like lightenings, no man could tell how, or by what meanes, but it was burned vp, and quite consumed. These and many more such lyke terrible tokens, infinit & inumerable, fortuned among the Thebans.

div.head: ¶ Of Dioxippus.
div.p:
DIoxippus the Athenien, a worthy wrestler at Olympus, at what time he passed into the Citie of Athens on horseback (as the custome of such wrestlers craued) a great swarme of people, some from this place, and some from that place, came clustering into the streates, as most desireous to haue a sight of the man. Among all which multitude, there was a certaine woman, passing faire, and beutifull, who came as the reste did, to behold Dioxippus in his brauery. As Dioxippus rode through the throng, casting his eyes rounde aboute and espying this young woman (an entysing snare of slippery Lady Venus) was suddenly ouercom with the comlynesse of her countenaunce, insomuch that his face was seldom beside her, which was subiect to as many colours (by reason of the preualent, and forcible perturbation of his minde) as the chaungeable Cameleon: this affection of Dioxippus (being lyke vnto a violent streame which will perforce, haue issue) became so manyfest in the ende to the people, then and ther assembled, that one with another gaue this opinion, that there was some blossome of beuty which had bewitched his hart. But among all the rest, Diogenes Sinopensis, rebuked this mans mind, so losely led with loue into lust, for he bought him a golden looking glasse, of Corynthian worke, and sayde to thē which stoode by him: En pugilem vestrum magnum, quomadmodum
a puella configitur. Beholde youre valliaunt wrestler, how pittifully he is pearced, and as it were, gored to the heart, with the vaine beuty of a young gyrle.

div.head: ¶ Of verity or truthe, and of benefits or good turnes.
div.p: THis is the sentence of prudent Pythagoras. Haec duo diuinitus data hominibus, longe sunt pulcherrima, veritatem amlecti, & beneficijs operam dare: vtrumque enim cum Deorum immortalium operibus comparari possunt. Two things ther be geuen to men from heauen, which ar most excellent, the one is to imbrace Truthe, and the other to doo Good: both which may be compared with the workes of the Gods euerlasting.

div.head: ¶ Of Dionysius, and of Philip.
div.p:
IT fortuned vpon a time, that Dinoysius the second, & Philip ye sonne of Amyntas met together, and falling into communication of many matters (as the vse and custom is in conferrence, & circular talke) they harped both vpon this string: Philip asked this question of Dionysius, Quomodo, cum tantum regnum accepisset a parente, non id defendisset, & conseruasset. How it chaunced, that he, hauing receiued so ample a patrimony, and so large an inheritaunce of his father, did not defend, and mainetaine the same. Who made this aunswer
vnto Philip, Non mirum, quoniam cum reliqua mihi pater omnia reliquisset: fortunam solam, qua ea parauerat, & tutatus fuerat, non etiam tradidit. Meruaile not man, at that sayth he, for my father leauing all thinges vnto me in aboundaunce, to possesse: did not deliuer in lyke maner, vnto me his flourishing fortune, and good luck, wherby he obtained, and gouerned the same.

div.head: ¶ Of the honour, exhibited to the Northerne Winde called Boreas.
div.p: DIonysius prepared a nauy of thirtie sayle, well fraught with Bisket, bread, béefe, and conuenient victuals, and no lesse furnished with warlike necessaries, in his expedition against the Thurians: But the blusteringe blastes of Boreas the Northren winde, wrestled so violently with them, that it did not onely hinder them in their passage, but also sunck certaine of their vessels, rent their sayles, burst their mastes, and spoiled al things vnto them belonging. Wherupon the Thurians exhibited heauenly honour to the Northren Winde, by a common consent proclaymed it frée of their incorporation, partaker of all immunities to their citie pertaining, allowed it an house to dwell in, furnished with conuenient implements, and vtensiles domesticall, and offered vnto it (as vnto a God) yearely sacrifices. Not the Atheniens therefore only thought the Northren Wind their fauourer: but the Thurians also esteemed it their defender. The selfe same thing to haue bene done of the Megalopolites reporteth Pausanias.

div.head: ¶ The Persian law concerning the kings counselours.
div.p: THe custome of the Persians was, that if any man ministred counsell to the king, in obscure, difficil, ambiguous, and doubtfull matters, he should stand vpon a golden plate: And if the counsell, which he vttered, were approueable, necessarie, and holsom, he should receiue the golden plate in recompence of of his labour, and departe so rewarded. Neuerthelesse, if he stood in contradiction with the king, & said otherwise then the king himselfe did, it was prouided, that whipping and skourging, should be his satisfaction and wages. But to deale in this order (wherein extreame iniurie apparauntlye is practised) with a good man, agréeeth not (in my iudgement) with reason or right: for thus ought vagabonds to be serued, and slauish hyrelinges: greater courtesy, to the prudent, should be exhibited.

div.head: ¶ Of the loue of Archedicas.
div.p:
ARchedicas loued a certaine harlot in Nancrata, but she (in consideration of his case) was hauty, high harted, disdainfull, pitilesse, exacting large sums and demanding vnmesurable gaines, for one halfe houres delectation: her fashion and custome was, first to haue her rewarde in hande (for shee lyked to deale the surest way) and then for a while to shewe suche signes of solace and such louely lecherous tricks of disport, as might content the desyre of him, who laide her downe so liberall, or rather so prodigall a payment, as shee accustomably required,
afterwards she would wax straunge (as though she were to woo againe) and wold medle no more, except she were accordingly pleased. The youngman (Archedicas I meane) being inflamed with the loue of this harlot, but not inioying her company, to quallyfie his kindled concupisence (for she was wonderfull wealthy, and therfore the more high minded) fixed his phantasies so firmly vpon her, and kept the image of her body somuch in his memory, that at nighte going to his bed, and laying him downe to sléepe, such imaginations occupied his braine: that he fell into most pleasaunt and delightsome dreames, wherein, he thought that he was in naked bed with the woman, and vsed her body in actual venery, insomuch that, Titillatione earnis spermate euocato, the séede of generation slipped from him in his sléepe: And thus were the sparkling flames of his affections quenched for a season.

div.head: ¶ Of Alexander when he was dead.
div.p:
ALexander, the sonne of Philip, and Olympias, when he was dead at Babilon, he lay vnburied: He (I saye, who vaunted himselfe to be the sonne of Iupiter) whiles his Péeres and Nobles, were at variaunce about succession in the kingdōe, remained aboue ground and his carrion carkasse wanted a sepulchre: which is bestowed vpon the body of euery poore, impotent, and succourles begger, ye law of nature exacting such speciall duties in funeralles, that the dead should not be vnbuyried: He neuerthelesse, continued aboue ground for the space of twenty dayes and tenne, and so remayned, till Aristander Telmisensis (whether he was pricked thereunto
by som extraordinary, and heuenly motiō, or by som other rare, secret and mistical meanes) rushed into the route of the Macedonians, and made this short speache vnto them then assembled: Omnes omnium seculorum reges Alexander faelicitate superauit, tam viuus, quam mortuus: Etenim Dij immortales mihi notum fecerunt, in quacunque terra ipsius anima requiem primum esset habitura, cam faelicitate abundantem & ab omni hostili vastatione in perpetuum fore liberam. Alexander, when he was liueing, and now also being deade, excelled all Kings of all Ages, in felicity, happines, beatitude, and prosperytie: For the Gods euerlastinge, haue reuealed and made manyfest vnto me, that in what region soeuer the soule of Alexander first did rest, the same should be crowned with plenty and aboundance, it should not feare the wasteing of forreigne force, nor be subiect to the violent inuasion of the spightful aduersarie. When the Péeres of the people, and noble men hard these words pronounced by Aristander, they cut of all quarreling for supremacie, and euery one of them put to his helping hand, with no lesse desire then duty, to conuey Alexanders carkasse, into his owne empire, that they might possesse their Treasure, and althings in peace, hauinge among them the soule of so Conquerous a king (so wel accounted of in heauen, and so much merueiled at in the earth) as an assuraunce of the valliauntnesse, a warrant of the continuance, and a speciall pledge of the perpetuitie and euerlastingnes, of the dominion vniuersal. Ptolomeus (if report may challenge credit) made inquisition and search after the dead body of great Alexander, found the same, and caused it to be caryed (with all spéede possible) to the citie of Alexander, situate and built in Egipt. As for the Macedonians they were calme, quiet, and styl, Perdiccas onely excepted, who pursued, Ptolomey with might and mayne (not so much for the loue, duty, and reuerence
which he had to Alexander, as for the words of prophesie, pronounced by Aristander) and after he had ouertaken Ptolomey, he stayed him perforce, insomuch that there arose betwixt them, a sharpe and sudden conflicte and encounter, about the carkasse of ye Macedonian Monarche (I meane) Alexāder. This skirmish was comparable (in som respect) to that which sproung about the simulachre of Troy, as Homer recordeth, saying that Apollo rushed among ye thickest of the Nobles for Aeneas: But Ptolomey suppressed the power of Perdiccas, and cooled his courage: For he made an image which resembled Alexander the puissaunt, he garnished it gayly and gorgeously: he beutifyed it with apparell of princelynesse, he adourned it with Epigrams, inscriptions, and poesies of high honour, he layde it in a Persian Chariot, and decked his coffin and beiare, brauely with golde, siluer, and yuory, as became the estate of an Emperour: As for the carkasse it selfe, it was but homelye handled, for it was wrapt in no costly geere, but very basely vsed, and as present occasion craued, priuily sent away, by secret and vnknowne waies to thintent it might not be intercepted or staid. Now whē the lord Perdiccas espied ye sumptuous simulachre of Alexāder, & saw euery thing (as he thought) royally executed, & pompouslye perfourmed, hee paused from his spéedye pursuit after Ptolomey, perswading himselfe, that he had obtayned the thinge (namely the dead body of Alexander) whereabout such strife and contention kindled, and burned, betwéene them both so eagerly. But he was deluded for all that, and vnderstoode the truthe somwhat to late, and perceaued that he was craftely circumuented, after he had prolonged his pursuit, & was not able to continue the same any further Of the ende of Alexander (nothing like the course of his lyfe) this declaration, is a cléere, smooth, bright, and glistering Glasse.

But leauing to discourse of Perdiccas, Ptolomey, and Alexander (whose dooings are copiously registred, in the volums of famous Historiographers, and compendiously here mencioned by me, in this short abstract, and abridgment) I wyll haile vp mine ancker, hoyse vp my sayle, and direct my shipp to the thirtéenth hauen, which lyeth betwixt me, and the ende of this my determined voyage and purposed passage, hopeing that as I haue hitherto had good luck and prosperous successe in my Nauigation, so to finde a fyt ariuall, aunswerable to mine owne expectation.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the thriteenth Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: ¶ The thirteenth Booke of the variable Hystorie of Aelianus.
¶ Of Atalanta.
div.p:
OF Iasione Atalanta this brute is blased. When shee was borne, her father (not regarding her) forsooke her vtterly, defending his fact, with this bréefe and blunt saying, Non faeminis opus habeo, sed viris, I haue no néede of womē, but of mē: sonnes I set by, but I care not for daughters. Howbeit the fellow to whom she was delyuered to be made away, did not kill her, but being touched with tendernesse, and kindled with compassion, carryed her to the mountaine Parthenius, and laide her by a spring, wher was a gréene banck, a caue, & a groue of oks: this hapened to her in the sucking yeares of her infancy. The childe was reiected, caste away, and appointed for the slaughter, howbeit it came to passe preposterously, her luck being louely, and her fortune fauourable, This to be true the euent, and successe of thinges evidently proue: For shortly after that the babe was left to aduenture, a wilde beare, whom certaine huuntsmen had lately robbed of her whelps, hauing her dugs swolne, as it were, with aboundaunt increase of milk, raunged that way & (as it came to passe, by ye inopinable prouidence of almighty God) was so far from deuouring the swéet infant, that she delighted in it aboue all measure, gaue it suck most tenderly: whereby insued a mitigation of woe and gréefe to the heare, and sufficient sustentatiō to the
prety babe which otherwise had béene comfortlesse: This Beare after shée had geuē sucke to the Childe, raūged about, to séeke her whelpes which were takē away, & cōtinued her comming by ye same place, where ye séely infāt lay, whome shée noursed, succoured, fostered, & reléeued with her milke, in stede of her owne whelps, whome (because shée had vnluckely lost) shée could not feede, and cherishe. The huntsmen (who had spoyled this beare of her younge) sought vpp hill & downe dale for this beaste, to catch & insnare her, that, as they had gotten ye whelps, so they might also haue the Damme: and as they were searcheing euery corner of the Groue of okes, where the Beare raunged (after her accustomed manner) through pasture plotts for sustenance, they happened vppon Atalanta the Babe (whose name, at that tyme, was not Atalanta, for it was geuen her afterwardes by occasiō) and they carryed her away with them out of the wildernes, where shée lay desolate, and forsaken, to their owne habitations, and dwellings, bringing her vp among thē with such countrey fare, as with them was vsuall. In processe of tyme, when shée began to growe in stature, and increased in yeares (althoughe youthe be subiect to infinite infectiōs, and poisoned with innumerable pestilent enormities) yet shée (such were ye gracious endowements, of her modest minde) imbraced chastitie, abstained from the company of men, desired, and delighted to liue solitary, and the hills of Arcadia were her accustomed walking places. Not farre from thēce (if I said wc in the same circuit or compasse I should not lye) there was a plaine plott of land, watered with braue brokes, and swéete springs, growne about wyth tall okes, open to the puffes and blasts of the whisking windes, & ther was a woode of a notable thicknesse, and largenesse. Why should yt bée tedyous and wearysome to héere of Atalantas denne, as in Homer of Calipsus? in the bottō or valley wherof, was a certaine lōg caue, of a wōderful
profundity and depthe, the passage wherunto was perilous, by reason of the fortifications and fences of stéepe and breaknecke bancks, the créeping Iuy grewe therabout, wrapping the bodyes of the young trées, and tender plants, as yt were with armes, endeuouring to clyme vp to the very tops. There spronge yellowe safron, in the plaine plott, I meane, and also in the wyld wood there flourished the floure deluce, and other flouers of sundry sorts, and diuerse coulors, which did not only delight the eyes of the passingers, but did so season the spirable ayer with their swéete sauours, and perfumed smel, that the braines were abundantly comforted. And albeit they, by their fragrant, orient, aromaticall, and heauenly vertue, dispearsed a singular sollace, and a pleasure incomparable, to all the corporall senses and powers of the body, yet the sense of odoration or smelling, peculiarly, and aboue the rest, was serued with plētifull delectation, Furthermore, there grewe goodly laurell trées, whose gréenenesse neuer vanished, but continued and kept colour without variation or chaunge, then which comfortable hew what might minister more recreation to the eye sight. Besides the aboue rehearsed pleasures, there grewe at the mouth, or entraunce of the caue (as it were in the forme, of arbours) vine trées both red and white, clustred with purple grapes, garnished with gréene crangles about the braunches, & deckt with indented leaues in all places, which offered manyfest (that is somwhat more then probable) arguments and tokens, that Atalanta was not in subiection to ydelnes, nor yet vnfrutefully occupied. Furthermore there were cléere springs, whose running water resembled Christall, the holsome, and healthfull streame wherof was seruiceable, as well to drinke for the asswageing of thyrst, as also to washe, & to bathe ye body, for ye refreshing of ye flesh. These springs did afford speciall succour to such trées as grewe ny that plot of land, maintaining
the lyfe of them with their comfortable moystenes, and preseruing the increase of sap with their excellent virtue. This princely pallace (for it was a peculier place, and, to say the truthe, péereles) as it was fytt, apt, and conuenient for delectation, so was it not vnméete, for the meditation of wisdom, learning, & knowledge: and such a place was it, as therby was declared most euidently the skilfulnes of the young maiden, her dilligence, her art, excercise, industrie, and painefullnes. She was more wise then nyce, (for she was nyce in no degrée) considering ye hardnes of her life, & how shée counted want, welth: and skarsity sufficient riches. For her bed, she had not the fine tyke stuffed with softe fethers, she had not blancketts of fustion or flannell, she had not couerlyds of costly tapestry, she had not shéetes of chosen Holland, she had not curtains of changeable sarsenet, she had not labells of glittering metall, she had not tassells of twysted silcke: but all such superfluity being put a parte and not so much as once thought vppon, she quieted her selfe with the hard hydes of brute beasts. As for her meat, it was not pigeon, plouer, partriche, nor phesaunt, it was not capon, quaile wodcok, nor herneshewe: it was not larke, sparrowe, bullfinche, rudock, nor black byrde: but it was fleashe of the forest, that was her ordinary diet. Her drincke was not cōpound with grapes or with graine: but simple, single, small, thynne, and without mixture, for it was the cléere running water of the riuer. And as for her apparrell, such was it, as became her proper person, her vertuous estate, and sober trade of lyfe: yea such, indéede, was it, as Diana her selfe was therwithall well pleased, and in no respect discontented. For she had this saying in her mouth, by often repetitiō, Tam in tenui & inornato vestitu, quam in perpetua virginitatis conseruatione, Dianam imtari volo, I meane to imitate Diana, as well in playne and homely garments, as in the kéeping of perpetuall virginity and maidenhed. This Atalanta, was by nature,
swiftfooted, in so much that no wild beast was of power, strength, or abilyty to out run her, nor any man of might sufficient to insnare & tangle her by traps, if she were disposed to fetch her ful course: Not only such therfor as saw her, but such also as heard of her by report, were kindled with ye fier of affection to loue so worthy a maiden of honor. But let vs procéede (if it séeme not troublsome) to describe & set forth, her beutyful fauour, & other ornaments of the mind, which made her a mirrour to the multitude. And first of al, to begin at ye wel hed, namely with her stature & bignes (when she was but a wench in comparisō of womās degrée) she surpassed all of the female sex, vniuersally without exception: notwithstanding they had aspired to maturitie of yeares, and fully attained to perfection and rypnes of Age. As for her fauour, and comelynes (as well in proportion, as in complexion) no damosell in all Peloponnesus might be her match, her countenaunce was manlyke, and somwhat sower to beholde, the occasion wherof, was her foode and sustenaunce, which was (as is before remēbred) the flesh of sauage & vntamed beasts: she was stoute, sterne, valiaunt, victorious, couragious, and constant, she abandoned all wanton and insolent excercises, shée did not addict, conforme, and apply her selfe to the company of women and wenches, to follow their practises in the hils which she haunted, she kept her accustomed closset, and chamber vsuall, she was not of their number to whom the mothers haue geuen sucke, or the nources milke and pappe, she was not cumbred with superfluous fattnes of fleshe, and why? because she kept her body within the limits of measurable quantitie, and indifferent substaunce, by Hunting, and semblable excercises of actiuenes & moueing: her haire was yellowe, but not by any extraordinary meanes, (as many women vse to coulour their locks) not with stayning Lye, not wc trumpery oinctments, nor any such ylfauoured slabbersauces: but her vissage being couloured with the beutifull
beames of the glorious sunne, glittered more cleare and bright then gold, siluer, or any other metall or minerall. What floure in the feeld or the garden, is so faire, so fyne, & so fragrant as the face of a pure and vnblemished virgin shining with shamefastnes? There were in Atalanta twoo qualities, which moued men to admire and woonder her countenance of maiesty, & wel proportioned making, feare also and terror which her grim lookes did strike into the hearts of the beholders: No white liuerd or Lubberly Lurdane might loue her seeing her frowning face, no cowardely turneback, might abide to behold her: ther was such a brightnes yoked with her beuty, that they both, lincked together, blinded the eyes of the lookers on. Many things made people meruaile at her, & principally, this, for that she came seldom in sight: for she did not offer her selfe of set purpose to be viewed of any man, but vpon occasion, whē she was chasing some wild beast, or taking reuengment vpon one or other with sodain & sharp force, then appéered she to such as were within the compasse of the ground, wher she was to be séene like a sparkling starre, or rather, like a flashe of lightening, clattering out of a cloude: after which appearaunce she vanished with suddaine motion, like an Arrowe out of a Bowe, and hid herself among the thick Okes in the gréene Groue, or els in som vally, and shadowed secret angle. It fortuned that two youngmen of the country bordering hard by, whose names were Hylaeus, and Rhoecus both Centaures, two presumptuous companions, & inclined to lechery & wantonnesse, resorted to the caue or denne of Atalanta, about midnight, hoping (as it might be suspected) to obtain such grace and fauour at her hands, as they themselues would wishe and desire. These twoo lusty blouds, in this their louely enterprise, vsed no Musicians or any thinge els which youngmen were accustomed vnto, in the City, but they had flaming torches with them, which cast a glittering
