lighte, at the shineing sier whereof, the people generally, quaked for feare, Atalanta only excepted. Then, Lo, did they stripp the pinetrées of their braunches, wherof they made wreathes, and garlands, adorning themselues therwithall, and running vp hill and downe dale with a continuall clattering noyse of weapons, burning vp trées in their passage towardes the maydens mansion, moste iniuriously: She, not ignorant of their intent (for she spyed the flickering flames throughe a clyfte, or rifte) and knowing very well what fantasticall, fonde, and furious fellowes they were, was neuer a whit dismaid, nor once chaunged her countenaunce (a sensible argument of a minde frée from commotions) but bent her bowe tightly, drewe it strongly, and leuelled a sharpe arrow at one of them, wherwithall he was so wounded, that immediatly followed an ineuitable faintnes of all the limmes and members, in so much that his feete faultred vnder the burthen of his body, and downe he fell to the grounde, as to much inféebled, to succour himselfe. The other companion, perceauing what was done, laide loue aside, and turned his study a contrarie waye, he forgate wooing wordes, and beetoke him to woundinge weapons, as one precisely purposed, and absolutly determined, to take present and vndeferred reuengment, of his companions destruction. Whiles he was harnessing him selfe to those practises of hostilitie, and sought to be furnished compleatly with force of furiousnesse, Atalanta discharged a swift, and a sharpe headed flighte at him also, which wroughte in him semblable & sodaine dispatch, in all respects, as it did in his partener. And thus much of Atalanta Iasione, at this instant, suppose I sufficient, wherin (as in a mirour, and a cleere looking glasse) we may behold the natiuitie and byrthe, the education and bringing vp, the practises and behauiour, to be short, the comendable course of the lyfe of Atalanta.

div.head: ¶ Of Macareus, who for his crueltie, and wickednes was punished, of the Gods euerlasting.
div.p:
A Certaine man of Mitylen, named Macareus, a sacrificing prieste of God Bacchus, in countenaunce and fauour, resembled great gentlenes and courtesie, yet in lyfe, and maners, no man more wicked, no man more abhominable. It fortuned vpon a time, that a certaine soiourner lodged at his house, and committed to his credit, a certaine sum of money in golde, This Macareus, being assaulted with auarice, and caryed as it were into captiuitie to couetousnesse, makes a hole wc a mattock, in a secret place of the temple, and therein hides the golde, where with he was put in truste: after a fewe dayes were expired, the soiourner desired to haue his owne, vpon which request Macareus led the man (misttrusting no mischéefe, nor doubting any daunger) into the temple, vnder a pretence, cloke, and colour, to restore the man his right, and hauing (as he thought) oportunitie of time and place, to worke his villanie, murthered the man: which being compassed to his contentation, he tooke vp the golde, and layd the right owner thereof (whom he had iniuriously slayne) in the selfe same place, couered him ouer with earth, and damd vp the pit in such sort as althings (in his thinking) were cock sure, perswading him selfe that, as men be deceiued & mocked, so the powers supernall (the eternall Gods I meane) might be deluded, and blinded. But the matter fell out vnhappely enough- and had another euent then was hoped for on Macareus parte: for after a few daies were passed, the solemne seruice, and obsequies, of God (which were yearely) approched, and was celebrated, accordinge to the auncient
custome, wherein Macareus behauinge himselfe after a gorgeous and gloryous estate, and being very busy in the festiuall ceremonies, his two sonnes, which were left at home, did imitate their fathers order in holy seruice, the one representing the oblation, the other the sacrificer, in such sort, & effectual maner, that the younger brother cast himself prostrate vpon the ground, and laid his head vpō a block very méekly, which the elder brother with an old rusty whineard or cankard woodknif, did chop of from the shoulders: Anon came the seruants of the house, & seeing what was done, gaue a great shout, a terrible outcry, and pitiful noyse, as merueilously amased at so straunge and bloudy a spectacle. The vehemency of this lamentable clamour, and outrageous roaryng, spéedely pearced to the eares of the mother, who came, lyke a mad woman, to vnderstand the meaning of the matter: and séeyng one of her sonnes slaughtered, & weltring in stremes of bloud, and the other holding a rusty glaue in his hand, and all stayned with the crimson bloud of his brothers fleashe, caught vp a fyre brande very fearcely, and in the heate of her great rigour, did so thumpe and sowse her liueing sonne, that he dyed the death in her owne presence. Then cam tideings to Macareus what butcheries were committed at home in his priuate house, who, immediatly vppon the report, lefte holy seruice, and, lyke a moonesicke man, or rather a féeind of hell, ranne home with might and maine, and haueing in his hand at the same instant a burninge torche or taper, dyd so beat, bounce, and bast his wife, ouer euery limme and ioynct, that shée was soone dispatched of life, also. The rumors of these murders, spread abroad amonge the multitude, in somuch that, vpon the generall knowledge of such rare, and seldome chaunces, Macareus was apprehended, examined, and tormented, to confesse each circumstaunce of this bloudy tragedie: And as he was opening the matter,
and discouering the mischiefe which he committed in he holy temple, prophaning a seuerall and sacred chappell, with twoo notorious and inexpiable trespasses, the panges of death oppressed him, and he gaue vp the ghoste vppon a soudaine. As for the innocent soiourner, who lost his life against lawe, and conscience: to him was greate honor exhibited, and a monument made, at the mandate and commaundment of highe Ioue, in his perpetuall remembrance. Thus was Macareus punished, in his wife, in his children, and in himself, for his thefte, his murther, and abhominable hehauiour.

div.head: ¶ Of the Tumbe of Belus, and the infortunate woonder shewed to Xerxes.
div.p: XErxes, the sonne of Darius, opening the tumbe of auncient Belus, found therin a certaine vessell, or measure of glasse, wherin the body of the dead man was laid, drowned all ouer with oyle: yet was not the vessell full, but did lacke almost a hand bredth, to the brymme: Next vnto this measure lay a columne or piller, of a prety bignesse, wheruppon was imprinted this Patheticall poesie.

Qui hunc sepulchrum aperuerit, & vrnam non impleuerit: pessime se habuerit. He which openeth this tumbe, and doth not sill vpp the measure, shall haue ill lucke, and crooked fortune. When Xerxes had read these words, his coulour altered, and he waxed as pale as ashes, commaunding, that oile should be poured into the measure immediatly, without intermission or ceasing, till it was replenished & filled. There was labour on al sides applied, but yet to no purpose, oile was brought, and emptyed in the measure, but it could not be filled for all that, after continuaunce
of toyling without aunswerable successe, they still supposing to sée a profitable end of their paine, and yet disapointed, beganne to be weary of such waste working, and gaue ouer so fruteles a labour. Then was the Tumbe closed vp againe, the vessell béeing vnfilled, and Xerxes the king departed with a heauy and perplexed spirit: and good cause why, for it cam to passe vpon him, as the poesie did prognosticate, which was ingrauen vppon the piller aboue specified. For he prepareing an army of fifty thousand men, and marching forward with the same, against the Grecians, had very yll successe, and vntoward luck: for not his Souldiours only were slaine in cruell battell most miserably, but he himself also, at his returne from the field, finished his lyfe most infortunatly, being murthered in his bed in the night season, by the hands of his sonne, begotten of his owne fleashe, bloude and bone: then which death what myght be more lamentable?

div.head: ¶ Of Euripides, who was starck druncke, at a certaine Bancket
div.p:
KIng Archelaus made a delicate & sumptuous bancket, for his frends and familiars: wherat Euripides was present, carowseing chéerly, and sparing neyther, bole, goblet, maizer, nor cup: at the laste he was ouercome, and béecame starcke staring drunck. The Poet béeing in his madde moode (witte suppressed and remembraunce quite quenched) waxed wanton, and beganne to be full of lecherous and lewde toyes, imbracing the Tragicall Poet Agatho, in his armes, (for he sat next his elbow) and kissed him, as if he had béen a flowreing younge
damosels, when he was (to say the truth) a man of fourty yeares olde, and vpward. Agesilaus demaunding whether he deserued to be estéemed, and made of, yea by God saith he, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . For, not the glorious spring only, of all good things is the best, but also the plentifull haruest.

div.head: ¶ Who first fell in loue, with beutyfull Boyes.
div.p: LAius (as it is imagined) was the first that boyled in the loue, of faire and beutyfull Boyes, insomuch that, by the force of this perturbation, he stole away Chrysippus the sonne of Pelops: whereupon sprunge a custome among the Thebans, which dispensed in such sorte with ye filthy affection, that it was not counted or thought any poynte of disshonestye, to loue faire faced Boyes, and to vse the bodies of personable springalles.

div.head: ¶ The properties of the wines of Arcadia, Thasus, and Achaia.
div.p:
IN Heraia, a féeldy plotte of Arcadia growe Vine trées, aboundinge with clusters of grapes, whose sap and syrrop being pressed out, and turned into the nature of wine, hath that efficacy in it, being tasted, that it maketh the Arcadians as wise as wodcocks, or rather much worse, namely méere blockish and senselesse. Moreouer the selfe same wine hath this singular operation in it, that by the drinking of the same, the women of
Arcadia are made pregnant, great bellyed, fruitful and full of children. The Thasians haue two sorts of wines among them, of which one after it is tasted, lulleth men a sléepe, and ministreth vnto them swéet rest, and delectable quietnes: the other is an aduersary and professed foe to lyfe, a cause of tedious watchinge, & an instrument of trouble and molestation. Furthermore in Achaia, besides Ceraunia, is wine made, the drinking whereof doth affoorde a specyall benefit to great bellied women, for it procureth spéedy, and easy deliuerance to them, of their aborsements.

div.head: ¶ Of Thebes taken by Alexander, and of Pindarns
div.p: WHen Alexander had taken the citie of Thebes, he solde all the frée men there, the priestes only excepted: and such also as were his fathers auncient intertainers (for king Philip in his young yeares was deliuered to them in hostage) he discharged: with all such as were knit to them in any degrée of kynred, or lyne of consanguinitie. Furthermore he made the familie of Pindarus honourable, and suffered his house to stand safe, sounde, and vndamnified. To conclude, he made a sore slaughter of the Thebans, and a bloudy butchery, for there were slaine of them foureskore and ten-thousand: and thirtie thousande he subdued as captiues, and prisoners.

div.head: ¶ Of Lysander.
div.p: LYsander the Lacedemonian, at what time he was in Ionia, reiected the lawes of Lycurgus as laborious and troublesome, leading his lyfe in loosenesse, leudnes, lechery, and licentiousnesse.

div.head: ¶ Of Lamia.
div.p: LAmia an harlot of Athens, had this sentence in her mouth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . The Lyons of Grecia, are made Foxes at Ephesus.

div.head: ¶ Of Dionysius who wedded two wyues in one day.
div.p: DIonysius matched himselfe in marriage with two wiues in one day, namly with Doris Locrensis, and Aristanela the daughter of Hippanius, and sister to Dion, with whom he slepte, and tooke his pleasure by turnes: The one of them folowed in his expeditions, and warlike affaires, and there did him seruice: the other tarried at home, to intertaine him at his returne from battell, and to shew him pleasure in time of peace, and tranquillitie.

div.head: ¶ Of the subduing of the Persians, and of Isocrates.
div.p: ISocrates the Rhethorician (as I haue receaued by report) was the cause efficient of the Persians subiection, and the procurer of their seruitude vnder the Macedonians. For the Panegyrical oratiō which Isocrates made to the Grecians was carryed into Macedonia, and first of all excited Philip against all Asia: and successiuely, after his death, Alexander his sonne, heire to all his fathers possessions, that hee might finishe the quarell which his father begonne.

div.head: ¶ That Meton withdrew himselfe from a voyage which he should haue gone, and of the outrage of Vlysses.
div.p: MEton the Astronomer, when the Armie of the Grecians made their expedition and voyage into Sicilia, he was inscrouled, and named in the bill of particulars for one of the number. The man presupposing what daungers were lyke to insue, and followe, beganne to be affrayde, and séemed wonderfull loth to saile vpon the Seas, wherupon he deuised with himselfe what menes he might vse to auoyd so venturous a voyage. After he had experimēted many, but none, for al that auailable for his purpose, he fained himself frantique, and dissembled madnesse: Furthermore that his hipocrisie in this point might challenge credit among men, and draw them into an opinion that hee was lunatique indéede, he played many outragious partes, and practised much mischéefe, amonge all which his furious vsage and desperate behauiour, he set his owne house (which was nigh to Paecilia) one a light fyre, and burned it to coles and ashes. Whereupon the Captaines generall, and gouernours of the army, supposing that he was, as he pretended, mad indéede dashed his name out of the Cataloge or Table, and dischargd him of that voiage: Now questionlesse (in mine opinion) Meton dissembled his madnes much more fraudulently and craftely then did Vlysses Ithacensis: for Palamedes tooke this man in ye tryp & rebuked him, as for the other, not so muche as one man amonge all the Atheniens, did so muche as once vtter a worde against him in his reprehension.

div.head: ¶ Of the ample liberalitie of Ptolomeus.
div.p: IT is sayde, that Ptolomeus the sonne of Lagus, had a singular delight and pleasure in making his fréendes rich: for saide he, Melius est ditare quam ditescere: Better it is to inriche other, then a man to inriche himselfe.

div.head: ¶ Of the verses of Homer, and of his poetrie,
div.p: THe olde auncients (time out of minde) soūg the heroicall Verses of Homer, diuided into certaine partes and portions: Some made a rehearsall of the contention by sea continued, some of the victory of Agamemnon, some of the furnished fléete and prepared Nauie, some of Patroclus, the rewardes of his ransome, the open Pageants appoynted in his honour, and their prices, some of the violating of oathes, and cracking of credit, some of the exployts and martiall feates at Pylus, & Lacedemon, some of the barks and vessels passing vnder sayle, some of Alcinous fables, some of the Bathes, Banes, Lauers, inchauntmentes, and witchcraftes of Cyrces, some of the slaughters of the wanton wooers, cōmitted as well in open feelde, as also in Laerta: some one thing, and some another. Lycurgus of Lacedemonia carried the whole body of Homers Poetry into Grecia, out of Ionia in his voyage and peregrination. After that (as sundry circumstaunces ministred occasion, (Pisistratus, collected all his verses together in a boundell, and reduced them in to two formall Tomes, sections, or volumes, wherof the one is called the Iliades, the other is named the Odysses.

div.head: Of diuers men which were vnmeasurably doultish, blockishe, and foolishe.
div.p: THe makers of enterludes, and penners of familiar playes, make mention of one Polydorus, who was wonderfull blockishe, and doultishe: This man (besides that his incomparable folishnes) was made of a straunge and a miraculous kinde of metall, for notwithstanding he was in great and notorious daungers, of fyer, and such like, yet was hée so frée from any inconuenience and harme, that his skynne was not once synged, much lesse scorched: then how farre his flesh was from suffering shipwracke, please it you to giue iudgement. Furthermore, they make commemoratiō of another fellow, called, Cecyllio, who attempted to tell the waues of the swelling Sea as they boyled in the tumbling streame, (O extreame foolishe Asse) There is in like maner, a certaine brute blowne abrode, of one Sannyrio, a fellow not vnlike the last, of whome wée made lately relation, who sought for a ladder to go downe into a pitcher: Finally, it is recorded that Chorebus, & Melitiades had but small witt, in their great béetle heds comprised.

div.head: Of the people Apolloniatae, of their countrey: and of Epidamnus.
div.p:
THe city of the people Apolloniatae, bordereth vppon the brymmes of Epidamnus, situate in the bosom of Ionia: In certaine lāds lying therabout, are mines of brimstone, which runne wt a streame as doe other fresh springs and riuers. Not farr from thence is a fyer, which flameth continually, and a litle hill not of any greate compasse, but yet
terrible by reason of his perpetuall burneing, this hill smelleth of Suphur and Allum, and round about it are goodly, flourishing groues, and gay, gréene medowes: which (notwithstanding they are pitched nye the places remembred, which spit flashes of flameing fyer) yet are they free from harme, & hasard, and theyr braunches, boughes, twigs, blossoms, leaues, and what soeuer béesides, sustaine no manner of annoyaūce. As for the fyer yt selfe, that burneth day and nyght without intermission or ceasing, without extinguishment or quenching (as the Apolloniatae reported) before the battell béetwixt them had, and the Illyrians. These Apolloniatae expelled (according to the Lacedemonian lawe) straungers out of their citie. But ye people of Epidamnus prohibit none their country, so farr be they from the disposition of the former people.

div.head: An old prouerbe of Phrynicus.
div.p: PHrinycus feareth a swarme of waspes like a cockrel. This adage or prouerbe, is agréeable to such as suffer harme and hurt: For when Phrynicus the Tragediographer, or writer of stately and pithy playes, was in captiuity & imprisonment at Miletum, hée being in a greate feare and horror of minde, for his present estate, was by that meanes cast out, of the Atheniens.

div.head: Of Dionysius.
div.p: DIonysius ye great Tyrant of Sicilia, had Tragedies in highe veneration, and bloudy showes, (which excited sorrowes & lamentations) he precisesly commended, which representations hée himselfe, erwhile, would publishe and practise. As for Comedies, enterludes, and popular playes, he did not regard them but vtterly reiect thē, in respect of this reason, that they prouoked laughter, which he, at no hand, might acquaint himself withall.

div.head: The Opinion of Cleomenes, concerning Homer, and Hesiod.
div.p: CLeomenes after his homely māner, spake bréefly and wisely saying, thus. Lacedaemoniorum poeta Homerus, Helotarum vero Hesiodus. Homer is the Poet of the Lacedemoniās, and Hesiod of the Helotans: because the first discourseth of warrs and martiall prowesse, this other of husbandry, and Tillage,

div.head: Of one which willingly dyed, to the end he might see his predecessours.
div.p:
A Certaine Megalopolitane of Arcadia, whose name was Cercidas, lying vppon his death bed, said to a cōpany of his acquaintāce these words. Non aegre mortē obio, spero namque
me conuenturum ex philosophis Pythagoram, ex historicis He cataeum, ex musicis Olympum, ex poetis Homerum. I am not loth to departe this life, for I hope it wil be my good luck to sée and talcke with Pythagoras, among the philosophers: with Hecataens among the historiagraphers, wc Olympus among the musicians, and with Homer amōg the Poets. Which words so soone as he had vttered, he gaue vp the ghoste.

div.head: Of the Phrygian harmonie.
div.p: YF any man sound the harmonie of Phrygia vnto the Celaenes, the pipe moueth as if it weare quicke: if yt bée sounded to Apollo yt is quiet, still, and void of styrring.

div.head: Of the Temple of Homer, and of his picture.
div.p: PTolomeus Philopater, building a Temple in the honour of Homer, placed his picture in the same, very séemely and orderly sitting, & made rounde about him all such cities as fauoured Homer, and estéemed of his name. Galateon the painter, described the same Poet, in liuely coulours artificially, in this manner: that is to say, spueing, vomiting, and as yt were casting vp a full and ouer burthened stomacke, and all other Poets, of greate dignity and worthines, lapping and licking vp the superfluitie of his Gorge, namely the lothsome vomyt. A homly and lothsome description, but yet an excellent and singular mysterie.

div.head: ¶ Of the Lacdemonian Lycurgus.
div.p: LYcurgus the Lacedemonian, and son to Eunomus, being purposed to conforme and shape the Lacedemonians (his country men) to iustice and equytie, receaued an vnworthy pension and reward, incōsideratiō of an enterprise so honourable, for Alexander dashed out one of his eyes by casting a stone at him (as some suppose) or as othersom think by smiting him with a cudgel or waster, This example is agréeable to such as ar otherwise recompenced, then their expectation and hope did put them in comfort of, by painted promises. Euphorus reporeth that this Lycurgus was thrust into exile and banishement, where he dyed with hunger, and perished with famishment.

div.head: ¶ Of diuers men, to whom their owne lawes haue bene preiudicial, and their owne statuts an hinderaunce.
div.p:
LYcurgus enacted and made a lawe, that womē should not ride in coches at the festiual solemnities of the triumphes called Misteria: whatsoeuer she was that durste violate the law in that pointe, she should suffer such penaltie as it pleased him to appoynt. So it fortuned, that his owne wyfe was the firsts that transgressed the aforesayde ordinance, yet notwithstanding, such was the singularitie of this lawemaker,
that as she was accused as an offender, so was she also (without any countenaunce of parcialitie) condemned, and punished as a trespasser. Pericles in lyke maner, enacted, ye none should be incorporated & made a mēber of the body of the Athenien common wealth, but such whose fathers and mothers were citizens legitimate and ordinarie: the which statute had infortunate successe, for after he had buried his owne sonnes lawfully begotten, and thereby had no posterytie to enioy the foresayde priuelege: a youngman, basely borne, being his bastard by the body of an harlot, was lykewise excluded from the commoditie and benefit of the same statute. Whereby it is manyfest, that the purpose of Pericles, was repugnant to his fortune, and his law contrary to his luck.
Clisthenes the Athenien, was the inuenter of exile and banishment, whose chaunce it was (vpon circumstaunces offered) to partake the smarte of his deuised punishment.

Zaleucus Locensis, cōmaunded that the whoremonger and adulterer should lose both his eyes: But when he made that a law, he knew not what should insue, neither was the euent of things to come apparant vnto him, neither had he foreskil in the mutability of fortune, whereby he might haue intercepted ye course of such a statute. For his owne sonne was taken occupying a whore, & therby did incurre the smart of the law: Howbeit compassion in this point pleaded for parcialitie, but the father being vnwilling, that a law made, sealed and confirmed, with the suffrages and consenting voyces of all estates, should be broken: cōmanded the executioner to pluck out one of his owne eyes, and one of his sonnes eyes, to thintent that the youngman should not be blemished with the deformitie of blindenesse: nor the lawe in all respectes left vnsatisfied.

div.head: ¶ Of Pindarus whom Corinna ouercame.
div.p: PIndarus a Theban Poet, in a case of cōtentiō for preeminēce & superioritie, haueing ignorant, vnskilful and vnlearned auditors, was ouercome and vanquished of Corinna fiue seuerall times, notwithstanding the controuersie was so determinable, and the matter so arbitrable: whose blockish blindnesse Pindarus reprouing with inuectiue words, called therwithall vpon his aduersarie Corinna.

div.head: ¶ After what sort Diogenes comforted himself, in the tempestes of pinching pouertie.
div.p:
DIogenes Sinopensis being forsaken of all men, was left solitary, because of his beggerlynesse, and inabilitie, touching hospitalitie and intertainement to bee exhibited to his acquainetaunce, and because of his bytter and sowre language which he vsed of custome against such as he rebuked, wherby he became contemptible, and no better accounted thē an abiect or castaway: at length he behaued himselfe frowardly and vntowardly, as wel in maners & conditions, as in speache, & comunication, insomuch yt this his morositie & crookednes, ingendered a certaine heauinesse, wherof, insued a consumption of his body (after hee was abandoned from the tables of his fréendes, and acquaintaunce) and being thus distressed, he fell to eating gréene herbs, and leaues which fell from trées, for the preseruation of his lyfe: to the partaking and tasting of which course sustenaunce,
when he perceiuing a mouse to come, and behelde how pretely it did eate the offalles vpon the ground, which he had cast away, hee began to recouer himselfe, and with this present spectacle was so comforted, that hee vtered these wordes with a pleasaunt countenaunce: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . This mouse hath no néede of the Atheniens meate and drinke, and why then art thou gréeued (O Diogenes) that thou art not partaker with the Atheniens of their dinners and suppers? by this meanes dyd hee rescue and succour his hart, which before was (as it were) hanged and haultered in heauinesse.

div.head: ¶ Of the body of Socrates.
div.p: IT is supposed that Socrates was chast, modest, and continent of body: And for that cause, in a vniuersall infection when the Atheniens were disseased one by another lyke scabby and rotten shéepe, insomuch that some neuer recouered of their disease, but died as past all remedy, Socrates being an od man among the rest, was cléere from all contagion of sicknesse, yea hee was not so much as once molested with any grudging of disease. Now certenly if this mans body was in so singular an estat, I leaue it to your arbitrements, to iudge of his minde.

div.head: Of the seruant of Diogenes, who was torne in peeces with dogges.
div.p: WHen Diogenes left his countrie, one of his seruants named Manes, footed after him for a while, and being at length tyred with wearynes, or rather disdaining his company, tooke his héeles, and plaid the runnegate: when certaine men came to Diogenes, and gaue him aduise to séeke after the lewde fellow, he made them this awnswer. An non turpe esset, cum Manes Diogenis non egeat, Diogenem Manis indigere? Is it not a beastly thing, and a déede discommendable, that Diogenes should stād in néede of Manes, and Manes, contrarywise, stand in no néede of Diogenes? The self same vnthrifty seruaunt, being afterwards (as opportunity serued) apprehēded, was brought to Delphos was torne in péeces and mangled in mammockes with Cur dogs: A punishment most méete (I tell you truthe) for runnegates from their masters.

div.head: Of Hope.
div.p: PLato had this sētence in his mouth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Hope is the dreme of mē whiles they are wakeing.

div.head: Of Olympias, heuily lamenting the death of Alexander, and lying aboue ground vnburied.
div.p:
OLympias the mother of Alexander, when shée hard that her sonne was kepte aboue grounde a longe tyme, after he was dead, shée tooke on very pittifully, & made this mourneing lamentation. O fili, fili, tu cum in deorum numerum referri volueris, & id perficere summo
studio couatus sis, nunc neque illorum quidem, quorum omnibus mortalibus aequale & par ius est, particeps fieri potes, terrae & sepulturae. My sonne, my swéete sonne, néedes wouldest thou be recounted among the Gods immortall, & didst what thou couldest to accomplishe thy purpose: But now, my sonne, my swéete sonne, thou art so farr from being heauenly, that thou art most vile, wāting the common benefit of buryall: wherof not so much as the lowsey begger is depriued. Thus did shée bewayle her yll lucke, and frowarde fortune, detecting also, the pride and vanity of her sonne Alexander, in her bitter lamētation.

div.head: That Xenocrates was pittifull.
div.p: XEnocrates the Carthaginean, Platoes companion, gaue euident tokens of his pittifulnes, and manifest paterns of his compassion, conceiued as well towards dum creatures, and vnreasonable: as extended to men politique and ciuil As this man was sitting (at a certaine season) in a sunny place, a litle chirping sparrowe, being fearcely followed of a coruoraunt hauke, almost wearyed to death, and fainting in flighte, fled into the bosome of Xenocrates, which selly byrd hée entertayned with delight, and harboured it tenderly, tyll all daungers were past. Som man would haue killed the simple foule, but he gaue her frée passage to flye whether shée would, vttering these wordes when he cast her vp into the ayre, Hosti supplicem non prodidi, The succourlesse soule crauing rescewe, I haue not betrayed into the clawes of the aduersarie.

div.head: How Socrates aunswered an impudent harlot
div.p: XEnophon sayeth, that Socrates, vppon a time, fell in communication with the harlot Theodota, a woman (notwithstanding her lewdenes of lyfe, and corruption of manners) passing faire and bewtifull. He had conference also with Caliste, who vttered these words in course of talke to Socrates, Ego tibi Socrates, multum praesto: Nam cum tu neminem a me possis abalienare, ego cum libitum est tuos omnes a te auoco. I excell thée, Socrates, many degrées, for when thou canst not allure men from mée, I canne entyse any of thyne from thée, when soeuer I lyst: To whome Socrates shaped this aunswer, Quid mirum est? siquidem tu ad decliuem &c. What wounder is that? for thou doost trayle men downe the dale of vice and destruction, but I hayle them vp the hill of vertue and Eternity, whervnto is no easy passage, or common climeing.

div.head: Of the fortune of the harlot. Rhodope
div.p:
RHodope the harlot, was the fairest amonge all the Aegiptians, and of bewtie (as the rumor runneth) incōparable. To this Rhodope was Fortune fauourable, and bestowed vppon her, a gift worthy her comelynes, and to her proportion aunswerable: For as shée was washing her self, vppon a time, and her wayting maydens kéeping her
apparell, an Eagle came swingeing downe out of the Christall ayer, and snatcheth vp with her talans, one of Rhodopes shooes, and caried the same with her as far as Memphis, and there let it fall in the lap of Psammetichus as he sate in iudgement: at the fairenes wherof, and the cunning workemanship therin shewed he much meruailing, and besides that, wondering not a little at the straunge déede of the Eagle, commanded that a general search should be made throughout al Grecia, for the person whose fine foote, that prety shooe fitly serued: in ye executing of which precept Rhodope was founde, and therupon presented to Psammetichus, in so much that the vertue of her amiable personage, did not only kindle the fier of loue in Psammetichus hart wherby he had her in no small estimation, but did so inflame his affections, and wynde his wil in suche knots of intangling desires, that hée maryed her forthwith, and enioyed her company in the pleasaunt and delectable bed of wedlocke.

div.head: Of Dionysius.
div.p: DIonysius after he had commanded ye a Lyon, which he caused to be brought before him, should be slaine, he chaūged his mind, & in ye point made restrainte of his determination: This did he thrée seuerall times, and still altered his intent, and yet agayne after that thrée tymes, & reuolted as often from his former will kissing and imbracing the beast with teares destilling downe his chéekes, & cursing himself, because he (being at length subdued and brought vnder the slaueishe estate of feare) drewe out his sword, and commāded the Lyō to be slaine, vttering therwithal these words following: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . O Lyon thou maist no longer liue.

div.head: ¶ Of the natural medicines, and healthfull preseruatiues, which hartes vse when they be diseased.
div.p: SVch as discourse vpon things naturall, and expresse their peculiar properties, affirme that hartes when they stand in néede of a remedye against any daungerous disease, vse to eate wilde Persley. And againste the infection of scabs and itche, procured by the poyson of the Spiders Phalangia, they are acustomed to deuoure Creuisses. Thus hath nature vouchsafed of her clemency, to instill in sundry thinges, seuerall operations, for the maintenaunce of her creatures, in their proper kinde.

div.head: ¶ Of the death of Eurydica, the daughter of Philip.
div.p: OLympias sent to Euridica, ye daughter of Philip, who was begotten vnto him by the body of a wyf which he had at Illyrium: shee (I say) sent vnto her thrée fatall thinges, wherewith to finish her lyfe, Cicutam, Laqueum, & Ensem, present poyson to dispatch herself, a hempen haulter to strangle her selfe, and a perceing sword to murther her self: of which thrée execrable things, she elected and chose one, namely the hempen haulter to compasse the mischiefe of her death.

div.head: ¶ Of Gelon, and of them which laid in waight to worke him harme.
div.p: GElon, the tyraunt of Syracusae, behaued himselfe merueilous mildely, gently, and peceably in his kingdome: But certaine busy braines, (malicious men I meane) sought waies to worke him harme, wherof when Gelon was informed and certified, he called a court, and sommoned an assembly, or session of Syracusans, which being done, in the presence and countenaunce of them all, he went vp into an hauty and high place, in maner lyke a Pulpit, hauinge on his body harnesse, and in his hands, weapons, bright and glistering, in which sort and order, he stoode be for them, making a commemoration and rehearsall of all his merits and dutifull desarts on their behalfe, & deliuered vnto their eares and mindes a discouerye of such deuilish miscreants, as sought meanes to cut him short both of worship and life: hauing thus done, he vnarmed himselfe, laide downe both armour and weapons at his féete, and vttered these wordes to the congregation, and head of people: En amictus tunicula, uudus armorum asto, dedo me vobis, vt pro voluntate, libitoque mecum agatis.

Beholde I stande before you naked, vnarmed, in a thin and single wastcote, I yéeld my lyfe into your handes, my body is yours at commaundement, deale with it according to your pleasure. At this compendious oration of Gelon, the whole assembly of Syracusans were much amased, and thereupon, immediatly were so affectioned in minde, that néedes they would (there was no way to the contrary) deliuer those traitrous varlots, and rebellious villans to the kings power, to punish them according to the proportion of their offence, and gaue him their suffrages and vniuersall consentes, to continue ouer
them his dominion and gouernment, Yet notwithstandinge would not Gelon buisy himselfe about these yll disposed persons, but lefte them to the people, that they should correct that in the offenders which was punishable. In the high veneration of this man, the Syracusans erected and planted a standing Image, wearing a single Peticote, slit downe right, and open all about: and it was a monument, and sempiternall testimony of the perfect goodwyll, whereby he fauoured the people, and a singular document also, and effectuall instruction for his successours, in seat of gouernment.

div.head: ¶ Of Alcibiades.
div.p: ALcibiades, estéemed of Homer out of measure, and had him in precise estimation, for his learnings sake: wherefore, when hee (at a sudaine season) came to a certaine schole, where sundrye authors workes were read and learned, hee desired to haue the Iliades of Homer (thinking that so famous a writer might not be wanting, in any place consecrated to learning) but when the Scholmaster, said vnto him, that he had no part or percell of that Poet, Alcibiades checked him in great anger and displeasure, tearming hym by the name of a patch and a doull, and adding moreouer vnto that his sharp rebuke, this sentence: That so many as were of his teaching, would proue lyke the maister, namely starke asses. The same Alcibiades beinge sent for, by the Atheniens, out of Sicylia, about a matter of lyfe and death, refused to be obedient to any such preiudiciall message, sayeing. Stultum est iudicium querere, non fuga tibi consulere, cum fugere possis. & cet.

It is a poynte of extreame folly, and madnesse, for a man to séeke iudgment against himselfe, and not to vse the benefyt and aduantage of flight, when oportunitie to escape, is offered. And when a certaine mā put forth this question vnto him, Annon credis teipsum patriae? Canst thou not finde in thy hart, to trust thy owne cuntrey with thy lyfe? he made this aunswere, Imo ne matri quidem crederem, no syr sayth hee, with so precious a treasure, I woulde not credite my naturall moother: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . For I doubt greatly, least she, through ignoraunce, and want of vnderstanding ye truth, shold dele erroniously, and so lay downe a black stone in stéede of a white. The same Alcibiades, heareing that the Citizens with one consent, had pronounced him a condemned man, and sounded the sentence of death against him: is it euen so (sayth he) now vndoubtedly, we will shewe that wee are yet aliue: wherupon he made preparation towards Lacedemonia, and moued war against the Atheniens, this war was called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Decelium prelium, of some place, peraduenture, where it was fought. The same Alcibiades had this sayeing in his mouth. Nil uouum est, si Lacedaemonij intrepide mortem in bellis occumberent, defugiunt hoc modo legum seueritatem & cruciatum, atque labores alacriter prompteque cum morte commutant: It is no worlds wonder, that the Lacedemonians lose their liues in battell, valiauntly and couragiously: for by that meanes they flie the rigour of lawes, and make an exchaunge (willingly) of tedious labours, with peaceable death. This Alcibiades was accustomed to saye of hym selfe, and his déedes, that he leade a lyfe lyke the Sonnes of God Iupiter.

Quotidie namque morior, & reuiuisco, for I die
daily & recouer lyfe againe: meaning that so long as he was in the fauour & goodwill of the people, he was haile fellow well met with the gratious Gods: and when hée lost the loue of the people, then he lytle differed from the corrupt case of a carrian Carcasse.

div.head: Of Ephialtes.
div.p: EPhialtes, being cast in the téeth with his pouerty, & distressed estate, spake these wordes to the Captaine that vsed that exprobration: And why doost thou not make rehersall of the other thing, namely that I loue lawe, and regarde right.

div.head: Of Themistocles.
div.p:
A Riche chaine of Golde, made after ye Persian maner, lay vppon the groūd, by the which Themistocles stāding, sayd to a boy in this sorte: Syr boy why doost not thou take vp so benificiall a losse, pointing to the chaine: for thou art not Themistocles. Whē the Atheniens had openly reuiled him, and after that called him to rule and gouernment agayne, he sayd thus: Non laudo eos homines qui eodem vase, & matula, et ad infundendum vinum vtuntur. I canne, in no case, account thos men worthy commendation, which make one vessell serue twoo seuerall vses, namely to powre wine in, & to pisse in. The same Themistocles, spake somewhat (belyke) to Euribiadas the Lacedemonian, which moued him to choler, & being discontēted offered to smite him wc a cudgell, to whome Themistocles vttered these wordes: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . smite and spare not, so thou
geue eare & marke. For Themistocles knewe yt he spake nothing which might (any way) empayre and diminishe the profit of the Common wealth.

div.head: Of Phocion.
div.p: CErtaine persons, who were condēned, and iudged to dye with Phociō made wofull lamentations, bytter complaints, and sorowfull mournings. Whereuppon Phocion (speaking to one particular man, among the rest) sayd, doost thou not persuade thy selfe, (O Thudippus) that yt is a precious thing, to dye with Phocion.

div.head: Of Epaminondas.
div.p:
AT what tyme Epaminondas at his returne out of Laconia, was condemned to dye, because he bare supremacy, and dignitie imperiall ouer the Boeotians, the terme of foure whole monethes, against the prescript and tenure of the lawe: wherof hée hauing vnderstanding, and perswading him selfe of the worste, gaue commandement, to his companions, and confederates, to lay, the whole burthen of blame vppon his shoulders, because he vrged & constrained them to offend against their wills: at his entrance into the Session house, and standing at the barr, he said yt hée would alledge no reasons more probable and plausible, thē his déeds of armes and cheualrie: neuertheles sayth hée if they may not preuaile, I besech you let my lyfe pay the price of my trespasse: and graunt thus much vnto me besides, that ther may be erected vppon my sepulchre
or graue, a piller of stone, and theruppon let this be ingrauen: that throughe my procurement and instigation, the Thebans (long nilling, and resisting) spoiled, sacked, raced and battred downe Laconia, with violēce of weapon and Fyer: which was not, so muche as once touched by sorren force for the space of fiue hundreth yeares expired & past: and to reare & build, vp againe Mecena, which lay lyke a desert, and wast wildernes for the terme of three hundred and thirty yeares together. That I was the cause, of the concord, knit among the Arcadians: and that by my meanes the Grecians had their libertie restored &c. When Epaminondas had cast these notable remembrances, in their bosoms, the Iudges being ashamed of themselues, discharged him quite, and pronounced him frée from all suspicions of offence, whereuppon insued his present deliuerance. So that by the course of this description, wee are instructed, and (as it were by manyfest demonstrations and sensible reasons) absolutely taught, that the vertuous disposition of a man, his honest and vppright trade of lyfe, his wisdome, policie and experience, his valiantnes, manhoode and puisaunce: his willing hart to benefite all men, his nilling mind to hinder any man, doth more vehementlie kindle the coles of consideration, and sooner set sincere iudgement one fyer, then the painted speache of the eloquent Rhetorician, Albeit he were cōparable to Apollo or Mercurie. And as the said Epaminondas returned from the Court of Assise, a litle whelp of his owne, met him and fauned vppō him, most louingly, wagging his taile, and skipping vp and & downe (all which were resemblances of inward ioy) in the open streate: wheruppō Epaminondas (as it is reported) said thus to such as were by, Hic catulus pro beneficio gratiam reponit &c. This whelp, remembreth a good turne, and is thankfull therfore: But the Thebans (of whome I haue honorably deserued) haue condemned mée for
my commendable déeds, & haue donne, what they might, to recompence my dutifull deserts with death, most despitefully.

div.head: Of Timothie.
div.p: TImothie the Athenien Captaine, was supposed to haue liued in beatitude & happines, and to haue had a perpetual flowe of all felicity at his harts desire. This man affirmed oftē, that Fortune was the cause of his goode lucke & singuler successe, and not Timothie. Painters therefore haue described this captaine in liuely colours, (to his reprehension, rather then to his aduauncement) brightly harnessed, and well weaponed, and Fortune standing ouer his head, holding in her hands a spreding net, wherwithall shée caught cityes and regions. The same Timothie being demaūded of Themistocles, in what thing he did principally delight, and take pleasure: made this aunswer, In yt a solemne assembly of people, at the publike pageants of Olympus, behold, and looke stedfastly vppon my person, as yt were with one eye.

div.head: Of the Contention betwene Themistocles and Aristides.
div.p: THemistocles, and Aristides the sonne of Lysimachus, wer both subiect to the tuitiō of one man, vnder whose wings they were brought vp, instructed, & trayned: These twaine, in their Childehoode, fell often times at varriaunce, & quarelling: this contention, tooke originall in theyr young yeares & continued vntill the time of their old and withered age.

div.head: ¶ Of the vngodlines of Dionysius.
div.p: DIonysius poysoned his mother, and therby wrought her destruction, O wofull mother, O deuilish sonne: The same Dionysius suffered his brother Leptines to be slaine in battell vpon the sea, whom he might haue succoured and saued without his priuate preiudice, and daunger (O infortunate youngman, O butcherly beast.

div.head: ¶ Of a Dragon, which was mindfull of a benefite.
div.p:
THere was in Achaia, a citie named Patrae, in the same citie there was a boy which bought him a litle serpent and brought the same vp no lesse louingly, then delightsomly, this Serpent as it grew in bignesse, so it increased further in familiarity, in somuch that the young lad spake vnto it, playde with it, lay with it, and continued dayly in company with it. In tract of time it grew from a worme, to a serpent, from a Serpent to a viper, and from a viper to a monsterous Dragon, ougly to sée to, and hideous to beholde: whereupon the Citizens consulted amonge themselues, how they might be deliuered of the same, sithence the Citie (wherin concourse of ciuill people ar frequent, and vsuall) ought not to be pestered with such a pernicious monster. In the ende, policye so prouided, that this Dragon was chased out of the citie (a place of peoples resort) into the desert or wildernes (a conuenient lodge for such horible monsters) In processe of yeares, the lad, aforesaide, waxed a proper youngman, and returninge
(vpon a time as his fortune was) from commō games, and shewes, with other of his companions, fell into the hands of théeues, and perceiuing himself ouer matched, & therfore comfortles, and fearing there withal the losse of his swéete lyfe, made a great outcry, and roring noyse. Anon lo, at this soudaine exclamation, the Dragon aboue named came flinging out contrary to all expectation, (but yet at the appointment of supernall prouidence) & put som of the théeues to spéedy flight, other some he slew, & made to sure for starting, & the youngman he preserued aliue, defended and kept vnharmed whom the gréedy aduersaries had otherwise vnmercifully murthered.

div.trailer: ¶ The ende of the thirteenth Booke of Aelianus.

div.head: The fourteenth and last Booke of Aelianus his variable Hystorie.
¶ Of the inclination of Aristotle towards dignitie.
div.p: ARistotle, the sonne of Nicomachus, a man both in opinion and déede, of singular wisdome, and perfect experience, when as one derogated from him at Delphos his due dignitie, and peculier estimation, he wrot vnto Antipater thereof, in this method and order: Ea quae Delphis mihi decreto sunt assignata, quibusque nunc priuatus sum, animum meum afficiunt, vt neque mihi magnopere cordi sunt, neque tamen omnino non cordi sunt. Those thinges which were assigned vnto me by consent and decrée, and whereof I am (at this instant time) quite dispossessed, in such a sorte occupy my minde and cogitations, that I haue no great good likeing of them, and yet I doo so estéeme of them, as of thinges not altogether to be reiected and abhorred. These wordes (as my simple iudgment gathereth by the circumstances of the letter) do not issue from a minde infected with ambition, neither would I, by my wyl, burthen Aristotle with such an iniurious accusation: for he supposed most prudently, that betwixt the attainment of worship, and the losse therof againe, after it was once gotten, is infinit oddes: yet could he with the bridles of reason restraine his affection. It is no matter of waight (in comparison) to be inglorious and vnworshipfull simply:
But the depriuation of dignitye, after it is once purchased, that is it which stingeth a man with sorrow and goreth the hart with heauinesse.

div.head: ¶ Of Agesilaus, and of the periurie of certaine outlandishe people.
div.p: AGesilaus commended certaine people of forreigne countrées, in that they did violate their oathes, and therby became periures: Hee accounted them praise worthye, because that, by foresweringe themselues, they purchased the heate and heauy displeasure of the Gods, and wonne his fauour, goodwill, fellowship, and society.

div.head: ¶ Of Prodigalitie.
div.p: TImothy sharply inueihed against the prodigalitie of Aristophanes, vseing these wordes: Cui nihil satis est, eidem etiam nihil turpe. He that neuer hath sufficient, thinketh nothing filthy, dishonest, or vndecent.

div.head: ¶ Of Aristides.,
div.p:
ARistides Locrensis, beinge bytten of a Polecat, insomuch that the sore festred, rankled, and put him to extreame anguish, drawing towardes deathes dore, vttered these words, Mors mihi multo iucundior futura fuisset, &c. Death had bin more welcom to me by many degrées, if it had bin my fortune to haue falne into the renting clawes of a Lyon, or the rauenous chaps of a Pardale: whereas now I thinke mine ende ignominous, shamefull, and inglorious, for that
yt is mine vnhappy luck to be bitten of a vile vermine, and thereuppon to lose my life. which wordes, minister this opinion vnto mée, that he was more greued with the shame and infamie, which did issue from ye nipping of such a baggage beaste, then hée was at the losse of his lyfe.

div.head: What manner of men the Atheniens did choose, to gouerne their Common wealth.
div.p:
THe Atheniēs did not cōmitte the charge of the Common welth in tranquilitie and peace, and the offices of warrlike affaires to Citizens only, not withstanding they were men most méete and seruiceable for the purpose: But oftentimes put straungers in such places of countenaunce and credit, when the other were dissapointed. Neuerthelesse, they dealt not so honorably with all, but such only did they exalt, and shewe them selues in such sorte beneficiall vnto, whome they vnderstode by frequēt & cōmon reporte, and experimented also in sundry actuall circumstances, to bée good men, honest men, and not vnméete, for the administration of the Common wealth. They did inaugurate and cōfirme, Apollodorus Cizicenus Captaine in warre oftentimes, notwithstanding he was an Allien, and Outlander. The like courtesie did they communicate and bestowe, vppon Heraclides Clazomenius, and diuers others, whose vertues reaped reputation: For this was familiar and ordinarie amōg the Atheniens, that such, as by their behauiour, deserued commendatiō, should not only prepare to themselues a plausible opinion among the people, but bée elected
also and established, in highe place of authoritie and gouernement. This notable humanity of Athens, not only discouered in furthering their owne citisens, by their bountifulnes, but also most apparently veryfied, in aduaunceing such as were knyt vnto them, in no degrée of consanguinitie, (and yet for vertue sake worthy of singular honour) deserueth (no doubte) double dignitie & worthines.

div.head: The opinion of Aristippus, concerning a constant and vnchaungable minde.
div.p:
ARistippus vseing strong reasons, pithy perswasions, and substantiall arguments, exhorted men, to conceaue no care of things past, after they wer past: nor of things to come before they were com: His reasō was this. Animi namque bene constituti signum est, et hilarae cogitationis argumentum, For that saith he, is a certaine signe of a constant minde, and an infallible token of an established conscience. The same Aristippus, did impart and giue this auailable aduise vnto men, Nempe in diem animum intendere, illamque solum modo diei partem, qua quisque quid ageret, aut cogitaret, Namely to direct and leuell all the cogitations of their mindes, to the present day (yea) to that portion of the day only, wherin either the instruments of the body ar to be vsed, or the faculties of the minde to be occupied: The Philosophers reason, (not so prompt and ready, as true and learned) was this: Solum enim praesens in nostra manu positum, non praeteritum, neque instans, For saith hée neither that which was, neither that which shalbe, but that which is, ought wée to meditate vppon, and herein to bée conuersaunt: for that which in past, returneth
not, & that which shalbe is vncertaine, But in things presēt is profit to be obtained.

div.head: The lawe of the Lacedemonians concerning the coulour, the habit, & estate, of the body And of such as were fat and ful of fleash.
div.p:
THe Lacedemonians made a lawe that no man should haue a colour resembling any loosenes or licentiousnes of life, they made a statute also against the increase and abundance of fat and flesh, as méere burthens to the bones: for their meaning was that euery mans cōposition, makeing, proportion, and state of members, should bée in that plight alwayes, that no exercise of actiuitie to thē might com amysse: Againe the one is a declaration of sluggyshnes, the other a manifestation of womanlines: neither of which qualities to the Lacedemonians were agréeable. This also was written in their lawes, and religiously obserued, that euery tenth day (nothing to the contrary withstanding) the youth (whom we call stryplings, of fourtéene, fiftéene, or sixtéene yeares olde) of the Lande, from the first to the last, that is, all and euery of them, should be stript bare, & discouer their nakednes, that sufficient viewe might be takē of their bodies, and such whose skynnes were scratcht, and their fleashe pincht, raced, and blemished with blewe blowes and skarres (which among them was counted an excellent habite and estate of body, very good likeing, and passing plight) they were precisely praised, and meritoriously commended: But if any were found, whose skinne was smothe his fleashe soft, and his limmes and ioynts tēder, so farr were such from fauour excluded, that both lawe & magestrates cōmāded thē to be sharply scourged.
Furthermore the officers called Ephori, had a principal care, and speciall regarde in veweing euery day ye wearing garments and apparell of the foresaid Striplings: and if any thing were found about them vnfyt, vnhansome, and vnseemely, it was punishable. Moreouer it was not dispensable by lawe, that any kind of vittellers (Cookes and Butchers, for the vtterance of fleshe excepted, whome the statutes of the land did tollerate) should bée suffered in Lacedemonia: if any were knowne other wise to practise and occupie, Sparta spued them out of the bosom of her bounds into banishment, as superfluous and noysom excrements of the disseased. The same Lacedemonians perceauing Nauclydes, the sonn of Polybias extreame fat of body, and that his grosnes was suche (procéeding of ease, pleasure, and ydlenes) as they therwithall were offended, They tooke and lead him through an assemblie of people, euery one staring vppon him as vppon a worlds wonder: Besides that they threatned to punishe him with expulsion out of the city, if he (leauing that corrupt order of lyfe which ingendred such excessiue substance of fat and fleash) did not confirm him selfe to an alteration and chaunge, wherby that deformitie in him might somewhat be diminished, sythēs the lawes of the land lothed thereat, as awnswerable to Ionia, rather then to Lacedemonia, which abhorred such porklyke grosnes, estéeming the same a thing so far from commendation, that yt did incurre vtter infamie reproche, and contempte.

div.head: How Polycletus, and Hyppomachus rebuked the vnskilfulnes of the multitude.
div.p:
POlycletus made two seuerall pictures, at one tyme, one after the common fashion and plaine forte, the
other cūningly, and lyke a worthy worckman. He grewe in popularitie and fauour of the multitude after this manner. As euery man cam to sée his picture and gaue iudgment therof, (som sayeing, if this were thus, it would be well, if that were so, it would be better) so did he alter and chaunge his worcke, as desireous to conforme himself to their contentment, and studious to compose and frame his pincell to their opinion and lykeing. At last (as tyme, in his thinckeing, séemed conuenient) he sett both his pictures abroade, as well that which he had shaped and proportioned after the mindes of the multitude, as that also which the people had not séene: at one of these twaine euery man woundred, at the other euery man laughed, accounting the first a spectacle of pleasauntnes and supposeing the other a mirour of maddnes. Polycletus standing by, and perceauing the peoples disposition, held his peace for a season: at lenghte, as tyme offered occasion, he spake in this wise to the Beholders. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . The picture which youe so much disprayse and reprehend, did procéede from your owne opinion, skill, & experience: But the picture which you aduaunce and commend, was of myne owne makeing. Hippomachus the Musitian, when his disciple and scholar swarued beside his art, as he plaide one his instrument, and yet notwithstanding, purchased a popular Plaudite, he smote him with a staf sayeing: Perperam fistulasti, nam alioquin hi tibi non applauderent, naughtely and vnskillfully hast thou plaid, otherwise this rude assembley woulde not haue commended thy dooing: By this hystorie is discouered, ye ignoraunce of the foolishe people.

div.head: ¶ Of the patience of Xenocrates.
div.p: Xnocrates Chalcedonius, whē he was rebuked by Plato of vnthankefulnes he was not once aggréeued at that reprehension, but vttered thes fewe words to the fellow, who incited and prouoked him to ouer thwart Plato againe, for his insimulation and rebuke: The thing which I dooe, Now, (sayth hée) to mée is more profitable (meaning silēce and forbearaūce) By which wise and prudent Apophthegme he stopped the mouth of that malicious merchaunt.

div.head: How Phocion gaue Demas quip for quip.
div.p: THe Atheniens preferring Demas before Phocion, made him their Captaine Generall and Ringe-leader in battel: who perceauing himselfe in higher place of reputation, came to Phocion, and all in a brauery and Iolitie of minde, spake these words to Phocion after a flouting fashiō: Lend me (good Syr) your slouenly mantyll which you vse to weare in warrfare: To whome Phocion framed this frumpe, with equall waighte and measure of disdaine: Thou wilt neuer want the lyke so long as thou art in a slouens skynne.

div.head: What manner of man A King ought to be towards his subiects.
div.p:
PHiliscus, whilom, said vnto Alexander of Macedonia
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Win glorye, doe what yu
canst to amplifie thy renowne: But yet in thy doings haue this consideration, that thou beest not a plague & pestilence, but rather healthfullnes and tranquilitie: Meaning that to ouerthrowe and supplant the estate of people, to race cittes, and to subuert Commōwealths was a very pestilence: But to haue a carefull eye ouer the people, and to let them quietly clocke vnder his spreding wings, was the benefite of peace, and the commoditie of concorde.

div.head: Wherin the King of the Persians spent the tyme of his progresse.
div.p: THe King of the Persians going in progresse, (to the intent that hee might not think the time tedious) caried in his hand braunches, of Byrche and therwithall A knyfe, wherwith hée did cut of the small spriggs, from the stalke and hackeled and hewed the rest in litle slices: with this kinde of worke did the King occupie his hands, not confirming himselfe, either to peruse any page, leaf, or lyne of any philosophicall pamphlet, either, to meditate or studie, any thing worthy knowledge, or to determine vppon any kinde of circumstance which might merit remembrance.

div.head: Of the Tragedies of Agatho.
div.p:
AGatho intermedled Opposites and Cōtraries, much in his Tragedies: A certaine fellow (allowing his owne dooing, more then another mans) would néedes put them out, as friuolous, pretending to amend them, and to better Agathos building: To whome Agatho spake these words, Quid bone vir? Quomodo tuipsius oblitus es? vt Agathonem ex Agathone reijcere, at{que} delere coneris
what now Sira (sayth he) hast thou forgottē thy self, that thou goest about to pull Agatho from Agatho. He was so delighted with his dooings, that he estéemed them, euen as he reputed of his owne person.

div.head: ¶ Of Stratonicus the Musician.
div.p: WHen a certaine man, had very courteously intertained Stratonicus the Musician, coming into an vnknown place, and being, as then, destitute of any other harbour: he was meruailous glad of the mans gentlnes, and yealded him, thancks innumerable, in that he vouchsafed him the benefite of his house at ye instant. But, after a while, when Stratonicus sawe, now & thē one, now & thē another, & anō too or thrée more (as they came) to be sēblably intertained, & no difference made betwene man and man, but all (lyke Graues end Barge passingers) for their penny considered: sira (sayd he) to the fellowe (his seruaunt, as I suppose) which kept him companie, let vs pack hence spéedely from this place for I thought we had met with a gentle Pigeon, but I perceaue we haue mette with a rauening Faulcone: meaning that he tooke the house, wherin he was purposed to soiourne, for an vnfrequēted place, and not for an harbour of all resort, inclined to the spoile.

div.head: ¶ Of the sentences of Socrates.
div.p:
THe sentences of Socrates, were compared to the pictures of Pauson the paincter. For when a certaine man, desired Pauson to paincte him a flyeing horsse, he contrarywise paincted a galloping palfrey. Now when the man, to whom the picture belonged, was angrie with
Pauson, in that he made not the horsse answerable to his expectation, and accordinge to the tenoure of the couenant, Pauson held him selfe contented, and willed the angry fellowe to turne the table vpside downe, which when the man had doone: the horsse which, before séemed to gallop, appeered then to flye: euen so, the sentences of Socrates the Sapient, had in them, certaine ambiguities, and doubtful mysteries, which might not be vnderstoode with such facilitie: But if the meaning of them were meditatiuely marked, and prudently pondred, they should soone shewe themselues naked to the eyes of the wit: For this Socrates was loth to smouther his conscience, with the concealing of truth, and nilling to incurre the enuy of his auditorie: for which occasions he vsed to season and temper his disputations, with crooked, obscure, mistie, and darck phrases of speache.

div.head: ¶ Of the ambition of Hipponicus
div.p:
HIpponicus the sonne of Callias, intending to erect and sett vp a standing image (as a principall present) in the honor and aduauncement of his countrie: A certaine man cam vnto him, and gaue him counsell that (sythence hee was determined to attempt such an enterprise) he would graunt the worcking therof, to Polycletus the famous and excellent Grauer, To whom Hipponicus made this aunswere: Non eiusmodi donarium apud animum proposui, cuius gloria non ad consecratorem, sed ad factorem sit reditura. Hold thée contente (my frend) it is not my meaneing, to bestowe such a present vpon my countrie, as the maker therof shal carry a way the crowne of commendation, and the prayse of the principall procurer lye buried in the graue. For this is an assured truthe, that such as beheld the image, would
sooner haue aduaunced the artificiall handy woorcke of Polycletus, then the liberal gifte, and frée hart of Hipponicus.

div.head: ¶ Of Archelaus, and of the pictures of Zeuxis.
div.p: ARchelaus (by the report of Socrates) spent a greate summe of money, in the beutificing of his house, for he hyred Zeuxis Heracleotes (ye notable workman) to adorne, & garnish it with pictures of the finest fashion: in so much that ye fame of Archelaus house grew in such honour, that many cam from farr countreys, and outer parts of the world to haue a sight of the same. This man laid out largely vppon paincted postes, but vppon his owne person, he would nothing bestowe, nether was his house in so great admiration, but he himself was in as greate contempte: for no man, woulde once vouchsafe to take the paines, to go to Macedonia in his behalf, except his labor had bin throughly considered, & his paines recōpenced with ample rewards: wherwith honest and good men, indéede, ar not once allured, much lesse intrapped, notwithstanding the allurement of the commoditie.

div.head: ¶ The punishement, that a certaine master would haue his seruaunt suffer.
div.p:
A certain inhabitant of Chius being kindled with anger against his seruaunt spake these wordes: Non in pisirinum ego te detrudam, sed ad Olympiam ducam. I wil not thrust ye into litle ease, I will not haue ye grinde in the mil nether will I haue the laid fast by the héels in stocks: But it is my minde to haue the to the highe hill Olympia. For
he supposed with himself, that to stand vpon the top of the hill Olympia, wher the sonne beames might fry his fleash, was more tormēntable, then to runne about and turne a whéele, which, in comparison, was but a méere sport.

div.head: ¶ Of the mildenes, sobernes, and honestie, of Archytas, in communication.
div.p: ARchytas was a sober man, and in sundrie respects of behauiour, notable: yea such a one was this Archytas, as by no meanes, mighte awaye withe leude speach & corupt communication. This man, when as vrgent necessitie (as a man would haue thought) might haue constrained him to vtter a thing in words, which wēt flat against his mind, he brideled his toung with such silence not withstanding, that he spared his speach, with manifest resemblaunces of sobrietie. Howbeit, if the matter requiered discouery, and yet séemed to impugne his will, he wrot it downe in his vsuall characters, satisfying the expectation of som, in causes of importaunce. But is not the modestie of this man merualous, who could tēper his toung when matters of much weight moued him to frée vtterraunce?

div.head: ¶ Of a certaine Sybaritishe tale, deseruing laughter.
div.p:
A Certaine Sybarite, a Schoolemaster by his office and calling (which kinde of men are very loose liuers, as all other Sybarits are) when a certaine boy, which went with him by the way, spying a figge vnder foote, stooped, tooke it vp, and offered to eate it: he chid him curstly, and ther by so terrified the lad, yt he made him forsake ye same
The Master haueing gotten the aduauntage which he soughte, and snatching the figge from the boy (who was vnder obedience and corection) deuoured it vp quite, with a lickerous paier of lipps, & a coruorant throte. When I read this, in the Sybaritishe hystories, I could not bridle my self from laughter, to sée the craftie foxe beguile the selly shéepe, vnder a pretended showe of simplicitie, and therfore haue I (that yow might vnderstand the same with me) sett it downe in writeing, not as a thing memorable for any commodious circumstaunce, as that in peruseing this Encheiridion of shorte hystories, you might ponder this tale, as a paterne of dissembling dealing in all poincts dissalowable.

div.head: ¶ Of the Poet Syagrus.
div.p: THer was a certaine Poet named Syagrus, the successour of Orpheus and Museus: who is reported to haue béene the first, that discoursed vpon the Troian warres. The argument or matter is hauty and highe, yet he was so bould as to comprehend the same in his spareing poetrie.

div.head: ¶ Of a Tyraunt, forbidding his subiects to haue conferrence, and comunication one with another.
div.p:
A certaine Tryzan Tyraunt, intending to cutt of all occasions of rebellions, treasons insurrections, and conspiracies, made a lawe for the inhabitants of his land, ye no mā, eather priuately at home, or publiquely abroade should be so bould as cōferr and talke with his neighbour,
fréend, and acquaintance, this prohibitiue proclamation was vniuersall: A déede (I tell the truth) both grienous and intollerable. But this commandement of the king, as it séemed to restraine necessitie (for talke and conference is naturall and may not so straightly be limited) so it was soone violated, infringed and broken. Howbeit, not with manyfeste tokens, but with secret signes of the senses, made one to another, one while of the face looking sowrely, stearnly, sorrowfully, merely, &c. another while of the handes and fingers bent this way and that way importing many mysteries, and semblably of other senses, whereby one certefied another of their meanings & determinations. This changable copie of countenaunces, and variable significations of the organs of the body, gaue the king to vnderstand, what a heauy yoke of seruilitie, he had layde vpon the shoulders of his subiects, and how impaciently they tooke such extreame and vnreasonable barbarisme The consideration of this secret and significant communicating of counsell, moued the king excéedingly: for he mistrusted, that he had not yet made al sure, safe, and sounde enough, but this speaking silence (as it were) of his subiects, and the manifold induments and putting on of faces, did prognosticate and foreshew, some imminent mischéefe, intended againste his proper person. Wherefore he made a newe lawe beside the former, which did abrogate the libertie of vseing such signes as are before mencioned. This extremitie, kindled no smal fyre of enuy, in the hartes of his people, and specially in the hart of one particular and priuate man (who either of valliauncie or els of desperation) tooke the high way into the market place of the citie, where he stoode wéeping and wayling in a most pitifull plight, & round about him a swarme of people flocked, thick and three-folde, howlyng and lamenting in lyke maner. Hereuppon word was carried to the king, that no man vsed to
speake by signes, but that all priuie and secret tokens of countenaunce, all mistical motions of bodely members, and all other semblable significations (whereby his subiectes did communicate the conceipts of their molested mindes) were vtterly lefte, and that those their former fashions, and trade of behauiour, was turned into a vniuersall and straunge kinde of lamentation: vpon the reporte of which tidings, the king (fearing still that inconueniēce, which faine he wold haue cut of, & could not) maketh preparatiō, & (wt as much spéede as he might by any possibility) setteth forward one foot, wc a traine of his guarde and Pēsioners: intending to suppresse this insolent and vnaccoustomed kinde of spectacle: Howbeit, the people (whō the present perturbations of their intollerable subiection pricked) gathered together in a flock, & espying a farre of, a certaine glimmering shew of ye king and his traine, made themselues ready to rebell against his person, and first of all encountred his assistauntes, from whom they violently wroonge their weapons, and by that meanes left them vnmunified and naked: and bending the fulnesse of their force against the Tyraunt, hackt and hewde him in péeces. Thus may we perceiue that Metus est malus duturnitatis custos, Nothing can continue, which feare hath in kéeping.

div.head: ¶ Of Clinias and Achilles, who aswaged their anger, with the sweetnes of Musicke.
div.p:
CLinias, a man in behauiour right honeste, and in the profession of Philosophy a Pithagorian, at what time he was angrie, and perceiued the motions of so monstrous a fiende rageing in his harte, leaste that
his minde should be corrupted with the contagion of so vile and yrksom a Caterpiller, he betooke him to his musicall instrument, the strings wherof, at all times were ready tuned, and with the swéetenesse of the noyse filled his eares, and delighted his minde: A certaine man comming vnto him and demanding what his meaning was to do so, he made this aunswer: Nunc mitigor animo. Euen now, sayth he, I was in a vengeable choler, but now the heat of the same is quite quallified. Achilles (of whome, the verses Homericall make mention) soung swéetely to his Cyterne, and called to memorie, the puisaunt exploits, & feates of Cheualrie, wherin the auncient worthies were not inglorious: By which delectable excercise, and preseruing receipte, he vsed to slake the fiery flames of indignation, and to winde in the pleasure and profit of a pacified minde. This man, being an expert musitian, in the riche spoile & botie which he obtained of his enemies, notwithstanding he might haue taken many a precious Iewel, and inestimable ornamēt, yet the first thing wheron he laid his hāds, was a swéete melodious Cyterne: wherby may be coniectured, that he preferred musicke, before fat spoyles.

div.head: Of diuerse which contemned money for the safetye of their Citizēs and of certaine debters, and Creditors.
div.p:
THeocles of Corynth, Thrasonides, & Praxis of Mitylen, contemned riches declaring therein, the naturall nobilitie of their mindes, and discouering by their discréete demeanour, that they weare true Gentlemen indéede. These worthy and famous persons, sailyng in Seas of substance, and waues of
worldly wealth, and séeing their Citizens, to want that wherewith they themselues did bounde, laboured by wayes of exhortation, and persuasion, to procure reléefe out of the purses and stoare of the riche, to the indigent and needy, for the attenuating, and empaireing of their impouerishment. But diuerse, not disposing themselues, to the counsels of the forsaide persons, sauouring of liberalitie; and large bounty: would in no case bee wonne to the procurement of their owne hindraunce. Whereupon Theocles, Thrasonides and Praxis not obtaining that which they intended, and hauing hartes conformable to vertuous excercises, opened the sluses of their substaunce, and let the streames of their liberalitie runne abroad to the commodity of such whom lack had ouerburthened, whereby many debtes were discharged, many billes of demaundes aunswered, many great summes of money payed, many exactions cléered, and infinite reckonings blotted out of the Booke: by which excellent déede they deserued, and atchiued, (shall I say golde, and siluer, which are corruptible) no, but euerlasting fame, perpetuall praise, and renowne sempiternall.

Moreouer such (sée the inconueniences of couetousnes) as would not conforme themselues to the persuasions of the abouenamed Theocles, Thrasonides, and Praxis, through their gréedye gapeing after priuate gaine (whiles they did straine a Gnat, and swallow a Camell) they did incurre double daunger: namely the losse of their mony, and their liues, for such persons, as were indetted, and had not wherwithall to aunswer to such summes as they did owe, by pondering their owne pinching pouertie, became so bould and desperate, that they cast violent handes vpon their creditours, & smote them downe to the ground, with bloudy woundes irrecouerable: after which Sarasen sorte they dealte with as manye, as ventured within the compasse of
their weapons. Had they not béene better, to haue forgeuen their debts, and so haue saued their liues, rather then by couetousnes to haue sustained so shrewd a shipwracke?

div.head: The persuasion of a certaine man, for the maintenance of cōcord and vnitie, in the common wealth.
div.p: THe people Chii, being at variance and dissention, yea at defyance, and dealing of blowes, among thēselues: A certaine man, of nature courteous and ciuil, and such a one, indéede, as loued peace, and vnitie: vnderstanding that their desire was, to haue al such expelled out of the liberties of the Citie, and the suburbes of the same, as were an occasion of enimitie and contention, vttered these words very politiquely, and plausibly: Nequaquam, sed cum victoriam obtinuerimus, relinquamus aliquos, ne procedente tempore, non habentes aduersarios, nobis ipsis, bellum mutuo inferamus: I would not wish you to dooe so (sayth he) but rather, yea euen then, when wée haue the victorie, let vs relinquish and leaue some foes among vs: least peraduenture, in processe of time, wée hauing no enemies vppō whōe to wreake our wrath fal together by ye eares, one with another, and so proue instruments of our owne preiudice and daunger. By this counsell, sounding to reason, he suppressed that-presēt stryfe, and set them at peace and vnion: for he seemed vnto them to speake none otherwise, then the spirit of truth gaue him vtterance.

div.head: Of Antagoras, reuiling Arcesilaus.
div.p: ANtagoras the Poet, reuiled Arcesilaus Academicus, in the commō place of Assemblie, howbeit to his owne harme and dammage: But Arcesilaus not regarding his cōtumelious termes, and slaūderous language, helde himselfe patiēt: Neuerthelesse to suppresse the insolencie of his speache, he vsed this aduantage. When he perceaued much people standing together in a throng, he resorted thither, walking and talking with them, to the intent that if Antagoras came to vppraide him, he might spyt out his poyson, in a full auditorie, to the end, that he therby, might purchase the sharper reprehension, and incurre the greater shame: when therfore Antagoras fortuned, or rather appointed, to be in the self same place, and after his vsuall order, spake spitefully against Arcesilaus: the present assemblie of people turned themselues towards Antagoras, and accused him of his extreame foolishnes, and misdemeanour.

div.head: Of Agesilaus.
div.p: I Thinke them worthy commendation and praise, which cut of mischiefes whē they beginne to budde & blossom, lest by not restraining them of libertie when they are yoūg, they might procure foule enormities when they are olde, and esestablished. Agesilaus coūsell, therfore, was profitable, in alotting such to dye the death, as without cause clustered together in a confederacie, a litle before the Theban insurrection.

div.head: Of Pytheas the Orator.
div.p: ONe accused Pytheas that hée was a naughtie and leude fellow, wherof Pytheas made no denyall, for hée acknowledged himselfe culpable in conscience: Howbeit he vttered this speache apollogetical and defensorie, in his owne behalf: That none of thē yt bare rule in ye Athenien weale publique, remained, so short a tyme, in mischiefe and naughtines: he reioyced againe, one the otherside, that he continued not such a one as he was reputed to be: and supposed that he was iniurious to no man, in any respect, but innocent & vnblameable, yf he was not cōpared to such as were wicked in the highest degrée. This is but a foolishe, and a ridiculous opinion of Pytheas the Rhetorician: For, not he onely which doth iniurie, is yll to be adiudged, but he also (in my iudgement) which thinketh theruppon, is not good to be estéemed.

div.head: Of Lysander, carrying mony into Lacedemonia.
div.p:
LYsander carryed money into Lacedemonia, and made the people of the land, to offend against the highe Gods commandement, (for they were charged, yt no passage should lye opē to golde or siluer, in Sparta) diuers wise men therfore, maintaining integritie, and righteousnes, with no lesse affection, then perseueraunce and constancie, opposed and set them selues against Lysander, and resisted him, in this his pernicious enterprise. Other some, there also were, of a contrary inclination, who did both fauour and further Lysanders purpose: but as the other men, by their vertue woonne worship
& renowne, so these, for their labour, purchased reproche and infamie: Yea, ye noble name, and flourishing fame, which they had obtained in tymes past, being blemished and stained, came to naught and perished.

div.head: Of Annon, who would needs be accounted A God.
div.p:
