ANnon the Carthaginean, by reason of his boyleing concupiscence, and wādring desires, would not content himselfe, with the estate of a man but sought most ambitiously to clyme aboue all temporall preeminence and wordly dominion, namely, to the dedegrée of a God. To the intent therefore, that he might compasse his purpose, he bought him many disciplinable byrds, apt to singe songs, and to sounde words which were taught them: all which hée fedde and taught in a seuerall place, wherunto, there was no common accesse or comming: The words which he taught them to speak weare these 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and nothing els but onely Annon is a God, Annon is A God, Annon is A God. When they had béene long schooled in this point, and had learned their Kyrieleson all alyke, and as Annon dremed, so perfectly, that it was not possible for them to swarue, he tooke them one by one & threwe, thē into the foure quarters of the world, supposing, assuredly, that (as they did in close corner, and couert cage) so they would in opē ayer, sing none other sōge, but the same, which he had so studiously taught them, theruppon persuading himselfe, that ye name of Annon should be blased through out the world vniuersall, and this his deification proclamed, in euery region, both Ciuil & Barbarous. But yt came to passe,
farre otherwise, then the slumbring phantasses of Annons ambitious minde conceaued: for the Byrds being restored to their naturall place, and cutting the spireable ayre with their slickering fethers, and hauing be sides that, recouered their originall trade of lyfe, chaunged also the counterfect note, which Annon taught them, and resumed the ordinarie kinde of tunable and harmonious noyse, which Lady nature had assigned them, by her immutable ordinaunce. Thus was Annons ambitious hart spoyled of vaine hope, and the deification which he hunted after so gréedely, was turned to his shame: for what reasonable creature woulde be so presumptuous, or what honest nature durst be so venturous, as (not contented with the title of mortalitie, and yet discended of corruptible sperme) to exalte and aduaunce his owne priuate person, with such notable paternes of imprudence, and such rare Pageantes of impudence,

div.head: ¶ Of Polomey, who was syrnamed Tryphon,
div.p: PTolomeus Tryphon (for that was his syrname) at what time a certayne beautifull womā, was desirous to haue some talke and communication with him, and he perceaued her meaning in that behalfe, saide thus to the younge damosell: Prohibuit soror ne sermonem a speciosa faemina susciperem, My Sister for bad me to enter talcke with any faire woman: vpon whose wordes she replied in this sorte, with a man then, belike, you may: which when Ptolome heard, he gaue her commendation.

div.head: ¶ Of Timandridas, who did not praise his sonne for increasing his substaunce, whiles he was absent.
div.p: TImandridas a certaine Lacedemonian takeing his iourney into a far country, committed the administratiō, gouernment, and charge of his whole houshold to his sonne: who in the absence of his father was not ydle, but bussily occupied in worldly affaires, for the augmenting and increasing of his stock: Afterwardes Timandridas, returned home, and finding his wealth and substaunce, more by many portions inlarged then it was before, saide these wordes to his sonne, by way of reprehension. Multos deos, familiares, atque Hospites nostros &c. Thou hast beguiled, both the Gods aboue, our neighbours about, our acquaintance and customers: for the surplusage of our substaunce, ought of dutie, to be distributed vnto them. But (saith he) Dum in viuis agas pauperem atque egenum videri, et cum vita defunctus sis, opes, & diuitias rei familiaris apud te deprehendi, id turpissimū in hominū societate existit. To, séeme poore and néedy whiles a man is aliue, & to be found rich and wealthy in possessions and goods, when he is dead, is the foulest faulte, and most vnséemely blemish that can créepe into the felowship and societie of men.

div.head: ¶ Of Plato and Diogenes.
div.p:
PLato, reasoning vpon certaine points of learning, in presence of Diogenes, who séemed not attentiue to ye wordes which were vttered by ye Philosopher, tóoke occasion to be displeased with Diogenes thereupon, and saide vnto him, in the boyling beate of his choler. Quin diligenter sermones meos auscultas Canis? is this the eare
thou geuest to my doctrine, thou Dogge? whereat Diogenes, nothing offended in minde, with such reprochefull language, saide to Plato againe. At ego nunquam eò sum reuersus, vnde veni, quod Canes solent. But I neuer returned back againe thither, from whence I came, which is a propertie incident to Dogs: rebuking in this shorte reply, and ouerthwart phrase of speache, the fatherly Philosopher, for his iourney into Sicilia. Moreouer, it is a saying in ye mouthes of some, that Plato accustomably called Diogenes, furious and frantique Socrates.

div.head: ¶ Of whom the Aegiptians learned their lawe, and of their Iudges.
div.p: THe Aegiptians, vaunt very gloriously, of this thinge, as of a rare, and incomparable priueledge, namely that their lawes, statutes, ordinaunces, and iniunctions, did flow from diuine Mercurie: Such also among them, as occupied the seates of iudgementes, belonged to the order of priesthoode: so that a double title of dignitie in them did incurre, namely Titulus Iudicis, & Insigne Sacerdotis, among the number of whom, he occupied the principall place in geuing sentence, that was the eldest and the most auncient. Prouided alwaies, that he which supplied that Rome, ought of dutie, in vprightnes and integritie, to excell all other men. Moreouer he did weare in a colar which houng about his neck, a precious Saphyre stone, wherin was in grauen this Gréeke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which signifieth Truthe, meaninge, thereby, that as they had that costly and sumptuous Tablet hanging downe their bosome in outward sight, so they shuld haue the vertue (represēted in the precious stone) déepely planted in the furrowes of their remembraunce.

div.head: ¶ Of Lais.
div.p: LAis the harlote, was called by the name of Axine, which worde declared the vntowardnes of her nature, and discouered her vnhoneste gathering of gaine, for shee vsed to take too great a reward, for a moment of pleasure, of traueilers specially, whom she knew to be sharp set, by reson of their absence from home, & to haue no time of tariaunce, because of the spéedines of their iourney

div.head: ¶ That they proue themselues fooles which vaunt of their progenitors.
div.p: THey deserue dispraise, and extreame laughter (in my opinion) which brag of their progenitours, and think them selues trim men, because their forefathers were famous in feats of armes: For who knoweth who was ye syer of Marius? Assuredly not we, his valianntnesse and puisaunce is recorded in sundrye histories, but yet who begat him remaineth doubtfull and vnknowne. The same we affirme of Cato, Seruilius, Hostilius, Romulus, &c. all notable and puissaunt péeres, in the Romane Empire.

div.head: ¶ Of pictures, and Images.
div.p:
WHen I take a vew of the caruers cutting in fashioning an image, and the painters drawing, in framing a Picture: I conclude this, that in both their handywoorkes, exquisite iudgement is bestowed, and that in these Artes, reason is moste necessarie:
This to bée true, I canne bring diuers testimonies for no caruer nor painter hath at any time, béene so farr sequestred from reason, and so much depriued of iudgement, as to describe and set out the nyne Muses, God Iupiters Daughters, in a wrong shape and preposterous proportion, namely, in harnesse lyke the skirmishing Amazones: which is an argument that the life which is allotted to ye Muses should not be tumultuous but peaceable and full of tranquilitie, For, Quid Musis cum Marte? what felowship haue that Muses wc Mars? what agréement betwixt learning, and weapons.

div.head: Of Epaminondas and of Pelopidas.
div.p: AMoūg many notable sayings and doings of Epaminondas (which indéede are innumerable) this among the rest is registred: speaking to Pelopidas, he vttered this sētence, Non prius interdum discedendum e foro quam nouum aliquem amicum ad veteres adieceris. That a man should depart out of a common concourse of people no day, before he had gotten a newe friend to his olde: meaning that the life of man is continued with mutuall loue, which, where soeuer it be wanting, all things there are soone dissolued, and brought to desolation.

div.head: How Antalcidas found fault with a gifte which was sent him, because it was sprinkled with sweete compound water.
div.p:
THe king of the Persians (for I will féede your fansies, by your leaue, with a péece of pleasure) made a garland of roses, and sprinkled the same all ouer with perfumed waters, & swéete smelling oyntments: which when he had doone, he caused the same to bée caried to
Antalcidas (who at that tyme was embassadour for peace) for a present: But Antalcidas, not so well liking of the thinge brought & offered, said: Suscipio quidem donū, atque animi promptitudinem laudo, sed Rosarum odorem naturaeque fragrantiam, artis adulteratione perdidisti. I thanke thée for thy gifte, and I commend thy frée and liberall hart, neuerthelesse I must tell thée thus much, yt with thy curious cost, thou hast spoiled the swéetenes of the roses, and by thy counterfetting of smells, hast quite dasht the delightsomnes of the fine flowers.

div.head: The crueltie of Alexander, the Pherensian Tyraunt.
div.p: ALexander, ye Pherensian tyrāt, was a merciles mā, and a bloudy butcher: for at what tyme, Theodorus ye tragediographer, set forth the history of Aerops, with great vehemencie of minde, pitifull speaches, lamentable gestures, and semblable circumstaunces, seasoned with the sap of sorow: Alexander arose out of his seate, (the teares trickling downe his chéekes) and departed from the Theater, or Stage, where this tragedie was played with such liuely and effectuall representations: The soudaine goyng away of whom, ministred no small doubt to the mindes of many men, but chéefely to Theodorus: whereupon Alexander, excusing the Poet, saide in plaine wordes thus to Theodorus, I departed not ye place to this ende & purpose, therby to make the contemptible and despised, but rather, for that I was touched with a sodaine shame of mine owne person, whom the represētations of things, moued to that compassion and pittie, which could not pearce my flinty harte, in the ponderous and waighty estate of my poore people and subiects.

div.head: ¶ Of the madnesse of Apollodorus procured by wine.
div.p: APollodorus carrowsing wine, more excessiuely then the residue of his companions, could not conceale the filthye and lothsome vice of drunkenes, nor couer the fruites and mischiefes of the same: But being inflamed and kindled with the heat of so strong a liquor, waxed fearce and vnruly, and framed his body to the disposition of his nature.

div.head: The sentence, or opinion, of Xenocrates.
div.p: XEnocrates, the familiar friend of Plato, had this sentence in his mouth, of Custome: Nihil interest pedesné an oculos in aliena domo defigere. That betwéene entring into a mans howse, and lookinge therin: was no differēce. His reasō was this, for (saith he) as well they which looke, where they ought not, as they which enter, where they should not, are in equall proportion of reprehension and blame.

div.head: Of Ptolomeus anb Berenice.
div.p:
TO Ptolomeus, at what tyme he sat, playeing at Tables, an officer read a Catalogue of condemned mē, their trespasses, & the order of ye processe against thē, yt he might pronounce sentence, what kinde of punishment, they were to suffer after the measure of their merits.
But Berenice, ye wife of Ptolome, takeing ye scroule out of the registers hands, interrupted him in réeding forward the seuerall inditements, which remained: saying Non sic obiter animus est aduertendus, cum de hominis salute disceptetur, sed cogitandum, et relinquenda ludicra. Yt is not méete to determine rashly and vnaduisedly in matters of lyfe and death, but all tryfling toyes, and exercises of disporte set aside, such waighty causes ar skilfully to bée decided: for (sayth shée) casting of a payre of dyce, and remoueing table men from place to place, is not lyke to hanging, killing, and murthering, quick and reasonable creatures. Ptolomeus, at the hearing of these wordes of Berenice his wife, pondered so precisely of that present occasion, that he would neuer (from that time, forward, when he was recreating himselfe in any kinde of game) allowe causes of life and death, to be called to accounte.

div.head: The Lawe of the Lacedemonians, against Couetousnes.
div.p: A certaine youngman of Lacedemonia, hauing bought a plot of land, for a small and easy price (and, as they say, dogge cheape) was arrested to appeare before ye magistrates: & after ye trial of his mater he was charged wc a penalty. The resō, why hée was iudged worthy this punishmēt, was, because he being but a yoūgmā, gaped so gredely after gain, & yawned after filthy couetousnes: For yt was a most commendable thing, among the Lacedemonians, not only to fighte against the enemie, in battell manfully: but also, to wrestle and struggle with couetousnes, (that misschiefous monster.) valliauntly.

div.head: ¶ Of diuers notable and famous Women.
div.p: WEe are now determined to speake somwhat, in the praise of worthy women, and to deliuer you a bedrowe of such as deserue commendation. And firste of all we wil begin with the most renowmed. Such a one was Penelope, the chaste: Alcestis, the constant: Laodamia the wife of Protesilaus, the louing: these women were Grecians. Now to come & touch our owne country, Cornelia, the learned: Porcia ye péerles: & Cestilia, the famous: These women were Romanes. More could I recounte, but I wyll not, least I might be suspected of flattery, and cast in the téeth with parasitical practise, and the art of adlation: which I vtterly abhorre.

div.head: ¶ Of the Army of the Magnets, against the Ephesians.
div.p:
THe Magnets (a people bordering by the floode Meander) making war against the Ephesians, vsed this order in their incounter. Euery horseman had with him to the féeld, a dogge to hunt, and a footeman to throw the dart: Now when they were prepared to geue the onset vpon their aduersaries, the Ephesians: they did let lose their dogges, who ranne fiericely vpon the souldiers of the contrary side, byt them, tare their flesh with their téeth, and interturbed the whole aray, in such sort, that they could not deuise what were best to be doonne, for their owne succour, whiles the dogges did so wearie and plague them. Then the
Dart men gaue ye second assault, playeing their partes also with full purpose to vanquish their enemies. And last of all, the Magnetian Horsemen, prepared their power, against the Ephesians. And thus you haue a straunge kinde of order in warfare, as appeareth, in mine opinion.

div.head: Of the Image of Helena, made by Zeuxis, and of the painter Nicostratus.
div.p: ZEuxis, when he had painted ye picture of Helena, Nicostratus beheld it earnestly and wondering at the workmanship, therein shewed, was greatly amased: One coming vnto him, and demaūding the occasiō of his sodaine astonishment he made this wise and prudent aūswer: Non id me rogares, simeos haberes oculos. Thou wouldst aske me no such question, if thou hadst mine eyes in thy hed. The same, may be applied (in my iudgement) to a learned and eloquent phrase of writing, and speaking: For except a mā haue discretion and iudgement in a settled minde, and attentiue eares therunto pertaining, yt is not possible to determine with reason, and soundnes of opinion: No more then yt is possible for a Bunglers and Botchers eye, to espye an errour in, artes and sciences surpassing their capacities.

div.head: What persons they were, whome Alexander disliked.
div.p: PTolomey, for his dexteritie and actiuenes: Arrius, for his buisines, and combersomnes, And Python, for his deuise of nouelties, and straunge thinges.

div.head: Wherefore King Philips pleasure was, to haue the sonnes of noble men, attend and waighte vppon his princely person.
div.p: PHilip did take and choose, the sonnes of Noble and honorable men, to serue and attend vppon his persō, not of an iniurious, and spitefull minde, but to this end and purpose, that they might he acquainted to abide labour, indure to take paines, and be alwaies prompt and redy to do their duty. For whatsoeuer he was amōg them, that addicted and gaue himselfe to loosenesse of lyfe, and conformed not himselfe to the kinges commaūdement, dilligently and dutifully: he did incurre the displeasure of his maiestie excéedinglye. And for this cause was Apthonetus taken and scourged, because (when he was surprised with thirst) he brake order, and left his way to lodge at a commō Inne. He caused Archedamus also to lose his lyfe, because he, being charged and commaunded by the king, to continue in armour, contrary (neuerthelesse) to the precept geuen him, put it of and vnharnessed himselfe. He thought he might be so much the more bolde, and presumptuous vppon the kings fauour, as (for lucres sake, and desire of gaine) he flourished in faire speaches, and flatering phrases, wherewith he persuaded himself to auoide his princes displeasure.
